webTitle: West Indies crushed four days from Test

fields.headline: West Indies crushed four days from Test
fields.trailText: West Indies go into Thursday's first Test against Australia on the back of a demoralising defeat by an innings and 63 runs at the hands of Victoria in Melbourne.
fields.body:
West Indies will go into Thursday's first Test against Australia battered and bewildered after a demoralising defeat by an innings and 63 runs at the hands of Victoria in Melbourne.

The tourists, who had lost their opening match to Western Australia, were bowled out for only 114 as the Australian Test squad member Colin Miller, with three for 26, finished off their second innings. The left-armer Mathew Inness, three for 47 yesterday, took nine wickets in the match.

Facing a 177-run deficit, West Indies crumbed against a side at the foot of the current Sheffield Shield rankings and playing without Shane Warne, Paul Reiffel, Matthew Elliott and Ian Harvey. Ridley Jacobs top-scored with 25, Brian Lara departing on 20.

Meanwhile, Zimbabwe's captain Heath Streak put the good of his side above a possible double century for Andy Flower by declaring their first innings on 422 for nine on the second day of the first Test against India in New Delhi yesterday. Flower was left stranded on a career-best 183 after facing 351 balls and striking 24 fours and two sixes in almost eight hours.

fields.headline: Youhana sparkles on home turf
fields.standfirst: Paul Allott salutes a crucial innings from a fixture of the Pakistan team
fields.trailText: Paul Allott salutes a crucial innings from a fixture of the Pakistan team
fields.body:
Looking at the pitch at Gaddafi stadium on the first morning of the first Test here in Lahore, an Englishman might have been declared mad to suggest the game would still be in progress at teatime on the fifth day.

The surface looked certain to disintegrate and produce a result. And of course the Pakistan spinners were favourites to do the producing.

The stalemate that fizzled out yesterday pointed to two major factors. The pitch has proved too slow for all the bowlers, and the batsmen on both sides produced obdurate cricket. It was not a pretty match but it will boost England more than the hosts.

Nick Botting, the artist commissioned by MCC for a series of paintings at this game, had more fun watching his own paint dry on the final day than the spectators had viewing the action, such as it was.

The game ended in a draw thanks mainly to a wonderful innings over the weekend by Yousuf Youhana. One of the younger members of the Pakistan side at 26, he has played 25 matches and averages more than 36, a figure which will increase over the next few years. Significantly he is the only player ever present in the Pakistan team this year, having played nine Tests and 41 one-day internationals.

His innings of 124 was his career best and spanned six hours and 13 minutes. Whether he saved Pakistan from defeat may be a moot point but he certainly saved them from following on on Saturday evening.

He came to the crease when Pakistan were 199 for three and stayed until he was ninth out at 400, undone eventually by the persevering Ashley Giles who nicked his outside edge. At 236 for six Pakistan still needed 45 to avoid the follow-on and Youhana's heart must have skipped a beat when, eight short of the 281, his former captain and senior partner Wasim Akram tamely popped a catch to mid-wicket.

From this point, though, Youhana took total control of the innings, nursing his partner Saqlain past the follow-on and then ensuring Pakistan were safe by batting until lunch on the last day. This was an innings of maturity and class and marked him alongside Saeed Anwar and Inzamam-ul-Haq as the key to Pakistan's batting strength.

Yousuf Youhana is a local boy from a working-class background. His father was a railway worker and the family lived only yards from the Lahore railway station. The streets were his playground and, with such limited facilities and resources at his disposal, it is almost a fairy tale that he has assumed hero status in his own city and his own country. Lahore is his favourite ground. In three Tests here he has had scores of 120 not out, 83, 0 and now 124, averaging an amazing 109.

Astute observers will have noticed that Youhana crosses himself as he steps into the ground and again when he gets to the milestones of 50 and 100. He is only the fifth non-Muslim to play for Pakistan. Thus his Christian beliefs set him apart from the rest of his side but there is no exclusion, his popularity with team-mates and the opposition bears witness to that.

His contribution was not lost on the Pakistan captain Moin Khan: "Our boys did well to avert the follow-on. It was a good toss to win for England and they batted well with Thorpe showing the grit. I am extremely pleased with the performance of our boys, especially Saqlain and Youhana.'

"We may look at the option of making a couple of changes for the second Test," he added.

Both teams will prepare for it, in Faisalabad, in reasonable heart. England still have their fair share of injury worries - Nasser Hussain's wrist as well as his back - but equally worrying was Ian Salisbury's performance. He was handled with kid gloves by Hussain and curiously by Pakistan's batsmen, who were never in any danger of getting out to the leg-spinner but never collared him either.

He may well play in a week's time but England will be stronger if they pick another batsman, Michael Vaughan, or the ebullient Dominic Cork who is always likely to make things happen.

fields.headline: Court date for Atherton
fields.trailText: Mike Atherton has received a summons to appear in a Pakistan court to defend an action of defamation brought against him by the journalist he referred to as "a buffoon".
fields.body:
Mike Atherton has received a summons to appear in a Pakistan court to defend an action of defamation brought against him by the journalist he referred to as "a buffoon" during a press conference in 1996.

The hearing, which he is not obliged to attend (although he can send a pleader) but which would be "heard and determined" in his absence, is set for December 7, the first day of the third Test in Karachi. Atherton will probably opt for opening the batting.

It was in Rawalpindi after England's defeat there by South Africa in the 1996 World Cup that Asghar Ali, whose English is poor, tried to ask Atherton a question but several times failed to get through.

He was finally rebuffed, churlishly it has to be said, when tact from captain and management would have been a more appropriate response than "Will someone get rid of this buffoon?"

Ali, who is suing for damages of £150,000, maintains that he has lost both esteem and girlfriend as a result and is a laughing stock.

webTitle: Donald passes milestone and turns to Cronje

fields.headline: Donald passes milestone and turns to Cronje
fields.standfirst: Scoreboard
fields.trailText: Allan Donald claimed his 300th Test wicket as South Africa dismissed New Zealand for 229 and enforced the follow-on on the third day at Springbok Park in Bloemfontein.
fields.body:
Allan Donald claimed his 300th Test wicket as South Africa dismissed New Zealand for 229 and enforced the follow-on on the third day of the first Test at Springbok Park in Bloemfontein.

Donald, playing his 63rd Test, became the 15th player and the first South African to reach the landmark when he trapped Shayne O'Connor lbw in his 19th over yesterday. He said afterwards that his immediate reaction was to think of his country's disgraced former captain Hansie Cronje.

"As it happened my mind went out straight to Hansie," Donald said. "I felt that it would have been great for him to be there at mid-off. I almost felt like looking round to see if he was charging towards me.

"That's something that struck me immediately when it happened, that Hansie wasn't next to me. When milestones came or important partnerships were broken, he was always there, the first to congratulate me. I'll ring him tonight."

Donald, 34, said the achievement would spur him on to further records. "I don't feel different. I'd like to think of myself as a guy who keeps his feet on the ground," he said. "I take this sort of thing in my stride and now I'm looking forward to playing on wickets that are more responsive than this one and counting down the next 100 wickets. The next goal will be to get to 350 and to keep sliding up that ladder."

He added that he felt "enormous relief" when O'Connor was given out. "I think the crowd were getting a bit impatient, they wanted me to get it. I even thanked the umpire afterwards, to see his finger go up that quickly was a great feeling."

Donald finished the innings with three for 69, while his fellow fast bowler Shaun Pollock had figures of four for 37 as New Zealand replied to South Africa's 471 for nine declared. At the close the visitors were 82 for one, still requiring a further 160 runs to avoid an innings defeat.

fields.headline: Hussain hurt but happy
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan 401
England 480 for 8 dec & 77 for 4
Match drawn
Scoreboard
fields.trailText:
Nasser Hussain injured his wrist as the first Test ended in a draw. Mike Selvey offers his verdict.

Pakistan 401
England 480 for 8 dec & 77 for 4.
fields.body:
In the end it was Pakistan who had the final say. After an immense ninth-wicket stand between the centurion Yousuf Youhana and Saqlain Mushtaq had propelled the home side to within 79 runs of England's first-innings total, their bowlers reduced the visitors to 77 for four by the time the draw was agreed at four o'clock yesterday.

Of course, once Pakistan had avoided the follow-on by the skin of their teeth on Saturday afternoon the remainder of the game was going to be about little more than scoring points. On such days, when the pressure eases and tired cricketers can be vulnerable, it is important to try to escape unscathed. But that went by the board in the course of a memorably fierce new-ball burst from Wasim Akram, proving a point after some criticism of his lacklustre bowling in the first innings; he had spent time icing an ankle, so there may have been mitigation.

The England captain Nasser Hussain received a nasty blow on his right wrist in attempting to hook a short ball from Wasim, only the third delivery he faced. He immediately dropped his bat and called for help, and it was obvious he was in some distress. After on-field treatment from Dean Conway he walked disconsolately back to the pavilion.

An x-ray revealed no fracture and after the game Hussain, his wrist encased in strapping, explained that the injury would be treated as one to soft tissue and that he was hopeful of being fit for the second Test on Wednesday week in Faisalabad. "I've got brittle bones so I was concerned," he admitted. "I've been hit a good few times and this is the first time I've ever retired hurt. But I couldn't feel my fingers or get my hand back into the glove. It felt very sore and still does, and it took half an hour for the feeling to come back to the fingers."

It may be some days before there is confirmation that all is well, because often a fracture reveals itself only once swelling has subsided. Hussain will have a further consultation with a specialist today when he also receives an injection to ease the discomfort in his back.

If, however, he thinks that this is the cherry on the cake of a duff year that has seen him score only 267 first-class runs in 23 innings and break his thumb during the summer, then maybe the tide is turning just a little. In striking his wrist, the ball ricocheted down and knocked against the leg stump without dislodging the bail. Even a week ago that would have fallen to the ground as well.

Hussain was pleased with the overall performance of his team in a match which many observers expected to be over inside three or four days, with England struggling against the Pakistan spinners. In fact, although it was an exceptional toss to win - as no doubt will also be the case in the next two Tests - England showed a lot of character and variation in method in countering the spin of Saqlain and Mushtaq, in particular Graham Thorpe's diligent century and the vibrancy of Craig White.

Saqlain bowled himself inside-out during this match and deserved his nine wickets (it helps to have a bit of mystery on slow pitches, was Hussain's view) but Mushtaq did not take a wicket until he had Mike Atherton lbw in the second innings, looked short of form and may find himself ousted by the young pretender Danish Kanaria.

There is a feeling, though, that England, should they encounter precisely these conditions next time around, might well consider a different XI. Unquestionably the situation demanded two spinners but, whereas Ashley Giles acquitted himself through 56 overs, Ian Salisbury represented too high a risk; this was made clear on Saturday when, until Youhana had taken Pakistan to safety, he was allowed only two mundane overs at the start of play and another four after lunch.

If the captain cannot trust his spinner then the bowler may as well not be there. White's fine use of reverse swing, and some good work from Andy Caddick too - and indeed Wasim's riposte yesterday afternoon when he also removed Marcus Trescothick with his speed and movement - showed that pace has its place even on placid, dusty pitches. Without trying to prejudge next week's pitch, England would do well to consider the option of the extra batsman in Faisalabad.

It took England until 25 minutes after lunch yesterday before White had Mush taq leg-before to end the Pakistan innings.

On Saturday they had had just the sniff of something more positive when, with Pakistan needing 281 to avoid the follow-on, seven wickets were down for 273.

At this point Youhana had only 37 but he found an adhesive partner in Saqlain. Together the pair added 127 for the ninth wicket, Youhana reaching 124 with a six and eight fours in more than six hours - his fourth and highest Test hundred and third in eight innings - before he gave Giles his fourth wicket by edging to Alec Stewart. Saqlain, though, remained steadfast to the end, 32 not out in four hours' batting. White may have been a challenger for the man-of-the-match award but few quibbled when it went to the off-spinner. Not in Pakistan anyway.

In fact, although it was an exceptional toss to win - as no doubt will also be the case in the next two Tests - England showed a lot of character and variation in method in countering the spin of Saqlain and Mushtaq, in particular Graham Thorpe's diligent century and the vibrancy of Craig White. Saqlain bowled himself inside-out during this match and deserved his nine wickets (it helps to have a bit of mystery on slow pitches, was Hussain's view) but Mushtaq did not take a wicket until he had Mike Atherton lbw in the second innings, looked short of form and may find himself ousted by the young pretender Danish Kanaria. There is a feeling, though, that England, should they encounter precisely these conditions next time around, might well consider a different XI. Unquestionably the situation demanded two spinners but, whereas Ashley Giles acquitted himself through 56 overs, Ian Salisbury represented too high a risk; this was made clear on Saturday when, until Youhana had taken Pakistan to safety, he was allowed only two mundane overs at the start of play and another four after lunch. If the captain cannot trust his spinner then the bowler may as well not be there. White's fine use of reverse swing, and some good work from Andy Caddick too - and indeed Wasim's riposte yesterday afternoon when he also removed Marcus Trescothick with his speed and movement - showed that pace has its place even on placid, dusty pitches. Without trying to prejudge next week's pitch, England would do well to consider the option of the extra batsman in Faisalabad. It took England until 25 minutes after lunch yesterday before White had Mush taq leg-before to end the Pakistan innings. On Saturday they had had just the sniff of something more positive when, with Pakistan needing 281 to avoid the follow-on, seven wickets were down for 273. At this point Youhana had only 37 but he found an adhesive partner in Saqlain. Together the pair added 127 for the ninth wicket, Youhana reaching 124 with a six and eight fours in more than six hours - his fourth and highest Test hundred and third in eight innings - before he gave Giles his fourth wicket by edging to Alec Stewart. Saqlain, though, remained steadfast to the end, 32 not out in four hours' batting. White may have been a challenger for the man-of-the-match award but few quibbled when it went to the off-spinner. Not in Pakistan anyway.

webTitle: Quinn leaves Toon army without a scapegoat

fields.headline: Quinn leaves Toon army without a scapegoat
fields.trailText: Newcastle 1 - 2 Sunderland
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James' Park
fields.body:
Never has the chant of "Shearer, Shearer" been sung with such gusto, and never at such demoralised banks of Newcastle supporters. For the second successive year Sunderland had conquered Tyneside; the Toon army sat in stunned silence, struggling to come to terms with Saturday's breathless derby while the 3,000 visiting fans bounced joyfully up in the gods of St James' Park. For Geordies everywhere it promises to be another galling season.

Yet it could have been so different. With seven minutes of this pulsating match remaining, Niall Quinn clattered Rob Lee as he scuttled into the area. The challenge matched the frenzied atmosphere but, with the stadium barely able to watch, Alan Shearer fired his spot-kick right, Thomas Sorensen dived to his left and, as the ball was palmed for a corner, Newcastle were beaten.

"It doesn't get any better than this," said Sorensen. "When you come to Sunderland, the first thing you are told is that it doesn't matter where you finish, as long as it's above Newcastle. You can't put any points tally on this game and it was very emotional in the dressing room. I was close to tears; you don't know how to express your happiness."

The same goes for grief. Newcastle could have won this 121st derby at a canter but harder still for their fans to comprehend was the lack of any plausible scapegoat. Last year they could hide behind Ruud Gullit's sacrilegious decision to leave Shearer on the bench, replacing him with the Mackem Paul Robinson. Fingers could even be pointed accusingly at the deluge that engulfed St James' Park on that miserable night when Sunderland, as on Saturday, came from a goal down to win.

But this time the crestfallen manager was one of their own; the guilt-edged culprit the darling of Gallowgate. Bobby Robson, the usual spark in his eye eclipsed by disappointment, could hardly summon the words. "I feel very low because I thought we would win this one. It's a horrible disappointment but this isn't the end of our season," he said.

The visitors could have been swamped in Newcastle's riotous early attacks. After only 18 seconds Gary Speed found himself bearing down on goal, only for the ball to squirm awkwardly off his left boot. Sunderland, wheezing from the speed of the Geordie onslaught, were then floored as Nolberto Solano's cross was headed against a post by Speed. With Sorensen static and his defence in tatters, the midfielder prodded the ball over the line as he lay sprawled on the turf. The wave of attacks persisted with Clarence Acuna and Speed narrowly failing to convert a pair of Solano free-kicks.

Pressed into action, the Sunderland manager Peter Reid gambled after 66 minutes by hauling off Chris Makin - the defender was inconsolable as he trudged off the field - in favour of the Argentine winger Julio Arca. The move could have backfired but instead it paid dividends to win the match.

Within two minutes Kevin Phillips, turning inside Aaron Hughes, crossed for Don Hutchison to twist his body and smash a left-foot volley inside the post. For a split second there was jaw-dropping silence as even Hutchison, a Geordie, gauged exactly what had happened. Then the visiting fans exploded in raucous celebration.

Newcastle's response was swift - Solano thumping the post with a 20-yard free-kick - but they were just as rattled and, after 76 minutes, behind. Another Solano attempt was blocked, Sunderland broke at speed with Alex Rae sliding the ball through to Michael Gray whose wonderful cross was met by a wondrous header from Quinn.

"It was entertaining and passionate," admitted Reid. "We didn't get the credit we deserved last year but that was a great performance. That one was for the fans."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Pringle seals Charlton magic show
fields.trailText: Charlton 2 - 0 ChelseaA team beats a collection of individuals
fields.body:
Chris Powell celebrated as if he had just found Elton John's chequebook, Alan Curbishley shook each of his players by the hand, and in a sense it was easy to understand the delirium. Charlton's team cost less than Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink and derby wins are not to be sneezed at. Yet somehow this did not feel like an upset.

It was not only because Chelsea arrived without an away win since April that there was a certain inevitability about this defeat. As Claudio Ranieri has discovered, stars and stashes of money carry a club only so far. This was a victory for a team over a group of individuals.

Charlton have no one to match Gianfranco Zola's brilliance, no World Cup-winning defenders and no striker on the bench rated at the £12m Rangers have offered for Chelsea's Tore Andre Flo. Instead they are weighing up whether they can afford John Hartson. But they prevailed because they possessed the passion, organisation and team ethic that Chelsea lacked.

"The team that wanted to win won," Ranieri admitted before offering more damning indictments: "When the first difficulty arose we got nervous and that shouldn't happen. Eleven men don't make a team and we didn't play as a team."

What a telling contrast there was in the comments Steve McClaren made after overseeing Manchester United's derby win at Maine Road. The players had shown "work-rate, desire, togetherness," United's assistant manager said, "everything you need away from home to win the championship."

Ranieri knows the problem but not as yet how to solve it. When he arrived he noted it was spirit rather than talent that was lacking. Ten games later Chelsea are no nearer where they want to be, though of course the Italian's work has only just begun. "I am not a magician," he said.

Pulling rabbits out of hats must seem easy compared with masterminding an away win. It was in keeping with Chelsea's topsy-turvy existence that Marcel Desailly and Frank Leboeuf made basic errors and the team played as if they needed the shirt names to identify one another. The marking for Martin Pringle's goal was almost comically bad.

The disjointed performance was surely not helped by Ranieri repeatedly altering the formation. Tactical flexibility can be a sign of strength; here the tinkering seemed an admission of weakness. Whereas Charlton had a clear game plan, Chelseaoften bumbled along hoping a moment of magic would rescue them.

What makes it all the more frustrating for the fans and coach is that the team can be so impressive. For 20 minutes before Jonatan Johansson gave Charlton the lead Chelsea swarmed forward with real menace, hitting the bar and going close on other occasions. Once they fell behind they never regained that momentum. "Perhaps they need more mental toughness away from home," said Charlton's one-time Chelsea midfielder Graham Stuart.

Greater defensive cohesion would help too. Shortly after Stuart had sent Johansson clear to poke his shot beyond Ed de Goey, Marcel Desailly might have been sent off for fouling the Finn en route to goal. That Pringle headed in unmarked from a last-minute corner when Chelsea outnumbered Charlton 2-1 in the box said everything.

With Richard Rufus outstanding in Charlton's backline, Chelsea rarely looked like equalising. Flo, who may be allowed to leave if he hands in a transfer request, had a shot saved and Eidur Gudjohnsen headed just wide but they got what they deserved: nothing.

fields.headline: Liverpool lapses let in Tottenham
fields.trailText: Tottenham 2 - 1 Liverpool
fields.byline: David Lacey at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Few heavyweight titles are won with a glass jaw, even fewer with a susceptibility to sucker punches. Winning the title looks beyond Liverpool this season and unless their defence stops dropping its guard, a place in next season's Champions League by finishing second or third will again pass them by.

Yesterday Liverpool lost a match they initially looked well capable of winning because, in the words of their French manager Gérard Houllier, "we made two childish defensive mistakes".

These errors saw Tottenham score twice in nine minutes towards the end of the first half after Robbie Fowler had given Liverpool the lead with his first league goal of the season.

After that Houllier's team, for all their possession, did not regain the initiative in the face of tenacious and disciplined resistance by the youthful defence George Graham fielded in the absence of the injured Sol Campbell and the suspended Ben Thatcher.

There is never a bad time to beat opposition of Liverpool's stature, and for Spurs the moment was especially opportune given the prospect of demonstrations by supporters disgruntled by what they see as a lack of progress in signing new players. Not for nothing did Graham observe that "five of the players we had out there today were home grown".

For Houllier, Liverpool's repeated defensive lapses are all the more frustrating as they come after a season in which they were the most parsimonious opponents in the Premiership. And after this match it was clear that his patience was nearing exhaustion.

While both of Tottenham's goals were avoidable, the first must have struck a raw Gallic nerve. Having taken the ball off Sergei Rebrov, Spurs' Ukrainian striker, near the corner flag, the Liverpool central defender Stéphane Henchoz played it straight up the touchline to the advancing Stephen Clemence, who then received a return backheeled pass from Rebrov before centring low for Les Ferdinand to turn in the equaliser.

"When you are under pressure you don't try to pass the ball," Houllier grumbled, "you clear it. This was not an 18-year-old, this was an international player.

"We've now conceded 21 goals in the league this season and 10 of them could have been avoided. And I think that in 11 of the 14 matches we've played we have scored first. Had we won all of those we would now have 33 points, the same as Manchester United.

"Until we solve this problem we will not be up there with the leaders. United scored in the first two minutes at Manchester City on Saturday and defended well enough to win. That is the difference between us."

From Houllier's point of view Tottenham's second goal was hardly more forgivable. This time Liverpool's defence stood still, appealing for offside against Ferdinand, who was running back, as a long pass from Luke Young reached Clemence on the left. This time the midfielder's cross was high and true, and Tim Sherwood rose well to head the ball past Sander Westerveld.

Relatively cheap though the goals were, they restored the confidence of a Spurs side starting to lose its way against Liverpool's superior passing and the efficiency with which Gary McAllister, Dietmar Hamann and Danny Murphy were denying Darren Anderton and Sherwood space in midfield.

Once Fowler had scored, moreover, Tottenham's unbeaten home league record looked to be ending as Liverpool moved forward to settle the contest by half-time. Fowler's goal was typical of his style, a clinical left-footed shot low inside the right-hand post after Murphy had cleverly hooked a long ball from Hyypia into his path.

Once behind, however, Liverpool rarely regained their rhythm, and after Neil Sullivan had pushed wide a shot from Owen at the start of the second half they came no closer. In fact Stephen Carr nearly extended Tottenham's lead after 67 minutes when his intended centre beat Westerveld and rebounded from the far post.

Having taken the ball off Sergei Rebrov, Spurs' Ukrainian striker, near the corner flag, the Liverpool central defender Stéphane Henchoz played it straight up the touchline to the advancing Stephen Clemence, who then received a return backheeled pass from Rebrov before centring low for Les Ferdinand to turn in the equaliser. "When you are under pressure you don't try to pass the ball," Houllier grumbled, "you clear it. This was not an 18-year-old, this was an international player. "We've now conceded 21 goals in the league this season and 10 of them could have been avoided. And I think that in 11 of the 14 matches we've played we have scored first. Had we won all of those we would now have 33 points, the same as Manchester United. "Until we solve this problem we will not be up there with the leaders. United scored in the first two minutes at Manchester City on Saturday and defended well enough to win. That is the difference between us." From Houllier's point of view Tottenham's second goal was hardly more forgivable. This time Liverpool's defence stood still, appealing for offside against Ferdinand, who was running back, as a long pass from Luke Young reached Clemence on the left. This time the midfielder's cross was high and true, and Tim Sherwood rose well to head the ball past Sander Westerveld. Relatively cheap though the goals were, they restored the confidence of a Spurs side starting to lose its way against Liverpool's superior passing and the efficiency with which Gary McAllister, Dietmar Hamann and Danny Murphy were denying Darren Anderton and Sherwood space in midfield. Once Fowler had scored, moreover, Tottenham's unbeaten home league record looked to be ending as Liverpool moved forward to settle the contest by half-time. Fowler's goal was typical of his style, a clinical left-footed shot low inside the right-hand post after Murphy had cleverly hooked a long ball from Hyypia into his path. Once behind, however, Liverpool rarely regained their rhythm, and after Neil Sullivan had pushed wide a shot from Owen at the start of the second half they came no closer. In fact Stephen Carr nearly extended Tottenham's lead after 67 minutes when his intended centre beat Westerveld and rebounded from the far post.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Beattie brace exposes Villa's poverty of ideas

fields.headline: Beattie brace exposes Villa's poverty of ideas
fields.trailText: Southampton 2 - 0 Aston Villa
fields.body:
They call Doug Ellis "Deadly", but John Gregory does not want a chairman with that name; he wants a lethal striker.

There is tension in the air with Aston Villa and not only from the dressing-room row that followed the manager's half-time substitution of an incandescent Paul Merson here on Saturday.

He was not the only one to be angry. Gregory himself appears close to boiling point over his chairman's refusal to prise open his chequebook and strengthen the Villa squad enough to lift them from fifth in the table into a Champions' League spot.

"I do not want to fall out with anybody," said Gregory ominously, "but there comes a time when you have to act."

Asked if it was worth taking the gamble of buying a striker with that Champions' League place now within Villa's grasp, Gregory again pointed the finger. "You're talking to the wrong person".

It may seem odd that Ellis should hold back, given the cash available to teams playing in Europe's premier competition. But maybe the old boy has his reasons.

And, after watching Villa's wretched first-half performance at the Dell on Saturday, he would certainly be within his rights to assert that the team's problems go way beyond Gregory's assessment.

On this evidence the chairman would probably have to spend the next 10 years' TV money to rebuild a side capable of mounting a serious top-three challenge. A more realistic view is that Villa are fortunate to be as high as they are in an ordinary division and dreams of a Champions' League place are about as realistic as a Ralph Nader presidency.

All it took to stymie Gregory's side in Saturday's decisive first half was the sort of tactical nous that was lost to England when they replaced Glenn Hoddle with Kevin Keegan.

By keeping Villa's wing-backs busy with two wide men in a 4-1-4-1 formation, the Southampton manager perplexed the away side and removed much of their attacking outlet.

With Matthew Oakley just in front of the Saints' back four to stifle Merson and Southampton first to everything, the home side took an unbroken grip on the game.

Their cause was further helped by David James. Some believe he is a good enough goalkeeper to play for England. Unfortunately he continues to share their tendency for suspect judgment.

On 21 minutes he made a suicidal dash from his line to intercept Jason Dodd's cross, got nowhere near the ball and watched helplessly as James Beattie's header looped over him into the net. Two minutes later Beattie stole in front of Ozalan Alpay and the striker's header appeared to go through James on the line.

After replacing Merson and Steve Stone at half-time, Villa played better, forcing Southampton's Paul Jones into several saves including a point-blank tip-over from Lee Hendrie.

But Villa were still far from inspired and eventually the home side laid claim to their seventh point from the last nine. Beattie's contribution to that run has been five goals, after an 18-month spell without even one. Which is why, despite Southampton being 10 places below Villa, theirs was the more positive outlook on Saturday evening.

webTitle: Boos in ascendant as Robson's choice go down without spirit

fields.headline: Boos in ascendant as Robson's choice go down without spirit
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 0 - 3 Leicester
fields.byline: David Hopps  at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
The belief that football managers build sides cast in their own image does not hold true for Bryan Robson. How one of the most committed and energetic footballers of his generation has assembled a Middlesbrough side so wanting in spirit is hard to comprehend. Robson insists he is not quitting; if only he could be so sure about his team.

If Robson's dedication can be taken for granted, his tactical acumen cannot. To face Leicester's wolfish midfield trio of Robbie Savage, Muzzy Izzet and Neil Lennon with a bit-part striker (Whelan), an allegedly disenchanted import (Karembeu) and a player of limited worth who was lucky not be sent off (Stamp) was an exercise in futility.

Robson has had no greater crisis during his 6 years in charge but the chairman Steve Gibson would rather lose a hand than his old mate Robbo, so even after seven successive defeats Middlesbrough are trying everything they know to save him. The priority is to stop the crowd turning ugly; the chief executive Keith Lamb offered some guff in the programme about everything being cyclical and Mark Page, the former Radio 1 DJ, continues to run the most partisan PA system in the Premiership.

Unrest, though, is growing. Robson was booed on his sole appearance in the technical area. Gianluca Festa, who has demanded a transfer because he cannot win a regular place, has become the crowd's idol, a rare example of a foreign import who claims to "love" Middlesbrough. Joseph-Desire Job, meanwhile, plays as if leaving the place cannot happen a minute too soon.

Leicester, third and proud of it, are testimony to Peter Taylor's resourceful coaching. Just as they did under Martin O'Neill, they reek of cohesion, spirit and togetherness. Leicester, so the statistics indicated, won double the tackles, many of them conceded without a fight. Boro were pitiable.

One shaven-headed fan complained as he left the ground: "I tried swearing, standing up in my seat and smoking but still the stewards wouldn't throw me out." He should have tried it in front of Lamb, who once banned a journalist from Middlesbrough for life for standing on a chair.

Ugo Ehiogu was made captain for his home debut but it was an inspirational ploy that failed Robson almost at once. Leicester were two up within 13 minutes, with Dean Gordon the culprit on each occasion. First he conceded a penalty with a reckless tackle on Izzet, after Christian Karembeu had carelessly lost possession. Izzet scored from the spot. Then Trevor Benjamin beat Gordon all too comfortably to head home Lennon's cross.

Another error, this time from Phil Stamp, granted Leicester a third goal soon after half-time, Darren Eadie, filling in at wing-back after Callum Davidson departed injured, scoring from Ade Akinbiyi's cross. Lennon should have had a penalty when Mark Schwarzer brought him down - and should also have been sent off when, the penalty refused, he swung a petulant fist at the goalkeeper. After Tim Flowers had retired with a shoulder injury, Alen Boksic's 22-yard free-kick struck a post.

Next week Bradford City, the bottom club, visit the Riverside. A club desperately seeking miracles from a new manager against a club insistent that their old manager can still turn things round. "We cannot afford not to win," Robson admitted.

That losing streak in full

Bryan Robson's team have lost their last seven league and cup matches, their most recent victory coming at the Dell more than eight weeks ago.

Sept 30 Southampton 1 - 3 Middlesbrough

Oc 16 Middlesbrough 1 - 3 Newcastle

Oct 21 Charlton 1 - 0 Middlesbrough

Oct 28 Ipswich 2 - 1 Middlesbrough

Oct 31 Wimbledon 1 - 0 Middlesbrough

Nov 4 Middlesbrough 0 - 1 Arsenal

Nov 11 Man Utd 2 - 1 Middlesbrough

Nov 18 Middlesbrough 0 - 3 Leicester

fields.headline: First Division round-up
fields.trailText: Watford slipped up again, beaten 3-2 by Preston, who led three times with goals by Jon Macken, Mark Rankine and Iain Anderson. Tommy Mooney and Steve Palmer scored for Watford.
fields.body:
Watford slipped up again, beaten 3-2 by Preston, who led three times with goals by Jon Macken, Mark Rankine and Iain Anderson. Tommy Mooney and Steve Palmer scored for Watford.

Bolton stayed on the heels of the leaders with a 2-0 win at Norwich, Michael Ricketts and Gudni Bergsson the scorers.

Birmingham leapfrogged Burnley with a 3-2 win over the Clarets, Dele Adebola, Martin O'Connor and Mark Burchill scoring for the Blues. A David Dunn penalty maintained Blackburn's seven-match unbeaten run, with a 1-0 victory over Wolves.

The former Queens Park Rangers striker Kevin Gallen was hero and villain on his return to Loftus Road with the bottom club Huddersfield. Gallen fired the Terriers in front but had a penalty saved by Ludek Miklosko which would have secured Town's first win in 18 games. Karl Connolly earned Rangers a 1-1 draw.

Barnsley won for the first time in five games when Bruce Dyer's goal a minute before the break was enough to give them a 1-0 success over Sheffield Wednesday. A last-gasp winner from Trond Andersen gave Wimbledon a 2-1 win at Nottingham Forest, seconds after Tony Vaughan's goal seemed to have earned a point for Forest.

Marcus Bent scored two in Sheffield United's 3-2 defeat of Grimsby, while Lee Hughes scored a hat-trick in West Bromich Albion's 3-1 win over Gillingham.

fields.headline: Manning silenced by comic defence
fields.trailText: Radcliffe 1 - 4 York
fields.body:
For two minutes, about as long as their club president can go without offending someone, Radcliffe Borough dared to dream. Half an hour later, four down - and it should have been eight - for once in his life even Bernard Manning admitted he was speechless.

So much for the romance of the Cup. At least the admirably vocal Radcliffe supporters, who had made the short journey to Bury's more accommodating ground, were disabused of hope quickly and so could relax and enjoy the occasion.

"We came with no intention of defending and sure enough, for most of the first half we didn't," said their manager Kevin Glendon. By the time his team twigged that they were in fact allowed to tackle, kick and mark the opposition just like a normal game, they were looking at a double-figure hiding.

At least a determination not to be completely humiliated saw Radcliffe produce a second-half performance in which they could take pride.

Ironically Borough had the first chance of the game, Simon Carden acrobatically volleying wide after just 90 seconds; 32 minutes later the skipper Mark Dempsey forced the City goalkeeper Alan Fettis to save well. In between they handed York the freedom of Gigg Lane.

Perhaps a dozen times the visitors were given clear sight of goal and Graham Potter (unmarked left-foot volley from edge of area), Lee Bullock (unmarked header from cross), David McNiven (unmarked shot from 20 yards) and Scott Jordan (just unmarked) duly took advantage.

The rest of the time, assorted York players contrived to hit the post, bar (twice) or somehow miss altogether.

After the break, while York continued to create and miss chance after chance, Radcliffe created several opportunities of their own. Fettis again saved from Dempsey, before the striker Niell Hardy turned his marker on the edge of the area and scored 20 minutes from full-time.

The dream may have been long forgotten, but the applause and more to the point, financial contribution, of a crowd some 25 times higher than average may persuade Manning to take the club, for which he is currently open to offers, off the market.

"If we could get just a tenth of these people to come every week there wouldn't be a problem," said the chairman Bernard Manning (Jr).

webTitle: Harris puts Lions on the fast track

fields.headline: Harris puts Lions on the fast track
fields.trailText: Leigh RMI 0 - 3 Millwall
fields.byline: Trevor Haylett at the New Den
fields.body:
Nothing associated with the railway arrives early these days, so when Millwall scored from their first attack the New Den dropped its jaws with surprise. A foul, a converted spot-kick, and that was it: Cup dreams over for the Nationwide Conference team after just 45 seconds.

Leigh RMI - it stands for Railway Mechanics Institute - had been forewarned in the dressing room about Neil Harris's awareness around goal, which has put him on the list of most Premiership scouts.

Yet when the kick-off produced a long ball from deep which was headed towards Harris, the Leigh defender Neil Durkin clearly forgot his manager's words of caution and lunged rashly into the challenge as the Millwall No9 cleverly rolled the ball across his body.

Harris banged home the subsequent penalty and Millwall were on their way, although their failure to add a second goal for another 66 minutes was not to the liking of their supporters who booed them off at half-time.

Despite the early setback Leigh, who chose to make the lucrative switch from Hilton Park after being drawn at home, retained their composure and knocked the ball around quite well while lacking teeth in front of goal.

"Having seen them perform I'm glad it was switched to our home ground", said an admiring Mark McGhee.

Presumably one of the reason McGhee landed the Millwall job was the strength of his FA Cup record. This was Millwall's first win in the competition since 1995 when they put out Chelsea. By contrast, McGhee's previous tie was a semi-final with Arsenal and as a player he celebrated victory in the five finals he contested in the Scottish equivalent.

McGhee would have had more concern for his team had Leigh possessed a forceful striker to feed off Steve Jones's trickery and pace. They had few shots at goal but nothing was on target.

"We weren't embarrassed and that was important," said the manager Steve Waywell. "We got off to a bad start and some would have expected us to crumble at that point but it didn't happen."

Having said that Leigh were sorely in need of the calibre of marksmanship that gave Marc Bircham a second goal on the volley and provided Paul Moody with a delicate chip over Dave Felgate.

fields.headline: Hampton caught by the postscript
fields.trailText: Barnet 2 - 1 Hampton
fields.body:
Alan Simpson, master of the half-hour comedy script, commands the half-second verdict as well. "A choker," said Hampton's president of 33 years who, with Ray Galton, gave the nation Hancock's Half-Hour and Steptoe and Son. He had just seen Hampton caught and passed at the post.

Craig Maskell, their player-coach, who scored more than 130 league goals, had nodded them ahead midway through the first half as Barnet's defence suffered an attack of the totters under Dean Green's cross and H-H-Hampton's half-hour had stretched beyond an hour when Tony Richards forced home a corner. Then, in added time, Darren Currie blasted the Ryman League side out.

Simpson was not surprised. He had seen Barnet, then in the Southern League, beat them by the same score with a last-minute goal 24 years ago; Jimmy Greaves had scored the first. Saturday was Hampton's first time in the first round.

"I'm a pessimist," said Simpson. "Success is not funny; failure is." He was not laughing, though. They lost not only the £2,000 for winning but the cash from a trip to Walsall - riches indeed for a club who draw crowds of 250.

Hampton harnessed Richmond Borough last year in an attempt to broaden their appeal but this is rugby territory. The Simpson connection helps with publicity, albeit exploited diffidently by the writer. When the world twigged last week horse, cart and camera turned up at the Beveree stadium.

Maskell turned up in September 1999 and is top Ryman scorer with 12 this season. If he is on the way down with crucial experience, Green is rising at 23, starting the season with Leyton Pennant and catching the eye with poise, feint and a strong right foot unmatched by his left. Jason Shaw, too, was a key man in front of defence as Barnet, who beat Blackpool 7-0 the week before, struggled to find a way through.

When they did, the Beavers' American keeper Eric Talbot, helplessly caught in Barnet's pyramid of celebration, was sent off on a linesman's mystifying say-so. Richards followed. TV evidence, historic in Hampton's case, offered no explanation and may be brought to bear in appeal. Talbot, after earlier heroics, was ill-served by the whole episode, though Americans are liable to leave things hung these days. Simpson, meanwhile, is reworking The Wrong Arm Of The Law.

Saturday was Hampton's first time in the first round. "I'm a pessimist," said Simpson. "Success is not funny; failure is." He was not laughing, though. They lost not only the £2,000 for winning but the cash from a trip to Walsall - riches indeed for a club who draw crowds of 250. Hampton harnessed Richmond Borough last year in an attempt to broaden their appeal but this is rugby territory. The Simpson connection helps with publicity, albeit exploited diffidently by the writer. When the world twigged last week horse, cart and camera turned up at the Beveree stadium. Maskell turned up in September 1999 and is top Ryman scorer with 12 this season. If he is on the way down with crucial experience, Green is rising at 23, starting the season with Leyton Pennant and catching the eye with poise, feint and a strong right foot unmatched by his left. Jason Shaw, too, was a key man in front of defence as Barnet, who beat Blackpool 7-0 the week before, struggled to find a way through. When they did, the Beavers' American keeper Eric Talbot, helplessly caught in Barnet's pyramid of celebration, was sent off on a linesman's mystifying say-so. Richards followed. TV evidence, historic in Hampton's case, offered no explanation and may be brought to bear in appeal. Talbot, after earlier heroics, was ill-served by the whole episode, though Americans are liable to leave things hung these days. Simpson, meanwhile, is reworking The Wrong Arm Of The Law.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Feelgood factor as Canvey fight back

fields.headline: Feelgood factor as Canvey fight back
fields.trailText: Canvey Island 4 - 4 Port Vale
fields.body:
Canvey came into this game like mice but finished it like lions, coming back from 4-2 down in the 89th minute to maintain their hopes of a second-round derby against Southend. In between we had enough goals for several Cup ties, enough chances for several more, a missed penalty and diverting interruptions from a streaker of such impeccable Essex credentials he kept his white socks on. They haven't had this much fun on the island since Dr Feelgood split up and they stopped lock-ins at the King Canute.

The tide, which had flowed against the Islanders for most of the match, turned in the last minute of regular time. They were down and all but out, but then Andy Jones, their longest-serving player, pulled one back and Neil Gregory, a former Ipswich and Colchester striker, headed the equaliser in off a post. Joy was so unconfined that the streaker hobbled back on with his trousers round his ankles.

It must be the air around here. The island boasts the highest rate of teenage pregnancies in Essex, and both defences yesterday were more wanton than a Canvey hen party at kicking-out time.

Brian Horton was shocked at such outrageous behaviour but still reckoned he deserved a less embarrassing outcome. "At times we made them look, you know, non-League," the Vale manager said. "It's ridiculous, even if you've conceded four, that you go away with a draw."

It had looked all over at half-time when Vale led 2-0 and Canvey had not produced a shot on target, but then Jeff King, who has led the team to the top of the Ryman League after winning promotion five times in six seasons, shook the Gulls out of their shells and Peter Smith, who played for Horton at Brighton, picked them up by the scruff of their neck.

"I was trying to get them going," King said. "I tried to calm them down before the game - and that didn't work."

Canvey are a passing team, but you would not have known it from this performance. Some of the Islanders favoured putting the ball into channels and some tried to put it into the English Channel.

The first goal was a gift from one central defender; the penalty was a gift from the other. Jeff Minton converted the first and missed the second, hitting the post after running in from all of two paces.

Smith turned the game around. Picking the ball up wide on the right, he moved inside in search of an angle and then with his weaker foot found the top corner of the Vale net from 25 yards.

Canvey always looked vulnerable to crosses and within a minute they went missing under another one, from Dave Brammer, and Mark Bridge-Wilkinson headed in from beyond the far post.

The Islanders were not sunk, though they needed help from Vale. Mark Goodlad was rash enough to supply it, when he rushed from the Vale goal to bring down Canvey's leading scorer Wayne Vaughan, who did not even have the ball at the time.

Two minutes later Canvey thought they had equalised but Micky Bennett was offside. Vale still looked more likely to score: Brammer and Ville Viljanen shot over from good positions, Craig Davidson cleared an Allen Tankard header off the line and Ashley Harrison made a series of saves, including two in quick succession from Bridge-Wilkinson. But another cross undid them, and Minton converted it to restore Vale's two-goal lead with less than 15 minutes left. It should have been enough.

fields.headline: Earnshaw sends Rovers reeling
fields.trailText: Cardiff 5 - 1 Bristol Rovers
fields.body:
Cardiff's revival under Alan Cork continued in spectacular style yesterday as Bristol Rovers of the Second Division were dumped out of the competition.

A second-half hat-trick by the 19-year-old Robert Earnshaw extended their unbeaten run under the latest member of the former Crazy Gang to arrive in South Wales to six matches and what is more, Cardiff are doing it in a most un-Wimbledon-like way.

Since the owner Sam Ham mam moved Bobby Gould upstairs and made Cork head coach six weeks ago, Cardiff have collected 11 points out of 15 by playing a passing game. Although he may have profited from long-ball tactics as a no-nonsense target man, Cork has virtually outlawed them at Ninian Park and yesterday the policy paid dividends.

After falling behind early on, Cardiff refused to panic and were level by the break before overwhelming a lacklustre Rovers side with an impressive four-goal spell.

"I felt Earnie was below average today and I was thinking about taking him off before his second goal ," Cork revealed.

"As long as the boys keep being enthusiastic and wanting to pass the ball, we'll always score goals. Sam is driving me mad at the moment. He says he spent 14 years at Wimbledon teaching me how to elbow and kick people and now I've got people passing the ball!"

Since missing out on a play-off place by losing here in May, Rovers have declined. The strikers Jason Roberts and Jamie Cureton have gone and the team are now becalmed in the middle of the table.

As his visibly shaken players boarded their coach, Ian Holloway could not hide his anger. "That's the worst performance I've seen in my time as manager of Bristol Rovers," he admitted. "It was 1-1 at half-time but we looked punchless and that's what happens when you keep selling your centre- forwards. I apologise to our supporters for that performance; it was absolutely awful."

Rovers took the lead in the eighth minute when a cross by Vitalijs Astafjevs was headed into his own net by Andy Jordan. It was hardly the best way for the 19-year-old defender to start his first full game since arriving from the other team in Bristol last month.

Cardiff equalised seven minutes later when Nick Culkin failed to hold Andy Legg's long throw-in and Keith Evans hooked the ball in from 10 yards. Six minutes after the break Evans sent in Earnshaw and, as Culkin rushed out, the diminutive striker slipped the ball into the far corner.

On 71 minutes, Fortune-West headed in a Legg corner and soon after Josh Low capped a fine performance by setting up Earnshaw for his second, this time rounding Culkin before sliding home. Fortune-West nodded for the Welsh Under-21 striker to complete his hat-trick with a precise finish from 16 yards nine minutes from time.

Having not watched Cardiff's resurgence under Cork, the superstitious Gould decided to stay away yesterday. And Hammam, after acknowledging fans' chants from his usual position alongside the dugout, may well be tempted to impose a permanent ban on the former Wales manager - don't put it past him.

webTitle: Clough is the tops in passing deadlock

fields.headline: Clough is the tops in passing deadlock
fields.trailText: Kidderminster 0 - 0 Burton
fields.body:
This meeting of like-minded managers with a shared past ended perhaps predictably in stalemate. A pretty game can be guaranteed when Jan Molby and Nigel Clough lock horns again a week tomorrow; a swift resolution cannot.

While the former Liverpool room-mates have transferred their passion for passing to their teams, if Saturday's goalless, chanceless draw was any guide, penalties may well be required in the replay.

Burton minds will be on weightier matters before then. On top of earning a replay against Kidderminster on Saturday, Clough's side moved to the top of the Dr Martens League Premier Division on goal difference when Crawley lost at Bath. It was a good day's work all round, which will become rosier should Burton win at Crawley this weekend.

Clough insisted, as his position requires, that the league takes precedence but he, along with Molby, has appeared in a Cup final and, with the not insurmountable challenge of a home tie with Carlisle the carrot, both will be forgiven for a touch of daydreaming this week.

The two seasons Clough and Molby shared at Anfield was sufficient to foster a mutual respect. Both are also earning admiration for the route they have chosen to enter management. By not jumping in at the deep end, both have swum rather than sunk.

Clough continues to be influential on the pitch as well. His superior vision remains and he was Burton's main source of inspiration on Saturday. Molby, still wearing his lucky green shorts despite the chill, must have wished he could have entered the fray as well. Despite dominating possession, Kidderminster did not have the guile to breach Burton's defence. A long night may be in store next week.

fields.headline: Scottish  round-up
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill hailed his side's display as one of the best of his managerial tenure after Celtic destroyed a managerless Hearts 6-1 at Celtic Park in their Premier League encounter.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill hailed his side's display as one of the best of his managerial tenure after Celtic destroyed a managerless Hearts 6-1 at Celtic Park in their Premier League encounter.

The club, shaken this week by the news that Alan Stubbs' cancer had returned, responded in the best possible way - even after going a goal down to Colin Cameron's strike. Celtic battled back to leave the visitors buried by half-time with goals from Joos Valgaeren, Lubo Moravcik, Henrik Larsson and Johan Mjallby. After the break Larsson added his second and Stilian Petrov grabbed Celtic's sixth.

O'Neill revealed that the striker Chris Sutton will undergo a scan tomorrow on his big toe, a major worry ahead of next Sunday's Old Firm clash at Ibrox.

Rangers were held to a scoreless draw by Dunfermline, while Hibernian suffered a 2-0 home defeat at the hands of Aberdeen.

Claudio Caniggia bagged a brace for Dundee, 5-0 victors over visiting St Mirren. Dundee United fell 1-0 at St Johnstone while Kilmarnock won 2-1 at Motherwell.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: First round round-up
fields.trailText: Full round-up and second-round draw.
fields.body:
The Conference leaders Yeovil thrashed the Second Division's Colchester 5-1. Steve Whitton, the Colchester manager, said his team were "mentally and physically second best".

Yeovil's top scorer Warren Patmore opened the scoring and Barrington Belgrave and Terry Skiverton put the Glovers 3-0 up before Colchester pulled one back through Karl Duguid. But a Darren Way penalty and Patmore's 14th of the season gave Yeovil a 17th league scalp.

Their manager Colin Addison said: "It was a marvellous Cup tie and a wonderful performance by our lads."

Kingstonian, at the other end of the Conference, also reached the second round with a tremendous 3-1 win at Second Division Brentford.

Geoff Pitcher shocked the Bees just before the interval and Sammy Winston struck twice in 15 minutes. Lorenzo Pinamonte's last-gasp goal was no consolation for Brentford.

But there were no giant-killing exploits by Sudbury. The Jewson Eastern Counties League side were swept aside 6-1 by Darlington, 76 places above them in football's pyramid. Glenn Naylor scored a hat-trick for the Third Division team.

Gateshead, upset by what they perceived as their poor treatment by Halifax, earned a second-round trip to Swindon with a 2-0 win over the Third Division strugglers.

Matt Pearson, the manager of the Unibond Premier Division side, said: "I was fuming before kick-off because we were not even given a cup of tea when we asked for it. We couldn't even get back into our dressing room at half-time and if this was the amount of respect we were receiving we certainly weren't going to give them any back."

Gary Fletcher scored a 72nd-minute equaliser for Northwich Victoria as they drew 1-1 at the Second Division's Bury, who had led through Nicholas Daws.

webTitle: ITV keeps nation waiting for Millionaire winner

fields.headline: ITV keeps nation waiting for Millionaire winner
fields.trailText:
4.30pm: ITV bosses will tonight keep viewers on tenterhooks by switching to a commercial break during the £1m question in Chris Tarrant's quiz show. By Matt Wells.
Nov 20: ITV fury at dumbing down slur
Nov 20: interactive quiz: how well would you do?
Nov 20: Tarrant gatecrashes Victor funeral
fields.body:
ITV bosses will tonight keep viewers on tenterhooks by switching to a commercial break during the £1m question in Chris Tarrant's quiz show.

The 58-year-old winner, Judith Keppel, said today she was "flabbergasted" when Tarrant decided to keep her waiting in the final round of the hit quiz.

She correctly answered the question. "Which king was married to Anne of Aquitaine?", but she had to wait more than two-and-a-half minutes before she learned she had become a millionaire.

Ms Keppel, a garden designer from Fulham, is clearly well-educated and the tabloid race to trace her ancestry is now on.

She was also outed today as a distant relative of Camilla Parker Bowles.

However she insisted she could do with the prize money.

She said: "I am not by any means rich, money hasn't been a terrible problem but it hasn't always been easy. I am not on the breadline."

It is also understood she is directly descended from Alice Keppel, mistress of Edward VII and great-grandmother of Camilla Parker Bowles, who is thought to be a distant cousin.

Her first husband was Mayfair art gallery owner Desmond Corcoran. Her second husband, from whom she is separated is Neil Shand, a TV scriptwriter who works for Des O'Connor, Jim Davidson and Bruce Forsyth.

webTitle: Real prospect turns Leeds legs to lead

fields.headline: Real prospect turns Leeds legs to lead
fields.trailText: Leeds 0 - 1 West Ham
fields.body:
Anything West Ham can do Real Madrid, the current champions of Europe, can do better. It is a worrying thought for Leeds after a performance that will have left the Spanish spy at Elland Road filing a most encouraging report to his bosses.

West Ham were without their most difficult yet productive talent, Paolo di Canio, who was apparently excused duty because he developed a stomach bug just as the squad were about to journey north. In the Italian's absence Redknapp's team were still committed and clever enough to outwit their leaden hosts.

David O'Leary denied this was a "foot-off-the-pedal job" - a mere warm-up for Real on Wednesday. "We looked tired today," he added and for once he was not offering a thin excuse for his cherished young ones. His team clearly did not have the wit or energy to break down a simple system.

On this evidence Leeds' only similarity with Real will be the all-white kit, adopted in the Don Revie era in flattering imitation of the Spanish masters. White, as every good outfitter knows, makes one look not only cooler but bigger. On Wednesday Leeds will need any edge they can get.

Disconcertingly West Ham wore the dark navy favoured by Real for away matches. On Saturday it was almost indistinguishable from the kit of the three officials, who changed at half-time - and the Leeds goalkeeper Paul Robinson, who did not. The mischievous waited for a handball incident in the home area but it did not materialise. Instead Lucas Radebe chopped down Frédéric Kanouté in the dread zone, only for the referee Paul Taylor astonishingly to wave away penalty appeals.

Kanouté, kneeling on the turf, shook his head in disbelief but West Ham finally made sense of the first half when Kaba Diawara and Trevor Sinclair combined before Nigel Winterburn headed down and in at the far post. It was the 36-year-old full-back's first goal in the claret and blue.

Winterburn and another ancient, Stuart Pearce, matched Rio Ferdinand in subduing Mark Viduka and Alan Smith - no mean feat given the Australian's streak of scoring Leeds' last eight Premiership goals. Smith was easier meat: he has not delivered in the same number of games.

O'Leary was never going to talk up Ferdinand, knowing he would only be talking up the young England centre-back's price further than the £15m Leeds have already offered West Ham. Instead he readily praised the young Frenchman Kanouté, who gave Radebe, no less, a roasting.

Kanouté was denied the goal his highly imaginative and unstinting performance as lone striker deserved. But, given the quality of his opponent, Redknapp's eulogy was justified: "Almost unplayable, awesome ... he's got strength, pace and skill." If only he could score.

Redknapp had less kind words for di Canio, who last week again stoked verbal crossfire at Upton Park over Ferdinand's England suitability. The manager accepted the Italian's excuse - "he felt that if he got on the coach he might be sick" - but Harry was clearly not happy. "Leeds is a tough place to come," he concluded. "In fact not everyone in the team wants to come to Leeds, do they?"

Friction there may be but Di Canio clearly has a future at West Ham. He may drive his manager and his team-mates to distraction but how can Redknapp drop the man he calls his "footballing genius"?

webTitle: Beckham paints the town red again

fields.headline: Beckham paints the town red again
fields.standfirst: United speed five points clear on home front as two English Eurostars break down
fields.trailText: Man City 0 - 1 Man Utd
fields.body:
When the dust has settled on this neighbourly spat, the Manchester rivals will feel that for now and the foreseeable future the only thing they have in common is the letter M in their postcodes.

It may have been one of the most important dates in City's calendar since the best part of five years ago but United will consider that, with Panathinaikos on the Champions League agenda at Old Trafford tomorrow, it was probably not even the biggest game of the four days.

However unpalatable that may be for Manchester's blue contingent, that is the way it is. Their time may come but at the moment it must feel like light years away. United's advanced artillery has taken them five points clear at the Premiership's summit and City must make do with their sling and stones as they now hover perilously above the relegation zone.

City's fans will continue to loathe United's with a passion and those from Old Trafford will continue to treat those from Maine Road with the sort of condescending tone usually reserved for a well-meaning but simple cousin. In United's fanzines "city" no longer even merits a capital C.

From the moment they emerged to Two Tribes by Frankie Goes to Hollywood, City's intentions carried no element of surprise but apart a few spiky moments when Alfie Haaland and Danny Tiatto seemed to be playing an adaptation of brag with anyone in a red shirt - "I'll match your studs and raise you another two inches" - the tribal warfare amounted to nothing more than minor skirmishing.

When you have silenced the Boixos Nois in the Nou Camp and the Curva Scirea at the Stadio delle Alpi, as United have done against Barcelona and Juventus, the vitriol spewed up by Maine Road was never going to see them hoisting the white flag.

"Their blood was boiling but we had ice in our veins," summarised Gary Neville, alongside David Beckham as the coolest of the lot.

United looked as though they could step up one, two, even three gears but their profligacy might have been costly had City not been quite so stagnant in attack. Chances came and went and in the end the City manager Joe Royle might reflect that the fan who hit Beckham with a pound coin had a better aim than any of his front players.

By then, however, the damage had been done with a Beckham free-kick special which Royle clearly felt his goalkeeper Nicky Weaver should have saved. "I would beg to differ," protested Weaver, but his instinctive step to his left, just as the ball was struck, had proved fatal. Beckham's kick went the other way and the City supporters, having waited patiently since April 1996 to renew hostilities with the enemy, had enjoyed only 95 seconds before being blanketed by a familiar feeling of nausea.

Four successive defeats have left City treading water but they have acclimatised to the Premiership as well as they would have dared to anticipate and if their defence and attack click together, rather than one or the other going awol, they should survive with a bit to spare.

The problem is that sometimes too much can be expected too soon. Two seasons ago in a 24-hour period, the memories of which will still redden the cheeks of any self-respecting City fan, Royle's team lost in front of 3,007 fans to Mansfield in the Auto Windscreens Shield and United hosted Bayern Munich in the European Cup to a full house. Compared with that, a 1-0 defeat to England's premier team shows that City are still making a lot of progress, even if United are disappearing into the distance.

webTitle: Derby ruffle feathers of broody Bantams

fields.headline: Derby ruffle feathers of broody Bantams
fields.trailText: Derby 2 - 0 Bradford
fields.body:
Before this match both sides looked in danger of extinction, like those poor creatures David Attenborough has been talking about in State of the Planet. They will struggle to survive, certainly at this high altitude.

Bradford, who are expected to unveil Jim Jefferies as their new manager today, are surely doomed. But Derby's first win of the season, at the 14th attempt, will give them much heart, particularly as this was their fourth clean sheet in succession.

After the match the manager Jim Smith beamed in the direction of the Nigerian World Cup defender Taribo West, who has been signed on loan from Milan, and said: "He's one of the best in the world, a top-class defender.

"I didn't know where the hell he was playing at first. He was on the left, then on the right and then in the middle. I'm not sure that will work against Manchester United next week. But he seemed to know what he was doing. And everyone else looked comfortable around him. If he is looking to impress people, that suits me fine. He is here for three months and maybe until the end of the season."

West's assurance seemed to rub off on Georgi Kinkladze, who not only set up both goals but at times played keep-ball as mischievously as the old Celtic wizard Jimmy Johnstone. For the first goal, 10 minutes after the break, Kinkladze ran at the Bradford defence before slipping the ball to Malcolm Christie. The shot was low and accurate, though the goalkeeper Matt Clarke should have done better.

For the second goal Kinkladze passed left to the overlapping Seth Johnson, whose cross was headed home with some power by Rory Delap.

"This win has lifted a big stone off our backs and now the lads will be looking forward to Manchester United," said Smith. And he seemed to mean it.

Kinkladze added: "The signing of Taribo will certainly make us a better team. I feel I can now show you the form of two and three years ago. I thought it worked very well in the second half."

Bradford's caretaker manager Stuart McCall, who was suspended for this match, said afterwards: "The new boss has already proved that he can motivate people and turn things around.

"When he was manager of Hearts he had a fresh approach and built a very good young side. He had new ideas. The timing of this appointment is good because there is still plenty of time to change things."

Derby's Craig Burley was impressed by Jefferies north of the border. "He had his hands tied because he was always selling players. But he was impressive.

"He has always wanted young players around him and has worked the foreign market very well, particularly in France. I'm sure he will do the same at Bradford."

After this match the new man will know the size of his task - if Jefferies is a judge.

fields.headline: Stephen Lee: a biography
fields.trailText: Stephen Lee is a senior research fellow in voluntary sector management at the centre for charity and trust research at South Bank University and chief executive of the Kingston Smith fundraising support unit. He is respected at home and abroad as an authority on fundraising and the voluntary sector.
fields.body:
Stephen Lee is a senior research fellow in voluntary sector management at the centre for charity and trust research at South Bank University and chief executive of the Kingston Smith fundraising support unit. He is respected at home and abroad as an authority on fundraising and the voluntary sector.

Having undertaken research and later taught at Lancaster University, Lee entered the voluntary sector in 1982 as deputy chief executive at the Charities Advisory Trust and Directory of Social Change. Following further senior appointments in charities, Lee held the post of director of the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers (ICFM) for eleven years. During this period he gained wide knowledge of charity fundraising, marketing, charity law, governance and ethics.

In his professional capacity at Kingston Smith, Lee advises commercial and non-profit clients on corporate governance, fundraising and marketing.

His principal current research interests include public trust and confidence in giving (with professor Adrian Sargeant); donor and client rights; joint cost allocation in non-profit marketing and risk agency analysis pertaining to non-profit governance.

Lee is a frequent broadcaster and conference speaker on non-profit matters, nationally and internationally. A fellow of the Royal Society of Arts and honorary fellow of the ICFM, in September 2000 he received the inaugural professional fundraising lifetime achievement award. He is also a trustee of the Carers National Association.

fields.headline: Arsenal go through Moscow motions
fields.trailText: Everton 2 - 0 Arsenal
fields.body:
With the home side shorn of 10 first-team regulars, the debate over Everton's proposed move away from Goodison Park might have been expected to take centre stage over a victory for the visitors.

But after a result which left the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger, if not incandescent with rage, then decidedly ashen-faced, not one of those in blue favours seemed even remotely bothered where their club's home will be thre seasons hence for, like all good supporters, they opted to live for the moment, to rejoice in the achievements of today rather than concern themselves with the problems of tomorrow.

Bearing in mind a casualty list which features Richard Gough, Paul Gascoigne, Duncan Ferguson, Francis Jeffers and Abel Xavier, this really was some achievement.

Afterwards Wenger, as he digested the unpalatable manner of his side's first League defeat since the season's opening day, spoke of distracted minds, of carelessness and of squandered opportunities.

He did not speak of the dismal contribution of Dennis Bergkamp and Nwankwo Kanu, nor of the profound clumsiness of Ray Parlour and Robert Pires, but his reluctance to condemn those who had let him down so comprehensively was, perhaps, understandable for this morning he must face having to lift shattered morale en route to Moscow and the reopening of his club's Champions' League campaign on Wednesday.

"Maybe our minds were already on the game against Spartak but, if that was the case, it is not at all acceptable," he said.

"It is a worry to drop five points behind Manchester United in the table. If you lose five points to Derby and Everton in successive games you must be concerned."

The Arsenal manager was probably not being disrespectful to Everton but, by refusing to concede that his own, admittedly weakened, team had been outwitted by a collection of reserve and fringe players, he was arguably guilty of dereliction of duty.

After a series of abject home performances Everton were almost a revelation, full of running, nicely disciplined and with sufficient guile - just - to claim a most de served success.Unlikely heroes in blue were dotted all over the place. From the Israeli Idan Tal on the left of midfield to the unsung but tireless Mark Pembridge in the centre, the Everton team was awash with men who would not even claim to be household names in their own homes; and yet they coasted to victory.

"Their players get paid at the end of every month, so I wasn't surprised to find that they could play football," said Wenger with his one nod in the direction of gallows humour.

In truth, a game which held more intrigue than it did smart football seemed likely to end without a goal until Everton struck 10 minutes into the second half, Danny Cadamarteri finishing neatly after Gary Naysmith's long pass had drifted over Arsenal heads.

The last word went to a former Gunner, Kevin Campbell steering home a rising drive after Cadamarteri's determination and muscle had undone a laboured Arsenal defence.

At the final whistle the old lady that is now Goodison rose as one to acclaim the most improbable of triumphs.

But, whisper it, her days are numbered.

webTitle: McManaman expects big challenge at Elland Road

fields.headline: McManaman expects big challenge at Elland Road
fields.trailText:
Leeds v Real Madrid
Leeds may have had a bad day against West Ham but Steve McManaman has warned that Real Madrid will be expecting the worst this Wednesday.
fields.body:
Steve McManaman has warned that Real Madrid will not underestimate Leeds despite the Yorkshire side's anaemic performance against West Ham on Saturday.

Real, who won 1-0 at Villarreal on Saturday, travel to Elland Road for their second-phase Champions League match on Wednesday and their former Liverpool midfielder McManaman said: "Leeds have an exceptional team. We are not going to underestimate them at all, but we are not worried about going there."

The influential Lazio midfielder Juan Veron will miss the Champions League matches against Anderlecht and Leeds after injuring a fibula when Argentina played Chile on Thursday. He missed Lazio's 1-1 home draw with Milan on Saturday and is expected to be out for another three weeks.

Milan have also been hit by injuries before this crucial phase of European competition and will be without their key trio of Alessandro Costacurta, Francesco Coco and Demetrio Albertini for tomorrow's match against Galatasaray.
