webTitle: Kids' stuff softens the primal screams

fields.headline: Kids' stuff softens the primal screams
fields.trailText: Every Saturday I turn on Soccer AM in the hope of having a good scoff, but usually end up being hugely entertained - their take on the Manchester derby was no exception
fields.body:
Everyone, to quote the great philosopher Mani from something called Primal Scream, was bang up for it. Mani was a guest on Sky's Soccer AM talking about Saturday morning's Manchester derby, which Sky appeared to be bang up for to a degree that threatened the ozone layer.

Being bang up for it, of course, is very much Sky's stock-in-trade, especially for events to which they hold exclusive rights: you watch, they will even be bang up for Coventry-Ipswich tonight. But I detected a new level of excitement over City-United. The Hollywood-style trailers, running all week - Return of the Jedi, Batman ... And Now the Most Eagerly Awaited Sequel of All - were something to behold.

Soccer AM's take on the match was leavened, I am pleased to say, with a touch more irony. Sitting on the sofa beside the bass guitarist Mani, who represented the red half of Manchester, was the City fan Noel Gallagher of Oasis, who in his cool, semi-detached way, seemed to be as bang up for it as anyone.

Soccer AM, which I switch on most Saturday mornings prepared to scoff at the posing and mugging of the presenters Tim Lovejoy and Helen Chamberlain, invariably ends up entertaining me hugely. It is children's television, I suppose, but in the tradition of the genre, there is plenty there for mums and dads, and the tone of voice remains more or less adult.

This is not an easy trick to pull off, as BBC1's Football Fever on a Sunday morning is proving. Football Fever is clearly aimed at a similar audience to Soccer AM, with Matt Smith and Katy Hill standing in for Tim and Helen, but fails dismally to cut the mustard. There is nothing inherently wrong with the material - the jokes are not very funny but a lot of those on Soccer AM are not either - but Matt and Katy are trying far too hard.

The kind of connection with the audience Soccer AM manages is not achieved overnight. It will not happen for Football Fever without a good, long run and without some more adult features (obviously not in any top-shelf sense of the word) out of which the humour can grow organically. My guess is that Football Fever will disappear from the schedules before any of that occurs. A new vehicle should be found for Matt Smith, though, who is nearly as relaxed as Tim Lovejoy without being quite so "involved with himself", as the Americans might put it.

One of the secrets of Soccer AM is the quality of its guests, selected from a rarely changing cast list. Neil Ruddock is a regular: "always revealing something that's going to make the papers," according to Tim. His revelation this week was that he had decided to retire from international football to spend more time with his family.

Mani has also been on the show a time or two, as has Noel, so both had an easy familiarity with Tim and Helen. "I know you're rivals," said Tim, "but do you still like to get together for the craic?" "I haven't done drugs for two years," protested Oasis's cheeky chappie. When Tim expressed mock outrage at their casual style of dress, Noel said they had decided to dress like a carpet fitter and a plasterer - my thoughts exactly - so they would not be confused with a boy band.

Mani, who helped officiate over the draw for the LDV Vans Trophy - née the Auto Windscreens Cup - was described by Noel as "the drinking man's Ted Croker," a joke I suspect which flew straight over the head of the show's mostly young audience but still drew a chuckle from the young ones round my place.

This, I think, is exactly the tone for which this sort of programme should be striving. Meanwhile regular features such as the five-minute phone-in, the Third Eye and Feed The Goat (don't ask), keep the show rattling along. The production team is to be congratulated on the finest show of its type since the heyday of Fantasy Football.

In a way this sort of programme helps put football in its place, unlike the irony-free zone that is Sky Soccer. It seemed odd moving straight from Mani and Noel to the match itself, the title sequence for which made the trailer for Jaws appear a model of restraint. "It's been a long time, too long," intoned the announcer over portentous music. "It is a city awash with red and blue. Today, as the tides come together, at last the wait is over. One city united. Today divided ... " And so on.

It was, of course, the first Manchester derby for five years, or as Martin Tyler put it, plugging Sky's range of digital services, "the first Manchester derby in the interactive era".

I have to say at the pub in Salford where I watched the match, enthusiasm for any sort of interaction, beyond that with the bar staff, was strictly limited. The morning kick-off was not madly popular either but the match was enjoyed and Sky were generally felt to have done, well, a bang-up job.

webTitle: Fundraising chief quits to set up first charity think tank

fields.headline: Fundraising chief quits to set up first charity think tank
fields.trailText: Stephen Lee is quitting his job as chief executive of the Kingston Smith fundraising support unit to start a charity think tank.
fields.body:
Stephen Lee is quitting his job as chief executive of the Kingston Smith fundraising support unit to start a charity think tank.

Lee will join up with professor Adrian Sargeant, a researcher in fundraising, to establish the first policy think tank specifically aimed at charity and voluntary organisations.

Lee says: "I am delighted to be working with Adrian to identify and meet the marketing, fundraising and management needs of charities."

At Kingston Smith, Lee provided specialist advice to commercial and non-profit clients on corporate governance, fundraising and marketing.

Previously, he was director of the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers for eleven years. During this period he established himself as an authority on charity fundraising, marketing, charity law, governance and ethical issues.

Stephen Lee will be joining SocietyGuardian.co.uk for an online chat on Wednesday November 22 at 3pm. He will be happy to answer questions on any aspect of fundraising from how to get started to attracting committed supporters.

fields.headline: Newsnight exposes paedophile
fields.trailText: The BBC plan to expose a paedophile tonight in an extraordinary undercover investigation by Newsnight. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The BBC is planning to expose a paedophile tonight in an extraordinary undercover investigation by Newsnight.

In a disturbing documentary, a young woman uses secret cameras to confront her abuser and members of the paedophile ring into which she and other members of her family were sold.

The Newsnight special has been six months in the planning but has been kept a strict secret for fear of reprisals and injunctions.

It has been made with the co-operation of the victims of the abuse as well as participation of organisations working with the victims.

The programme also includes an interview with the alleged abuser.

The decision to go ahead with tonight's Newsnight film was taken after legal advice and approval from BBC2 controller Jane Root and head of editorial policy Phil Harding.

Newsnight's special investigation highlights how the public and media's pre-occupation with paedophiles snatching young children masks the reality that most child abuse occurs within the home or amongst family and friends.

The programme will also cause clashes with the police and social services who come in for criticism.

webTitle: Ministers commit to Euro defence force

fields.headline: Ministers commit to Euro defence force
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: EU defence ministers, in Brussels to discuss the setting up of a rapid reaction force, announced that the Union would meet its 2003 goal of being able to field a force of up to 60,000 ground troops within 60 days and to maintain such a force on mission for one year.
fields.body:
EU defence ministers, in Brussels to discuss the setting up of a rapid reaction force, announced that the Union would meet its 2003 goal of being able to field a force of up to 60,000 ground troops within 60 days and to maintain such a force on mission for one year.

The force, which will consist of 100,000 troops, some 400 aircraft and 100 ships, aims to be ready to respond to crises and take on a variety of tasks from evacuation of EU nationals to peace enforcement by heavily armed combat troops.

The plan is already being savaged by critics as a de facto European army.

The British contribution will include 12,500 ground troops, 72 combat aircraft and 18 ships. However, MoD officials say that to allow 12,500 men to mobilise quickly, a total commitment of 20,000 would be needed.

Defence secretary Geoff Hoon said it made sense for EU countries to pool expensive military assets in common operations and insisted that the EU was not setting up an army or a standing European force.

"It is extremely disappointing that what is a very sensible commonsense way of planing a European commitment is becoming subject to rather hysterical comment," he said.

Chief of defence staff, General Sir Charles Guthrie, said that the rapid reaction force would make Nato stronger, not weaker.

But senior military figures from both sides of the Atlantic added their voices in opposition to the European rapid reaction force.

General Sir Anthony Farrar-Hockley, the former commander-in-chief of Nato forces in northern Europe, said European states lacked the military hardware and skills the Americans could provide through Nato. "Only two nations of any substance in Europe have all-professional, all-regular forces - that is France and Britain," he said.

However, the EU's foreign policy head, Javier Solana, insisted that the force would benefit Europe. "This new capability will help the Union to advance its key objectives - peace, stability and the protection of human rights. The Union has worked hard for many years in pursuit of these goals. Now we shall be able to do more to advance and protect them," said Mr Solana.

Meanwhile, the British minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, was today drawn into a war of words with the Conservatives over the government's plans. William Hague, the Tory leader, yesterday ridiculed government claims, saying that the proposed force was nothing less than a standing army for the EU, further eroding British national sovereignty.

"If it looks like an elephant and sounds like an elephant, then it is an elephant," he said.

Mr Vaz hit back, insisting there was no European army in the making: "I would say to Mr Hague - if it looks paranoid and incoherent, and it sounds paranoid and incoherent, it must be the leader of the opposition."

Shadow defence secretary Iain Duncan Smith said that the Tories would put the force back under Nato control, and insisted that the rapid reaction force would lead to disputes and problems between Nato and Europe.

"We will have no truck with this because this is embryonically moving towards a Euro army to separate Nato and push the Americans out of Europe and that would be very dangerous," he said.

The EU defence ministers will tomorrow meet Poland, Hungary, Turkey, Norway, Iceland and the Czech Republic, the six Nato members that are not in the EU. Each is expected to offer its own contribution to the force.

fields.headline: Flo set for £14m Rangers move?
fields.trailText: Tore Andre Flo is set to complete a £14m move to Rangers in time for the Old Firm derby against Celtic on Sunday, according to unconfirmed reports.
fields.body:
Tore Andre Flo is set to complete a £14m move to Rangers in time for the Old Firm derby against Celtic on Sunday, according to unconfirmed reports.

This morning Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson revealed they had turned down a bid from Rangers - thought to be around £12m - for Flo last Friday, and said that Claudio Ranieri wanted the Norwegian to stay.

"We have had an offer for Flo but there is no deal imminent. His agent, however, has indicated to us that he wants to leave but he has not come to us and said that," he admitted. "We really do not want to sell him."

Matters have moved on since Hutchinson's comments this morning, with both Flo's agent and Rangers admitting a move is close. Website football365 have even reported that a deal has already been completed, but Rangers are refusing to comment on the speculation.

"Tore Andre has given clear signals that he wants more first team football and, since he isn't getting that at Chelsea, a transfer could be right around the corner," agent Gunnar Martin Kjenner told NTB. "Tore Andre thinks Rangers is a great and exciting club.

And this afternoon Rangers also confirmed they are in talks with Chelsea. "We will find out in the next 24 hours if he is coming to the club or not," admitted chairman David Murray. "He has some individual matters to resolve with Chelsea and, if these are resolved, then I am hopeful that he can become a Rangers player.

"Of course, any deal has to be right financially for Rangers. There is a maximum for everything at this club and we would not put the club at risk."

webTitle: Scottish childcare recruitment campaign greeted with calls for higher salaries

fields.headline: Scottish childcare recruitment campaign greeted with calls for higher salaries
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive's high-profile campaign to recruit an extra 5,000 childcare workers has been broadly welcomed - but it may not be enough to solve the staffing problems of the future, writes David Mitchell.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive's high-profile campaign to recruit an extra 5,000 childcare workers has been broadly welcomed - but it may not be enough to solve the staffing problems of the future, agencies have warned.

The campaign, launched last week by deputy minister for education Nicol Stephen, is part of the executive's action plan, unveiled in the summer, to train and develop more workers in early education, childcare and playwork.

During the next four weeks, advertisements in the Scottish and regional press will highlight a wide range of qualifications and jobs available across the childcare sector. These include nursery nurses, child minders, playgroup leaders and workers in out-of-school care, such as breakfast and after-school clubs.

The Scottish executive claims that it is well on track to meet its target of recruiting an extra 5,000 childcare workers by 2002 - as part of an overall drive to improve access to high quality, affordable daycare for children aged up to 14 years.

Nicol Stephen said: "The executive is committed to giving children the benefit of high quality early education and care. For this reason, we are extending nursery places to all three- and four-year-olds and investing significantly in childcare.

"To meet these aims, the number of employees working in childcare needs to expand significantly. The recruitment campaign will encourage many more people to take up the challenge of working with children in Scotland to ensure that they achieve their full potential."

Children in Scotland, an umbrella organisation for voluntary agencies, welcomed the initiative - but it said much more needed to be done to improve pay levels and career opportunities in the sector.

"It has to be recognised that as long as salary levels and opportunities for career development remain limited in the childcare profession, it will be very difficult to recruit and retain staff," said policy officer Douglas Hamilton.

"For many childcare workers, particularly nursery nurses, there is nowhere for them to go, and few opportunities for promotion in the place where they work. If they want to progress, they have to go into management, look outside, or do something different altogether.

"One suggestion is that there could be ways of providing roles that have increased responsibility for other areas, but there don't seem to be those opportunities at the moment. The reality is that within the setup there is still not going to be the potential. They may develop qualifications, but there is nowhere to take them in the workplace."

One Parent Families Scotland also voiced doubts about the campaign and questioned whether it would be effective enough to recruit more men into the sector. A recent survey of Scottish colleges providing childcare courses revealed that Scotland has lower than the UK average of male students, with less than 1%.

"I think people will be resentful that large amounts of money are being spent on advertising campaigns, when the real issue is how do you make it more attractive by increasing pay and conditions," said spokesperson Ian Maxwell.

"A lot more needs to be put in place to support men on training courses and working in childcare. There are some encouraging moves in this direction, but they are largely the result of individual projects rather than any unified move by the Scottish executive. Until you do that, recruitment campaigns such as this could be counterproductive, and we would rather the money was spent on support."

webTitle: Dome wins new lease of life

fields.headline: Dome wins new lease of life
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The government today named the Legacy company, which wants to turn the Millennium Dome into a hi-tech business centre, as its preferred bidder for the attraction.
fields.body:
The government today named the Legacy company, which wants to turn the Millennium Dome into a hi-tech business centre, as its preferred bidder for the attraction.

The firm, headed by Labour party-supporting property entrepreneur Robert Bourne, had threatened to pull out of the deal unless a favourable government response was not forthcoming soon.

Now, with the dome closing to the public at the end of the year, the attraction's immediate future seems secure.

Legacy wants to create a business mini-city within the dome, in Greenwich, south-east London. Established business will be housed alongside new start-ups in an enterprise that could mean 14,000 new jobs within three years.

Mr Bourne said: "We are very pleased to be given the preferred bidder status. We've worked very hard on our offer and we are delighted the government has awarded it to us."

Asked if they had forced the government into the move by threatening to withdraw their bid, Mr Bourne said: "Both ourselves and the government wanted to come to a decision as quickly as possible.

"Obviously the governmnet have a huge investment in the dome and these things take time. We have been patient and our patience has been rewarded."

He said that his company's creation - to be known as Knowledge City - would aim to become "one of the world's leading centres of innovation and excellence in the fields of high technologies, e-commerce and bio-science, so that the Dome can become a real symbol of Enterprise Britain".

Legacy said that Knowledge City had the support of such organisations as BT, the London Business School and the Open University.

David James, the chief executive of the dome, said there would now be a period of "detailed negotiaions with Legacy on the terms attached" which would hopefully be completed by February next year.

He said a formal exchange of contracts would then follow and that after the dome closes at the end of the year, the decommissioning process would begin as expected.

Asked if he thought Legacy may bulldoze the super-structure of the dome, which is not built to last indefinitely, Mr James said: "I am certain they are not and that would be part of the acceptable terms."

Mr Bourne said: "We have built into our business plans maintaining its fabric. Our plan is a long-term plan which will see £150m invested over three years."

And Mr Bourne added: "There is an opportunity to move a number of companies in quite early on in the process. The dome itself will be decommissioned and that process will last until May-June next year.

"But there is space outside the main part of the dome where we can accommodate companies from as early as the spring of next year."

Asked if Legacy's plans would suffer from negative stigma surrounding the dome, Mr Bourne said: "No, not at all. It is a great opportunity and the dome is an icon, a fantastic structure. The investment in the infrastructure of the dome gives us a great head start."

Legacy had finished second to the Dome Europe consortium in the competition to take over the site at the end of this year. But, backed by Japanese finance group Nomura, Dome Europe pulled out in September as the full extent of the dome's financial crisis became apparent.

The government then turned to Legacy again, but the company had grown increasingly frustrated by the delay in getting the official green light for its bid.

Last week, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, headed a meeting where ministers heard a report on the Legacy bid from regeneration agency English Partnerships which owns the Dome site.

Despite Legacy initially saying they would "regretfully withdraw" if no favourable decision was made by the end of last week, Mr Prescott said more time was needed to study the bid.

Legacy responded by retreating from its earlier stance, saying it was happy to give the government a few more days.

Ministers are still reeling from the political embarrassment caused by the dome's financial flop caused by far-lower-than-expected visitor numbers.

The extent of the mismanagement by all concerned was highlighted in this month's report by government spending watchdog body, the National Audit Office.

News of the preferred bid came in a parliamentary written answer given by Hilary Armstrong, the minister for local government and the regions.

She said: "Legacy has been awarded preferred bidder status because they have confirmed that they will resolve all outstanding contractual issues within an agreed timetable.

"Negotiations will continue and if all goes well we expect to exchange contracts during February. Progress will be reviewed regularly. English Partnerships will be working closely with Legacy to agree a masterplan for the dome and associated land."

Ms Armstrong added that English Partnerships and Greenwich council were working together to put in place a new partnership for the next stage of the regeneration of the Greenwich peninsula.

fields.bodyText: The government today named the Legacy company, which wants to turn the Millennium Dome into a hi-tech business centre, as its preferred bidder for the attraction. The firm, headed by Labour party-supporting property entrepreneur Robert Bourne, had threatened to pull out of the deal unless a favourable government response was not forthcoming soon. Now, with the dome closing to the public at the end of the year, the attraction's immediate future seems secure. Legacy wants to create a business mini-city within the dome, in Greenwich, south-east London. Established business will be housed alongside new start-ups in an enterprise that could mean 14,000 new jobs within three years. Mr Bourne said: "We are very pleased to be given the preferred bidder status. We've worked very hard on our offer and we are delighted the government has awarded it to us." Asked if they had forced the government into the move by threatening to withdraw their bid, Mr Bourne said: "Both ourselves and the government wanted to come to a decision as quickly as possible. "Obviously the governmnet have a huge investment in the dome and these things take time. We have been patient and our patience has been rewarded." He said that his company's creation - to be known as Knowledge City - would aim to become "one of the world's leading centres of innovation and excellence in the fields of high technologies, e-commerce and bio-science, so that the Dome can become a real symbol of Enterprise Britain". Legacy said that Knowledge City had the support of such organisations as BT, the London Business School and the Open University. David James, the chief executive of the dome, said there would now be a period of "detailed negotiaions with Legacy on the terms attached" which would hopefully be completed by February next year. He said a formal exchange of contracts would then follow and that after the dome closes at the end of the year, the decommissioning process would begin as expected. Asked if he thought Legacy may bulldoze the super-structure of the dome, which is not built to last indefinitely, Mr James said: "I am certain they are not and that would be part of the acceptable terms." Mr Bourne said: "We have built into our business plans maintaining its fabric. Our plan is a long-term plan which will see £150m invested over three years." And Mr Bourne added: "There is an opportunity to move a number of companies in quite early on in the process. The dome itself will be decommissioned and that process will last until May-June next year. "But there is space outside the main part of the dome where we can accommodate companies from as early as the spring of next year." Asked if Legacy's plans would suffer from negative stigma surrounding the dome, Mr Bourne said: "No, not at all. It is a great opportunity and the dome is an icon, a fantastic structure. The investment in the infrastructure of the dome gives us a great head start." Legacy had finished second to the Dome Europe consortium in the competition to take over the site at the end of this year. But, backed by Japanese finance group Nomura, Dome Europe pulled out in September as the full extent of the dome's financial crisis became apparent. The government then turned to Legacy again, but the company had grown increasingly frustrated by the delay in getting the official green light for its bid. Despite Legacy initially saying they would "regretfully withdraw" if no favourable decision was made by the end of last week, Mr Prescott said more time was needed to study the bid. Legacy responded by retreating from its earlier stance, saying it was happy to give the government a few more days. Ministers are still reeling from the political embarrassment caused by the dome's financial flop caused by far-lower-than-expected visitor numbers. The extent of the mismanagement by all concerned was highlighted in this month's report by government spending watchdog body, the National Audit Office. News of the preferred bid came in a parliamentary written answer given by Hilary Armstrong, the minister for local government and the regions. She said: "Legacy has been awarded preferred bidder status because they have confirmed that they will resolve all outstanding contractual issues within an agreed timetable. "Negotiations will continue and if all goes well we expect to exchange contracts during February. Progress will be reviewed regularly. "The dome has proved to be the top pay-to-visit tourist attractions in this country and has acted as a catalyst for the regeneration of what was a poisoned peninsula, scarred by hundreds of acres of wasteland." webTitle: McManaman rebirth continues on the anniversary of Franco's death

fields.headline: McManaman rebirth continues on the anniversary of Franco's death
fields.trailText: On 20th November 1975 General Francisco Franco, Spain's dictator since 1936, finally drew his last breath. Yesterday, 25 years on, Francoist die-hards and a new crop of neo-fascists flocked to Madrid's Plaza de Oriente to salute the man who ruled Spain with an iron fist for 35 years.
fields.body:
On 20th November 1975 General Francisco Franco, Spain's dictator since 1936, finally drew his last breath. Yesterday, 25 years on, Francoist die-hards and a new crop of neo-fascists flocked to Madrid's Plaza de Oriente to salute the man who ruled Spain with an iron fist for 35 years.

But for all those who donned shaven heads, bomber jackets, unfeasibly tight jeans and took to the streets chanting "Franco, Franco" in Madrid, or anywhere else, there were far more people filling football stadiums in Vigo, Villarreal and even Vallecas. As questionnaires this weekend showed, Spain's younger generations see Franco merely as "a thing of the past". There are new heroes to worship now: men like Rivaldo, Figo and Mendieta. And McManaman.

It's true - reports of Macca's footballing death have been greatly exaggerated. Real Madrid's Scouse superstar has played four games on the trot, and this weekend he was the toast of the football press after Madrid's 1-0 win away at giant killers Villarreal. It was Macca whose, admittedly tame, cross ex-Barca man (double the fun) Guillermo Amor turned past his own keeper to secure victory for Vicente Del Bosque's side.

Madrid sports daily AS was even kind enough to declare it: "Macca's goal with some help from Amor". But it's off the field where MacManaman is really winning them over. To judge by the Spanish press, Macca, who didn't complain "and asked for nothing but respect" when the club shunned him during the summer, is the very incarnation of the perfect English gentleman. It's nice to know that it's not just the Sun and the Mail that indulge in comforting national stereotypes.

McManaman's "goal" was all the more valuable for the failure of Valencia and Deportivo to collect all three points. The top two both played poorly and drew 1-1. Valencia in Vitoria against Alavés, and Depor down the road in Pamplona against Osasuna.

Scaloni headed the season's fastest goal - 17 seconds - to give Depor the perfect start, but the current champions couldn't capitalise and Cruchaga equalised 15 minutes later. Meanwhile Valencia came from behind against Alavés, with the awkward but strangely effective John Carew finishing off Mendieta's pass.

Things only continue to get worse for Barcelona however - this time it was Zaragoza who beat them 3-0. Three goals in 15 minutes either side of half time were enough to sink a Barça side looking desperately short of ideas up front and comically awful at the back. This goalkeeping hilarity just runs and runs - this time it was Arnau's turn. A backpass from Petit wasn't even dangerous - not that is, until Arnau decided he could play a bit and ended up gifting Zaragoza their second.

Up in the director's box, Joan Gaspart, who afterwards said there was "no reasonable excuse" for Barça's performance could barely watch. Not surprising. What is surprising is that Gaspart continues to support Lorenzo Serra Ferrer and that poll on Catalan TV this weekend suggested that only 50 per cent of the culés want him to go.

Elsewhere, Rayo Vallecano moved into a Champions League place with a 4-2 home win against Málaga, with Bolo, Bolic, Bartelt and Bravo (as in Juliet) getting the goals. There were four goals, too, for Real Sociedad at home to Numancia (4-1), and Oviedo against Valladoilid (4-1).

Las Palmas ended Mallorca's five game unbeaten run with a comfortable 1-0 win in the Canary Islands, and Racing scored late on to secure a 1-1 draw with Celta in Vigo. Meanwhile Rangers must be kicking themselves - Raul Tamudo scored again as Espanyol secured a 2-1 win against Athletic Bilbao, taking them to tenth in the table.

Among all the additional column inches on Franco this weekend was the revelation that the dictator didn't support Real Madrid after all. Not that that's likely to have any effect on the club's membership - these days even Madrid's right-wing Ultras have long-since transferred their loyalties to Raul and co.

webTitle: Urban white paper brings unprecented change

fields.headline: Urban white paper brings unprecented change
fields.standfirst: The government's paper on urban regeneration paves the way for vast improvements, writes Esther Knight, assistant director of the Centre for Local Econonic Strategies
fields.trailText: The government's paper on urban regeneration paves the way for vast improvements, writes Esther Knight, assistant director of the Centre for Local Econonic Strategies.
fields.body:
The House of Commons responded mutely to the long awaited urban white paper and members of parliament struggled to find in it much that was new. But their response was misplaced. This paper adds up to unprecedented change for those involved in urban regeneration and renewal.

This is the first attempt in almost a quarter of a century to bring together the government's approach to urban areas at the strategic regional and local levels. Significantly, it sets up a new committee at cabinet level to oversee this process.

The paper also makes explicit the link between urban population and pressure on the countryside.

Key recommendations from Lord Rogers' urban taskforce report "Towards an Urban Renaissance" influence the paper, and it uses as its starting point the links between the social/economic and environmental factors at play in urban areas. To put it simply, joined up problems require joined up solutions.

At the national level, the government has committed itself in the chancellor's pre-budget statement to a series of measures designed to encourage development in run down areas. These include money for transport and a review of the framework aimed at putting urban renewal at the heart of the country's planning system.

The statement also gives the government's regional office a greater role in joining up urban initiatives and extra resources for regional development agencies.

At the local level, new legislation gives local authorities wide powers to act in the interests of economic, social and environmental wellbeing of their areas.

Pilot local public service agreements in councils are monitoring public services, while the introduction of local strategic partnerships, bringing together local agencies and community groups to coordinate regeneration work, places much greater emphasis on local consultation.
The white paper aims to tackle poverty and social exclusion through economic growth and links quality of life with quality of public services. All the new initiatives are designed to recognise that the needs of individual areas are varied. The "tool kit" approach - which moves away from the "one size fits all" attitude - is to be welcomed. This white paper increases the scope for local action, though not necessarily local power.

fields.headline: EMI signs internet deals
fields.trailText: EMI has signed a series of internet deals which will see its vast back catalogue downloaded over the web, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
EMI has taken the e-initiative by sealing several internet access deals, a day before it announces its latest results.

The UK record company has joined up with European internet firms DX3 and On Demand Distribution and US internet music company Streamwaves.

The European deals will allow EMI's considerable back catalogue to be downloaded over the web. The companies specialise in technology which encrypts records and collects royalties from the user.

EMI said: "Music fans have loudly declared that they want music on demand."

Music downloads over the internet represent a serious threat to record company revenues, and record companies have reacted by jumping into bed with the sites.

German media giant Bertelsmann, which is attempting to merge its BMG label with EMI, has signed a deal with rogue website Napster and Universal Music has joined up with MP3.com.

The City will be listening out for news on the proposed merger of EMI and BMG at tomorrow's results, though analysts say it is unlikely anything will be announced until the deal is completed.

webTitle: Yahoo ruling hailed as landmark case

fields.headline: Yahoo ruling hailed as landmark case
fields.trailText: Internet giant Yahoo has been ordered to ban French web users from accessing its English-language sites that sell Nazi memorabilia. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet giant Yahoo has been ordered to ban French web users from accessing its English-language sites that sell Nazi memorabilia.

In what French authorities are hailing as a landmark ruling, Yahoo has been given 90 days to stop French internet traffic from straying into prohibited territory.

Under French law, Yahoo can be fined F100,000 for each day it exceeds the deadline, if the company ignores the judgement.

The case, prompted by a short-lived auction of Nazi memorabilia on Yahoo.fr, will have far-reaching implications for international internet law.

It was brought by the Paris-based International League against Racism & Anti-Semitism (LICRA) and the Union of French Jewish Students (UEJF).

A third French anti-racist group, MRAP, joined the action at a later stage.

The organisation used French law, which bans the sale of Nazi memorabilia, to get the site closed down.

However, they pursued the case to the courts in a bid to establish a precedent that would stop users in one country gaining access to illegal material in another.

While Yahoo's French-language portal, Yahoo.fr, does not host such auctions, French internet users, like all others, can move over to Yahoo.com and come across memorabilia such as Nazi books, daggers, SS badges and uniforms.

Yahoo's defence was that its English-language Yahoo.com services are US-governed and that auctions of Nazi material cannot be barred because of US constitutional rights to freedom of speech.

The ruling could have repercussion on other big US internet businesses that tap into local markets, especially Amazon.com and eBay, which dallies in consumer-to-consumer auctions.

webTitle: Landmark ruling against Yahoo! in Nazi auction case

fields.headline: Landmark ruling against Yahoo! in Nazi auction case
fields.standfirst: Special report: Free speech on the net
fields.trailText: In a landmark ruling, a French court has ordered the internet giant Yahoo! to block French web users from its auction sites which sell Nazi memorabilia.
fields.body:
In a landmark ruling, a French court has ordered the internet giant Yahoo! to block French web users from its auction sites which sell Nazi memorabilia.

The decision closed a seven-month court battle started by several anti-racism groups that accused the California-based company of trivialising the Holocaust.

Yahoo! shares fell sharply at the news, down 5.4% to $48.50 (£35) in late morning trade on the Nasdaq stock market.

The court gave Yahoo! three months to find a way to block French users from visiting English-language auction sites where Nazi books, weapons, SS badges and uniforms are offered for sale.

Although Yahoo!'s French portal does not host Nazi memorabilia auctions, French users can easily click over to the company's English-language services, where such auctions are available. In France, it is illegal to sell or display anything that incites racism.

When that three-month period is up, Yahoo! will be subject to a 100,000-franc (about £9,500) fine for each day it does not comply, the court said.

Internet experts are concerned the case could set a legal precedent regarding the right of one country to reach across borders and impose its own laws on online material that is stored in other nations.

During the trial, Yahoo!'s lawyers argued that blocking the site from French web surfers would be technically impossible. The internet has no borders, they said, and there is no effective means of preventing its users from travelling where they like.

"We regret having to put in place measures that won't be effective," said Christophe Pecnard, a lawyer for Yahoo!, adding that he hoped "that other countries won't take the same route." Pecnard also said he would study ways to appeal the decision.

The trans-Atlantic legal battle began seven months ago, when two Paris anti-racism groups sued Yahoo!, angry that French people had access to more than 1,000 objects of Nazi memorabilia on the site at yahoo.auctions.com.

In May, a French judge ordered Yahoo! to pay £1,000 (£720) to each of the two advocacy groups that sued, ruling that the company had offended the nation's "collective memory."

The judge also ordered Yahoo! to find ways to block French users from its Nazi auction sites or other Yahoo! sites with content deemed to be racist.

The advocacy groups that sued Yahoo! have argued that there is a moral high ground in this case that should shield the French from the commercialisation of Nazi objects.

Laurent Levy, a lawyer for the Movement Against Racism and for Friendship Between Peoples, called the decision "exemplary." Levy said: "It resolves the question of borders on the internet."

In its ruling, the Paris court said that it is technically possible for Yahoo! France, the company's local subsidiary, to block at least 90% of French users from the sites in question.

Earlier this month, a team of Internet experts testified that it was possible to keep some French web surfers from seeing the sites, though one specialist, American Vinton Cerf, expressed concern about hindering internet freedom.

fields.headline: Universities face staffing crisis
fields.trailText: Universities are drifting towards the sort of staffing crisis that hit nursing in the health service, ministers were warned today.
fields.body:
Universities are drifting towards the sort of staffing crisis that hit nursing in the health service, ministers were warned today.

Sir Michael Bett, who chaired a recent inquiry into pay in higher education, said the new money announced by the government last week was not enough to prevent the coming crisis. He had recommended that between £400m and £500m was needed to raise pay, especially for starting salaries and senior academics, and to tackle inequalities suffered by women staff. David Blunkett, the education secretary, has promised increased funding for pay from next year, rising to £170m in three years time.

Universities were trying to tackle recruitment and retention problems by redeploying resources but that meant other jobs were going unfilled, Sir Michael told the annual meeting of the Higher Education Funding Council for England. At some point the overstretched elastic would snap. It is quite true we found there was no crisis in higher education - yet. It is a gradual process of rundown due to inadequate money for pay. We are running down the quality of our universities.

What happened in nursing could easily happen in higher education. For years the people running the hospital trusts and the government said there were adequate numbers of nurses and there was no need to make special payments. Then there was a regrading of nurses that went catastrophically wrong and took a long time to sort out. A few years later the present government woke up to a real crisis in nursing.

We can go on as we are in higher education and nobody will notice very much but one day we will wake up and discover there is a real crisis, said Sir Michael. He welcomed the extra money announced by the government but said it was nonsense to suggest it was enough. But Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the funding council, said the government had given higher education a pretty good settlement, with spending set to rise to £6.4bn in 2003/4. He signalled an increase in collaboration between institutions in pursuit of the governments agenda of widening participation, innovation, better research and helping business and the community.

fields.headline: Help for your RAE submissions
fields.trailText: This special report provides an essential aid for the last hectic days of preparation for the Research Assessment Exercise writes Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
There are now only 160 days to go. On the 30 April 2001, thousands of carefully crafted university submissions will be delivered to the higher education funding councils. The 2001 Research Assessment Exercise will finally have reached its second crucial phase. The outcome will no longer be in university hands: referees will start their marathon seven month review of research quality in university departments.

Already departments will have recruited new researchers, re-organised activities, and taken part in entire dummy runs of the assessment in the run up to the deadline. Yet as preparations are finalised and tactics are honed, the next five months could make all the difference. Key decisions over the coming weeks will in many cases determine whether departments secure a higher or lower rating - an outcome on which both funding and reputation over the next five years rests.

This special report on the RAE provides an essential aid for the last hectic days of preparation.

News and analysis articles will monitor and digest the latest developments in the exercise. It will monitor the views and policies being discussed and developed in universities. There are also the statements, clarifications, and interpretations from the RAE team managing the exercise.

Listed too, are all the links to the best internet resources dedicated to the assessment. Apart from the RAE team's official pages, there are now several useful websites available. These range from a search engine trawling all official RAE 2001 information to an easily accessible search of the results of the 1996 assessment. We also list the home pages of many of the panel chairpeople - revealing the academic profiles of the pivotal figures assessing university submissions.

The exercise, of course, is more than just a race for research ratings. About £1bn in public money is distributed on the back of the ratings every year. How these grades get translated into core research grants (decided by the funding councils only after the ratings are produced) is a keenly debated topic - the key question being how selective funding should be. We list links to the particular funding methods implemented by the English, Scottish and Welsh funding councils.

The obsession with the RAE has generated a whole academic literature in itself - considering the nature, impacts and consequences of the exercise. We have selected the pick of the bunch of papers. Some are informative and thought provoking. Others perhaps offer more in the way of entertainment than enlightenment.

Finally, we look to the future. All the funding councils are currently reviewing their research funding models. It now looks as if the RAE will remain in some form after 2001. But will there be a UK wide framework to speak of? And how will the changes impact on university researchers?

We also hope to provide feedback and views from the experts themselves: the academics whose lives will be focused on RAE 2001 until the 30 April deadline passes.

Please email comments, suggestions, and views to: lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Number of trainee teachers rises
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Recruitment to teacher training has risen for the first time in eight years, according to government figures published today.
fields.body:
Recruitment to teacher training has risen for the first time in eight years, according to government figures published today.

Ministers hope the figures - which appear to show the impact of new training salaries as well as more opportunities for on the job training - will quash the Tories' claims of a deepening teacher recruitment crisis.

Nevertheless they still reveal that while targets in the primary sector have again been met, there is a 13% shortfall of trainees required to fill jobs in secondary schools.

The latest figures published by the teacher training agency (TTA) show that 28,000 trainee teachers have been recruited. The rise means that there are now more than 2,000 more new trainees than the same time last year. Overall there has been an 8% rise, with a 14% increase in graduates.

There has also been an increase in the number of graduate recruits to shortage subjects - technology, modern languages, science and maths.

Labour inherited declining recruitment from the Tories and has since introduced a series of measures intended to make teaching and training, more attractive. These include performance-related pay for teachers, as well as the new training salaries and "golden hellos" of £4,000 for post-graduates training in shortage subjects.

The government has succeeded in attracting the 13,000 trainees it needs to meet its targets in the primary sector, but there is a 13% shortfall in meeting the targets for secondary schools.

There, it has attracted 14,508 trainees compared with the 16,615 it needs.

Drop-out rates for trainees also remain high, with many failing to enter the classroom once they are qualified.

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, said: "We welcome these figures but cannot be complacent. We know that schools are still finding it hard to recruit the teachers they need in subjects such as maths and physics because of the hugely competitive labour market for such specialisms. Areas like London and the south-east are especially tough when graduates may have an even wider range of careers to choose from."

Publication of the new figures comes three weeks after the TTA launched a recruitment drive, backed by a £7m advertising campaign on television and in newspapers.

Ralph Tabberer, chief executive of the TTA, said: "It is a competitive market and we are not complacent about the need to attract many more high quality people into the profession."

The shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "No matter what they are saying about the past, it is the future that counts. We will only see any increase in recruits into teaching turned into teachers in classrooms if the government gets off the backs of schools and makes the profession something that people want to actually go into."

Teachers' leaders said the increase was negligible. Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, said: "Considering all the incentives now in place, there ought to have been a much bigger rise. This is a very small step when there is another million miles to go."

Meanwhile, Tony Blair's vision of an educational "Sandhurst" will move a step closer this week when he launches the national college for leadership for heads, deputy heads and other senior teachers.

The prime minister will launch the "virtual" side of the college at a London conference for newly-qualified head teachers on Thursday.

fields.headline: Don't knock the nurdle
fields.standfirst: Lawrence Booth says any criticism of England's performance in Lahore is over the top, but the visitors must continue to build on what they've learnt
fields.trailText: This was an excellent result for England, and those who argue otherwise have extremely short memories. If you can remember as far back as last Tuesday you may recall that the pre-series hype was all about England's spin-phobia: nobody thought they could keep out Saqlain Mushtaq and Mushtaq Ahmed, and few imagined the game would last four days, let alone five. England's goals were understandably limited: avoid both humiliation against the spinners and defeat in a country where they haven't won for 39 years. They did this with aplomb, and even threatened to make Pakistan follow on, which was a bonus.
fields.body:
This was an excellent result for England, and those who argue otherwise have extremely short memories. If you can remember as far back as last Tuesday you may recall that the pre-series hype was all about England's spin-phobia: nobody thought they could keep out Saqlain Mushtaq and Mushtaq Ahmed, and few imagined the game would last four days, let alone five. England's goals were understandably limited: avoid both humiliation against the spinners and defeat in a country where they haven't won for 39 years. They did this with aplomb, and even threatened to make Pakistan follow on, which was a bonus.

On their last visit to the subcontinent, in 1992-93, England lost all four Tests in India and Sri Lanka. Sixty-one of their 80 wickets fell to spinners, their average innings total was 271 and they scored at 2.55 runs an over. At Lahore England's 480 for 8 came at the rate of 2.45 an over. So to discover that some people thought this over-cautious is perplexing - particularly as the pitch was slow, the outfield slower and the opposition world-class. Look what happened when England tried to be too aggressive: Trescothick, Atherton, and eventually Thorpe were caught sweeping, while Hussain ballooned into the covers. England learned that the best method was to hit the bad balls and pick off what they could from the rest. And they learned that quickly.

In reality a huge burden has been lifted from England's shoulders: they can now look forward to the rest of the series without being too paranoid about Saqqy's doosra or Mushy's googly (that's if he's picked for the second Test); and they can approach the three-Test series in Sri Lanka - not to mention next winter's passage to India - with greater confidence. Any short-term criticism of Thorpe's dour approach must be seen in this context.

Incredibly, 14 of the 16 wickets claimed by the slow bowlers went to finger-spinners, and the two that didn't came too late to matter. A lack of pace and bounce in the wickets hampered the leggies, and although Faisalabad and Karachi are likely to be more helpful, England will have to make a decision abut Ian Salisbury. His figures of 31-5-71-0 were curious: he didn't get wallopped, but he didn't take a wicket and, as the five maidens show, he was milked with ease. It could just be that the Pakistan batsmen didn't want to hit him out of the attack. With Michael Vaughan available again for the second Test, England may consider omitting Salisbury, playing seven batsmen - assuming Nasser Hussain's wrist mends in time - and relying on Ashley Giles, Graeme Hick and Vaughan for spin.

Craig White would then drop to No. 8. This is no reflection on his 93, which brilliantly fulfilled one half of Hussain's plea that England's batsmen either nurdle (like Thorpe) or attack. But it would strengthen the tail. And it would show that England aren't falling into the trap of believing that White is suddenly a world-class allrounder on the strength of an innings in which he was dropped twice and should have been given out caught bat-pad. =His knock should be seen for what it was: a sign that White is increasingly confident and can play when he's not forced to lunge forward against the quicks. Reminiscent, in other words, of Chris Lewis, who hit a hundred in India eight years ago but not much else. From nowhere White has become a central character. But it's crucial to England's chances in this series that this isn't overplayed.

 Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of Wisden.com

fields.headline: Wardman takes home news brief at Sky
fields.trailText: 5.45pm: Sky News has promoted home news editor Phil Wardman to the new post of head of home news.
fields.body:
Sky News has promoted home news editor Phil Wardman to the new post of head of home news.

Meanwhile, deputy news editor Jane Elston will replace Michael Wilson, who last week was given the job of special reports editor, heading up Sky News's new investigative unit.

Deputy news editor Jane Elston replaces Wilson as news editor, working alongside news editors Rob Kirk and Roger Protheroe.

Mr Wardman has been a news editor at Sky for five years after working at Reuters, GMTV and Central TV.

Ms Elston previously worked on the home and foreign desks at ITN.

webTitle: First Tuesday to restructure after job losses

fields.headline: First Tuesday to restructure after job losses
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: Dot.com networking organisation First Tuesday is to restructure following a number of redundancies, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Dot.com networking organisation First Tuesday is to restructure following a number of redundancies forced by its US parent company Yazam.

As the UK office awaits an official statement from the US, it was confirmed that two people had been laid off in London.

Speculation mounted today that another two had resigned and that further job losses could be on the cards. Globally, some 5% of Yazam's workforce is believed to have been axed so far.

The restructure comes less than four months after New York-based internet start-up investor Yazam bought First Tuesday for just over £40m.

None of the original three founders - Nick Denton, Adam Gold and Julie Meyer - are still with the company, although Ms Meyer still speaks at the conferences and events. She is said to be getting ready to go it alone, but has not revealed her plans. First Tuesday is now run by Reade Fahs.

First Tuesday, which began in London in October 1998 as a meeting place for investors and innovators, grew quickly to a network across 85 cities in 42 countries.

It was hailed as the shining star of the internet revolution and in its heyday, entrepreneurs were fighting for tickets to First Tuesday events.

Despite its popularity, it struggled to make enough money to cover operational costs and was bought out by Yazam.

webTitle: Florida battle royale to start at 7pm GMT

fields.headline: Florida battle royale to start at 7pm GMT
fields.trailText: The differences in Florida vote totals remain paper-thin today as lawyers for Al Gore and George W Bush prepare to argue before the state's supreme court over a manual recount of punch ballots that could determine America's next president.
fields.body:
The differences in Florida vote totals remain paper-thin today as lawyers for Al Gore and George W Bush prepare to argue before the state's supreme court over a manual recount of punch ballots that could determine America's next president.

Republicans want to stop the ongoing hand recounts in three heavily Democratic counties. Democrats, looking for new votes to whittle down Bush's 930-vote lead, are fighting to get them included in the final official tally. The court is expected to begin hearing the legal arguments at 7pm GMT today.

Around six million votes were cast overall in make-or-break Florida. A weekend tally of overseas absentee ballots has stretched Mr Bush's official lead. However, uncompleted hand recounts over the weekend in Broward and Palm Beach counties cut it slightly to 834 votes as of midnight Sunday.

The hand counting resumed today in Palm Beach County, to be followed later in the morning by Broward, while Miami-Dade County was expected to begin its hand tally.

Mr Gore narrowly won the nationwide popular vote and holds a slight edge over Mr Bush in the all-important electoral college tally. But neither candidate will reach the required 270 electoral votes to be declared the nation's 43rd president without Florida's 25 electors.

Prospects for an abrupt end to the election deadlock are highly uncertain. Mr Gore's allies are not ruling out pressing ahead on other fronts if the state supreme court does not support them.

Floridian Democratic senator Bob Graham, who is close to the Gore campaign, said today that the state's entire vote should be counted again by hand. "What we're trying to achieve here is an election that has credibility by the American people. That credibility would likely be enhanced if all Florida voters had their ballots hand counted," he said.

Both candidates maintained low profiles yesterday, with each going for a run and then to church. Meanwhile, their lawyers filed legal briefs with the Florida supreme court, which had ruled on Saturday that Florida's controversial secretary of state, Katherine Harris, could not certify the state results until the court decided whether to allow the hand recounts to be included.

Mr Bush's lawyers said it would be unfair "to keep the state and the nation on hold" during interminable recounts while Mr Gore's attorneys argued for some counties to get more time to complete hand tallies.

Ms Harris, a Republican activist, tried to distance herself from the presidential rivals. Mr Gore's supporters pointed to her campaigning for Mr Bush as a sign of bias. Ms Harris said in separate court filing: "It is clear, that for the Democrats and the Republicans, the object is to win, and that is understandable. The stakes are very high."

Mr Gore's legal team asked the court to set a generous standard for officials to "ascertain the electorate's will" when ballots were punched in the disputed presidential election. They said local election officials in close cases can "determine the voter's intent" by closely examining the ballot.

The Democratic vice-presidential candidate, Joseph Lieberman, said: "It seems to be that they're doing everything they can to stop the recounting of votes because they're slightly ahead and they fear that after the recounting they won't be."

In Broward County, Mr Gore's count by Sunday night showed a net gain of 108 votes, with more than two-thirds of the 609 precincts counted. Set aside for the time being were ballots with tiny pieces of paper in the punch-card.

Republicans had accused Broward's three-member canvassing board of bowing to political pressure from Democrats in undoing a decision to throw out ballots that did not have two corners poked out of the punch-hole.

Ed Pozzuoli, a Republican, said: "The Gore campaign now wants to lower the bar because it needs more votes."

Democrats said the ruling allows voters' intentions to be noted. Democratic attorney Charles Lichtman said: "These chad marks didn't get on the ballot by osmosis."

Miami-Dade County mechanically sorted ballots by machine yesterday in preparation for beginning its hand count. Mr Bush's attorneys protested the action, saying it would alter the delicate ballots, but a circuit judge gave the go-ahead.

The Democratic vice-presidential candidate, Joseph Lieberman, said: "It seems to be that they're doing everything they can to stop the recounting of votes because they're slightly ahead and they fear that after the recounting they won't be." In Broward County, Mr Gore's count by Sunday night showed a net gain of 108 votes, with more than two-thirds of the 609 precincts counted. Set aside for the time being were ballots with tiny pieces of paper in the punch-card. Republicans had accused Broward's three-member canvassing board of bowing to political pressure from Democrats in undoing a decision to throw out ballots that did not have two corners poked out of the punch-hole. Ed Pozzuoli, a Republican, said: "The Gore campaign now wants to lower the bar because it needs more votes." Democrats said the ruling allows voters' intentions to be noted. Democratic attorney Charles Lichtman said: "These chad marks didn't get on the ballot by osmosis." Miami-Dade County mechanically sorted ballots by machine yesterday in preparation for beginning its hand count. Mr Bush's attorneys protested the action, saying it would alter the delicate ballots, but a circuit judge gave the go-ahead. fields.headline: Survey reveals widespread child abuse
fields.trailText: More sexual abuse of children is perpetrated by siblings than by fathers or stepfathers and violence towards children is more likely to come from mothers than fathers, according to a survey for the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.
fields.body:
More sexual abuse of children is perpetrated by siblings than by fathers or stepfathers and violence towards children is more likely to come from mothers than fathers, according to a survey for the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

The charity, which last night demanded urgent government response to its findings, published the most comprehensive survey so far of child abuse in the UK, showing 6% suffered serious physical neglect, 6% were emotionally maltreated and 1% were sexually abused by a parent.

Mary Marsh, the charity's director, called on the government to rethink its opposition to the appointment of children's commissioners for England, Scotland and Northern Ireland.

"The appointment of such watchdogs, as is being advanced in Wales and across Europe, must be the government's first response to this report."

The charity's findings come from a UK-wide survey of the childhood experiences of 2,869 young people aged 18-24 by the research company BMRB International.

By asking a large representative sample of young adults to give their recollections confidentially on computer terminals, the charity thinks it obtained the most accurate picture so far of the extent of abuse. It says it would have been ethically wrong and difficult to survey children directly.

According to the findings, published today on UN Children's Rights Day, one in 14 suffered serious physical abuse at the hands of parents or carers, including being hit with a fist or implement, beaten up, or burned and scalded on purpose.

That proportion is equivalent to nearly 1m of the children in Britain today. The NSPCC said 49% of the victims were treated violently by their mother, 40% by their father and 8% by a step-parent.

One in 12 suffered bullying and discrimination regularly and more than four in 10 experienced it at some point. In the first polling research into the prevalence of emotional maltreatment, the charity found 6% experienced multiple attacks on their self esteem, including terrorising, humiliation, withdrawal of affection and harming of possessions or pets. Girls were twice as likely as boys to suffer from this type of cruelty.

One in 10 - mostly girls - have been forced into sex acts under the age of 16 and involving people known to them. In 43% of cases, the perpetrator was a brother or stepbrother, compared with 19% saying a stepfather and 14% naming their father.

The survey found more than nine in 10 young people said they grew up in a loving family, but one in four said there were childhood events that they found difficult to talk about.

Ms Marsh said: "For many young people, serious stresses and unhappiness cast a dark shadow over what should have been an otherwise happy childhood.

"Some young people interviewed in this research suffered serious forms of abuse during their formative years, often on a regular basis and often in silence. For many, the damage done will last long into adulthood."

She repeated the charity's call for independent commissioners to protect children, similar to the statutory bodies for women, ethnic minorities and disabled people. This was Labour policy in its 1992 election manifesto, but was dropped in 1997.

A Department of Health spokesman said: "Any type of child abuse is unacceptable and the government has already taken steps to tackle this. This includes a national care standards commission by April 2002 with 70 officers around the country.

"It will have a national director for vulnerable children who will understand the new standards for those in care or at risk of abuse."

But David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health committee, said: "The time is ripe for the government to follow the example of other European countries by introducing an independent children's rights commissioner... There are now no excuses for putting off such a move."

Julian Brazier, president of the Conservative Family Campaign, said: "I'm very much in support of the campaign for a children's commissioner. I strongly believe that politicians and the public must unite to help the NSPCC rid society of cruelty to children."

webTitle: Israeli rockets hit Gaza after bomb blast

fields.headline: Israeli rockets hit Gaza after bomb blast
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: In its most punishing strike yet, Israeli helicopters hit back hard at Palestinian targets in Gaza today, firing dozens of rockets after a roadside bomb blew up an Israeli school bus, killing two and wounding nine.
fields.body:
In its most punishing strike yet, Israeli helicopters hit back hard at Palestinian targets in Gaza today, firing dozens of rockets after a roadside bomb blew up an Israeli school bus, killing two and wounding nine.

Gaza City was plunged into darkness as electricity went off during the raid, around nightfall. Among the buildings hit were the Palestinian police headquarters, a building run by Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's political movement Fatah, and the security police headquarters. Before the raid, Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak called his cabinet into special session to formulate the response to this morning's attack on the armoured school bus.

The Israeli military said three Palestinians had set off a bomb made of a mortar shell and a detonator as the bus left Kfar Darom, an isolated Jewish settlement in the Gaza Strip.

Two Israeli adults were killed and nine people, including five children, were injured in the blast.

Israeli deputy defence minister Ephraim Sneh, speaking for the government in a parliamentary debate, said the "tracks lead, apparently, to the military institution of the Palestinian Authority"; headed by Mr Arafat, and that Israel held Mr Arafat responsible.

Mr Arafat's Fatah faction denied that it was responsible for the bombing. "The Fatah movement is not responsible for today's attack, and whenever Fatah carries out an attack it will publicly claim responsiblity," Ahmed Ghneim, a senior official in the faction, said.

Israel army radio reported that Palestinian gunmen were firing at the Israeli helicopters. Israel television reported that helicopters had fired rockets at the Jabaliya refugee camp on the outskirts of Gaza City.

If confirmed, this is the first time that the Israelis have targeted a refugee camp for rocket fire in the nearly two-month-long conflict that has left at least 238 people, mostly Palestinians, dead. In the parliament, rightwing opposition leader Ariel Sharon said Mr Barak's government was not doing enough to protect Israeli citizens.

"Jews are being killed in the only country where they have the ability to defend themselves, and the government is not doing all it can to defend them," Mr Sharon told MPs. Three different groups - Palestinian Hezbollah, Al Aqsa Martyrs and Omar Al Mukhtar - claimed responsibility for this morning's attack. The first two have not been active before, and it was not clear whether they had ties to existing Islamic militant groups, which have carried out roadside bombings in Gaza in the bast. The third, Damascus-based Omar Al Mukhtar, is a little-known splinter of a tiny PLO faction.

Hamas leader Sheik Ahmed Yassin was evasive when asked whether his group was responsible. "What happened today is a natural outcome of the many deaths on the Palestinian side," he said, referring to more than 200 Palestinians killed in seven weeks of Israeli-Palestinian fighting. "Our targets are not children, but the military."

Mr Arafat consulted with security officials and ordered an investigation.

Last week, Mr Arafat ordered Palestinians to stop shooting at Israelis from areas under Palestinian control. However, the ban did not refer to attacks in areas of the West Bank and Gaza that remain under Israeli control.

The Gaza road where the mortar shell was detonated is under Israeli security control, while the surrounding area is under Palestinian rule.

The school bus left the isolated Jewish settlement of Kfar Darom in the heart of the Gaza Strip at around 7.30 am, carrying pupils and teachers were to an elementary school in Gush Katif, a bloc of Jewish settlements in the south of the strip.

webTitle: Global warming talks stalled as leaders arrive

fields.headline: Global warming talks stalled as leaders arrive
fields.trailText: World leaders gathered in the Netherlands today at the start of the ministerial negotiating round of vital talks aimed at curbing climate change.
fields.body:
World leaders gathered in the Netherlands today at the start of the ministerial negotiating round of vital talks aimed at curbing climate change.

The meeting, which began last week at a preliminary level, is in deadlock after a long-running argument between the US and Europe. Environment ministers from at least 150 countries have arrived in the Hague with the aim of overcoming this.

An agreement reached in 1997 in Kyoto, Japan, called for a worldwide reduction of emissions of carbon-based gases by an average of 5.2% below 1990 levels during the five-year target period of 2008-2012. Europe is committed to cutting emissions by 8%, Japan by 6%, the US by 7%.

However US negotiators want to trade their requirement to cut emissions against lower-than-expected pollution from Russia and the developing world.

On Thursday, the European Union rejected a US proposal which would enable it to meet half its Kyoto target without reducing emissions.

This morning Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands appeared at the Congress Centre at the Hague before speeches by French president Jacques Chirac and Dutch premier Wim Kok. Britain's deputy prime minister John Prescott, who is leading the UK delegation, is due to make a keynote address to the conference tomorrow.

Mr Prescott is expected to underline how flooding, which in past weeks has devastated properties and farmland in the south of England, the Midlands and Yorkshire, has brought home to Britons the urgency of the situation. Yesterday, he acknowledged that there were differences between Europe and the US, though he held out hope that a compromise could be reached. "I wait and see what their final negotiating position is before I come to a conclusion. I do think you can get an agreement ... There are some signs that some give is coming in this situation," he said.

Margot Wallstrom, the EU commissioner on the environment, argued that it was not too late to preserve the environment, but stressed that the time had come for decisive action. Asked whether she felt that America was the "villain of the piece", Ms Wallstrom said: "It would be absurd if the biggest emitter of greenhouse gases would not sign the Kyoto Protocol, or ratify it."

There has been speculation that US president Bill Clinton may decide to attend the Hague talks on his way back from a trip to Vietnam.

Who wants what

US, Russia, Japan, New Zealand, Australia, Canada
• Forests, crops, etc at home counted as carbon credits.
• Aiding forestation abroad to be counted as a credit.
• States that have met carbon reduction targets can sell their surplus to those that have not.

European Union
• Domestic action to cut burning of fossil fuels.
• Strict limits on carbon trading.

G77 and China
• Developed countries to make real domestic cut.
• US to pay overdue contributions to allow World Bank to finance green energy projects in G77 countries.

webTitle: ITV fury at dumbing down slur

fields.headline: ITV fury at dumbing down slur
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: ITV bosses are furious with suggestions that they have dumbed down the questions on tonight's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? just to kill off the BBC in the ratings.
fields.body:
ITV bosses are furious with suggestions that they have dumbed down the questions on tonight's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? in a concerted attempt to kill off the BBC in the ratings.

Suspicions were immediately raised about the quality of questions when reports emerged that someone will win the £1m jackpot for the first time in the two-year history of the show.

The BBC believes it is more than just coincidence that a millionaire emerges because tonight's episode is scheduled head-to-head with the last ever episode of One Foot in the Grave.

But sources at ITV have pointed out that the Chris Tarrant quiz show has actually strengthened its lead over the BBC sitcom over the last five weeks.

One source said: "It is a great shame to see the BBC reacting with such cynicism. Who Wants to be a Millionaire? has been winning the ratings battle with One Foot in the Grave for weeks now. They are both great British programmes. Why can't the BBC just accept that Millionaire is hugely popular without these unpleasant and unfounded attacks."

Five weeks ago when One Foot in the Grave began it was neck and neck with Millionaire with 10.2m viewers.

But by week two One Foot in the Grave was trailing by 1m viewers and by last week the gap had widened to 2.4m.

Celador, the maker of the quiz show, was due to hold a press conference at 2.30pm giving reporters the first chance to meet winner Judith Keppel, a 58-year-old garden designer from Fulham.

She impressed viewers immediately after she emerged as the only one to correctly answer the fastest finger first round which involved putting four prime ministers in chronological order.

ITV only confirmed Ms Keppel's victory at lunchtime, under pressure from reporters.

'We are very disappointed that news of this win has leaked in advance of transmission origin. We really wanted to keep it a secret so as not to spoil viewers' enjoyment of the programme," said the spokeswoman.

webTitle: Space station: the toilet works great

fields.headline: Air conditioner thumps, but the toilet works great
fields.standfirst:
The three crew of the space station take in their first delivery of essential supplies - eventually
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: A Russian cosmonaut aboard the international space station had to bring in a cargo ship by remote control Friday night after an automatic system failed.
fields.body:
A Russian cosmonaut aboard the international space station had to bring in a cargo ship by remote control Friday night after an automatic system failed.

Yuri Gidzenko used a joystick to guide the Russian Progress ship to a safe linkup with the space station, almost an hour later than planned. It was the first Progress docking for the three-man station crew, on board for just two weeks.

Everything was going well earlier in the evening as the Progress, loaded with food, boots, brackets, cables, an air conditioner and other supplies, closed in on the space station.

Once the cargo ship was within 300 feet, however, its automatic docking system would not lock onto the space station, and Gidzenko was forced to take over.

He brought the cargo ship to within 15 feet of the space station, then stopped because of glaring sunlight and a camera lens fogged by ice. Some 40 minutes later, he finished the job. Because the space station was out of communication at the time of contact, Mission Control had to wait another 40 minutes before knowing whether the docking had been accomplished.

"I would like to congratulate you for your bravery and heroism and your ability to be patient," a Russian flight controller radioed up.

"You guys have used a lot of adrenaline, huh? OK, well, you guys relax a bit. You've earned it."

Nasa astronaut Bill Shepherd, the station's first commander, moved into the space station for a four-month stay on November 2, along with Gidzenko and Russian cosmonaut Sergei Krikalev.

The three men have just two weeks to unload the cargo ship. Space shuttle Endeavour is scheduled to lift off November 30 with new solar wings for the station, and the cargo ship must be gone by the time the shuttle arrives.
