fields.headline: Court cases hit by strike
fields.trailText: Thousands of criminal cases have been dropped by one of Britain's busiest courts because of a strike by council staff.
fields.body:
Thousands of criminal cases have been dropped by one of Britain's busiest courts because of a strike by council staff.

Hundreds of defendants at Glasgow district court, which deals with cases such as breach of the peace, shoplifting, minor assault and drugs offences, are being dismissed each week because of disruption caused by court staff taking part in a dispute over pay.

The court deals with around 2,000 cases a week and more than half of them have been dropped since the strike involving court clerks began at the start of the month.

The crown office, which handles criminal prosecutions in Scotland, has said efforts were being made to delay or reschedule as many cases as possible but admitted that more than half of all cases were being abandoned because of the action.

"It is an area of concern and we are in close liaison with the police to try to resolve this issue," a spokeswoman said. "Matters which are already progressing through the court are not too much of a problem in that we can keep pushing them back. But it is becoming a matter of discretion with new cases what we can do with them. We have to confirm the fact that we are having to drop cases."

The spokeswoman said some of the more serious cases were being redirected to stipendiary magistrates where possible, and there was an option to re-raise cases at a later date. However, she admitted that it was unlikely that all dropped cases would be resurrected because of the courts' general workload. "The district courts work to their capacity. Any disruption over a period of time does cause problems," she said.

The situation has been condemned by opposition politicians. Phil Gallie, the Scottish Conservatives' justice spokesman, said underfunding of the criminal justice system was to blame. "For us to abandon serious charges seems to me to be total failure by the Scottish executive."

A spokeswoman for the executive said prosecutors at the court were trying to make the best of a difficult situation. She added that it was possible that some of the court cases would be resurrected.

Around 40 court staff, mostly clerks, have been on an indefinite strike since the beginning of November. Their action is part of a series of measures by the local government union Unison, aimed at securing a higher pay award. Council services across Scotland have also been disrupted by one-day stoppages.

Unison's Glasgow branch secretary, Angela Lynes, said yesterday: "We did notify Glasgow city council two and-a-half months in advance that these staff would be brought out, and they chose to ignore that fact."

Council workers had been offered a 6.1% pay increase over two years, but Unison has called for a higher offer over one year. The GMB and TGWU unions originally sided with Unison in the dispute, but voted to accept the latest deal after the convention of Scottish local authorities upped its original offer.

Scotland's councils are now planning to impose a pay offer on workers.

The court deals with around 2,000 cases a week and more than half of them have been dropped since the strike involving court clerks began at the start of the month. The crown office, which handles criminal prosecutions in Scotland, has said efforts were being made to delay or reschedule as many cases as possible but admitted that more than half of all cases were being abandoned because of the action. "It is an area of concern and we are in close liaison with the police to try to resolve this issue," a spokeswoman said. "Matters which are already progressing through the court are not too much of a problem in that we can keep pushing them back. But it is becoming a matter of discretion with new cases what we can do with them. We have to confirm the fact that we are having to drop cases." The spokeswoman said some of the more serious cases were being redirected to stipendiary magistrates where possible, and there was an option to re-raise cases at a later date. However, she admitted that it was unlikely that all dropped cases would be resurrected because of the courts' general workload. "The district courts work to their capacity. Any disruption over a period of time does cause problems," she said. The situation has been condemned by opposition politicians. Phil Gallie, the Scottish Conservatives' justice spokesman, said underfunding of the criminal justice system was to blame. "For us to abandon serious charges seems to me to be total failure by the Scottish executive." A spokeswoman for the executive said prosecutors at the court were trying to make the best of a difficult situation. She added that it was possible that some of the court cases would be resurrected. Around 40 court staff, mostly clerks, have been on an indefinite strike since the beginning of November. Their action is part of a series of measures by the local government union Unison, aimed at securing a higher pay award. Council services across Scotland have also been disrupted by one-day stoppages. Unison's Glasgow branch secretary, Angela Lynes, said yesterday: "We did notify Glasgow city council two and-a-half months in advance that these staff would be brought out, and they chose to ignore that fact." Council workers had been offered a 6.1% pay increase over two years, but Unison has called for a higher offer over one year. The GMB and TGWU unions originally sided with Unison in the dispute, but voted to accept the latest deal after the convention of Scottish local authorities upped its original offer. Scotland's councils are now planning to impose a pay offer on workers.

fields.headline: PeopleNews.com axes staff
fields.standfirst: Useful link: PeopleNews.com
fields.trailText:
PeopleNews.com has laid off staff just two months after launching, reports Amy Vickers.
Useful link: PeopleNews.com
fields.body:
PeopleNews.com, the gossip website set up by former Tatler editor Jane Procter, has laid off staff and restructured just two months after launch.

Chief executive Kelly Moulton has been replaced by operations, business development and marketing director Simon Walker, and the games and diaries editors have both been made redundant.

A number of technical staff have also lost their jobs, although new CEO Mr Walker said these staff were all contractors brought in to set up the website.

"You don't keep the builders around when they've built the house do you?" he said.

Explaining the reason for the two editorial redundancies, Mr Walker said PeopleNews was rejigging the site so that the diaries and games channels could be integrated more into the rest of the site.

He said the two channels didn't work well as separate entities and would be dropping into the news sections of the site.

"It's all about getting the right people doing the right things," explained Mr Walker.

"Sources close to the latest developments questioned the given explanation, saying they had been told the cut-backs were part of a cost-saving exercise and that a lot of money had already been spent.

Mr Walker denied that PeopleNews would be the next dot.com disaster and maintained that the site had "plenty of money left".

He said the next step would be to pull in big sponsorship deals and boost ad sales across the site.

A number of content distribution deals are to be announced in December and a deal with a digital TV company to run a PeopleNews branded short daily slot is in the pipeline.

Mr Walker said PeopleNews was on track to rack up 45,000 unique users by the end of the year, having already pulled in 20,000 unique users since launch.

PeopleNews was set up by Ms Procter with ex-Sunday Times editor Andrew Neil as a non-executive director.

It raised £4m in venture capital from antfactory and Italian venture capitalist GoldenEgg, and is looking for a strategic media partner to take it to the next phase of development.

According to Mr Walker, Kelly Moulton has been freed up to work on this fundraising and partnership initiative.

webTitle: Jon Henley on creating the EU rapid reaction force

fields.headline: Saying 'non' to Nato
fields.standfirst:
Negotiations have begun over troop allocation for the EU rapid reaction force, but the alliance is already showing signs of strain, writes Jon Henley
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: View from Paris: Negotiations have begun over troop allocation for the EU rapid reaction force, but behind the unified front trouble is brewing, writes Jon Henley.
fields.body:
If France ever wanted to turn the EU rapid reaction force being forged today in Brussels into somthing that might some day, in some way, rival Nato, it has not got off to a very good start: the commanding officer will be German, and his number two will be British.

The decision to appoint General Rainer Schuwirth as chief of staff and General Graham Messervy-Whiting as his deputy came as unpleasant and thoroughly unexpected news in Paris and will be seen as something of a put-down here for the country that, together with Britain, pioneered the historic plans for a joint EU military capability.

But it may well have been unavoidable given the strong misgivings in Whitehall and Washington about France's precise intentions with the 60,000-strong EU force, which is due to be in place by 2003 and will be deployed if Nato as a whole does not want to get involved in a new crisis in, for example, the Balkans or Africa.

From the outset at the Franco-British St Malo conference two years ago, warnings have come thick and fast from British conservatives - a notably strident Lady Thatcher among them - that the creation of a self-sufficient European defence capability was all part of a deliberate French strategy to weaken Nato.

"The real drive towards a separate European defence is the same as that towards a single European currency - namely the Utopian venture of creating a single European super-state to rival the US on the world stage," Lady Thatcher said last year.

Britain, she said, in a sentiment shared by many in the British eurosceptic camp, should be extremely wary of any move to lever it away from a strictly US-led Nato strategy in support of France's "long-standing ambition to end US military hegemony in Europe".

More recently, British officials in Brussels confirmed they feared an attempt by president Jacques Chirac to push EU defence too far away from Nato, and Alexander Vershbow, the US ambassador to Nato, warned of "new political frictions in the transatlantic relationship" if the EU created a planning unit for its fledgling defence policy.

The exact terms of Nato's relationship with the new EU military capability, most particularly in terms of strategy, planning and information-gathering, is at the heart of the disagreement, which will prove difficult to resolve before the proposed deadline of next month's Nice summit that close France EU presidency.

Officials involved in negotiations so far have often complained privately that France has tried to keep Nato "at arm's length", and are worried that the Nice summit could adopt proposals leading to the sort of duplication of strategic resources that the North Atlantic alliance insists must be avoided.

While most European Nato members want the EU to have access to Nato planning so as to avoid the risk that Brussels will create its own intelligence organisation, Paris, for so long ambivalent if not downright hostile to involvement with Nato, is keen for the EU to do just that - in opposition to London, which remains influenced by Britain's traditional ties with the US in the intelligence field.

"It is often said that Nato has top-level strategic resources that should not be duplicated," said France's defence minister, Alain Richard, recently. "But in fact, these are basically American national resources. What we have launched, over the past two years, should give us a level of capacity that will gradually make us less dependent on the alliance."

Today's Brussels conference is a matter of pledging troops. But whether or not the crucial strategic planning and information-gathering capacities of Europe's new defence capability can be agreed satisfactorily at Nice will depend largely on the compromises both Britain and France are prepared to make over their attitudes to Nato.

It is early days yet, but the appointments of Generals Schuwirth and Messervy-Whiting seem to show which one of the two is more likely to lose out. France, which has only recently abolished conscription and is currently in the middle of a wholesale reorganisation of its armed forces, with Britain's as the model, will not be very happy.

webTitle: Bradford voters launch campaign for mayoral referendum

fields.headline: Bradford voters launch campaign for mayoral referendum
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Bradford could be among the first councils in the country to adopt a directly elected mayor after local voters launched a campaign for a referendum on the controversial city management model.
fields.body:
Bradford could be among the first councils in the country to adopt a directly elected mayor after local voters launched a campaign for a referendum on the controversial city management model.

Under the Local Government Act 2000, the 50-strong People's Choice campaign group needs to collect the signatures of 18,000 of the local electorate to force their council to hold the binding referendum.

Campaigner Jim O'Neill said his group was confident it could collect the signatures by June 2001. This could mean Bradford joining councils such as Birmingham in a national democracy day of mayoral referendums in October 2001.

Mr O'Neill said the campaign wants to force a referendum, rather than persuade the council to have its own: "We want to turn the leadership of this city into a civic, broadly based role, rather than the party political role we currently have."

Politicians on the city council are, however, opposing the move. Margaret Eaton, the Conservative who leads the hung council, expressed concern that a mayor would concentrate power in too few hands, and that a forced referendum would limit the opportunity for voters to consider other options for reforming the council.

She said: "The electorate has no concept of who will be available for that kind of election, and they seem to think they could have a football manager or film stars."

Nearly 20 councils have so far agreed to hold a referendum for a mayor, or have local campaigns determined to force the issue - around three times the number that existed six months ago.

They include Berwick-upon-Tweed council, Bath and North East Somerset council and Liverpool city council. The government is attempting to bring as many councils as possible together for a democracy day in October 2001 or May 2002, in a bid to maximise turnout for the referendums.

fields.headline: Cilla beats Ant and Dec in TV ratings
fields.trailText: 14.30pm: With over 8m viewers last Saturday, Blind Date beat Friends Like These by over 2m. Jason Deans reviews the week's TV ratings.
fields.body:
Cilla Black made a triumphant return to ITV in the new series of Blind Date on Saturday night, comfortably seeing off Friends Like These. The TV queen's long-running dating gameshow proved that it still has legs, averaging 8.2m and a 37% share over sixty minutes compared to Ant and Dec's Friends Like These which had just 6.4m and a 29% share.

Her victory will go some way towards reassuring the TV host, who recently made it known she was unhappy with being marginalised in the schedule. Her last series of Moment of Truth was scheduled at teatime and did less well in the ratings as a result.

Caroline Quentin's BBC1 sitcom Kiss Me Kate made a disappointing return for its third run on Saturday night, despite moving to a post-watershed slot to allow what the Radio Times described as a "slight broadening of the humour". The comedy, set in a counselling centre, averaged 5.2m and a 23% share from 9.30pm.

Kiss Me Kate was preceded by Have I Got News for You, which shifted to 9pm on Saturday night to make way for Children In Need the previous evening and had 6.5m. Both were beaten by ITV's Clint Eastwood film In the Line of Fire which pulled in an average of 7.4m.

On Friday, BBC1's annual Children in Need charity night pulled in more than £12m for charity, but also put up a sturdy ratings performance. The fund-raising extravaganza averaged 6.8m - a 29% share - between 7-10pm; and then 5.2m and a 44% share after 10.35pm.

BBC1's Ten O'Clock News also had a very good Friday night, averaging 7.2m and a 34% share. On Sunday night, Rory Bremner's satirical special on Tony Blair, My Government and I, averaged a respectable 2.3m and a 10% share on Channel 4 from 9pm.

ITV had a big Sunday night, ratings-wise. Both Coronation Street and Heartbeat topped 14m viewers and a 50% share; while Cold Feet had 9.5m - 1.5m more than its debut the week before - and 41% of viewing. New ITV music series Smash, which looks at the history of the British hit single, also opened promisingly. The first instalment, on rock anthems, averaged 6.7m and a 34% share from 10pm.

On a bad night for BBC1, the showcase for the BBC's recent talent campaign, Stars of Tomorrow, averaged just 3.8m against Heartbeat on Sunday; while Robert Winston documentary Superhuman slumped to its lowest audience, 3.9m, on its final outing, opposite Cold Feet. But Panorama had its best Sunday outing since moving from Monday night five weeks ago, with a look at the extreme weather that has swept the country in the past month. The BBC1 current affairs show averaged 4.7m and a 28% share from 10.15pm.

webTitle: Climate talks fail to close rift with US

fields.headline: Climate talks fail to close rift with US
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: There is a "huge distance" between the US and the European Union after the first week of talks between 160 countries trying to negotiate a legally binding agreement to cut greenhouse gas emissions, it was warned yesterday.
fields.body:
There is a "huge distance" between the US and the European Union after the first week of talks between 160 countries trying to negotiate a legally binding agreement to cut greenhouse gas emissions, it was warned yesterday.

Jan Pronk, the Dutch environment minister and president of the conference, said: "We have made no progress in the first week. The only good thing to say is we are no further apart."

Mr Pronk had just been briefing John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, who with more than 100 politicians from around the world arrived in the Hague yesterday to take over from his officials for the final week of talks.

Mr Prescott was more optimistic. "There are difficult areas and all sorts of stumbling blocks but I do not think it is impossible. This is still Sunday, not Wednesday or Thursday... We all must find agreement, we will be unforgiven if we have not found agreement by the end of the week."

The talks are expected to deliver greenhouse gas reduction targets for the developed world of 5% by 2010, but each country has a widely different target and different ideas of how to reach it. Mr Prescott said that in Kyoto when the original agreement for reductions was reached the EU had wanted 15% and the US 0%. "No one thought we would make a deal there but we did," he said.

The US has been widely criticised for not taking domestic action to cut fossil fuel emissions. Instead it is claiming credit for removing carbon from the atmosphere by encouraging tree growth, changing farming practices and growing energy crops to burn in power stations. It claims that by managing existing forests properly it saves 300m tonnes of carbon a year - about half the US emissions.

If the conference ends in agreement, any treaty enforcing a new global code of behaviour on emissions will require ratification by most of the industrial countries. Without a US endorsement, it would be difficult for such a treaty to come into force. The US Senate has passed a resolution making its ratification conditional on assurances that US competitiveness on world markets will not be harmed.

Although the focus has been on the row between the so-called umbrella group - the US, Japan, Russia, Canada, Australia , New Zealand - and the EU, little has been heard of the role of developing countries. They do not have emission reduction targets, but under the agreement they should benefit from technology transfer and green funds to reduce their pollution as they develop. Most are critical of progress because funds and technology have not yet flowed.

However, a senior US source described as "chilling" a letter from the Nigerian government to Mr Pronk on behalf of Opec countries demanding compensation for lost oil revenues if cuts in carbon emissions took place. "They have promised to wreck the talks if we do not accede to their demands," the source said.

Kelee Kreider, speaking on behalf of the four largest US environmental groups, said the US was exploiting loopholes. The group estimated that 84% of US emissions could be discounted through not ploughing land and allowing existing trees to grow. "It is unclear to us that there will be any benefit to the climate," she said.

Roger Ballentine, President Bill Clinton's climate adviser, said: "The rift between the US and EU has been somewhat overblown...We want a deal out of these talks."

Another unresolved issue is how to enforce the treaty. The EU and some developing countries favour a fine for carbon emissions above the treaty target. The money would be ploughed back into carbon saving measures. A figure of £30 a tonne has been mentioned, which could potentially cost the US billions of dollars.

Who wants what

US, Russia, Japan, New Zealand, Australia, Canada

• Forests, crops etc at home counted as carbon credits.

• Aiding forestation abroad to be counted as a credit.

• States that have met carbon reduction targets can sell their surplus to those that have not.

European Union

• Domestic action to cut burning of fossil fuels.

• Strict limits on carbon trading.

G77 and China

• Developed countries to make real domestic cut.

• US to pay overdue contributions to allow World Bank to finance green energy projects in G77 countries.

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week fourteen, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Patrick Murray dissects the latest bets
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.08, Sean Ingle = £110.77, Football Unlimited punters collective = £60.12. Paul MacInnes = £56.46
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.08, Sean Ingle = £110.77, Football Unlimited punters collective = £60.12. Paul MacInnes = £56.46

Scott Murray
Blackpool v Telford United: Telford to win. £5 @ 5/1. Bet lost.

As November progresses Scott Murray's aura of invincibility is looking distinctly ragged (visible auras, what will they think of next?). After a plethora of long odds winners he's now backed two losers on the spin. But it's hardly the end of the world, the profit/loss column is still looking distinctly healthy.

There's certainly nothing wrong with backing good non-league teams against poor league sides in the FA Cup at fancy odds, but if you're backing 5/1 shots you have to expect to lose most weeks. The important thing at this stage is not to lose self-belief, to keep doing the things that have got you where you are in the knowledge that you're going to win in the long run. Patience is the name of the game; it is, as ever, a marathon and not a sprint and Mr M looks to have the stamina and self-control to get a place on the metaphorical podium.

Sean Ingle Monaco v Paris St-Germain: Paris St-Germain to win @ 2/1; Hamburg v Bayer Leverkusen: Leverkusen to win @ 2/1. Two £4 singles and one £2 double. Bet won £2.

Sean just can't stop himself. One minute he's moaning about the trebles only rule on matches in the Nationwide League (and rightly so) the next minute he's placing a double on games where singles are allowed. He's addicted to multiples.

There are two main reasons why you can't have singles on Nationwide matches. The first, as any bookmaker is happy to tell you, is that it is against FA rules to lay singles on non-live matches due to worries about match fixing.

The second, as every bookmaker would deny, is that the bookies like it that way because multiples mean more lovely profit margin, hence the total lack of effort on their part to get the rule changed. And hence the winning punter's desire to get round such restrictions by turning to other markets or other matches as the ever-sensible Mr I has done in this case.

But then he goes and spoils it all with yet another get-rich-quick double. I have to concede that Mr Ingle does seem to have a pretty good strike rate on his European football bets but his profits are not what they should be due to his unnatural attachment to the multiple. I've tried, Lord knows I've tried, to wean him off them, but the boy's hooked.

Piers Pennington, who is the head of advertising for the Association of Commonwealth Universities. Charlton v Chelsea. Charlton to win. £5 @ 5-2. Bet won £12.50

It's a bit of a mystery to me why this wasn't the bet of choice for all our punters. This is a once in a season bet, one of those prices that just looks so wrong you have to ask yourself what the catch is. A horribly out of form side with a terrible away record travel to a team playing well and with a fine home record and you can get 5/2 on the home side!

It's not like it's a cup match between teams from different divisions. The only possible explanation for the prices on offer is that one team is called Charlton and the other team is called Chelsea but this is surely taking the axiom 'form is temporary, class is permanent' too far.

Personally I bottled it and just got on the Asian handicap, keeping the draw on my side, but Mr Pennington had the courage of his convictions and the FUPC are all the richer for it. Shame he only had a fiver on it but this, surely, is the beginning of the comeback. Kick on boys, there's still plenty of time to make it a winning season.

Paul MacInnes is on holiday.

Coward.

webTitle: All you ever wanted to know about quangos... but were afraid to ask

fields.headline: All you ever wanted to know about quangos... but were afraid to ask
fields.standfirst: Andrew Cole sheds light on the quasi-autonomous non-governmental organisations
fields.trailText: 2pm: Unelected officials run vast areas of public service, reports Andrew Cole
fields.body:
What are quangos?
Quangos are public bodies that operate at arm's-length from government, but for which ministers are ultimately accountable. For this reason, ministers are usually responsible for appointments. The term, which is American in origin, stands for quasi-autonomous non-governmental organisation. These days, the preferred acronym is NDPB, for non-departmental public body. The full cast list includes major players such as London Transport, the environment agency, the BBC, the pay review bodies and the nationalised industries. But many are more obscure. Have you heard of the zoos forum, the advisory committee on historic wreck sites, or the apple and pear research council?

Who sits on them?
Anyone with the necessary talent and experience is entitled to be nominated. The overriding selection criterion is merit, although the final composition of the body should represent the community it serves. Some express concern that merit can take second place in the rush to meet equal opportunities criteria.

How many quangos are there?
There were 1,057 non-departmental public bodies at the last count - responsible for a total budget of £23bn. In addition, there are around 500 NHS trust and health authority boards. Groups such as magistrates and school governors are not quangos.

Has the UK always been run by quangos?
No. Earlier this century, you could count the number of semi-autonomous public bodies - such as the British Council and the BBC - on the fingers of both hands. But, in the 1970s, they began to mushroom, and, at their peak, there were well over 2,000 of them. The Thatcher government set about dismantling many of them - but also found it necessary to create additional ones.

How can I get on to a quango?
There are a number of different ways of being selected. Some jobs are advertised in the national and specialist press, while others may be advertised through internal websites. Sometimes names are put forward by so-called 'nominating bodies' - groups, such as trade unions or consumer bodies, that are independent of the quango in question. Most government departments maintain lists of potential candidates, while the public appointments unit holds a central register of applicants who have expressed a general interest in being a member of a public body.

What would I be letting myself in for?
Some jobs are full-time, while others only require a few hours commitment a month. Most are unpaid, others offer a daily fee, and some an annual payment or salary. According to the last annual report published by the commissioner of public appointments, 1% of those appointed or reappointed last year took home more than £50,000, and 10% earned between £10,000 and £50,000.

Are most of these appointments politically influenced?
A surprisingly small number of appointees have active political backgrounds - candidates have to declare whether they have been politically active in the past five years, but not whether they belong to a political party. Even in the health service, where controversy has been greatest, fewer than 15% of those appointed last year declared a political affiliation. But the politics of the government clearly influences the politics of quango members. In the final year of the Tory government, for instance, 14% of newly appointed chairs were Tory, compared to 2.3% for Labour. Last year the figures had reversed, with nearly 15% Labour chairs and just 3.4% Tory.

Does anyone keep a check on how appointments are made?
The post of commissioner for public appointments was created in the wake of the Nolan report in 1995. It is held by Dame Rennie Fritchie, who succeeded Sir Len Peach last year. Her role is to regulate, monitor and report on the public appointments process. However, only 12,500 of the total 35,000 public body appointments come within her remit.

What was Nolan?
The Nolan committee, chaired by Lord Nolan, was set up to examine standards of public life in the wake of the cash for questions row and other accusations of sleaze. He recommended that all appointments should be subject to independent scrutiny, that merit should be the overriding principle governing appointments, and that all public bodies should follow a code of conduct.

webTitle: Daily Mail out of race for Express

fields.headline: Daily Mail out of race for Express
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: The Daily Mail has been ruled out of the running for Express newspapers, which is likely to be sold within the week. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The Daily Mail has been ruled out of the bidding race for the Express newspapers, it emerged today.

Industry sources say the battle for ownership has turned into a two-horse race between the Hinduja brothers and OK! magazine publishing tycoon Richard Desmond.

United News & Media, owner of the titles, wants the sale settled within one week and will plump for the party which carries the least regulatory baggage.

Sources say the issue of the Express has become "a complete distraction" for United boss Lord Hollick, who is now determined to get on with transforming the company into a business information player, now retitled United Business Media.

Bids from the Hindujas and surprise entrant Mr Desmond, who owns publisher Northern & Shell, are Lord Hollick's favourites because they can be rushed through.

This is because they will escape the clutches of regulators because neither party owns another newspaper.

The Daily Mail's £120m bid would be immediately referred to regulators under newspaper watchdog rules.

However, they may be in a position to pick up the Daily Star, which could be sold on if the Hindujas win the race.

The brothers have already let it be known that they would be interested in selling the Star to the Mail.

The Daily Mail has been pushed out of the picture by United's shock demand for a non-refundable £60m deposit to see private financial documents related to the Express.

Such demands also appear to have put off a possible bid from Hollinger, owner of the Daily Telegraph.

Mr Desmond has refused to comment on his interest in the Express.

fields.trailText: Here are the questions from Saturday night's who wants to be a Millionaire Quiz. Judith Keppel answered six more questions to win a million pounds in the show to be broadcast tonight.
fields.body:
Here are the questions from Saturday night's who wants to be a Millionaire Quiz. Judith Keppel answered six more questions to win a million pounds in the show to be broadcast tonight.

fields.headline: Too many men on quangos
fields.standfirst: Despite attempts to open up quangos, most people still believe that jobs depend on belonging to the 'right golf club', reports Andrew Cole
fields.trailText: 2pm: As Public Service Week, an initiative of the commissioner for public appointments Dame Rennie Fritchie, gets under way Andrew Cole reports that most people still believe that getting a job on a quango depends on belonging to the 'right golf club'
fields.body:
It is five years since Lord Nolan produced his ground-breaking report aimed at eliminating sleaze within politics and opening up the shadowy world of quangos to public scrutiny.

There have been major changes as a result. A commissioner of public appointments now oversees and monitors the staffing of quangos; a code of conduct exists, to which many of these non-elected bodies have to subscribe; and the selection process is fairer and more open.

Sadly, however, these developments seem to have made little impact on public perceptions. A Mori poll, commissioned by the office of the commissioner for public appointments (OCPA) earlier this year, found that most people still thought appointments were politically influenced and bureaucratic.

Perhaps just as damning was the widespread belief that selection was based largely on personal connections. Being a "member of the right golf club" - rather than being able to demonstrate a proven track record - was the seen to be the most important factor.

Partly for this reason, the OCPA launches Public Service Week today. It will attempt - through seminars, workshops and role-playing exercises - to raise awareness of what quangos do and how ordinary people can get more involved.

But it is clear that it will have its work cut out. At the moment, despite the OCPA's best endeavours, the average quango member still fits the white, male, middle-aged stereotype.

According to latest figures, only a third of all public appointees are women and 4.7% come from ethnic minorities. Just 2.9% of new appointees last year were disabled, while three quarters were aged between 46 and 65 - with less than 3% under the age of 35.

Even some of these statistics don't tell the whole story. Most of the 33% of female appointees, for instance, tend to find themselves in lower status, unpaid roles. Only 3% of quango members who earn £50,000 or more are women.

It is also clear that politics still plays a significant part in the selection process. Nowhere has this been more apparent than in the NHS, where former health secretary Frank Dobson pledged to sweep out the "deadwood" among trust non-executive directors.

This led to a flood of Labour appointments. Between January 1998 and March 1999, the number of councillors on trust boards more than doubled - with 80% of these appointments being awarded to Labour.

In a hard-hitting report published earlier this year, Dame Rennie Fritchie, the commissioner for public appointments, suggested that political allegiance had been the "decisive factor" in the selection of a number of candidates and the whole process had become "politicised in a systemic way".

None of this has helped to improve the image of public bodies. But just as off-putting can be the selection process itself. Most applicants find they are faced with complex forms, arcane selection procedures, and long delays between initial application and final appointment.

Many jobs are still not advertised in the normal manner, and even where they are, the ad may be for a generic role - for example, NHS trust non-executive director - rather than a specific post.

Dame Rennie wants to see the selection process streamlined, and she supports the idea of advertising for specific posts wherever possible. She insists that much progress has been made over the past five years in making public bodies more representative, but she accepts there is still a long way to go - especially in the areas of disability and age diversity.

At the same time, the overriding criterion for selection has to be fitness for the job. "It's not enough to have the right recipe in terms of people who reflect their society," she points out. "They must also be people who can do the job."

The answer, she believes, is to bring more people into the pool of potential applicants, but then to appoint on merit.

webTitle: Austin Powers goes back to the 1950s for prequel

fields.headline: Austin Powers goes back to the 1950s for prequel
fields.standfirst: Plus: Nicolas Cage and Patricia Arquette to divorce; Jared Leto's drugs hell almost too much for fiancee Cameron Diaz; Goblin role goes elsewhere; Bruce Willis snubs Soderbergh's all-star remake; and British film given Greek gong
fields.trailText: Plus: Nicolas Cage and Patricia Arquette to divorce; Jared Leto's drugs hell almost too much for fiancee Cameron Diaz; Goblin role goes elsewhere; Bruce Willis snubs Soderbergh's all-star remake; and British film given Greek gong
fields.body:
 Prequels are indisputably the new sequels, and work is now under way on the 'backstory' for a third Austin Powers movie which is due to hit our cinemas in 2002. Director Jay Roach, who boasts considerable industry clout after the massive success of the Robert De Niro laughfest, Meet the Parents, revealed: "We have a concept based on a prequel, where Dr Evil and Austin are together in the 1950s as young men in some academy. Of course something goes wrong. Dr Evil goes off to some zone and Austin launches the British revolution in American music and colour, just to annoy Dr Evil."

 After a number of highly publicised ups and downs in their stormy relationship, Patricia Arquette and Nicolas Cage are finally splitting up. When Cage submitted divorce papers earlier this year, Cage admitted that the couple had only lived together for the first nine months of their five-year marriage. Although he u-turned on the break-up a few weeks later, any attempt at a long-term reconciliation now seems out of the question after Arquette filed her own divorce petition on Friday.

 Filming the uncompromising Requiem For a Dream for Darren Aronofsky almost caused star Jared Leto to split up with fiancée Cameron Diaz, claims the National Enquirer. In an almost monastic display of dedication, Leto pledged to give up sex while preparing for his role as a heroine junkie, much to the chagrin of the Charlie's Angels star. He also shaved his head and shed 25lb and was apparently so pooped after working on the production that he had to check into a Portuguese monastery to recover. Diaz responded by calling off their proposed wedding and suggesting that they take things a bit more slowly. Sensible.

 After last week's news that leading man Tobey Maguire harbours a fear of creepy-crawlies among other phobias, there was better news from the Spider-Man production today. Contrary to previous suggestions that John Malkovich had finally committed to play Spider-Man's nemesis, the Green Goblin, internet movie site Ain't It Cool News reckons that Willem Dafoe has definitely been confirmed for the role.

webTitle: 'Honour killing' casts medieval shadow over India

fields.headline: 'Honour killing' casts medieval shadow over India
fields.standfirst: Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: A scuffle breaks out among photographers outside the central bureau of investigation headquarters in Delhi. A rotund woman in her 50s in a flowing white robe, a dagger slung across her shoulders and her head covered as religiously ordained, steps out of a white car with tinted windows.
fields.body:
A scuffle breaks out among photographers outside the central bureau of investigation headquarters in Delhi. A rotund woman in her 50s in a flowing white robe, a dagger slung across her shoulders and her head covered as religiously ordained, steps out of a white car with tinted windows.

Flowerpots are smashed as television crews and snappers jostle for a glimpse of Bibi Jagir Kaur. But she remains unruffled, a confident half-smile flitting across her lips.

Ms Kaur is under pressure to quit as head of the shiromani gurdwara prabandhak committee (SGPC), which controls key Sikh shrines across India. She is the first woman to hold the post.

Earlier this month Ms Kaur was charged with the murder of Harpreet, her pregnant 19-year-old daughter. The SGPC chief has been freed on police bail.

Last year in Begowal, a village in Punjab, India's richest state, Harpreet married 21-year-old Kamaljeet Singh in secret. Ms Kaur did not approve - Mr Singh was poor and had cut his hair, against Sikh practise.

In April this year Harpreet died in mysterious circumstances while staying in a relative's house at her mother's behest. She had been led to believe that her family was prepared to accept Mr Singh and would formally organise a wedding ceremony.

Harpreet was cremated and her ashes disposed of the same day, breaking Sikh tradition. Her family claimed there had been no marriage between Mr Singh and Harpreet and that the latter had died of food poisoning.

Less than 24 hours after the cremation, Mr Singh contacted the police and produced photographs of the wedding ceremony, which had been attended by his parents at Begowal. He claimed Ms Kaur was using her political influence to suppress and destroy evidence. He also sought protection for himself and his family.

The Indian media describe the case as an "honour killing". But Ms Kaur's supporters claim that she is a victim of internal feuds within the Sikh political establishment.

Across the border, in Pakistan, "honour killings" are rampant. Scores of women are killed every year for allegedly bringing shame on their husband or family. Women's deaths are explained away on "the flimsiest of grounds", according to Amnesty International.

But Punjab on both sides of the border shares the same feudal ethos. "Prosperity has not has the slightest effect on patriarchy in Punjab," says Veena Kumari, a women's rights activist and lawyer .

A petition before the Punjab state human rights commission by lawyer Ranjan Lakhanpal, based in the Punjabi capital, Chandigarh, triggered the murder inquiry. He said: "This is the most famous, but certainly not the first, honour killing in Punjab.

"In rural Punjab, a girl wanting to marry a boy of her choice against parental wishes runs the risk of being killed especially if the boy is from another caste, religion, income bracket or community. In the last five years I have dealt with four such cases. None have led to convictions because such cases are almost impossible to prove. All traces of the dead body are spirited away."

For a country trying to position itself as a software superpower and a key player in the big league this century, the Harpreet murder case is a painful reminder that digital India must cope with medieval India.

webTitle: NHS finance director quits for private sector

fields.headline: NHS finance director quits for private sector
fields.trailText: One of the most senior managers in the NHS, finance director Colin Reeves, has quit to take up a job in the private sector.
fields.body:
One of the most senior managers in the NHS, finance director Colin Reeves, has quit to take up a job in the private sector.

In a separate move, Bill McCarthy, his deputy director of finance and one of the architects of the NHS plan, is also to leave, for an unspecified operational job in the health service.

The moves are the latest in a shake-up of the top tier of the NHS executive following the publication of the NHS plan, and the arrival in October of a new NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp.

Reeves, who has held the top NHS finance job for the past six and a half years, is to head up the review board of the Accountancy Foundation, a body set up to regulate and advise the accountancy profession.

The departures are thought to reflect a feeling among top managers at the Department of Health that with national policy decided, the next big challenge will be found in implementing the NHS reforms.

One manager paid tribute to Reeves as "a manager with great good humour, which often disguised how much impact his thinking had" on the development of NHS finance.

McCarthy was instrumental in drawing up the NHS plan. He was one of five people on a steering committee set up in April to design the plan, alongside health secretary Alan Milburn, former NHS chief executive Alan Langlands and the head of the Department of Health policy unit Simon Stevens.

Names mooted as possible replacements for the top NHS finance posts include John Bacon, acting NHS London regional director, where, as director of finance his former boss was Mr Crisp.

John Flook, director of finance at Country Durham health authority, and a member of the capital and capacity modernisation task force, is seen as a contender, as is Christine Daws, a deputy director of finance at the NHS executive.

Other names in the frame are Helen Chalmers, director of finance at University College London Hospitals NHS trust, and Jim Birrell, director of finance at the NHS north west region.

fields.headline: StepStone takes over German subsidiary
fields.trailText: 12.34pm: UK online jobs site StepStone is to take complete control of German subsidiary Job-Today, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Online jobs firm StepStone is set to take complete control of its German subsidiary. The company owns 92% of Job-Today, and has made a cash offer for the remaining shares.

StepStone's move to takeover the company in September was the first sign of consolidation in an over-crowded sector. The company has a strong pan-European presence, with sites in 18 countries, including the UK.

"We have bought Job-Today to fulfill a weakness in the German market. We were the third largest jobs site in a very large labour market, and this acquisition has taken us straight to number one," said a StepStone spokesperson.

The site was launched in 1996, and now has 420,000 subscribers, who can apply for the 115,000 vacancies that StepStone offers.

webTitle: Jefferies confirmed as new Bradford manager

fields.headline: Jefferies confirmed as new Bradford manager
fields.trailText: Jim Jefferies has spent his first morning as manager of Bradford City promising to do his utmost to pull the Bantams away from the Premiership relegation zone.
fields.body:
Jim Jefferies has spent his first morning as manager of Bradford City promising to do his utmost to pull the Bantams away from the Premiership relegation zone.

At a press conference today, the former Hearts manager admitted the Yorkshire club were among the favourites for relegation, but said he was hoping to emulate fellow Scots, such as Sir Alex Ferguson and George Graham, in achieving success south of the border.

"If I can do as well as the other two who have come down, we'll be very happy," he said. "Bradford have achieved a lot in the past few years. We know they're everybody's favourites to go down but hopefully we'll prove them wrong."

Jefferies, who has signed a two-and-a-half year contract, also revealed he wants to rein in the talents of wayward striker Stan Collymore. "When he was at Aston Villa we tried to get him on board ... but we lost out there. I don't think anyone can argue he can play. We have to try and get it out of him for the team."

Despite Bradford's precarious position at the foot of the Premiership, Jefferies insisted he was looking forward to a new challenge.

"It was time to move on from Hearts. A lot had been achieved there in the last five years but it was time for a new challenge," he said. "Having said that, there was nothing to go for and it looked like maybe I was going to have a break for a few weeks. But then I got a call from the chairman and he said come down for an interview. I jumped at the chance.

"Everything went well and I just hoped I would get a second call - which I did. I am delighted."

Jefferies, 50, revealed he had "not had a chance" to sit down with Chairman Geoffrey Richmond and discuss if he would be given any transfer funds. The Bradford chairman said he would listen to Jefferies' "observations and recommendations" before taking any action.

fields.headline: Drinks industry launches 'moderation' campaign
fields.trailText: 1pm: The drinks industry is launching a poster and radio campaign warning 18 to 24-year olds of the dangers of drunkenness, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The drinks industry is launching its first advertising campaign to persuade pub-goers that moderation is best.

With the slogan "If you do drink, don't do drunk", the poster and radio campaign aims to curb excessive drinking.

Launched today, the campaign is being run by the Portman Group, the drinks pressure group funded by the big drinks companies, including Bass and Guinness.

It highlights the dangers of excessive drinking with scenarios that include someone being injured in a pub brawl and someone heading home alone in a drunken state.

It will target 18 to 24-year-old drinkers, who are Britain's biggest boozers, and aims to warn them of the consequences of binge drinking.

The Portman Group will trial the campaign in Manchester with posters going up in dozens of pubs, clubs and student bars in the city. The ads will roll out nationwide after Christmas if they prove a success.

"Many young adults regularly drink to get drunk.They could be storing up long-term health problems, but drunkenness also exposes them to immediate personal risks to their dignity, safety and life.

"This pilot campaign will tell us how to communicate a message which is not necessarily seen as welcome by its target audience," said Portman Group director Jean Coussins.

The campaign coincides with the publication of a new MORI survey on public attitudes to the alcoholic drinks trade and industry. The survey, commissioned by the Portman Group, showed that three out of five people in the campaign's target age range of 18-24 believe the industry is socially responsible.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: CITY V UNITED: WAS IT REALLY A ONE GOAL SLAUGHTER?
fields.body:
CITY V UNITED: WAS IT REALLY A ONE GOAL SLAUGHTER?

Is there a City fan out there who: a) read Paul Wilson's match report on the Manchester derby yesterday and then b) spent their Sunday in the park, watching TV or lying on the sofa and relaxing? If our letterbox is anything to go by, the answer is an emphatic no.

Yes, the blue half of Manchester has spoken - and they are not happy with Mr Wilson. "I read Paul Wilson's article and found myself wondering whether he had actually been to the game!" says John Connolly. "Not only did I find it quite biased (which in this day and age of pandering to the Manchester United PLC is not unusual), it was also a times bordering on the lines of factual inaccuracy."

"Yes, United squandered chances, but did Mr Wilson not see the shot from Wright -Phillips that went inches wide, Haaland go round the goalkeeper only to see his shot go wide, or Goater just miss out on a one-on-one with the goalkeeper, or even the goal line clearance from Haaland in the second half?"

Jon Fyne, who writes all the way from Shizuoka, Japan, agrees. "Whatever happened to impartial, objective reporting?" he asks. "Mr Wilson's loyalties are evident everywhere, but particularly in his misplaced and misguided attack on City supporters. Not even the fans of the media' s darling, Manchester United, would have been getting an average of nearly 29,000 in Division 2."

Another grievance for City fans is the Observer's headline: "One goal slaughter." Gary Spencer, for one, is not impressed. "I've never witnessed a game where a winning manager says that his team had to grind out a result but a reporter suggests it was a slaughter!" he says. "The headline might has well have read 'Elvis Found On The Moon' for all the relevance it had to the game.

"I trust Mr Wilson enjoyed his prawn sandwiches and crisps," he adds.

Tim Schofield, meanwhile, picks up on the following quote from the Observer: "Sadly the Blues were too long out of practice to make it much of a match," before listing the stats from the game - including the fact that Manchester City had 17 goal attempts to Manchester United's ten.

Len Hampson wonders whether Alex Ferguson was really in South Africa. "Wasn't he at Maine Road covering the match for the Observer using the pseudonym Paul Wilson?" he asks, before continuing: "Best football coverage in Britain? Don't think so."

Finally, the last word on the Manchester derby goes to J.Griffin, a season ticket holder at Old Trafford.

"As someone who has followed United for long enough to remember City being the top side, I was amused to read in your column that the Blues put a banner out welcoming fans to Manchester," he says. "Although I was at the game I didn't actually see the banner concerned but believe it must have been aimed at City supporters.

"On the way up the M5 and M6 the amount of "Bluenoses" coming past us with their scarves hanging out of the windows and their little sky blue mascots in the back window had to be seen to be believed. What wonderful local support!" "Pot," "kettle" and "black" anyone?

ANGRY TOTTENHAM FANS WRITE

Only one set of supporters can match the anger - and volume of correspondence - of Man City fans this morning and they're dressed in Lilywhite. The target of Spurs fans' fury is Gerry Cox, whose preview article on the Tottenham v Liverpool game appears to have grossly misrepresented the Save our Spurs campaign.

"I am absolutely baffled as to how such drivel could get into a national newspaper," says Richard Garman. "Perhaps he could have a look at the website: www.saveourspurs.com, and see what the group is all about.

"This sort of incompetent and lazy journalism defies belief. SOS has NOTHING to do with George Graham. It is 100% aimed at Alan Sugar," he adds.

And there are hundreds out there who agree. "I am very disappointed that you seem to have misinterpreted our campaign," says Peter Hall. "All we demand is that Alan Sugar relinquishes control of Spurs so that some other "brain surgeon" can take over and have a chance to restore the glory days back to the Lane.

"George Graham is not on the SOS agenda in no way shape or form. Neither do we boo the players. Our members (and I must stress that is all we speak for) believe that Alan Sugar is most go after 10 years of mediocrity and underinvestment.

"The facts speak for themselves. In the ten years before Sugar's chairmanship we would have qualified for Europe nine times (if English clubs weren't banned). But during Sugar's chairmanship we have not even finished in the top six and only won one devalued competition.

"I'm sure you'll agree that this is unacceptable for a club of the size, stature and fanbase (we sold the second most replica shirts in the Premier League despite our on pitch failings) of Tottenham Hotspur. It's time for a change at the top and SOS aims to bring it."

Meanwhile Nick Ross sounds like a broken man after reading Cox's piece. "I cannot describe just how disappointed I am with this article. I have simply never ever read an article that is so untrue, opinionated, vitriolic and unfair, as this was, in the Observer ever," he says. "I'd expect such an article in "The People". Not in, what I have come to regard as the only newspaper I trust to print the absolute truth. I will never trust your papers fully ever again."

And if Mr Cox wants to wave his chin in the air and take even more criticism, then Football Unlimited readers are happy to oblige.

"Take a minute to contact the organisers of SOS. Ask questions. Get answers. Try writing an unbiased story for a change," is the advice Cameron Tilbury offers from Ontario in Canada. Matthew Simpson adds that "Someone should direct poor Gerry to Brian Glanville's article in the Sunday Times for guidance on how to write a balanced researched article."

The target of Spurs fans' fury is Gerry Cox, whose preview article on the Tottenham v Liverpool game appears to have grossly misrepresented the Save our Spurs campaign. "I am absolutely baffled as to how such drivel could get into a national newspaper," says Richard Garman. "Perhaps he could have a look at the website: www.saveourspurs.com, and see what the group is all about. "This sort of incompetent and lazy journalism defies belief. SOS has NOTHING to do with George Graham. It is 100% aimed at Alan Sugar," he adds. And there are hundreds out there who agree. "I am very disappointed that you seem to have misinterpreted our campaign," says Peter Hall. "All we demand is that Alan Sugar relinquishes control of Spurs so that some other "brain surgeon" can take over and have a chance to restore the glory days back to the Lane. "George Graham is not on the SOS agenda in no way shape or form. Neither do we boo the players. Our members (and I must stress that is all we speak for) believe that Alan Sugar is most go after 10 years of mediocrity and underinvestment. "The facts speak for themselves. In the ten years before Sugar's chairmanship we would have qualified for Europe nine times (if English clubs weren't banned). But during Sugar's chairmanship we have not even finished in the top six and only won one devalued competition. "I'm sure you'll agree that this is unacceptable for a club of the size, stature and fanbase (we sold the second most replica shirts in the Premier League despite our on pitch failings) of Tottenham Hotspur. It's time for a change at the top and SOS aims to bring it." Meanwhile Nick Ross sounds like a broken man after reading Cox's piece. "I cannot describe just how disappointed I am with this article. I have simply never ever read an article that is so untrue, opinionated, vitriolic and unfair, as this was, in the Observer ever," he says. "I'd expect such an article in "The People". Not in, what I have come to regard as the only newspaper I trust to print the absolute truth. I will never trust your papers fully ever again." And if Mr Cox wants to wave his chin in the air and take even more criticism, then Football Unlimited readers are happy to oblige. "Take a minute to contact the organisers of SOS. Ask questions. Get answers. Try writing an unbiased story for a change," is the advice Cameron Tilbury offers from Ontario in Canada. fields.headline: The Edge
fields.standfirst: All the numbers you really need from the weekend's Premiership action. Brought to you by IQ Sports
fields.trailText: Monday night's match: Coventry 0 - 1 Ipswich
fields.body:
Monday night's match: Coventry 0 - 1 Ipswich

Key Man: Matt Holland completed 32 of 38 passes, including 8 out of 9 in the attacking third.

Weak Link: Passing on both sides was plain awful - one in three went to the wrong address. There were also 12 off-sides in the game, 50% more than the Premiership average.

The Edge: Coventry made only 65 challenges. Ipswich have now scored 6 goals in the final 10 minutes of matches. Coventry have conceded 9 from crosses.

Sunday's game: Spurs 2 - 1 Liverpool

Key Man: Stephen Clemence completed 13 of 16 passes in the attacking third, including 3 of 6 crosses. He also set up both goals.

Weak Link: Despite Heskey's absence, Liverpool attempted 28 long passes - but only 5 found a red jersey.

The Edge: Tottenham's finishing (66% accuracy) and crossing (6 of 14 attempts found teammates) were superior. Every one of Tottenham's starting XI, excluding Sergei Rebrov, made 10 successful challenges.

Charlton 2 - 0 Chelsea

Key Man: Jonathan Johannson brought his season's tally to 6 Premiership goals and 3 assists.

Weak Link: Chelsea have now conceded 6 goals in the final 10 minutes of a match.

The Edge: Chelsea had 60% of possession. They also had 21 crosses, but did not create a single chance with a through ball. 47 of 175 challenges in the match were fouls. Charlton have conceded only three goals at home.

Derby 2 - 0 Bradford

Key Man: Georgi Kinkladze was involved in both goals and completed 44 of his 51 passes, including 19 out of 20 in the final third.

Weak Link: Bradford were way too predictable, attempting 32 crosses but failing to hit a single accurate through ball.

The Edge: Derby's new look defence recorded their third consecutive clean sheet. Chris Riggot won all 20 of his challenges.

Everton 2 - 0 Arsenal

Key Man: Kevin Campbell scored, and completed 15 of 18 passes in the Arsenal half to ease the pressure on the home side.

Weak Link: Kanu, Bergkamp and Wiltord managed only 4 scoring attempts between them.

The Edge: Arsenal had 63% of possession, but Everton were not tempted to chase - making only 79 challenges. Arsenal crosses found red shirts only 5 times out of 20.

Leeds 0 - 1 West Ham

Key Man: Stuart Pearce won 20 of 23 challenges and made 18 successful clearances.

Weak Link: There were 38 fouls in 90 minutes. Elland Road continues to produce the most fouls in the Premiership - more than 33 per game.

The Edge: Leeds had 60% of possession, but West Ham closed down Mark Viduka and Alan Smith who had only two attempts (both from Smith and both off target). The usually reliable Viduka was tackled out of possession 8 times. The West Ham back four - Ian and Stuart Pearce, Nigel Winterburn and Rio Ferdinand won 62 challenges between them.

Man City 0 - 1 Man United

Key Man: Fabian Barthez. He gave away two unnecessary corners, but his safe hands (4 saves, 11 claims) protected a slim lead.

Weak Link: Scholes, Butt and Keane completed only 15 passes in the City half and did not attempt a single cross - placing all offensive burden on Beckham (16 passes completed in forward 1/3 and 13 crosses)

The Edge: Steve Howey and Spencer Prior tamed United's attack with 27 clearances, 7 interceptions and 49 successful challenges in 52 attempts. City equalled the season's most attempts against United (a record they share with West Ham).

Middlesbrough 0 - 3 Leicester

Key Man: Neil Lennon completed 58 of 70 passes, including 14 of 14 in the final third, and made 20 successful challenges.

Weak Link: Robson's famous summer signings were disappointing. Christian Karembeu attempted only 3 tackles during the whole match. Alen Boksic meanwhile was dispossessed 14 times by Leicester defenders.

The Edge: Boro had 56% of possession, but Leicester won the tackling count almost 2-1 (144 compared to Boro's 75). Tim Flowers made 6 saves, and Leicester added to their amazing away record- having still only conceded one goal outside of Filbert Street.

Newcastle 1 - 2 Sunderland

Key Man: Niall Quinn was pivotal in Sunderland's attack, with 4 attempts on target, and 18 of 23 passes proving accurate in the final third.

Weak Link: Alan Shearer and Kevin Phillips managed only a single shot from open play (and that was off target).

The Edge: Newcaslte had a 79:25 edge in successful tackles in the first half, but the teams were equal (55:55) in the second. Sunderland had 21 accurate crosses to Newcastle's 7. Michael Gray found a teammate on 6 of 11 crossing attempts and Kevin Kilbane won all 9 of his challenges.

Southampton 2 - 0 Aston Villa

Key Man: A battling Dean Richards won 24 of 29 challenges, and had 15 successful clearances.

Weak Link: Villa's attack. Joachim and Ginola did not have a single scoring attempt between them. Paul Merson completed only 2 passes in the final third. Dion Dublin had the ball taken off him in 7 of 8 attempted tackles.

The Edge: Southampton had 6 of the game's first 7 attempts and settled the matter early. The teams were equal on possession, but Southampton made 155 challenges, Villa only 114. James Beattie was inaccurate on all 3 of his crosses, 13 of 23 passes and lost all the 4 tackles he attempted - but 2 of his 4 goal attempts found the back of the net.

webTitle: Did Olympic sponsors waste their money?

fields.headline: Did Olympic sponsors waste their money?
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Companies that paid out millions of pounds to become Olympic sponsors may have wasted their money, according to new research. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Companies that paid out millions of pounds to become official sponsors of the Sydney Olympics may have wasted their money, according to research from advertising strategists CIA Medialab.

A survey carried out by the company showed almost 50% of adults didn't know who any of the Olympic sponsors were, despite prompting by interviewers.

The findings are even more shocking given that over 80% of those questioned said they had watched at least some of the games.

Worse still for the sponsors, levels of brand recognition were the same for many of the sponsors' biggest competitors as they were for the sponsors themselves.

This is because of so-called hijack sponsorship, where companies that aren't official sponsors ally themselves to the games.

Nike, which paid an estimated £15m for its official sponsor status, actually scored slightly lower than arch-rival Adidas, which paid far less to be the official outfitter for the US Olympic team.

CIA says this is because Nike and Adidas spent roughly the same amount on advertising on television during the Olympics.

Oliver Rowe, operations manager at CIA Medialab, said: "I wouldn't agree that sponsorship fails to deliver, but the way people explain their involvement is crucial. As a rule of thumb you should be spending X amount on sponsorship and twice as much on telling people about it."

fields.headline: Oil and water don't mix
fields.standfirst: Jet skis were involved in eight out of nine accidents on Sydney's waterways last summer, writes  Patrick Barkham, and now they are being blamed for polluting the country's premier tourist hotspot.
fields.trailText: View from Australia: Jet skis were involved in eight out of nine accidents on Sydney's waterways last summer, writes Patrick Barkham, and now they are being blamed for polluting the country's premier tourist hotspot.
fields.body:
The dazzling light bounces off the green-and-gold ferries, the sailing boats, speedboats, 18th century replica clippers and the giant modern day navy and container ships that bob and weave through Sydney harbour.

It is just another weekend on Australia's busiest waterway. But new regulations and research casts doubt on the right of one group cutting through the aquatic traffic, Sydney's 5,000 jet ski users, to enjoy the harbour waters.

US environmental group Bluewater Network claims that running a two-stroke motor on a jet ski - also called personal watercraft - for one hour causes as much hydrocarbon pollution as a 5,000-mile car journey.

A yellow-grey smog hangs over the harbour on some busy summer weekends. The New South Wales Environment Protection Authority says that outboard motors, including jet skis and powerboats, cause 10% of volatile organic compounds and 6.8% of carbon monoxide in Sydney's air.

"There is a problem with personal watercraft emissions because of their two-stroke engines," said the EPA's Bernard Carlon. "But their total contribution to air pollution is very small."

The Green party has called for a complete ban on jet skis in Sydney harbour and is supporting a campaign by the Jetfree Coalition to create a 300m jetski-free zone around the entire coast of Australia.

"Jet skis are punching above their weight in the pollution stakes, in terms of accidents and in terms of complaints," said local Green party MP Lee Rhiannon. "I've lived around Sydney harbour all my life. Every time you're out there you see more and more of these things. Trying to ban them outright is not the solution. They need to be regulated and users given some space in which to do it."

Personal watercraft make up 6% of recreational vessels in New South Wales but attract 37% of complaints about public boating. Jet ski drivers caused eight out of nine accidents on Sydney's waterways last summer.

Jetski users point out that dirty two-stroke technology used by lawn-mowers causes more pollution than jetskis. The Australian Personal Watercraft Association's Steve Kaniowski said the Bluewater Network's figures were "impossible" given that cars consumed more fuel than jetskis.

Mr Kaniowski said the personal watercraft industry was at the forefront of reducing marine motor emissions. Two-stroke engines release up to 25% of their oil and fuel unburned. But new fuel injection systems have increased fuel economy by up to 30% and reduced exhaust emissions by up to 75%. Honda is set to manufacture a four-stroke jet ski, which will emit far less pollution than a car.

New regulations address public concern about noise and dangerous driving by jet skis' predominantly young, male users. "We have progressively introduced what are now the toughest controls on jet skis for any type of vessel in Australia," said Neil Patchett of the Waterways Authority of New South Wales.

Local councils have been given the power to bar personal watercraft from sensitive areas, while irregular driving, including "tearing around in circles, doing slalom turns, and all the things that your average citizen would say is annoying behaviour" is banned, said Mr Patchett.

"Complaints have reduced dramatically ever since the registration fee has been increased, which pays for extra education for users," said Mr Kaniowski. "We agree we should continue down that path." But he opposes the new capacity of councils to ban jet skis.

"We are being victimised," said Mr Kaniowski. "Not everyone is a hooligan on the water. I'm a successful manager in a big corporation. I've got every right and responsibility on the water and I'm also a treehugger."

"Sydney harbour is one of the most beautiful harbours in the world. There is plenty of water for everybody. It is everybody's water and it is everybody's to share."

fields.headline: Dot.com content provider Ready2 cuts staff
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Content provider Ready2 is hibernating in an attempt to get through the winter of dot.com discontent, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Ready2, the trend-setting content company set up by society girls Trinny Woodall and Susannah Constantine, has gone into hibernation in a bid to survive the winter dot.com snowstorm.

Fourteen staff were made redundant on Friday, leaving a skeleton staff of five to run the offline media parts of the business. Two of the remaining staff will maintain a far smaller website.

In a statement, Ms Woodall and Ms Constantine said: "We are obviously disappointed that we've been forced to take such a tough decision, but by restructuring and minimising our overheads we can make the cash we have last another year.

"We don't blame anyone for what's happened, it's an issue of timing. When faster access technologies such as broadband and DSL are commonplace, the need for great content will be glaringly apparent."

Ready2 still writes a weekly column in the Telegraph; has a weekly slot on GMTV and is currently negotiating a TV show on a terrestrial TV channel.

Ready2 said the redundancies were unavoidable but would now help the business stay afloat until the end of next year.

The latest lay-offs come less than four months after Ready2 first started shedding staff, and less than a year after the site was launched to market.

One of the more high-profile departures was Krista Johnson, sales and marketing director who was poached from a top position at Flextech Interactive, but only stayed six months. She left in August this year.

The plans to launch array of sites, including interior decorating and well-being channels, was kicked into touch in July when it was clear that the site would have difficulty raising further venture capital.

The problem with Ready2's over-ambition was that its only revenue stream was advertising as it never sold through the web. One plan was to move into consultancy for high-street retailers in a bid for extra revenue. However, nothing materialised.

Ready2 was launched last November with a £5m investment from venture capitalists Atlas Ventures and JH Whitney.

fields.headline: Magazines 'more offensive than newspapers'
fields.trailText: 12pm:The Press Complaints Commission has upheld more complaints against magazines than newspapers in the past year, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Magazines are a growing cause of offence with watchdogs upholding more complaints against them than newspapers.

With a glut of celebrity magazines providing a lucrative new home for paparazzi photographs, the Press Complaints Commission now faces a new regulatory battle.

Sources at the PCC, which ruled against OK! magazine for publishing unauthorised photographs of Prince William while on his gap year, said today it had upheld more decisions against magazines than against any other section of the press in the past year.

The PCC ruled that the magazine was guilty of "harassment" and "breach of privacy", after photographs appeared of the prince in the South American jungle.

According to sources, the photographs had been offered to all the tabloid newspapers but had been turned down.

The PCC refused to comment on the ruling until its official publication, which will not be made until three months after the date of the complaint.

But an insider said that the growth of the magazines sector and the importance of showbusiness in news meant that magazines now had as high profile a role in press ethics as newspapers.

The PCC has made a number of rulings against magazines concerning privacy and ethics, notably against Hello! for publishing pictures of Sir Paul McCartney praying in a cathedral, FHM for an article about student suicide, and Front for paying former gangster Reggie Kray.

The commission decided to investigate the Prince William incident following a complaint by Stephen Lamporte, principal private secretary to the Prince of Wales. The ruling, which is the first concerning the prince, is likely to be seen as a warning to the press before he starts university next year.

The ruling is understood to state that the prince was in a place where he would normally have been able to expect a reasonable degree of privacy.

An insider said: "The view that the commission took was that he was so far into the jungle that it's a bit different from just walking down the King's Road."

Meanwhile, the commission is waiting to hear from the Mail on Sunday as to whether it can resolve a complaint made by Buckingham Palace on behalf of Prince Andrew, after the paper published a story linking the prince with an alleged drug dealer.

An insider said: "The view that the commission took was that he was so far into the jungle that it's a bit different from just walking down the King's Road." Meanwhile, the commission is waiting to hear from the Mail on Sunday as to whether it can resolve a complaint made by Buckingham Palace on behalf of Prince Andrew, after the paper published a story linking the prince with an alleged drug dealer.

webTitle: Coronation Street to premiere on ITV2

fields.headline: Coronation Street episode to premiere on ITV2
fields.trailText: 11.45am:Coronation Street is to be premiered on ITV2 this Wednesday as part of ITV's strategy to beef up the channel, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
An edition of Coronation Street will be premiered on a channel other than ITV this week for the first time in its 40-year history.

Wednesday night's instalment of the flagship ITV soap will go out first on ITV2 at 7.30pm, when the main channel is showing live Champions League football coverage of Leeds v Real Madrid.

ITV bosses insist it is not the slippery slope for the soap, which has been the linchpin of the schedules for decades. It says it will only happen on two occasions and the soap will be broadcast on ITV at 9.45pm after the football.

A spokeswoman said: "Coronation Street is moved anyway because of the football and normally there is also football on ITV2. On these two nights we thought we would put it on at the normal time on ITV2 to give those viewers who have ONdigital and cable a chance to see it. Otherwise it will be on ITV as normal - after the football."

The move is a sign of the ITV companies' determination to beef up ITV2. As part of their strategy for closer cooperation, Carlton Communications and Granada Media are expected to focus on improving the programming, marketing and distribution of ITV2.

The channel is currently only available in around 2.7m ONdigital and cable homes in England and Wales, because of ITV's refusal to do a distribution deal with Sky Digital.

ITV2 has a 7.30pm window for Coronation Street because there is only one English team playing live in peak-time on Wednesday. Usually, the channel would carry live coverage of the second game involving an English side.

The next time this will happen is expected to be Wednesday December 6.
