webTitle: Bush and Gore face Florida judgment day

fields.headline: Bush and Gore face Florida judgment day
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Nearly two weeks of legal and political warfare are set to reach a climax today when the Florida supreme court hears legal arguments from George W Bush and Al Gore which could settle the outcome of the disputed US presidential election.
fields.body:
Nearly two weeks of legal and political warfare are set to reach a climax today when the Florida supreme court hears legal arguments from George W Bush and Al Gore which could settle the outcome of the disputed US presidential election.

Mr Bush filed a 56-page submission in Tallahassee yesterday that the court should halt the continuing recounts and allow Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, to certify the results for the state in their present form. That would make Mr Bush, the Republican candidate, the next president.

"In these heated circumstances, when so much is at stake for the state and nation, it is essential for this court and all public officials to be faithful to the rule of law," Mr Bush's lawyers argued in their submission, which asks the court to uphold Friday's ruling by Judge Terry Lewis that Ms Harris could declare a result.

Mr Gore wants the court to order Ms Harris to keep the election open, allowing three south Florida counties to finish hand recounts of 1.7m ballot papers and to order Ms Harris to include those results in the certified statewide totals.

"The right to vote is at the core of our democracy and the president is our nation's head of state. There is an overwhelming interest in ensuring that every vote is counted," Mr Gore's team contends in its submission.

The sides are due in court at 2pm local time to present one hour each of argument. The seven judges, six of whom were appointed by Democratic governors, one jointly by a Democrat and the Republican governor Jeb Bush, are thought likely to rule quickly, possibly today.

The manual recounting continued yesterday in the three counties which Mr Gore hopes will provide him with enough votes to claim victory in Florida and give him a majority in the national electoral college, but Mr Bush's lead in the state was looking harder to erode than Democrats had hoped.

The Texas governor led by 930 votes at the start of yesterday, after final counts of Florida's overseas postal votes gave Mr Bush a margin of 630 to add to the 300-vote lead he already enjoyed in the 6m cast on November 7.

Everything rests on whether Mr Gore is able to chisel out enough votes from the recounts in Broward, Palm Beach and Miami-Dade counties. But as all three recounted yesterday, there were few signs that he was picking up votes at anything like the rate he needed.

In Broward, where the count was the furthest advanced of the three, Mr Gore had picked up 85 votes after 274 of the county's 609 precincts had been counted. Officials said that the Broward count, where officials began recounting 588,000 votes on Wednesday, could be completed today.

In Palm Beach, where 462,000 votes were being recounted, officials refused to release rolling figures. The count could finish tomorrow.

Miami-Dade began counting 654,000 ballot papers yesterday in a process not likely to be completed until after the Thanksgiving weekend, which begins on Wednesday evening.

A Newsweek poll showed that a clear majority of Americans, 61%, continued to say that a fair and accurate count in Florida was more important than bringing the dispute to a quick halt.

webTitle: New rail timetables subject to change

fields.headline: New rail timetables subject to change
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: New train timetables being issued today could still be changed from week to week, rail bosses have admitted.
fields.body:
New train timetables being issued today could still be changed from week to week, rail bosses have admitted.

The long-awaited schedules had been expected to detail what services would be available over the Christmas period after weeks of rail chaos.

However, George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies industry body, said they were hoping to "roll out" future timetables. Asked if that meant that the new timetable being issued today would only cover this week, he said: "That is true. But it is almost certainly the same one which will be operating next week and the week after."

He added: "I am afraid it does remain uncertain ... these are very difficult times."

The new timetables will be fed into train companies' computers so they can be accessed via the telephone or the internet, Mr Muir said. They were not yet available but would be able to be accessed "progressively" through the week. He added: "Delays will continue across the network because there are still a lot of speed restrictions and some consequences of floods left to deal with.

"What we are trying to do this week is get away from the day-to-day changes in service frequency which have been the experience of the last few weeks."

 Meanwhile, railways operator Railtrack saw its shares slide 10% today as the City worried about the prospects for the group in the wake of the resignation of chief executive Gerald Corbett.

Mr Corbett's decision to quit on Friday led Railtrack's shares to fall 4% to 995p, and by mid-morning today they had fallen a further 104p to 891p.

fields.headline: Role reversal
fields.standfirst:
Now the Tories are the progressives

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: This coming Wednesday sees the 10th anniversary of the toppling of Margaret Thatcher, the leader who shaped the modern Conservative party and whose influence still haunts it. However much some of the faithful resent it, the new party leadership under William Hague will be eager at the next election to signal its break with the Thatcher tradition, and rarely more than on issues involving the way the country is run.
fields.body:
This coming Wednesday sees the 10th anniversary of the toppling of Margaret Thatcher, the leader who shaped the modern Conservative party and whose influence still haunts it. However much some of the faithful resent it, the new party leadership under William Hague will be eager at the next election to signal its break with the Thatcher tradition, and rarely more than on issues involving the way the country is run. In May 1997, Labour were the eager reformers, the Conservatives the stout champions of the status quo. Labour proposed devolution: the Tories resisted. The Conservatives boasted their opening up of government through John Major's code for access to government information, but Labour went far beyond that, pledging genuine freedom of information. Labour promised an end to hereditary peers in the Lords, a referendum on the voting system, and legal protection for human rights: the Tories opposed them all.

But much has changed since William Hague took over. Where Labour hesitates, Mr Hague endorses a substantial elected element in the new upper chamber. Where Labour retreats from a fully fledged freedom of information bill, the Tories say: go further. They have dropped their resistance to the devolution settlements for Scotland and Wales - as they have their opposition to letting the Bank of England set interest rates. Where Labour holds back, they favour prising control of select committees away from the whips. Mr Hague would restore two prime minister's question sessions a week, instead of Mr Blair's one. On the right to trial by jury they have made common cause with libertarian Labour.

This is an old, old story. In the Wilson years, the Tories warned of "elective dictatorship." In the heyday of Margaret Thatcher they forgot that objection. When Labour were out, they promised a cull of quangos: yet quangos proliferate. Reforms which open up government, give MPs more clout against the executive, or, like PR, threaten a party's chances of ruling alone, suddenly look less desirable once you are in rather than out. To find the Conservatives on the side of liberal enlightenment is heartening. But it may rather more reflect their present distance from power. If Mr Hague wins power and goes ahead and delivers, it will constitute an unexpected and wholly surprising break with the old, tried pattern which might be unkindly summarised as propose and retreat.

webTitle: Terminator 3 takes shape with sexy budget and sexy villain

fields.headline: Terminator 3 takes shape with sexy budget and sexy villain
fields.trailText: The long-awaited Terminator 3 is set to become the most expensive movie ever made, plus producers court Carrie-Anne Moss for sexy villain role
fields.body:
After a spate of mediocre movies and lukewarm box-office, Arnold Schwarzenegger must be hoping that the long-awaited second sequel to Terminator will put him back on track. It's certainly got the budget to dazzle spectators: Terminator 3 lining up to take the dubious distinction of the most expensive film ever made.

Movie spy site Coming Attractions reports that the film, tentatively scheduled for release in 2002, will have a budget of $210m (£147.4m), $10m more than the previous record holder, Titanic.

And that's the scaled down estimate. Schwarzenegger told Metro newspaper on Friday: "The two drafts I read were so big it would have cost $250m to make. So now they're toning it down. I think we can do it on a football field somewhere so it doesn't cost that much."

As we reported last summer, Schwarzenegger is overseeing rewrites of the script himself, and during promotion for his current box-office outing The Sixth Day, the star began hinting at plot details.

The villain will be a female Terminator, he revealed. "She can disappear, she can mould into someone else, and she is sometimes just an energy," he told The New York Post, in refreshingly plain English.

Big Arn let slip more of his cunning plan to Ananova. "They used a girl as one of the villains in X-Men and it worked for them. Our lady would also be very attractive and, of course, have a thing about me." Lucky lass Carrie-Anne Moss (best known for The Matrix) is reputed to be the producers' first choice for the role.

The current script focuses on the rise to self-awareness by global artificial intelligence system Skynet, before it turns on its makers and attempts to eliminate mankind.

Only Schwarzenegger and Edward Furlong, who played the young John Connor in Terminator 2, have agreed to star in the movie. As we reported earlier this month, Linda Hamilton has declined to reprise her role as feisty mum.

webTitle: Roy Hattersley:Hague's attempt to win Christian credentials

fields.headline: Playing for the God squad
fields.standfirst:
Hague's attempt to win Christian credentials looks unconvincing
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: We can take it for granted that Fraser Kemp - one of the most sensible politicians I know - had no real objection to William Hague appearing as guest goodie-goodie on Songs of Praise. The formal complaint, which the shrewd Mr Kemp has announced he is to make to the BBC, is intended to remind us of what an ass the leader of the opposition made of himself.
fields.body:
We can take it for granted that Fraser Kemp - one of the most sensible politicians I know - had no real objection to William Hague appearing as guest goodie-goodie on Songs of Praise. The formal complaint, which the shrewd Mr Kemp has announced he is to make to the BBC, is intended to remind us of what an ass the leader of the opposition made of himself. Thanks to the Sunday Telegraph, that cunning object has been brilliantly achieved. And, although he will not learn the essential lesson, Mr Hague will have been provided with further proof that politicians who jump on every passing bandwagon end up with bruised backsides.

Apparently Mr Hague's decision to Sing-Along-With-Greg-Dyke was taken out of desperation. He no longer accepts invitations from Newsnight because there is, according to an aide, no advantage to to be gained by "going on a show where you are treated like a criminal". The Today programme has been "boycotted" ever since the opposition leader was subjected to 32 interruptions during one interview.

Mr Hague is not the first condemned man to turn to God in his hour of need. But when other helpers fade and comforts flee, the usual procedure is to announce a sudden conversion. For Mr Hague nothing would have been easier. We know that he was once a devotee of transcendental meditation. All he needed to do was tell us when he lost his faith in yogic flying. Unfortunately for his reputation, the leader of the opposition chose to insist that (although no one had previously recognised his piety) he is a man of profound Christian belief. So he chose to explain that he performed the necessary devotions with the utmost determination.

Membership of the Anglican communion normally involves attendance at Sunday service. Mr Hague realised that - although his activities do not receive the publicity he would wish - some people might have noticed that he is not regularly in his pew for matins or even the lazy man's alternative of evensong. So he explained: "The truth is that I actually go to church two or three times a week. Because of the job I do, I attend a lot of services but it means that, come Sunday, which is the only day which I can spend with Ffion, we choose not to go to church but choose to rejoice in long walks."

The news that the leadership of the Tory party requires such regular church attendance will come as a surprise to many historians. However, since Mr Hague was not hit by a thunderbolt when he made that claim, we must assume it to be true - although I hope that an investigative journalist will take the trouble to keep a detailed record of Mr Hague's religious diary. More important, some Christians will argue that the apologia, whether plausible or not, is just an admission that Sunday sacrament is not one of the leader of the opposition's priorities and that he allows it to be pushed out of his diary by judo practice with Sebastian Coe and whatever else separates him from his wife. William Hague will brush such criticism aside.

He believes that he is worshipping God in those long walks. "I come from a family" he explained, "where my mother used to say: 'God is in the garden, in everything that grows.'" I suspect that Mrs Hague senior had read Lifemanship by Stephen Potter, a humourous work much in vogue in the 1950s. It was the sequel to Gamesmanship - subtitled "How to win without exactly cheating" - and it advised how to apply a similar technique to the game of life. It made specific recommendations to readers who did not wish to rise early on Sunday mornings. Do not, it urged, admit you are lazy. Baffle your critics by explaining that the true Christian finds God in everything around him.

Although I did not know it when I read Lifemanship, Potter's theology - set out so eloquently by William Hague's mother and endorsed by her son - is called pantheism. The Dictionary of Christian Theology defines this as the "doctrine that the whole universe is divine". It goes on to say that to Christians "pantheism is entirely abhorrent, because it does away with the absolute distinction between the creature and the Creator". So William Hague made history. He is the first Conservative leader to espouse a doctrine which the Church of England finds entirely repulsive.

I do not suggest that all over England rural deans are resigning their Conservative membership, that monks are abandoning their vows of silence to excoriate William Hague or that church wardens and sidesman are demanding his trial as a heretic. But one or two people who listen to Songs of Praise will realise that he constantly commits the sin of the apostasy. He says whatever seems convenient at the time. For a politician the punishment is worse than death at the stake. It is ridicule.

fields.headline: Victor Meldrew buried by Millionaire?
fields.trailText: 11.30am: The final episode of One Foot in the Grave has been plunged into a surprise ratings battle with a surprise jackpot winner on Millionaire?, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
If Victor Meldrew was running the BBC, his response would have been an unequivocal "I don't belieeeeve it."

In an extraordinary turn-up for the books, ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? has come up with its first ever £1m winner, according to press reports.

It is a result that has eluded the hit game show since it began more than two years ago.

And the question everyone is asking this morning is whether the questions in the show are any easier than normal?

For ITV will be screening the nail-biting episode at 9pm, at exactly the same time as Victor Meldrew bids the nation farewell on the BBC.

The grumpy pensioner, played by Richard Wilson, makes his final appearance in One Foot in the Grave and BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey has been looking forward to it for weeks.

She has planned a documentary on the making of One Foot in the Grave to precede it and hopes are high that it will pull in at least as many viewers as the 13m that final Inspector Morse attracted last week.

Now, however, the nation will be divided between the final episode of the BBC sitcom and the spectacle of TV's first ever true millionaire game show winner - Chris Evans gave away £1m last year on TFI Friday, but there was little hype or viewer interest.

Executives at the BBC are suspicious that the ITV show has been dumbed down to boost the ratings for the game show.

One BBC insider said: "It is bemusing. We are all suspicious as to how their first million pound winner comes along just as Victor Meldew is shuffling off this mortal coil.

"Call me old-fashioned, but this looks like more than a coincidence when ratings for Millionaire are down."

According to BBC figures, ratings for the ITV show are down by more than 1m over the past year. In 1999 the average audience was 13.5m but this year it stands at 12.2m.

ITV was refusing to confirm that a woman wins a million pounds on tonight's show, despite reports on the front page of today's Sun newspaper.

Judith Keppel, 58, scooped the jackpot in the programme, which was recorded last night.

She appeared on Saturday night's episode and had got to the £16,000 level using only one lifeline.

ITV insiders confirmed that the jackpot had been won but is refusing to release the questions ahead of tonight's show.

 Anyone with information on the show can contact us on MediaGuardian.co.uk.

fields.headline: Campaign Media Business round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date:November 20.
fields.trailText: November 20: Carat has won the planning brief for a Vodafone pan-European corporate rebranding campaign.
fields.body:
Carat has won the planning brief for a Vodafone pan-European corporate rebranding campaign.

BBC Worldwide is seeking a new head of advertising for its family portfolio of 19 titles.

Newsquest Media Sales has named Lisa Bourne as managing director.

Discover Networks Europe Online has made its 14-strong advertising and production team redundant.

ITV2 has won the rights to broadcast the first run of Coronation Street when sister network ITV is showing Champions League football.

fields.headline: Always a dull moment
fields.standfirst: In its determination to offer as little excitement as possible, Citroen has triumphed with the new Xsara, says  Giles Smith.
fields.trailText: In its determination to offer as little excitement as possible, Citroen has triumphed with the new Xsara.
fields.body:
Remember those wonderful old Citroens from the 60s, shaped like boats, low-slung, with the bodywork that almost covered the rear wheels? Those ones that it was technically illegal to drive without smoking Gauloises and wearing a pair of effortlessly tasteful sunglasses at the same time? Well, the new Citroen Xsara has absolutely nothing in common with them, except the name Citroen.

The Xsara may in fact be the most characterless car on the market right now, apart from the Ford Fiesta - which actually forces you to admire it, the way you have to admire anyone who pursues a project right to its very end. In its determination to offer as little as possible in the way of troublesome excitement, the Xsara goes to virtually heroic degrees of self-restraint. All you can do, in the end, is take off the shades, put out the cigarette and bow before it in unmitigated approval - along with 1m other Citroen Xsara drivers already out there on the roads.

Here's how exciting things get in the crazy world of the new Citroen Xsara: if you have a crash, the hazard lights come on automatically. Great news. You might be upside down in a field, but at least your indicators will be winking.

I should point out that, tempted though I was to see this innovative facility in action - and tempted though I was, for a variety of reasons, to put the car in a field - I contrived not to have a crash in my Citroen Xsara. I am therefore obliged to take Citroen's word on the blinker gimmick. But I believe it.

Other advances made by this new take on the old Citroen Xsara include three new ridges along the bonnet, clear glass in the headlamps and a bigger Citroen badge on the boot - which may now be opened using the remote control, or, as we must learn to call it, the "plip".

Plus the radio aerial has been repositioned. It's now at the back. And the buttons that operate the electric windows have been moved. But I'm not going to tell you where they are, because I don't want to spoil the suspense.

My Xsara came painted in a shade that Citroen refer to as Misty Lilac, or, as I preferred to think of it, Psychedelic Undercoat. Its message of a curtailed good time was at one with most of what lay within the car. The interior feels solid, reliable, uncomplaining, concerned not to startle you in any way. Even the screen for the navigation system (a daringly party-style extra in the context of the Xsara) is a modest strip, sitting quietly in the dashboard, rather than the usual loud screen, screaming for attention.

I drove one of the diesel models. There's a lot to be said for diesel engines, particularly in relation to fuel consumption, but also in relation to the creation of cars that are boring to drive. Traditionally with diesel, acceleration is sluggish. You put your foot down, and the car gets the idea a few minutes later, by which time you probably need to brake anyway.

Theoretically, in the Xsara, these are minutes you could usefully fill by catching up with some work on the Citroen Auto PC system - an on-board computer set-up, offering a voice-activated telephone service and email. Citroen's literature happily envisages the hyper-busy executive dictating orders to head office and confirmations to clients, "using time that could otherwise be wasted sitting in traffic".

Except you can't yet, because the Auto PC system is only fitted to the continental models of the Xsara and Citroen says it is "currently assessing the likely demand for such a system before deciding on availability in the UK". I wonder what's keeping it. Why would British drivers not go for computers in Citroens as avidly as, say, French drivers? My own research at the wheel - which caused me to log sensations of peculiar disengagement in a variety of on-the-road scenarios - suggested fairly firmly that the need for distraction in a Citroen Xsara was a pan-European phenomenon.

But it does seem generally that the exciting add-ons for the Xsara are only coming later to Britain, subject to further local testing. For instance, my time with the Xsara would have been perked up enormously, I feel sure, by the proposed incorporation of a reversing sensor - one of those devices which makes the car bleep at you in a panic when you start backing into the personal space of large objects. But again, for some reason, that's not coming along until next year.

To be fair to the Xsara's diesel engine, it's a high-pressure direct-injection model - which means that that traditional diesel sluggishness is, in actual fact, chivvied out of existence. No time to go shopping on the net between gear changes after all.

But only BMW, it seems to me, has genuinely got to grips with the most off-putting aspect of diesel engines, which is that loose, chesty cough they suffer from when ticking over. It's fine for idling post vans, but not necessarily the kind of soundtrack you want from a saloon, or even an enlarged hatchback like the Xsara.

That said, there's something about that unperturbable rumble which suits the car right up to its aerial. It's a steady and sturdy vehicle, but it's never going to flip your plip.

The lowdown

Citroen Xsara 2.0 HDi

Price: £12,995

Maximum speed: 112 mph

Acceleration: 0-62 in 11.6 seconds

Consumption: 52.3 mpg

At the wheel: Delia Smith

On the stereo: Sade

En route for: The Norfolk Broads

fields.headline: Poetic justice
fields.standfirst: As poet-in-residence in a barristers' chambers, Benjamin Zephaniah learned a lot about the law - and injustice. Here he talks to  Marcel Berlins, while, in a new poem printed below, he recounts the story of a Gypsy woman whose appeal for asylum was dismissed 'because rape does not constitute torture'
fields.trailText: As poet-in-residence in a barristers' chambers, Benjamin Zephaniah learned a lot about the law - and injustice.
fields.body:
Read the poem, aloud. Try to imagine that it's being performed in the poet's mellifluous voice, quietly indignant at the injustice he's describing. Benjamin Zephaniah feels his poems. He was angry and emotional when he wrote this one.

"I wrote it after being in court watching the appeal of a Polish Gypsy girl seeking asylum in this country. She'd been raped. I've taken a lot of the words actually used by the judge who decided her appeal. Rape isn't torture, he said. I couldn't understand how a judge can say that to a woman - you can't stay here because when you were being raped, you weren't being tortured. That's what the law says."

Zephaniah's been in a lot of our courts recently, not, as was once the case in his youth, as a reluctant participant, but as a poetic observer, a commentator in verse. He's just finished a spell as the official poet- in-residence to a set of barristers' chambers.

But not just any chambers. His attachment was to the radical barristers of 14 Took's Court, headed by Michael Mansfield QC, scourge of miscarriages of justice.

He'd originally been interviewed to do his residency with the Red Cross. "I told them that as a poet I speak my mind, I criticise, and if I see something wrong being done by my own country, I'm going to speak out against it. I would find it very difficult to keep quiet. They said they understood, but it was probably better that I went elsewhere." There was no danger that Mansfield's chambers would try to muzzle him.

The poems he wrote on his Took's Court experience, some not yet fully finished and honed, are about Bloody Sunday (he accompanied Mansfield to the inquiry), the Asian student Ricky Reel - the inquiry into whose death unearthed a depressing tale of police incompetence and neglect - and a variety of less publicised cases he witnessed with other members of the chambers.

"I was most touched by those poor people in the asylum cases. I could almost see their hearts pounding. They were so frightened. And I won dered what it must have sounded like, hearing of their fate through interpreters - I found it so strange even in English.

"Sometimes I got the feeling that the interpreters were also looking down on them. One of the women said afterwards that the court translator in her case had come from the very tribe that had oppressed her and that she'd fled from.

"I know that the judges' decisions in these cases have to do with following precedents. But I felt that even if the judges had legal knowledge, they didn't have much common sense. I was hoping that one of them would say yes, I know what the law is, but I'm going to let you stay in the country."

It was predictable that a spell with Mansfield's pugnaciously civil libertarian chambers would illuminate some of the darker aspects of the law and the criminal justice system. But Zephaniah is restrained in his criticisms. He found some of the judges hostile, but on the whole "reasonable chaps trying to do their jobs", though out of touch.

He tells of a judge who, when a witness said "then I went to Heaven", didn't know that Heaven was a popular London club rather than the afterlife. I suggest that such ignorance is probably widely shared, not just among judges. "What I did learn - and I don't think it's a good thing - is that a lot of what happens in court is theatre, how the lawyer performs. I also noticed the way a barrister would be like the guy down the road, and then he'd put on his robes and be a different person, just like in the theatre. I've been to prison for something I didn't do, and I didn't have a lawyer who performed very well; the other guy was like Shakespeare in comparison. I don't think the result of a case should be down to who performs better."

If Zephaniah ever had to appear before a court again, he'd think seriously about defending himself - "a poetic presentation of my case. But I know that if you're passionate, you lose out".

As a poet, he became fascinated by the sounds and the words of the law. "The thing that struck me was the language of the courts. Sometimes I struggled to understand what the judge and barristers were saying, and when I asked afterwards what it was all about it was something really simple which had been put in a complicated way. But I do think the language is kept that way to exclude us, to intimidate us."

Among all his reservations, did he find anything good about our legal system? "The most positive thing for me, what impressed me most, is that in this country we can bring our own government to court, and the people at the top have to listen to the judges and to answer to them. I was so glad when the judge told the government that they had to let those islanders from Chagos go back to their island. I know countries where the prime minister will have dinner with a judge and tell him how to decide a case. That doesn't happen here. That gives me hope, the independence of the judges."

Appeal dismissed

I can see your fearful tears

Before me on your statement,

From where I sit I can see your dark terrorised skin

Shivering and barely holding your self together,

I can see your gaping scars wide open

Begging for compassion,

And in addition to your evidence

Both documentary and oral

I have before me

The encyclopaedia of your oppression,

I have the names and addresses of your demons.

I don't have to see you dance to know your suffering

I don't have to hear you cry to know that you are crying,

I saw your harassers on the news

I saw your house on fire via satellite,

I have no doubt that you are not tolerated by your neighbours.

But let's face it

You are not a dissident,

You are not even a liar,

You are what I would call a credible witness,

But I have no reason to believe that your persecution was official.

You were not raped because of your dark skin

You were not raped because of your gypsy tongue,

You were raped because you are a woman

And rape is one of the things that can happen to........a woman

So go home.

You have been the victim of an act of depravity

And you may never love again,

Nevertheless you have only been raped

And in the books that I have read

Rape does not constitute torture,

Not within the ordinary meaning of the word,

So go home

And take your exceptional circumstances with you.

fields.headline: First class female
fields.standfirst: She's one of the world's most popular novelists, and now she's even on a stamp. So why does Barbara Taylor Bradford still polish her own furniture?  Simon Hattenstone finds out
fields.trailText: She's one of the world's most popular novelists, and now she's even on a stamp. So why does Barbara Taylor Bradford still polish her own furniture? Simon Hattenstone finds out.
fields.body:
We are desperate to impress. Barbara Taylor Bradford, possibly the world's most popular novelist, probably Britain's second wealthiest woman, definitely the country's richest author, is riding with us. I'm togged out in best shirt and tie, and the cabbie is pretending to be a chauffeur. He holds open the door while BTB pinches her fur to her bosom and slides into the back seat. We are driving a few hundred yards from the Dorchester hotel to Hyde Park so she can have her picture taken.

She looks magnificent, positively regal. Her russet gloves match her russet Hermes bag and russet shoes. Those amethyst and gold earrings twinkle in unison with the amethyst necklace. She smells of face powder and seems to have a giant butterfly attached to her nose, which just adds to the atmosphere. I feel as if I'm in a movie. Perhaps a remake of A Woman of Substance. Our Barbara, the Yorkshire lass who once scoured her mother's front steps, has grown into this formidable woman who can make or break multinational publishing companies.

Twenty years ago A Woman of Substance turned Barbara Taylor Bradford into a phenomenon. Until then she had merely been Barbara Taylor, successful journalist (woman's editor of the Yorkshire Post at 18, Fleet Street columnist at 20), and Mrs Bradford, wife to successful film producer Bob Bradford. The domestic saga of the servant girl who became a tycoon sold millions. Since 1980 she has written virtually a book a year, all of them blockbusters. Nowadays she is so famous, so feted, that she doesn't simply jet over from New York to launch new books. She launches films of the book and videos of the film and any number of BTB add-ons. Today she is in Britain to launch the BTB stamp.

It's a bright, windy day. The trees are bending, the leaves dancing their frenzied dance across the park. The only immovable object is BTB's awesomely lacquered hair. She gives me her Hermes bag to hold, removes her sunglasses and moues into the photographer's lens. She tells me how fans come up to her and say: "There was a terrible mistake in the newspaper the other day when they said you were 67, because you're only 50 aren't you?"

I think we're getting on well. BTB suggests we give lunch in the grill room a miss and head off straight to her suite. They say she's worth more than £70m. "You don't think the coat makes makes me look fat do you," she asks in languid Americanese with just a bristle of Yorkshire. "Not that I care."

She opens the door, ushers me in and introduces me to film producer Bob. I try not to look too disappointed. Bob, who doubles as BTB's manager, also has an amazing head of tanned hair. If BTB is a transatlantic Mrs Slocombe, Bob is a lugubrious Walter Matthau in The Odd Couple.

He orders sandwiches before presenting me with a plastic wallet containing two stamps. The people of Grenada and St Vincent have decided BTB is just the woman for their new $5 and $6 stamps. Bob and Barbara know it's a first, even if they're not quite sure how. "I'm the first woman other than the Queen of England on a stamp," Barbara says.

Barbara has reinvented the word stamp. She opens her mouth wide and stretches the solitary syllable into a grandiose whinny. "Normally in the United States and Europe, you cannot be on a stemmmmmp if you're alive unless you're the Queen of England." So she has become royalty? " Ooooh! I wouldn't dare compare myself to royalty."

Bob decides it's best to leave us alone. "Bye honey. Get some air!" BTB says. I tell her Bob reminds me of Walter Matthau. "Oh, why? Didn't he just die? Bob has a very dry wit. He makes me chuckle every day."

With Bob out of the way she gets straight down to business. "I've just staggered away from a verrrry complicated book . . . it's a murder mystery." This is BTB's first murder mystery. Normally she writes sagas about women who face up to all kinds of adversity and come out smiling and rich. She gets upset when her books are labelled romances. The novel she is proudest of, The Women in His Life, is based on Bob's childhood as a Jewish boy caught up in the Holocaust.

BTB says her heroines are role models for her readers. "I tend to write about women going out and achieving things, strong women who have integrity. While being strong they are not hardbitten. I might have a bitchy woman in a book, but she'd never be the lead. I have to write about the kind of women I admire. I've always admired achievers, doers, women who won't permit themselves to be victims." I ask whether she has been the template for her heroines or whether her earliest heroine, Emma Harte, became a template for her. "You know, I think it's a bit of both."

"My parents were both Gemini and so is Bob, and my agent is, and his assistant is. So I'm surrounded by Geminis. I think I've got a photo of a painting of Gemmy." She digs into her wallet and produces a beautiful portrait of her dead dog.

The sandwiches arrive, and BTB looks put out. She lifts up the phone. "Vanessa, it's Mrs Bradford. Could I have some horseradish sauce and mustard, and also some lemon for the smoked salmon, thank you."

BTB admits she is demanding, impatient of tardiness, laziness and incompetence. "I think a woman should be able to cook a meal and look after family affairs. I'm very old-fashioned like that. I wouldn't let any maid touch the wooden furniture. Only I polish it. Put too much polish on and you ruin an antique."

She and Bob don't argue because they are equally pedantic and bossy. "But we've nobody to boss, except each other and the dogs." Does she regret not having children? "I tend not to regret things that I can't change. I had a miscarriage and never got pregnant again, and I'm not someone who wants to go to two dozen doctors to find out why because I'm always too busy, too much in a hurry." She says it would be churlish to harp on about it when there has been so much love and luck in her life. Soon after the miscarriage, she began writing her novels.

The phone rings. "Oh Adrian! How are you? Oh, did I sound like Margaret Thatcher? Ha-ha-ha!" Adrian is not the first person to compare BTB with Lady T. "It was Lord Bellwin, a friend of mine who did a lot of work for Margaret Thatcher. He saw me giving a talk without notes and said, 'You remind me of a young Margaret Thatcher . . .' Please eat this because I've eaten so much today. I'll order some more."

Does she think she is like Thatcher? "I think I'm businesslike, organised, brisk, so there you might have an analogy. I did admire her. I do admire her." Once she was invited to Downing Street and, staring at a painting of Churchill, turned around and found Thatcher was standing alongside her. "I said to her, 'I was just thinking, when I was a little girl in Leeds I never dreamed I'd be invited by the prime minister to 10 Downing Street and be standing here looking at that painting,' and she said, 'Oh yes, I know what you mean Barbara.' "

The longer we talk, the flatter BTB's vowels become. As the hours pass, I lose sight of the huge-haired New York caricature and find myself talking to Barbara the bluff, likable Yorkshirewoman. I ask her whether she feels embarrassed by her money. She says she doesn't see it so she doesn't think about it, and anyway she has earned every penny. What does she do with it all? "I think one of the pleasures is to be able to give things to family and friends . . . not that either of us have much family."

Perhaps the price of her success is that the critics laugh at the dark handsome men and tall blonde women of BTB's world. Does that hurt her? "Well they haven't really read it; that's why. Well maybe you laugh. I don't know whether you do, but millions don't. Millions go out and pay good money."

She tells me about an actor who had been hammered by a critic. "I said, 'Let me tell you something. No critic has ever given one person one moment of pleasure, and you have, and I have.' I know it's a borrowed quote, but the public love me. They do. Otherwise I wouldn't be here talking to you, and I wouldn't be on a stamp."

Bob has returned, refreshed. "Bob, Simon says you remind him of Walter Matthau in The Odd Couple."

"Why? He's dead isn't he?"

"Bob, Adrian's three-quarters of the way through the book and he said I don't have enough superlatives. I think its brilliant. Are you listening to me? Baaaaarrrrrb? Simon, have a banana . . . I'm feeding up the boy from Manchester."

" Give him two bananas! " Bob bawls from behind his desk.

I ask BTB whether she likes herself. "I do like myself very much. I think I'm a very nice woman, and I think I've accomplished a lot. I'm a good friend, wouldn't you say that Bob? Baaaaarrrrrb? I'm loyal, very generous . . .'

"Yeah," Bob grunts lovingly.

"Understanding heart, compassionate. Compassionate, Bob?"

"A good wife . . . you're a good wife."

"My friend Bobbie Caplin said just the other day, 'Of course she has changed because she's a sophisticated woman of the world, but inside she's still the same girl from Leeds.' And I am when it comes to values. So there. So there."

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: The lowdown on DH Lawrence's ground-breaking heroine, Lady Chatterley
fields.trailText: No: 1764 Lady Chatterley
fields.body:
First name : Constance, aka Connie.

Age : A rumbustious 23.

Appearance: Under the counter before November 1960; on the classic fiction shelves since.

I meant what does she look like? "A ruddy, country-looking girl with soft brown hair and sturdy body, and slow movements, full of unusual energy. She had big, wondering eyes and a soft mild voice." (Not a bit like Sylvia Kristel, above, in the 1981 film version.)

Unusual energy? Read the book.

Oh, go on, give me an example. What do you think this is, Channel 5?

Please, just one. If I must. "She felt him like a flame of desire, yet tender, and she felt herself melting in the flame. She let herself go. She felt his penis risen against her with silent amazing force and assertion and she let herself go to him. She yielded with a quiver that was like death, she went all open to him . . . She dared to let go everything, all herself, and be gone in the flood."

Marvellous. She sounds like my kind of gel. You don't have a number do you? 014 118 3675.

Is that a mobile number? No, it's an ISBN number.

Pity. To whom did the rising penis belong? Mellor, wasn't it? Mellors.

A goalkeeper. Gamekeeper.

It's all coming back to me. Connie's husband was, er, incapacitated wasn't he? "The lower half of his body, from the hips down, [was] paralysed for ever."

Hence the wheelchair. And the gamekeeper.

And you are reminding us of Lady C's supercharged existence because . . . It is 40 years since the courts cleared Lady Chatterley's Lover of obscenity, and Penguin has produced a new edition to celebrate.

Not to be confused with: DH Lawrence's proper books.

Do say: "Sexual intercourse began / In nineteen sixty-three / (Which was rather late for me) - / Between the end of the Chatterley ban / And the Beatles' first LP."

Don't say: "Is it a book you would wish your wife or servants to read?"

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip makes a late run for the bookies and puts a fiver on Gore
fields.trailText: The Daily Star says that Jim Jefferies will waste little time in making his first signing at Valley Parade, bringing £500,000-rated Robbie Winters to Bradford from Aberdeen. He may also attempt to sign Hearts star Colin Cameron.
fields.body:
The Daily Star says that Jim Jefferies will waste little time in making his first signing at Valley Parade, bringing £500,000-rated Robbie Winters to Bradford from Aberdeen. He may also attempt to sign Hearts star Colin Cameron.

Manchester United, AC Milan, Internazionale and Bayern Munich are all interested in Dynamo Kiev's £10m-rated wing-back Kakha Kaladze, according to the Mirror. The 22-year-old Georgia international expects to decide his future in the next two months.

Tore Andre Flo will have to put a transfer request in writing if he is to leave Chelsea. Again the Mirror reports that the Norwegian striker is ready to quit Stamford Bridge, but says that the club are reluctant to let him go. "We made it clear we want to keep the player", managing director Colin Hutchinson said yesterday. "If he insists he wants to go then that will be a different matter."

John Gregory has been dropping teasing hints as to the identities of possible new recruits at Villa Park. Gregory went on a scouting trip to an unnamed destination last week, and told the press: "Where I went is for me to know and for you to guess. But it was a very useful piece of homework and I came back with three names to discuss with the chairman."

Paul Merson has threatened never to play for Aston Villa again after a row following Villa's 2-0 defeat by Southampton at the weekend. The Mirror claims that the former England man was heard to bark into his mobile "The way I feel I might never play for this club again."

Sunderland have admitted an interest in Cardiff City's teenage striker Robert Earnshaw according to Planet Football. The 19-year-old scored a hat-trick for the Bluebirds in their 5-1 FA Cup win over Bristol Rovers yesterday, and Peter Reid said: "He's a young lad that we've had reports on and we've looked at, but we've taken our interest no further at this stage."

fields.headline: War correspondent wins posthumous award
fields.trailText: 11am: Spanish cameraman Miguel Gil Morena De Mora has won this year's Mohammed Amin Award for his reporting from Kosovo. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Spanish cameraman Miguel Gil Moreno De Mora was posthumously awarded this year's Mohammed Amin Award.

Mr Gil Moreno De Mora, a former Rory Peck Award winner who had covered many troublespots including the Balkans and Africa, was killed earlier this year while covering the crisis in Sierra Leone.

Mr Gil Moreno De Mora, who was working for APTN, and Reuters reporter Kurt Schork, were caught in the crossfire after their jeep was ambushed. Both were killed.

The award was accepted by his brother.

Mr Gil Moreno De Mora had trained as a lawyer and turned up in Sarajevo at the end of the war in Bosnia. His coverage of Albanian refugees being herded onto trucks in Kosovo prompted the west to intervene in the region.

The award is given in honour of Mohammed Amin, who was killed in 1996 in Ethiopia after 30 years of covering troublespots.

It was Mr Amin's pictures of the famine in Ethiopia which first alerted the world to the severity of the situation, provoking an outpouring of grief that lead ultimately to Band Aid and Live Aid.

The award was set up posthumously, in 1997. Last year it was given to Sorious Samura, whose footage of the civil war in Sierra Leone stepped up pressure for western intervention in the region. Samura now has his own series on Channel 4.

webTitle: Life as a tube station assistant

fields.headline: It's hell down there
fields.standfirst:
Robert Kiley, the man who turned round the New York subway, has been asked to take charge of London Underground. But does he have any idea what it is really like in the gloomy world under London's streets? Jesse Fuller does - he has been a tube station assistant for the past three years.
Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Robert Kiley, the man who turned round the New York subway, has been asked to take charge of London Underground. But does he have any idea what it is really like in the gloomy world under London's streets?
fields.body:
The London underground is a great example of familiarity breeding contempt. The lucky Victorians who travelled through the tunnels from Farringdon to Paddington - in steam trains - were amazed and enthralled by the feats of engineering. When the escalator was introduced, the underground had to employ staff to ride it to prove its safety to an overawed public. The stations built in the 30s are among the finest examples of art deco architecture in London. Yet when I told a friend I was applying for the job of station assistant he warned me, quite accurately, that underground staff rank alongside traffic wardens in the London public's hall of disdain.

But it still looked like a pretty good deal. When I was in the dole office and I saw the advert, all I noticed was the wages: about £15,000 a year. They have since risen. Today the starting salary is £17,000 a year. Not bad for a job for which you do not need qualifications. Station supervisors in central London can earn around £30,000, and, with sympathetic bosses, you can go from station assistant to station supervisor in two years.

In the old days, wages were poor, drinking among staff was rife and the fact that King's Cross did not burn down every day truly is a reason to believe in God. After the 1987 fire, however, nothing could be the same again, and the so-called Company Plan shook up the organisation with a lot of mission statements, sackings and wage rises. Those who held on to their jobs were soon mingling with graduates and ex-professionals who had not found anywhere else to earn such a living wage.

So I took the job in good faith, with a half-formed plan to let all the fare evaders off, take night walks in the tunnels and even be friendly to the weary public. I was, after all, one of them, born and bred in the shadow of the underground roundel, and I had this dream of a station where the locals would know we were on their side - a place where only tourists would buy tickets and we would have a friendly word for the regulars at the end of their journey. Perhaps Jeffrey Archer's mayoral dreams crumbled faster, but there can't have been much in it.

The first thing that happened to me when I was set to work on my own on a ticket barrier was that I was immediately extremely bored. There is no adjective to describe clearly the state of mind into which a person can pass on a quiet day on the barrier. Like they say about enlightenment, to know it you have to experience it. There, however, the similarity ends.

Secondly, I found that the general public seemed to be, for some unfathomable reason, pissed off all the time. Once, early in my career, a man laden with luggage approached me at the barrier and asked to be allowed through the gate. Naively, I asked for his ticket. Luckily, the gentlemen was happy to put me straight, at no charge. "You fucking cunt. You want to see my fucking ticket do you. You want me to put all my bags down to show you my fucking ticket? I'll show it to you when I'm fucking through, you fucking cunt . . ." Meekly suggesting that showing me the ticket either side would require him to put down his luggage made no difference.

After a few of those kind of encounters the thrill of delivering excellent customer service begins to pall, to be frank. On another occasion I was checking tickets at the barrier and one lady showed me her ticket back to front. Innocently I asked her if I could see the front side of the ticket. "I was fucking showing you it, you stupid prick . . ." I hastened to point out that I would never have risked such an ear bashing had I seen the ticket, but this had no effect. She was convinced I was doing it simply to annoy her.

Rudeness comes in many forms, from the tramp who wants to beg in your ticket hall to the young whippersnapper who wants to get himself and 13 mates through the gates with one child's travelcard. There is also the faux-rebel who wants to prove himself by being rude to a uniform. This kind of person saunters straight past you at the barrier as though he is hard and bunking the fare and then, when you pull him up, gives a great big sneer and produces his monthly travelcard.

You soon develop tactics to maintain your self-esteem. Some are noble, but the most effective is simply to be ruder, faster - which is no mean feat - and the experts at this game are the booking clerks, secure behind bulletproof glass. The clerk's life is an exercise in frustration - trapped at the window, doing a job that requires concentration but little actual intelligence, faced with hordes of incomprehensible and indecisive idiots who are all trying to maximise the amount of effort you have to put in just to sell them a ticket. After days or, to be honest, hours of £2.10 tickets bought by credit card and unintelligible tourists on top of a rush-hour crowd of miserable Londoners, the more sensitive clerk starts to wilt, and only dishing out tongue lashings, not always appropriately, can restore his sense of pride.

"Why are you always so rude?" one customer asked the ticket clerk on my duty. "The others here are always nice." "Well come back when they're here then," he replied. On another occasion a customer couldn't believe what he had been hearing. "I've never heard such rudeness in all my life," he exclaimed. "You want to get out more," came the response.

Letters of complaint are inevitable. Every so often, usually long enough after an incident that only hypnotism will bring it back to mind, a hapless manager trots along from wherever it is they while away their hours, a piece of paper in his hand, and asks for your response to such a letter. This will be a litany of accusations that have been so dressed up that if it turned out you had been clad in a devil's costume and torturing small children it would come as a relief. Of course, the manager has his job to do, so he usually admonishes you in some manner, with increasing vehemence as the weeks go by until finally, driven by boredom as much as anything else, he threatens you with a warning and you try to keep your head down for a while.

The only behaviour, apart from rudeness, that can be safely relied upon is acute stupidity. Almost everyone who travels on the underground seems to be braindead by the time they reach the station. People constantly come and ask where to go to get the train and are then surprised to be told to go down an escalator. Sometimes they walk out of another exit back to the street. Even if there are only two platforms and two escalators, no questions are too humiliating to ask. Some ask where the Southern line is, so they can get back to where they came from that morning! There is no reasoning with these people, who take their right to be cretinous as God-given, and when the odd sarky remark slips out all hell breaks loose.

For the humble station assistant - fortunately not stuck behind glass - the only way to avoid all this is simply to skive. The younger staff are quite brutal about this, going to the toilet for 20 minutes at a time and taking two hours to go three stops up the line and back again. But the older staff, schooled in the heady 70s, when doing your duty meant getting your round in, are in another world.

I bumped into Derek, one such old-timer, one morning about four hours into his shift and he was off home. He had apparently been asked to take some urgent dispatch around the local stations, but when he showed me the envelopes they were all empty, having been planted there by him early that morning. This was such a regular feature of his day that I once asked him why he did not just come in three days a week. He said that then he would have to take his wife shopping. I asked him if he was satisfied with his job, but he looked at me blankly.

"I mean, don't you want to get more out of your job?" His eyes lit up. "Oh yes, I do," he said brightly. "I want more hours out of my job."

Once one of the managers went to him during the round of pay talks. "What do you think of this rubbish the RMT want, Derek," he asked. "They're never going to get a 35-hour week, you know." "Thirty-five-hour week!" Derek spluttered. "No one's getting me to work a 35-hour week!"

Of course, the familiarity Londoners have with the tube tends to be familiarity with overpricing, overcrowding and under-running. The consequences of 30 years of efficiency savings has left a skeletal system that has no slack to accommodate the inevitable mishaps. In addition, the inexorable rise in passenger numbers means that even a fully functioning train service is bursting at the seams.

Meanwhile, the organisation is being broken up in preparation for the most bizarre sell-off of them all, so that contractors working for the Victoria line, for example, cannot now attend an emergency job under the Northern line's jurisdiction - even if they are on the same station.

The current crisis on the national rail system is a sure indicator of the direction the underground is taking as management fragments and the staff are required to be multiskilled, in order that one person can do three people's jobs. If the underground has avoided the catastrophes of the train network, it is only because it has not yet succumbed to the full-blown idiocy of privatisation.

The tube's managers are hamstrung by the fact that - since for the most part they are much too lazy to do anything - their warnings and threats can be taken lightly, at least for the first five years or so. The managers who bounce in, full of energy and enthusiasm, are soon worn down by the sloth and malaise of the whole place.

It is this culture that has survived and even thrived despite the best efforts of the Company Plan. The underground clearly took on a lot of consultancy in the 90s, and so, suddenly, head offices are all open-plan; we are all getting personal development tasks, even if, in practice, these consist of being told to pick up more litter; and, most importantly, everyone is stressing our all-new customer focus. This all crumbles when it meets the wall of the culture, the negative, antisocial, institutionalising mindset, which nevertheless maintains people's self-esteem as they struggle to get by in stressful, frontline jobs with no incentive but the pay packet.

Most of the managers have not come up through the ranks at all; most have been shifted over from some office or other - I sometimes suspect there is a factory in Milton Keynes churning them out - and are not always sympathetic to the plight of those on the front line. After all, they have to justify their wages somehow, and they do it by stitching you up over sickness. No more than one sickness in six months, no matter how short or how well verified by professionals, is acceptable to keep warnings from your file. Once you are into the warning system, the amount of time you have to be illness-free grows exponentially. Invariably you end up coming into work sick as a dog.

Infectious illnesses, I might just add, spread fastest on the underground. But don't worry because the public-private partnership is coming and we will all be out of our jobs soon anyway. With the initiative of private finance I'm sure you can look forward to some fantastic customer service in the future. So long as you don't mind waiting for a train.

fields.headline: ITC restructures in cost-cutting move
fields.trailText: The ITC is restructuring to position itself for the creation of a single communications regulator with redundancies on the cards, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The Independent Television Commission is restructuring to position itself for the creation of a single communications regulator, in a move also designed to cut costs and reduce the watchdog's staff by 10%.

The cuts will lead to the loss of 22 posts out of a total ITC staff of around 200, and redundancies are expected.

Patricia Hodgson, ITC chief executive, said: "These changes are designed to help us deliver our new priorities, become more efficient and effective and fulfil our promise of putting viewers first."

The ITC is planning to put particular emphasis on public accountability and consumer protection, as well as continuing to police public service content obligations.

The existing content regulation operation will be streamlined, with simpler requirements for ITC licensees.

As part of the new focus on consumer rights, a new viewer relations unit is to be established with strong regional links. The ITC's audience research programme is to be expanded and greater use made of citizens' juries.

The regulator will set up a team tracking developments in new media and its impact on consumers, as well as a group focusing on the switchover from analogue to digital services.

In addition, a new ITC policy unit is to be established to focus on the communications white paper and subsequent legislation.

As part of its cost-cutting drive, the ITC is reducing its discretionary spending - which includes travel, stationary, office equipment and overtime - by 5%, as well as cutting back on engineering research and development.

Further cost savings will come from the closure of the ITC's Kings Worthy Court base in Winchester and other regional offices.

In future ITC regional officials will work from home and the regulator is planning to put more resources into regional community initiatives and contact with interest groups.

The changes are to introduced by June 2001.

fields.headline: Councils to shop online
fields.standfirst: Local authorties in England and Wales are developing plans for e-procurement, reports Dermott Calpin
fields.trailText: Councils in England and Wales spend a hefty £25bn a year buying things - everything from paper clips and computer systems to refuse trucks and wheelie bins.
fields.body:
Councils in England and Wales spend a hefty £25bn a year buying things - everything from paper clips and computer systems to refuse trucks and wheelie bins.

Consortia exist that encourage bulk buying. Moreover, many local authorities learned long ago that they could negotiate better pricing agreements by pooling their collective purchasing power.

The Improvement and Development Agency (Idea) has taken this one step further with its plan to set up the Idea marketplace - essentially, an online shopping mall for councils. The plan, quite simply, is to establish an electronic procurement portal that will enable councils to trawl through vast catalogues of goods and services, until they hit upon exactly the right combination of price and specification.

Gary Richardson, director of assets and resources at Slough borough council, was seconded to develop the project. He has calculated that local authorities make more than 35m separate purchasing transactions a year, and that the cost of just administering the present system is more than £2.5bn a year.

He estimates that setting up a web-based system for ordering and buying goods could save councils a minimum of 15% - releasing significant resources for other local council priorities.

Some 50 interested companies have joined forces to form 16 consortia that have lodged bids to set up and run the online service. A panel of experts is examining the final bids and the successful winners are due to be announced before the end of November.

"This is a impressive response from high-quality and blue-chip companies. We are amazed and delighted at just how many of the companies who attended the conference have put in a bid," says Richardson.

In a separate initiative by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, which is linked to the drive to secure best value in council services, Hilary Armstrong, the local government and minister, has set up a task force to review local authority commissioning and procurement policies.

The review, like the Idea project, is designed to highlight existing council purchasing practices and subject them to critical examination. It is being led by former water regulator Sir Ian Byatt, who has stressed the need for purchasing policies to be carried out "more effectively, so that local people get the services they deserve at prices they can afford".

Councils, contractors, professional organisations and unions have been given till December 8 2000 to respond to the review. The task force will hear oral evidence in the new year, and is expected to report by the end of May 2001.

fields.headline: Advertising: meritocracy or laddocracy?
fields.standfirst: Women make up half the staff in the advertising industry, but do they get a fair crack at what is still perceived as a laddish industry?
fields.trailText: 10.30am: The advertising industry could do better at attracting and retaining women employees, particularly in its creative departments, writes Debbie Klein.
fields.body:
Speak to most women who work in advertising today and they'll tell you it's a genuine meritocracy. If you do well, you're rewarded, no matter who you are. Most women in advertising think that their contribution is now more highly valued and respected than a decade ago.

This is reflected in the fact that women in the advertising industry are four times as likely to reach director level than in the average FTSE 100 company, which is all good news.

Of course, like any industry, there are areas where we could and should be doing better. The first is finding a way to accommodate those women who want to strike a better balance between their home and work lives.

Interestingly, it's not just women who want this, for while women (mainly those with children) have led the way, the attitudes of many men are not very different when it comes to wanting more flexibility. Accommodating their needs is the only way to keep this talent in the industry.

The challenge is to offer more flexibility while keeping clients happy, but I don't think this is an insurmountable conundrum. The answers lie in getting smarter with how we use technology. Looking at giving time benefits as well as salary benefits. Communicating the value of flexible working to our clients. Recognising that flexible working is no longer just a women's issue. But above all, we need to make it clear to employees that part-time does not equal second class.

The second area that warrants action from the industry is attracting more women into our creative departments, where women remain more under represented than in any other area of advertising. It starts with getting on the radar earlier with students at university and schools. Changing the way we recruit and train creatives. Making sure that would-be female creatives are in contact with positive role models.

A natural consequence of all of this should be that the biggest barrier of all will change, which is the laddish culture in many creative departments which women can find intimidating.

It's a credit to the industry that it is prepared to look at itself so critically and think about what it needs to do to attract, and keep, a pool of talent that is now in high demand from other creative industries. The challenge now is whether it will be able to apply some of the innovative thinking usually reserved for clients and their brands to its own ways of working.

Debbie Klein is head of planning at WCRS, the 13th largest advertising agency. She is author of a new report Women in Advertising:10 Years On which was commissioned by the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising.

fields.headline: Catherine ties the knot
fields.standfirst: Champagne, Welsh lamb and high security
fields.trailText: Catherine Zeta-Jones sealed her A-list celebrity status this weekend by marrying into one of America's leading acting dynasties in a lavish ceremony which seemed a far cry from her humble beginnings.
fields.body:
Catherine Zeta-Jones sealed her A-list celebrity status this weekend by marrying into one of America's leading acting dynasties in a lavish ceremony which seemed a far cry from her humble beginnings, writes Rebecca Allison.

The Swansea-born actress, 31, exchanged vows with Michael Douglas, 25 years her senior, before an elite gathering of Hollywood stars in the opulent surroundings of the Plaza Hotel in New York on Saturday night.

Meanwhile in the Mumbles, the seaside corner of Swansea where Zeta-Jones was born and raised, traders and wellwishers hung out bunting and flags to mark the occasion, undeterred by the remoteness of the event.

As champagne flowed 3,000 miles away in Manhattan and the glamour set partied into the night, traders at the shopping arcade in Zeta-Jones's home town sent a congratulatory fax to the couple.

Sir Michael Caine, Sir Sean Connery, Sharon Stone, Danny DeVito, Christopher Reeve, Jack Nicholson, Steven Spielberg, and Art Garfunkel were among those invited to the event dubbed the showbusiness wedding of the year. But the wedding, rumoured to be costing more than £1.2m, was shrouded in secrecy so as not to jeopardise a seven-figure picture deal with OK! magazine.

Hundreds of fans joined the hordes of photographers waiting outside the hotel. The couple reportedly asked guests not to give presents but to donate to a fund set up for their three-month-old baby Dylan.

Kirk Douglas, 84-year-old father of the groom, gave his seal of approval to the bride, admitting as he arrived: "I'd marry her myself, but my wife won't let me." Members of the Zeta-Jones family, including the star's 85-year-old grandmother, flew over for the event.

As the red dragon flag flew alongside the stars and stripes outside the hotel, the 250 guests ate a seven-course meal which included rack of roasted Welsh lamb and ale. Even the bride's wedding ring was bought from a family jeweller in Aberystwyth.

As champagne flowed 3,000 miles away in Manhattan and the glamour set partied into the night, traders at the shopping arcade in Zeta-Jones's home town sent a congratulatory fax to the couple. Sir Michael Caine, Sir Sean Connery, Sharon Stone, Danny DeVito, Christopher Reeve, Jack Nicholson, Steven Spielberg, and Art Garfunkel were among those invited to the event dubbed the showbusiness wedding of the year. But the wedding, rumoured to be costing more than £1.2m, was shrouded in secrecy so as not to jeopardise a seven-figure picture deal with OK! magazine. Hundreds of fans joined the hordes of photographers waiting outside the hotel. The couple reportedly asked guests not to give presents but to donate to a fund set up for their three-month-old baby Dylan. Kirk Douglas, 84-year-old father of the groom, gave his seal of approval to the bride, admitting as he arrived: "I'd marry her myself, but my wife won't let me." Members of the Zeta-Jones family, including the star's 85-year-old grandmother, flew over for the event. As the red dragon flag flew alongside the stars and stripes outside the hotel, the 250 guests ate a seven-course meal which included rack of roasted Welsh lamb and ale. Even the bride's wedding ring was bought from a family jeweller in Aberystwyth.

webTitle: Gaza Strip bomb targets school bus

fields.headline: Gaza Strip bomb targets school bus
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: A bomb has exploded in the Gaza Strip next to an armoured bus transporting children and teachers from a Jewish settlement to a nearby elementary school.
fields.body:
A bomb has exploded in the Gaza Strip next to an armoured bus transporting children and teachers from a Jewish settlement to a nearby elementary school.

Two adults were killed and nine passengers wounded, among them at least four children. A radical Palestinian group based in Damascus claimed responsibility.

'One of our Omar al-Mukhtar's fighting units carried out today a big bomb attack,' read a statement released to press, 'backed with hand grenades on a bus carrying Zionist settlers and accompanied by a Zionist patrol in Khan Younis."

"I believe the attack this morning cannot pass without a response by the Israeli government," announced Gilad Sher, an aide to Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak. "It's an attack so serious, so low, so contemptible, I believe there's no way to think at all that this can pass without a response."

In the past, similar attacks have been carried out by Hamas and Islamic Jihad, two Islamic militant groups that have tried to wreck Iraeli-Palestinian peace agreements with bombings and shootings at Israelis.

Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak convened his security cabinet for a special session to discuss Israel's response.

"This will not pass without a response," Gilead Sher, a senior adviser to Barak, told Israel army radio.

Last week, Israel rocketed Palestinian command centers in response to deadly attacks on Israelis.

The school bus left the isolated Jewish settlement of Kfar Darom in the heart of the Gaza Strip at around 7:30am this morning. Students and teachers were en route to elementary school in Gush Katif, a bloc of Jewish settlements in the south of the strip.

A large explosive device detonated about 70 meters away from the bus, killing two adults and wounding nine passengers, including four children, according to the army and hospital officials. One adult and one child were in serious condition.

Army officials said the armor of the bus and the considerable distance between the explosion and the bus helped blunt the impact of the attack.

About 6,500 Jewish settlers live in the Gaza Strip, among 1 million Palestinians. Jewish settlers have come under repeated attack in the past seven weeks of Israeli-Palestinian fighting. Several roadside bombs have exploded next to armored settler convoys in Gaza, and Israeli motorists have been fired on in the West Bank. Last week, four Israelis were killed in such attacks.

On Saturday, a Palestinian policeman opened fire on Israeli soldiers guarding farm land Kfar Darom, a heavily guarded settlement of 250 people. One soldier was killed and two were wounded in the attack.

In all, Israeli-Palestinian fighting has claimed more than 230 lives since Sept. 28. The vast majority of the victims have been Palestinians.

Israeli Foreign Minister Shlomo Ben-Ami said the attack was especially grave because the explosion was set off from a Palestinian-controlled area.

Last week, Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat called on Palestinian gunmen to halt their fire from areas under his control, but his decree did not extend to attacks from parts of the West Bank and Gaza that are under Israeli rule.

fields.headline: Brand Aid
fields.standfirst:
Capital Gold

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: What is it?
fields.body:
What is it?

Radio for the cardigan-wearing classes, Capital Gold is the radio station your accountant shaves to. Famous as the traditional last resting place of the Smashie and Nicey brigade of DJs, there is a certain comfort value in the familiarity of its playlist. Expect a heavy dose of nostalgia.

So what's the problem?

Listener numbers are none too healthy. Sadly, no one wants to listen to those old favourites from the 50s any more.

What are they doing about it?

Launching a rebranding campaign designed to "remove any perceptions of 'old' from Gold" and to remind consumers of the quality of the playlist. There's a new logo and an advertising campaign featuring such pop legends as the Beatles, Jimmy Hendrix and Mick Jagger.

The campaign coincides with the launch of a revamped autumn schedule, which includes two new shows presented by erstwhile glam-rock legend, Noddy Holder.

Programme controller Andy Turner says: "People still have this impression of us as only playing stuff from the 50s and 60s. We want to let people know we're playing a lot of stuff you might not expect to hear on Capital Gold and we've got real music experts such as Tony Blackburn and Mike Sweeney playing it."

History

Capital Gold began in 1987 as a spin-off from Capital FM. Over the years, Bruno Brookes, Keith Chegwin and Dave Lee Travis have all DJ'd for the station. It now broadcasts in Birmingham, south Wales and across the home counties as well as in London.

Who listens to it?

The core market is 35- to 54-year-olds, although its sports coverage attracts younger listeners.

What about the competition?

Capital Gold's main competitor, Magic FM, has gone for the quirkily cool option since it rebranded from Melody. Even Radio 2 has come over all trendy, signing up Mark Lamarr and Jonathan Ross alongside such old favourites as Terry Wogan.

What the experts say

Tim Ashton, creative director of communications consultancy Circus, believes one of Capital Gold's biggest handicaps is its name. "Capital makes you think of something very mainstream, and Gold suffers from an association with UK Gold and golden oldies. If they try to be too cool it could come across like your granny at a disco."

The future

Capital Gold acquires retro chic and hires Fatboy Slim to present its breakfast show.

fields.headline: NHS phone service rolls out
fields.trailText: The government's NHS Direct telephone service will be formally rolled out across England today as ministers step up their efforts to ensure that it becomes the main "gateway" to the health service
fields.body:
The government's NHS Direct telephone service will be formally rolled out across England today as ministers step up their efforts to ensure that it becomes the main "gateway" to the health service.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will announce that the service, which is staffed by nurses, will handle 5m calls a year by 2004, turning it into the national telephone line for the NHS.

All patients, except those in need of emergency care, will be encouraged to telephone NHS Direct as a first step in their treatment.

Ministers hope that this will improve efficiency by reducing the number of telephone calls to local GPs or to accident and emergency units.

NHS Direct staff make an assessment of a patient's need before offering advice which can range from encouragement to stay in bed for minor conditions to making an appointment to see a GP or to go to hospital. Under the new plans, NHS Direct will handle initial telephone inquiries on behalf of GPs' surgeries.

Ministers are bracing themselves for a confrontation with GPs who are said to be nervous about NHS Direct taking on their work.

Tony Blair will today hail NHS Direct as one of the greatest examples of how Labour has modernised the NHS.

Since NHS Direct was launched in March 1998 it has handled 3.5m calls, and it is hoping to be taking an average of about 100,000 a week by the end of this year. The service has been particularly popular among young mothers - 61% use the service regularly.

Mr Milburn is expected to say today that the NHS Direct telephone number - 0845 4647 - "looks set to become as well known and as well used as the emergency 999 number".
