fields.headline: Parents 'not told' of hospital errors
fields.trailText: Many parents are never told about errors in their children's hospital treatment, a study suggests today
fields.body:
Many parents are never told about errors in their children's hospital treatment, a study suggests today.

Nearly half the families of patients who were administered the wrong medicine, given or prescribed the wrong dose, or drugged by the wrong route, were not informed of the mistakes, according to a review of errors over five years at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Glasgow.

Although the overall error rate was low - one per 662 admissions - 40% of the botched treatments involved children under two. Eight per cent of incidents, 15 out of 195 errors, involved drugs given in doses 10 times too high or too low.

No patient died as a result but two cases, involving the wrong concentration of an anti-cancer treatment and the intravenous infusion of a sedative that was 100 times too high, were said to have had the potential to cause serious harm. Three others could have had moderately serious consequences.

Nearly 10% of the patients needed extra treatment or investigation, including, in four cases, an extra drug to mitigate the effects of the errors.

The authors of the study, published in Archives of Diseases in Childhood, said those responsible for recording errors sometimes thought it was not worth telling parents about labelling errors noticed before drugs were given. In other cases, it was considered unnecessary to cause "undue stress" when the child had come to no harm.

The researchers, from the department of child health at Glasgow University and the hospital's pharmacy department, say many hospitals have no system for reporting errors, unlike the Royal where there has been a mandatory scheme for years. This is to change soon when the NHS introduces compulsory national arrangements.

More than half the mistakes involved intravenous treatments, including antibiotics, anti-viral medication, anti-cancer drugs and feeding fluids and a third involved oral medication. Most errors happened on the medical wards and were reported by nurses.

The authors say it is important for staff to check calculations and avoid decimal points. Most errors were not down to negligence but organisational failures.

In a commentary on the study, Terence Stephenson, of the Queen's Medical Centre, Nottingham, suggests that, extrapolating the figures, there would be at least 1,675 avoidable medication errors a year involving children under 16 in English hospitals. Of those, 85 might involve moderate or severe reactions. The true figures were probably higher and although there had been no deaths in the Scottish study, fatalities did occur because of medication errors.

Improvements could include standardisation of infusion pumps regulating intravenous treatments and more thorough checking of prescriptions and calculations.
fields.bodyText: Many parents are never told about errors in their children's hospital treatment, a study suggests today. Nearly half the families of patients who were administered the wrong medicine, given or prescribed the wrong dose, or drugged by the wrong route, were not informed of the mistakes, according to a review of errors over five years at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Glasgow. Although the overall error rate was low - one per 662 admissions - 40% of the botched treatments involved children under two. Eight per cent of incidents, 15 out of 195 errors, involved drugs given in doses 10 times too high or too low. No patient died as a result but two cases, involving the wrong concentration of an anti-cancer treatment and the intravenous infusion of a sedative that was 100 times too high, were said to have had the potential to cause serious harm. Three others could have had moderately serious consequences. Nearly 10% of the patients needed extra treatment or investigation, including, in four cases, an extra drug to mitigate the effects of the errors. The authors of the study, published in Archives of Diseases in Childhood, said those responsible for recording errors sometimes thought it was not worth telling parents about labelling errors noticed before drugs were given. In other cases, it was considered unnecessary to cause "undue stress" when the child had come to no harm. The researchers, from the department of child health at Glasgow University and the hospital's pharmacy department, say many hospitals have no system for reporting errors, unlike the Royal where there has been a mandatory scheme for years. This is to change soon when the NHS introduces compulsory national arrangements. More than half the mistakes involved intravenous treatments, including antibiotics, anti-viral medication, anti-cancer drugs and feeding fluids and a third involved oral medication. Most errors happened on the medical wards and were reported by nurses. The authors say it is important for staff to check calculations and avoid decimal points. Most errors were not down to negligence but organisational failures. In a commentary on the study, Terence Stephenson, of the Queen's Medical Centre, Nottingham, suggests that, extrapolating the figures, there would be at least 1,675 avoidable medication errors a year involving children under 16 in English hospitals. fields.headline: Lynx freshens up
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Five years ago, saying you wore Lynx deodorant was like admitting you drove a Ford Cortina and shopped at Mr Byrite. But Lynx is becoming the deodorant of choice for men in their teens and early 20s, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Five years ago, saying you wore Lynx deodorant was like admitting you drove a Ford Cortina and shopped at Mr Byrite. Brands didn't get much more naff.

But Lynx is becoming the deodorant of choice for men in their teens and early 20s and the brand is now so successful it has spawned a chain of trendy barber shops and a razor.

It has a 30% share of the male toiletries market and even if older men don't like the product they still think the advertising is cool.

The dramatic turnaround in Lynx's fortunes was last week held up by Keith Weed, chairman of Lynx owner Elida Faberge, as a testament to the power of marketing.

Speaking at the Marketing Society Conference, Mr Weed said he realised something had to be done when he heard someone describe Lynx as "about as cool as Roger Moore in a safari suit".

Unilever has put its considerable marketing might behind the brand. It hired Bartle Bogle Hegarty, the advertising agency famous for reviving brands such as Levi's and Boddingtons, to create a fresh new campaign for a product whose advertising had become tired and cliche-ridden.

The result was a funny and irreverent campaign under the new line, "The Lynx Effect".

The ads, which centre on the idea that women will doing anything for a man wearing Lynx, won a top award at the Cannes International Advertising Festival - the ad industry's equivalent of the Oscars - and have been credited with helping to make Lynx fashionable again.

The latest featured Friends star Jennifer Aniston pictured in bed reading a book entitled How to Keep Your Man. The man in question is a nerd, naturally, transformed into a cool dude with a lick of Lynx.

But the advertising was part of a much bigger marketing campaign aimed at giving Lynx an edgier feel.

Elida Faberge began by sending the - predominantly female - Lynx marketing department clubbing in towns such as Leeds and Manchester, to give them a feel for their target market of 16 to 24-year-old men.

It then launched a variety of initiatives aimed squarely at young men, including a viral marketing campaign that allowed recipients to download onto their computer screens a cartoon of a man urinating the name of their girlfriend and a tie-up with FHM magazine.

But most ambitious was the programme of brand extensions. First was the launch of a Lynx razor in September, backed by a multi-million pound advertising campaign through BBH.

Now, Elida Faberge is launching a chain of Lynx-branded barber shops aimed squarely at young men. The first opened last month on London's Oxford Street and there are plans for a further two over the next six months.

According to independent industry figures, the Lynx brand was worth £80m this year in the UK alone. Lynx body spray, after shave and shower gel are all the best-selling brands in their respective markets and 50% of all 11 to 24-year-olds use a Lynx product at least once a week.

As Mr Weed says, "You have to constantly innovate to be successful. You need to have a willingness to fail and to learn from your failures."

fields.headline: Friends in need
fields.trailText: When a local council fails disastrously to deliver, should government intervene? This is not an academic question but an issue staring ministers in the face.
fields.body:
When a local council fails disastrously to deliver, should government intervene? This is not an academic question but an issue staring ministers in the face. What are they going to do about the London borough of Hackney? In the past, for all Whitehall's notorious centralised powers, the right of direct intervention in a district where a local authority had run off the rails was never available. Through 18 Conservative years, local government suffered ever tighter control, saw its taxing capacity capped and surrendered £30bn-worth of services to unelected quangos. Yet even Margaret Thatcher left Lambeth and Liverpool to clear up their own mess. Now this has changed. Under last April's Local Government Act the chief monitor of local councils, the audit commission, can in dire circumstances advise ministers to send in a hit squad to take over a council's services.

And dire is certainly the appropriate word for the state of Hackney today, even given its long history of political in-fighting, managerial incompetence and plain fraud. A succession of recent reports, starting with the audit commission's first local authority performance tables in 1995, has shown a steady decline across most services. Five years ago the borough was at the bottom of the league table, taking 37.4 weeks to let a vacant flat (compared to Knowsley's two weeks) and with 20% of its tenants at least 13 weeks in arrears (compared to Merseyside's 5%). Subsequent Ofsted and social service inspections have added to this picture of gloom. A third Ofsted report, published yesterday, reported that schools had lost faith in the local council.

But it is the audit commission's corporate report earlier this month, warning ministers that the borough was facing an across the board "meltdown", that has become the real catalyst. It disclosed that the council had collected only half its council tax, 17,000 of its poorest tenants were still awaiting housing benefit and the council was facing a budget deficit of £40m. Hackney was given until February to get its finances in order, agree spending cuts and improve council tax collection and housing benefit payments.

Surely, then, if there has been no improvement, a responsible government would send in a hit squad? Local autonomy is important, but so are civil rights. Some of the poorest people in London - 10 of London's 50 most deprived wards are in the borough - are suffering intolerable conditions: uncollected refuse, unswept streets and a catalogue of urgent but frozen house repairs. There are plans to slash early education programmes and cut 48 residential care beds. A tough hit squad, with powers to take over all services, may seem the best solution. Yet that is not going to happen. One obvious reason is that this would make Hackney the direct responsibility of Whitehall, and that is the last thing this government wants.

Hit squads sound fine, but where do you find them? Incompetency cultures become ingrained. Councils take years to turn round. It may sound less dramatic, but the audit commission's approach offers a far better chance of success. It set down in detail the changes which it wanted to see in better financial control, filling gaping management holes and reaching a political settlement. Local Labour and Tory leaders have reached a consensus; new managers are moving in; nearby authorities are lending support. The exercise is being closely monitored by a new team at the commission, headed by Wendy Thomson, who helped turned round neighbouring Newham. Wish her luck: given the problems of Hackney today, she will certainly need it.

webTitle: OK! chief takes lead in race for Express

fields.headline: OK! chief takes lead in race for Express
fields.standfirst:
Hinduja brothers left trailing by Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell Group

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: 8am: Publishing tycoon Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell Group, which publishes OK! magazine, last night emerged as the surprise front-runner in the bid battle for Express Newspapers. By Rob Griffin.
fields.body:
Publishing tycoon Richard Desmond last night emerged as the surprise front-runner in the bid battle for Express Newspapers.

Industry sources hinted that a deal could come as early as this week.

Mr Desmond's Northern & Shell Group, publisher of celebrity magazine OK! and soft porn titles such as Asian Babes, has been regarded as a serious contender only in the past few days.

United News & Media, owner of the Express titles, was initially sceptical but is now thought to favour Mr Desmond over the billionaire Hinduja brothers.

Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the investment bank advising United on the sale, is due to continue discussions with bidders and senior executives at United today.

Observers say an announcement regarding the sale is expected to be made "very soon".

Mr Desmond is understood to be planning a stock market flotation for Northern & Shell, which also includes the adult TV Fantasy Channel.

The group's OK! magazine now outsells rival Hello! and is reported to have paid Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas £1m for the exclusive rights to their New York wedding over the weekend.

Mr Desmond is said to believe that the addition of the Express stable, which includes the Daily Star as well as the Daily and Sunday Express titles, would provide a pre-flotation boost.

Speculation over the Express group's future has been intense, with no less than seven groups said to have expressed an interest, but the emergence of Mr Desmond as the lead contender will come as a shock to the Hindujas who were reported to be close to an agreement with United.

The brothers, who have manufacturing and oil interests across India and Europe, are believed to have tabled a bid of about £120m. Any acquisition would be made through Amas UK, their wholly owned subsidiary.

Yesterday it was revealed that the pair were looking to bring Gulf Oil, described as their prize asset, to Britain after taking over and rebranding a chain of petrol stations.

The Hindujas are also known to be interested in buying 40% of Air India from the Indian government, but reports that they are mounting a £400m bid for Go, the British Airways-owned cut-price airline, were last night dismissed by their spokesman as "pure speculation".

Prior to Mr Desmond, the brothers' main rival for the Express has been the Daily Mail & General Trust, owner of the Daily Mail newspaper, which is understood to have put in a similar bid.

But its approach began to falter after it was made clear that, as a rival, a non-refundable £60m deposit would have to be made to gain access to commercially sensitive information.

Among the other parties said to be interested were Hollinger International, publisher of the Daily Telegraph, but it, too, would need to post a similar deposit to proceed.

The Barclay brothers, who own the Scotsman and Sunday Business, pulled out of the running last month, although industry observers are refusing to write them off as bidders completely.

Weekend reports also suggested that two other groups were considering putting together rival bids.

A consortium involving showbusiness PR man Matthew Freud, Labour peer Lord Alli and media entrepreneur Chris Evans is said to be at an "early stage", while David Sullivan, owner of the Daily and Sunday Sport, is said to want the Express group's Daily Star title.

Mr Sullivan is understood to have hired investment bankers to put together his bid but was not interested in either of the Express titles.

webTitle: OK! censured for photos of prince

fields.headline: OK! censured for photos of prince
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Press Complaints Commission has censured OK! magazine for publishing unauthorised photographs of Prince William during his gap year in South America.
fields.body:
The Press Complaints Commission has censured OK! magazine for publishing unauthorised photographs of Prince William during his gap year in South America.

In the landmark ruling on the prince's privacy, the press watchdog ruled that the mag azine was guilty of harassment and a breach of privacy in printing shots of Prince William during a 10-week expedition with Raleigh International in Chile, St James's Palace confirmed last night.

The photographs of him hiking and crossing a river were taken with a telephoto lens, contravening the rules gov erning the young princes which were hammered out by the PCC and the British media after Prince William left Eton.

The PCC's ruling is the first concerning the prince and will be seen as a warning to the press before he takes up his place at St Andrew's University, in Scotland, next year.

The two-page ruling was not due to be published until January, three months after the complaint was lodged by the palace at the end of October. But a copy leaked to the Times newspaper said: "It was clear to the commission that Prince William was on a trip to a place where he had reasonable expectation of privacy and publi cation of these photographs was a breach of the code."

It also agreed with the palace that they had been obtained as a result of harassment. OK! has apologised to the Prince of Wales and Prince William. The magazine said that as far as it could ascertain the photographs were taken in a public place.

Last night a St James's Palace spokesman said: "It is very important to be clear that, during Prince William's gap year and his time at university, if pictures are used and they have been gained in a disruptive fashion, that is unacceptable."

webTitle: BBC rumbled as African orphan prank falls flat

fields.headline: BBC rumbled as African orphan prank falls flat
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: 8am: Police were called in after a BBC crew dumped a child actor pretending to be a homeless child from Africa on a childminder's doorstep, <Steven Morris reports.
fields.body:
It must have seemed such a good wheeze at the time. Following in the traditions of Candid Camera, the BBC team plotted to dump the child actor, pretending to be a homeless child from Africa, on somebody's doorstep and watch the hilarious reaction.

Unfortunately Gillian Dumbarton, a childminder, did not see the funny side and called the police. Officers sent the crew, filming for a pilot of a BBC show called Rumbled, on their way.

Yesterday the BBC apologised for causing offence after it was accused of poor taste.

Mrs Dumbarton had opened the front door of her home in Croxley Green, near Watford, to find a man asking if she wanted to help homeless African children.

A wooden box was then unloaded from a lorry and out popped a seven-year-old boy pretending to be in need of adoption. Mrs Dumbarton was told she would have to look after him.

But Mrs Dumbarton dialled 999. Neighbours worried about the sudden influx of strangers also phoned for help.

Police told the crew they were in danger of causing a breach of the peace and told them to stop filming. Mrs Dumbarton, a childminder for 20 years, said the trick was in poor taste. "I've got a sense of humour, but this was so unsavoury and in bad taste when you think of all the disasters that have hit people in Africa."

The BBC said the purpose of the show was to find out if members of the public "rumbled" the pranksters. "In this case we were rumbled," a spokesman said. "We are sorry if we have caused any unnecessary offence."

fields.headline: BBC shake-up shelved
fields.standfirst:
Ministers fight shy of clash before election

Special report: the future of the BBC
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: 8am: Ministers have watered down sensitive plans to curb the powers of the BBC's governors to avoid a damaging row with the corporation in the run-up to the election. By Matt Wells and David Teather.
fields.body:
Ministers have watered down sensitive plans to curb the powers of the BBC's governors to avoid a damaging row with the corporation in the run-up to the election.

Proposals to weaken the board of governors were to be included in a white paper on the communications industry, to be published next month. But, as the election draws near, ministers have stepped back from their instincts to act tough and will simply outline a range of options instead.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has long harboured ambitions to abolish the board. His frustration with the corporation's regulators was renewed this year when they approved the decision of Greg Dyke, the director general, to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm at short notice.

But it is understood that Number 10 and the Department of Trade and Industry - which is producing the white paper with Mr Smith's Department for Culture, Media and Sport - feel that a "gung-ho" attitude against the BBC would be unwise just before the election.

The white paper - the basis for a later communications bill should Labour be re-elected - will underscore the need for reform but will not give a definite blueprint. This means that ministers do not have to set out their views now: further consultation will take place before legislation in the next parliament.

In drafting the white paper, there have been tensions between the DTI, the DCMS and Downing Street policy advisers. Mr Smith was furious at the BBC's decision to move its nightly news, and the apparent complicity of the BBC governors' chairman, Sir Christopher Bland. The culture secretary was particularly irritated by Sir Christopher's response that Mr Smith was simply "a licence fee payer and therefore entitled to his view".

Mr Smith said yesterday that he would be watching "very carefully" viewing figures and programme quality after the move from the 9pm slot.

"If we are seeing a diminution of news, in quality and audience of news, then I think the governors of the BBC have to think very seriously about what they are going to do," Mr Smith told BBC 1's Breakfast with Frost.

Downing Street has significant doubts about taking on the BBC when the fight could be postponed until after the election, a view shared by the DTI. "There's a huge battle going on between the DTI and the DCMS over the BBC particularly," said a policy-maker at a national broadcaster.

Publicly, the BBC opposes the idea of placing the board of governors under the auspices of an independent regulator. Privately, senior policy-makers at the organisation concede that change is inevitable. "The devil will be in the detail," one said - the corporation will accept independent monitoring of programme standards and public complaints, but will fight to retain its influence over the BBC's remit and editorial independence.

The white paper will also map the way towards a single ITV company. At the moment, the network has two major broadcasters, Carlton and Granada, with several lesser players. Strict rules prevent any further consolidation. Recent reports that the way towards one network would be barred are understood to have been wide of the mark.

The white paper will signal a big upheaval in the way television, broadcasting and newspapers are regulated.

For the first time, the different media will be treated globally, rather than separately. Rules on cross-media ownership will be more flexible, and one regulator will oversee the whole industry.

Arguments over the detail have delayed publication of the white paper several times, and it is now due to be released on December 12.

Baroness Jay, Labour's leader in the Lords, yesterday angrily rejected suggestions that she was seeking to succeed Sir Christopher as "complete fiction".

Her spokeswoman said that Lady Jay was "bemused" by a report in yesterday's Sunday Times linking her to the chairmanship of the governors because she told the newspaper on Saturday night that its information was wholly inaccurate. "This is complete and utter rubbish," the spokeswoman said. "Margaret has no plans to become the chair of the BBC."
fields.bodyText: Ministers have watered down sensitive plans to curb the powers of the BBC's governors to avoid a damaging row with the corporation in the run-up to the election. Proposals to weaken the board of governors were to be included in a white paper on the communications industry, to be published next month. But, as the election draws near, ministers have stepped back from their instincts to act tough and will simply outline a range of options instead. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has long harboured ambitions to abolish the board. His frustration with the corporation's regulators was renewed this year when they approved the decision of Greg Dyke, the director general, to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm at short notice. But it is understood that Number 10 and the Department of Trade and Industry - which is producing the white paper with Mr Smith's Department for Culture, Media and Sport - feel that a "gung-ho" attitude against the BBC would be unwise just before the election. The white paper - the basis for a later communications bill should Labour be re-elected - will underscore the need for reform but will not give a definite blueprint. This means that ministers do not have to set out their views now: further consultation will take place before legislation in the next parliament. In drafting the white paper, there have been tensions between the DTI, the DCMS and Downing Street policy advisers. Mr Smith was furious at the BBC's decision to move its nightly news, and the apparent complicity of the BBC governors' chairman, Sir Christopher Bland. The culture secretary was particularly irritated by Sir Christopher's response that Mr Smith was simply "a licence fee payer and therefore entitled to his view". Mr Smith said yesterday that he would be watching "very carefully" viewing figures and programme quality after the move from the 9pm slot. "If we are seeing a diminution of news, in quality and audience of news, then I think the governors of the BBC have to think very seriously about what they are going to do," Mr Smith told BBC 1's Breakfast with Frost. Downing Street has significant doubts about taking on the BBC when the fight could be postponed until after the election, a view shared by the DTI. "There's a huge battle going on between the DTI and the DCMS over the BBC particularly," said a policy-maker at a national broadcaster. Publicly, the BBC opposes the idea of placing the board of governors under the auspices of an independent regulator. Privately, senior policy-makers at the organisation concede that change is inevitable. "The devil will be in the detail," one said - the corporation will accept independent monitoring of programme standards and public complaints, but will fight to retain its influence over the BBC's remit and editorial independence. The white paper will also map the way towards a single ITV company. At the moment, the network has two major broadcasters, Carlton and Granada, with several lesser players. Strict rules prevent any further consolidation. Recent reports that the way towards one network would be barred are understood to have been wide of the mark. The white paper will signal a big upheaval in the way television, broadcasting and newspapers are regulated. For the first time, the different media will be treated globally, rather than separately. Rules on cross-media ownership will be more flexible, and one regulator will oversee the whole industry. Arguments over the detail have delayed publication of the white paper several times, and it is now due to be released on December 12. Baroness Jay, Labour's leader in the Lords, yesterday angrily rejected suggestions that she was seeking to succeed Sir Christopher as "complete fiction". Her spokeswoman said that Lady Jay was "bemused" by a report in yesterday's Sunday Times linking her to the chairmanship of the governors because she told the newspaper on Saturday night that its information was wholly inaccurate. "This is complete and utter rubbish," the spokeswoman said. "Margaret has no plans to become the chair of the BBC."

webTitle: Prisons inspector says 'barbaric' youth jails must shut

fields.headline: Youth jails 'must be closed'
fields.standfirst: Prisons inspector urges Home Secretary to shut down 'barbaric' young offender institutions
fields.trailText: Youth prisons have become barbaric warehouses that should be closed immediately, according to the Chief Inspector of Prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham.
fields.body:
Youth prisons have become barbaric warehouses that should be closed immediately, according to the Chief Inspector of Prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham.

His comments were made against a background of increasing reports of violence, brutality and death in Britain's young offender institutions. Up to 90 percent of young people leaving prison reoffend within two years.

Ramsbotham, who has become increasingly outspoken in his demands for penal reform, said: 'If I had the power to do it, I would close these places and do it bloody quickly'. He said he was frustrated he did not have the same powers to intervene as other regulatory bodies, such as the Office of the Rail Regulator or the schools inspectorate Ofsted.

He said he had become increasingly irritated by the refusal of the Home Office and the Prison Service to act on his recommendations. Last year he described Feltham, Europe's largest youth jail in west London, as 'rotten to the core' and 'unacceptable in a civilised country'. He told The Observer that, although conditions in the juvenile wing of the prison had improved, they were still appalling for over-18s.

The only problem with closing young offender institutions, he said, was that there was nowhere else for the offenders to go. The number of children and young people in prison custody increased by 11 percent this year, to around 3,000.

He also confirmed reports in last week's Observer that he had been appalled by conditions at young offender institutions at Brinsford in Wolverhampton and Stoke Heath in Shropshire. 'What more can I do than say again and again that conditions in these prisons are unacceptable,' he said.

Ramsbotham said the responsibility for the 'completely inexcusable' treatment of young people in the prison system lay with the Home Secretary, Jack Straw, and the director of the Prison Service, Martin Narey. The Chief Inspector is especially critical of the number of 15 and 16-year-olds being held on remand while awaiting trial.

According to figures released to Parliament this week, in Feltham alone the figure has risen by more than 50 percent this year, from 91 at the end of March to 166 at the beginning of last month.

'You don't leave a 15-year-old locked up for 23 hours with nothing to do. There is literally no excuse for that,' Ramsbotham said. Problems at Feltham that had led to the murder of 19-year-old Zahid Mubarak by a mentally unstable cellmate known for his racist views were replicated throughout the system.

'This has to go right to the top. From the Home Secretary and the head of the Prison Service to the prison officer on the landing: the problem is that no one is taking responsibility and no one is accountable,' Ramsbotham said. 'Someone should be appointed to take full responsibility for prisoners under the age of 18 and another person for 18 to 20-year-olds.'

Ramsbotham has backed a report by the Church of England's Children's Society, to be published later this week, which will call for an end to the practice of imprisoning 15 and 16-year-olds on remand, which it believes is in breach of the new Human Rights Act. The long-term aim of the Children's Society is the ending of all custodial sentences for under-18s.

Britain locks up more young people than almost any other West European country and a child becomes responsible for a crime at the age of 10. This compares with 12 in Turkey and 18 in Belgium and Luxembourg. The Children's Society report will highlight horrifying new evidence that shows that half of all young people in prison have diagnosable mental illnesses. Last year there were more than 900 incidents of self-harm by young people in prison, including slashed wrists and eating glass.

Dorset police are now investigating 35 cases of alleged assault at the Portland young offender institutions where prison officers were said to run a military-style regime.

Frances Crook of the Howard League for Penal Reform, which provided evidence for the Portland inquiry, said: 'We all know that locking up young people in long-term institutions is damaging to them and damaging to us all. Because of the high rates of reoffending, we are probably creating more victims of crime this way. If there were 1,000 furry animals being held in these conditions, there would be demonstrations every day.'

The Liberal Democrat MP Dr Vincent Cable, chairman of the all-party police group, said last night: 'We have to question whether they should be closed altogether because they are doing more harm than good. Despite repeated warnings, nothing has been done to change the situation at all.

fields.headline: My New Media
fields.standfirst:
Stuart Gates

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: Stuart Gates
fields.body:
Favourite sites? Well ours, obviously. Also, ft.com and the Telegraph. I find easyjet very good for buying flights and I use British Airways as well. When I'm at home with my seven-year-old son I tend to migrate to the formulaone.co.uk website which is a good one for youngies as well as oldies like me.

Last online purchase? An item of leisure clothing on rohan.co.uk.

Most recent technological faux pas? I think the most embarrassing thing for me is that my son knows more about these things than I do. Not knowing how to do things properly is always something I find difficult.

Main news sources on the web? ft.com for the business news and the Telegraph because it's a paper that a lot of our customers read and I don't take the paper copy.

Most persistent spam emailer? I suppose there is a number of staff here who sometimes bombard me. My fear for the company is that people will email each other in place of talking. At home, my son is registered with a Pokémon site so they send spam everyday.

Time spent on the web? No more than an hour a day. I'm not a lengthy surfer.

Next boo.com/clickmango? Anyone who is putting short-term investments before long-term benefits. A lot of people thought the web was going to bring reward very quickly but I think it has to be seen as a long-term investment if it's going to be a success. The whole thing would scare me very much if we were a stand-alone business. We're very lucky because we've got established bricks and mortar behind us and we've got experience of mail order custom as well.

Least useful site/s on web? Any site that tries to be too clever. Too many flashy things and banner advertising really turn me off.

Most useful site/s on web? The news and the airline schedules are really useful, I think.

What screensaver do you use? I don't.

Most irritating thing about the web? The speed still. And the fact that there's no standard way to navigate your way around sites because they're all so different.

Do you bother with old media? Very much so. I still take papers and a lot of journals. Maybe they're there and I just haven't searched properly for them yet, but at the moment I'm happy getting them on paper.

 Stuart Gates is MD of Fortnum & Mason which is selling a range of Christmas hampers and gifts on its website fortnumandmason.com

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: Dot.coms in trouble do the strangest things: Beleaguered youth website ebop is going for the business-as-usual approach despite running out of cash and shedding staff.
fields.body:
Dot.coms in trouble do the strangest things (no 1): Beleaguered youth website ebop is going for the business-as-usual approach despite running out of cash and shedding staff. Although it is still only November, the office manager - one of four people left - was clocked putting up Christmas decorations after seven staff were laid off without pay. Why? He's American and thought it might cheer up remaining workers. Let's hope the Christmas cheer did the trick.

 On Tuesday the Daily Mail whipped itself into a frenzy about Oftel's long-overdue nudge to BT to increase unmetered access capacity, and splashed the story across the front page. Other papers gave the story proper treatment. Funny thing is that not only is the Oftel faux-pressure irrelevant to most ISPs because they don't give a monkey's hoot about unmetered access, but the next day Oftel was pummelled by the DTI for its lily-livered approach to the whole issue. The irony is that while the Mail got giddy over Oftel, it completely missed Jack Straw's cybercop initiative aimed at stamping out internet paedophilia. Is it posssible that the Mail has a confused internet policy?

*Compare and contrast. January 2000: "Wowgo is clearly positioned to become the market leading brand serving this valuable [teen girl] community," says Geoffrey Chamberlain, chairman of Durlacher, not ing that investors spent "two years of extensive research and development" on Wowgo. November 2000, statement from Wowgo and backers: "The company has been unable to raise further funding to continue development of its operations". Why did Durlacher and Unilever pull out? Another case of dot.com over-indulgence perhaps. The market is perplexed as to how Wowgo ever managed to spend £6m in less than six months. When will they learn?

*Only four days left to nominate the sexiest male and female in new media for the second Boobnight (Boobnight.co.uk) awards in December. It promises to be a controversial, fiercely fought-out affair with those strident boobnight honchos sticking their necks out and banning Martha Lane Fox because she's never found the time to make it to a Boobnight. How cruel.

*Welcome to Surfed, another pointless free monthly internet magazine. The launch issue of "the first free internet magazine that will change your life" offers readers the chance to win a vacuum cleaner. Fantastic. The mag, distributed in Sainsbury's and Tesco stores, even has fallen-from-grace Mirror city slickers Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell giving stock market advice. No doubt supermarket shoppers will love it though.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com <A HREF="mailto:amy.vickers@theguardian.com"amy.vickers@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Star-e, star-e sites
fields.standfirst:
First, it was spotty teenage music lovers who threatened the entertainment industry by downloading free music. Now the stars themselves are realising the power their own websites can give them.

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: First, it was spotty teenage music lovers who threatened the entertainment industry by downloading free music. Now the stars themselves are realising the power their own websites can give them.
fields.body:
It is either the biggest threat or the biggest opportunity the entertainment industry has encountered in years. That's what they said about Napster, too, but this is not another article about the peer-to-peer file-sharing phenomenon that enables music lovers to download music for free and is the focus of several high-profile court battles.

No, the latest potentially revolutionary development is "star-to-peer" networking. While the industry moguls have been tearing out their greying hair over spotty, scooter-hopping teenagers taking over their business, the artists themselves have been busy building up their own mini web empires, or at least laying the foundations for a time when they could conceivably bypass the retailer, the distributor, even the record company, and go directly to their fans.

Creative thinkers from David Bowie to Badly Drawn Boy have been using the internet to disseminate their material for almost as long as the internet has been around. In the meantime, fan sites - where you can go to chat about Kylie's new hair colour, or discuss the deep political message behind Eminem's latest lyrics - have become big business. Nsync.com boasts 800,000 unique users; BritneySpears.com, 500,000 and Eminem.com, 300,000 - figures any dot.com would die for.

It is only lately, however, that "brand-name" celebrities, such as Cher and novelist Stephen King, have woken up to the fact that the internet could be their future. And the former Baywatch star Pamela "Don't Call Me Babe" Anderson is about to launch PamTV.com, with assistance from the incubator Digital Media Campus. The trailer says it will offer everything from video clips to personalised photos, greetings cards and other exciting merchandise (what else would you want?). The fact that the founders haven't yet figured out how to make money from it doesn't matter. Despite 350,000 fan sites already dedicated to Pammy, they are halfway to digital domination. Why go anywhere else when you can get the real thing on PamTV, and start a pension plan for her?

The recent skirmishes between record companies and artists such as Courtney Love, The Offspring and Aimee Mann is an early indication of what the industry feels about stars "going behind their backs". When punk rockers The Offspring declared they would release their new album Conspiracy of One over the web as MP3 a month before the official release, their label, Columbia, ordered their manager to withdraw immediately or face the consequences. Meanwhile Courtney Love (a longtime member of the netterati) and her band Hole are still in dispute with their label, Geffen records, over Love's threats to distribute their music on the web.

Solo artist Mann, however, had no choice but to release her third album online after she was dropped by her label, Interscope. On her website www.aimeemann.com she launches into a polemic against her former employers and warns her fans off Aimee Mann - the Ultimate Collection, a "sub-standard and misleading" product, released without her permission.

For many artists, divided from their fans by several degrees of management, the net is a chance to wrest back creative control. Cult solo artist Momus, who was signed to Alan McGee's Creation Records in the 1980s, took matters into his own hands in 1995. He built a home studio, started designing his own record sleeves on a Mac and got a website www.demon.co.uk/momus where he could centralise his words, images and sounds. His 1999 album Stars Forever offered fans "portrait songs" on commission. He sold two a day and made $30,000 (£21,000). He points out that if he had been able to keep up the output, he would have made $730,000 that year.

"For me, it's about taking control of the means of production. Being signed to Creation was exciting, but also frustrating. They'd do all the things that artists are not supposed to be able to do, but they'd do them badly. There would be horrible artwork bungles (your face would be blurred or smeared), marketing campaigns directed solely at spotty guitar music fans in paisley shirts, press releases and ads marred by poor spelling and terrible syntax." Other artists, such as the Cuban Boys, Ani di Franco, kd lang and DJ Scissorkicks, who have turned to the net for alternative marketing techniques, would probably agree.

Bowienet (www.davidbowie.com), the fansite and "rock's coolest ISP", demonstrates just how masterful a marketing medium the net can be. On top of the conventional fan fare - chatrooms, music archive, biography, the avuncular "Ask David" service and so on - you can buy original Bowie artwork (at New York gallery prices), artwork of art students vetted by David, as well as CDs and downloads.

What Bowie devotee could resist this heartfelt request on the homepage from the reinvented cyber-Starman: "[use the message boards and email more please] and we'll continue to grow by leaps and bounds, I believe, and this gives me a lovely, gooey, sticky kind of fun-filled feeling"?

Other official fansites that have grown enormously and are now threatening to become media channels are www.normancook.net (Fat Boy Slim's award-winning fansite) www.bjork.com (a recent merger between the two biggest bjork sites), www.Cher.com and www.marilynmanson.com. Sting also obviously had plans for www.sting.com, the web domain that he tried, but failed, to "claim back" in a recent arbitration case, and we should watch out for further developments at www.-Madonna.com, the domain name the star recently won.

Is the Fan.com phenomenon something that should be keeping the suits at Warners and EMI awake at night? Chris Cass, MD of Vitaminic.co.uk, a digital A&R network that aggregates artists' sites, thinks they are worried and with good cause. "They spend all their money branding artists, and suddenly these brands are getting legs of their own. They're weighing up their options at the moment. To all these web upstarts, they are offering two alternatives: either capitulate, or play the game. Basically, they are afraid of creating another MTV - they don't want to have to spend ridiculous amounts of money on advertising something which they can't control."

Marc Geiger, CEO of the Artist Direct.com, a network that enables fans to get everything they want about their favourite band or artist in one place and provides artists such as Marilyn Manson, Beck, Rage, Mandy Moore, Korn, Neil Young and the Beastie Boys with their own media channels, has no doubt that "star-to-peer" direct marketing is the biggest shake-up the industry has had in years. But he does not see it as a threat. "The opportunity [for the industry] is far greater. Of course artists still need their record company relationships, their distribution offline, they still need marketing promotion. Direct marketing is a piece of the action, not a substitute."

Geiger believes the net has created "multiple new revenue buckets" for the artists and distributors, who are partners on the site. For the artists, it's a chance to expand their traditional income (from recording, publishing, merchandising and touring) to retail, e-commerce (online ticketing being a big hit) and advertising. More importantly, in the long term they can capture the data of their fans for the first time and build up a global network.

Geiger admits that it is still early days for artists on the net. "Only if the artist puts themself fully into it is it going to work. Yes, when Courtney Love gets on the bulletin board to have a rant, it lights up like a Christmas tree, but not all artists have the time." Perhaps in 10 years, he speculates, we will see the Oasis.net lifestyle community or the Spice World virtual theme park.

The day may indeed come when artists will free themselves of their management shackles and stand alone as brands, communities and retail outlets unto themselves. A few obvious ones, such as Madonna and Prince, are there already. It is more likely, however, that artists will continue to sit back and allow people to make money for them. After all, as Geiger points out, "Rock stars don't as a general rule drive their own limos, tune their own guitars, or produce their own records." So why would they start now?

When punk rockers The Offspring declared they would release their new album Conspiracy of One over the web as MP3 a month before the official release, their label, Columbia, ordered their manager to withdraw immediately or face the consequences. Meanwhile Courtney Love (a longtime member of the netterati) and her band Hole are still in dispute with their label, Geffen records, over Love's threats to distribute their music on the web. Solo artist Mann, however, had no choice but to release her third album online after she was dropped by her label, Interscope. On her website www.aimeemann.com she launches into a polemic against her former employers and warns her fans off Aimee Mann - the Ultimate Collection, a "sub-standard and misleading" product, released without her permission. For many artists, divided from their fans by several degrees of management, the net is a chance to wrest back creative control. Cult solo artist Momus, who was signed to Alan McGee's Creation Records in the 1980s, took matters into his own hands in 1995. He built a home studio, started designing his own record sleeves on a Mac and got a website www.demon.co.uk/momus where he could centralise his words, images and sounds. His 1999 album Stars Forever offered fans "portrait songs" on commission. He sold two a day and made $30,000 (£21,000). He points out that if he had been able to keep up the output, he would have made $730,000 that year. "For me, it's about taking control of the means of production. Being signed to Creation was exciting, but also frustrating. They'd do all the things that artists are not supposed to be able to do, but they'd do them badly. There would be horrible artwork bungles (your face would be blurred or smeared), marketing campaigns directed solely at spotty guitar music fans in paisley shirts, press releases and ads marred by poor spelling and terrible syntax." Other artists, such as the Cuban Boys, Ani di Franco, kd lang and DJ Scissorkicks, who have turned to the net for alternative marketing techniques, would probably agree. Bowienet (www.davidbowie.com), the fansite and "rock's coolest ISP", demonstrates just how masterful a marketing medium the net can be. On top of the conventional fan fare - chatrooms, music archive, biography, the avuncular "Ask David" service and so on - you can buy original Bowie artwork (at New York gallery prices), artwork of art students vetted by David, as well as CDs and downloads. What Bowie devotee could resist this heartfelt request on the homepage from the reinvented cyber-Starman: "[use the message boards and email more please] and we'll continue to grow by leaps and bounds, I believe, and this gives me a lovely, gooey, sticky kind of fun-filled feeling"? Other official fansites that have grown enormously and are now threatening to become media channels are www.normancook.net (Fat Boy Slim's award-winning fansite) www.bjork.com (a recent merger between the two biggest bjork sites), www.Cher.com and www.marilynmanson.com. Sting also obviously had plans for www.sting.com, the web domain that he tried, but failed, to "claim back" in a recent arbitration case, and we should watch out for further developments at www.-Madonna.com, the domain name the star recently won. Is the Fan.com phenomenon something that should be keeping the suits at Warners and EMI awake at night? Chris Cass, MD of Vitaminic.co.uk, a digital A&R network that aggregates artists' sites, thinks they are worried and with good cause. "They spend all their money branding artists, and suddenly these brands are getting legs of their own. They're weighing up their options at the moment. To all these web upstarts, they are offering two alternatives: either capitulate, or play the game. Basically, they are afraid of creating another MTV - they don't want to have to spend ridiculous amounts of money on advertising something which they can't control." Marc Geiger, CEO of the Artist Direct.com, a network that enables fans to get everything they want about their favourite band or artist in one place and provides artists such as Marilyn Manson, Beck, Rage, Mandy Moore, Korn, Neil Young and the Beastie Boys with their own media channels, has no doubt that "star-to-peer" direct marketing is the biggest shake-up the industry has had in years. But he does not see it as a threat. "The opportunity [for the industry] is far greater. Of course artists still need their record company relationships, their distribution offline, they still need marketing promotion. Direct marketing is a piece of the action, not a substitute." Geiger believes the net has created "multiple new revenue buckets" for the artists and distributors, who are partners on the site. For the artists, it's a chance to expand their traditional income (from recording, publishing, merchandising and touring) to retail, e-commerce (online ticketing being a big hit) and advertising. More importantly, in the long term they can capture the data of their fans for the first time and build up a global network. Geiger admits that it is still early days for artists on the net. "Only if the artist puts themself fully into it is it going to work. Yes, when Courtney Love gets on the bulletin board to have a rant, it lights up like a Christmas tree, but not all artists have the time." Perhaps in 10 years, he speculates, we will see the Oasis.net lifestyle community or the Spice World virtual theme park. The day may indeed come when artists will free themselves of their management shackles and stand alone as brands, communities and retail outlets unto themselves. A few obvious ones, such as Madonna and Prince, are there already. It is more likely, however, that artists will continue to sit back and allow people to make money for them. After all, as Geiger points out, "Rock stars don't as a general rule drive their own limos, tune their own guitars, or produce their own records." So why would they start now?

fields.headline: Success without excess
fields.standfirst: Six months as editor of the News of the World and Rebekah Wade is putting the squeeze, says Roy Greenslade MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: By the end of this week Rebekah Wade will have completed six months at the News of the World, having edited around 26 issues. So how has she done since replacing Phil Hall?
fields.body:
By the end of this week Rebekah Wade will have completed six months at the News of the World, having edited around 26 issues. So how has she done since replacing Phil Hall?

Let's start with the main controversy: the name-and-shame campaign that undoubtedly put Wade on the map. Few newspaper initiatives have provoked as big and sustained a public row, and none has led to such disgraceful outbursts of intemperate, and ill-informed, vigilante action.

Following the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne, Wade's attempt "to protect Britain's kids from perverts" by identifying a rogue's gallery of alleged paedophiles aroused roughly equal amounts of wrath and applause.

Her aim was to pressure the government into enacting "Sarah's Law", making a register of convicted paedophiles available to the public. But it was pressure on her from the authorities that quickly forced the abandonment of the naming-and- shaming aspect of her campaign. There were too many instances of mobs taking the law into their own hands, with virtually indiscriminate attacks on houses and people.

I never doubted Wade's sincerity. I also accepted that it was not a cynical exercise to raise sales. But it was dangerous. As a friend wrote to me: "What am I expected to do with the information Rebekah gives me if my neighbour is a paedophile, except to ensure he is no longer my neighbour?"

On the other hand, in my local Brighton pub, I heard nothing but praise for the News of the World. This was her core audience and her populist crusade is certainly the major reason circulation suddenly leaped back above 4m by August.

It is a campaign Wade is unlikely to win, but the recent decline in sales probably has little to do with that. Part of it is due to the inexorable downward trend for Sunday red-tops. The problem for all of them is how to survive in the face of growing apathy. Is there something wrong with the old formula of sex and sport? Is closure inevitable, or dare they try another course? How do they accommodate changes in society?

My reading of the News of the World under Wade suggests that it is trying to introduce an entirely different editorial agenda from that of her predecessors. There is still sin, of course. The revelations about the private life of Liberal Democrat peer Lord Holme, forcing him to resign as chairman of the broadcasting standards commission, were a sad reminder of the paper's past excesses. The public interest defence, that he was a moral arbiter, was paper thin. He didn't really warrant exposure.

But the NoW's sexual content now is generally less intrusive, relying more on titillating pictures than sordid copy. A story two weeks ago about "an orgy" involving pop star Martine McCutcheon's boyfriend stopped well short of embarrassing him.

In these days of safe sex, the News of the World now appears to be wearing a metaphorical condom. Even its exposure of Frank Bruno's alleged misbehaviour with a prostitute was noticeably restrained, as was a romp featuring EastEnders actor Michael Greco.

Many more pages are devoted to politics, though I can't see what qualities columnist Sion Simon has that his sacked predecessor Richard Stott lacks. Last week Julie Burchill was given a full page to profile Hillary Clinton, and the leader page was also devoted to the American election. It's impossible not to be struck by the paper's gradual, if hesitant, move towards the middle market, becoming a kind of red-top Mail on Sunday, or even a red-top Sunday Times. If the intention is to give it a Mail-style feel then it could well explain the baffling decision by Rupert Murdoch and his Wapping supremo, Les Hinton, to fire Hall at the end of May after five reasonably successful years.

Perhaps they thought he couldn't have carried through the kind of changes necessary to take the NoW into a new direction. News of the World editors have always faced difficulty in dealing with Murdoch who - despite the absurd Dirty Digger stereotype - has always preferred a less salacious paper.

Yet the whole ethos of the news and features operation is imbued with scandalous exposure. It's what the executives and reporters know and do best, and previous editors, while acknowledging Murdoch's strictures, could not ignore the weekly ration of sales-winning filth presented to them. Scared of sales falling too rapidly, they found it impossible to satisfy both the diktats of their boss and the appetites of their audience. Hall, as others did, therefore tried to steer a path between the two.

Wade appears to be on her way, if gradually, to a wholesale change. To help in her transformation she is being rewarded with substantial investment. In January, the paper is to be revamped into three distinct sections. There are rumours that its Sunday magazine is to become a 48-page Hello!-OK!-style celebrity-led glossy. Then there will an entirely separate TV and listings section, thought to be 56 pages. Both are evidently in dummy form and undergoing market research.

That kind of package could well make the going even tougher for the NoW's rivals - the Sunday Mirror and the People. The Mirror, after a brief moment of hope following a direct-mail initiative, is just about holding on to a regular 1.9m sale. The People, losing sales at a dizzying 5% a year, despite a lively editorial blend, is now down below 1.5m.

Wade's NoW therefore has a mammoth lead and she can, if she has her management's full support, dare to take risks. That "if" is important though. Underlying all that I've said is the implication that Murdoch, Hinton and Wade are united in their vision of a new millennial News of the World.

My hunch is that they certainly agree in outline, if not yet in detail. Wade has been given her head and it's up to her to strike the right balance. This is no easy task because much of the decision-making is a matter of nuance: "sexy" is acceptable, while "sleazy" is not; serious is good, dullness is unforgiveable.

But how does one draw the line? And what happens if a rival, spotting the NoW moving away from its old habits, tries to take advantage by invading its former territory? Murdoch, his eye always on both circulation and advertising revenue num bers, hates to see any sacrifice in sales and income, and will want Wade to accomplish her revolution without losing copies.

Given the decline of the market, and the likelihood of desertions among readers who, in the words of a rival journalist, "only buy the Screws for the shagging", it is surely impossible to expect the traditional reader to stay while Wade increases serious content at the expense of the trivial.

It will mean a good deal of trimming week after week as Wade tries to maintain that balance. So this is an appropriate moment to offer a warning to people in public life currently indulging in philandering, or thinking about it. Those News of the World investigators haven't gone away, you know. A couple of bad sales weeks and the lads will be on your tail. Wade may not relish sexual exposure, but she still knows the value of a juicy tale.

fields.headline: The future of TV? Ask Kofi Annan
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Net news
fields.trailText: New York is big. Not only is it big, it's also wired. So the city that never sleeps is always on. New jargon, old truths. That's what I told everyone here, in my role as a so-called "digital visionary", invited by the UN to a conference on the future of television.
fields.body:
New York is big. Not only is it big, it's also wired. So the city that never sleeps is always on. New jargon, old truths. That's what I told everyone here, in my role as a so-called "digital visionary", invited by the UN to a conference on the future of television.

It's a closely guarded secret of the digerati that old media truths will still have major clout in the new world. If advertisers want to sell their products, why not wrap them around a highly compelling piece of content? We all know the tune, but it's not quite the same old song . . .

What is changing is the context in which we view television. It's no longer merely via that box in the corner of our living rooms. This change will be accentuated by bigger bandwidth networks - in other words broadband technology. In the future, televisual content will be accessed by TVs, PCs, wireless devices and who knows what else.

When media-rich content is combined with high-speed interactivity on any device, anywhere at any time, Future TV Inc will be closer to realisation.

We will then see the development of what we term Lush Programming - multi-layered content that can be watched, played with, talked to, and personalised.

This content will be scaleable to different devices with a variety of screen sizes and resolutions and, like great TV now, will be based on innovative and compelling ideas. This type of proposition is an adman's dream.

Filthy lucre is, of course, what provides us with the majority of our funding. The ability to build a direct relationship with viewers, acquire new customers, and sell products will inevitably attract marketing spend.

Broadband trial results in Europe indicate that consumers' willingness to buy online is around eight times higher than existing narrowband technology. This is because of the quality of content, speed and convenience.

In New York, I talked the usual talk, but I don't know what the future of TV will be either. If I did, I would keep it to myself. The people that matter are those with the balls to come up with formats such as Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and, dare I say it, Big Brother.

Big ideas will always break down technology barriers and allow viewers to focus on the content. Forget about Enhanced TV, it's all about enhancing the viewer's experience. The best technology is invisible whatever the device.

I have never been one to allow a 10-minute speech at the UN to stand in the way of a four-day trip. I've been spending time in local bars, health food shops and Manhattan coffee houses talking over the finer points of the US internet experience.

Free local calls and a superior technology backbone means fast and cheap access. Broadband penetration now reaches 5m US homes. The ABC network has been running an interactive version of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? over the web. Viewers can watch the show and play along via their PCs. Interactive Millionaire has proved to be a staggering success for those with PCs in the same room as their TVs.

T here's the rub. This would not yet fly in the UK, where we have much lower home internet penetration, bandwidth restrictions and predominantly use home PCs for information and services rather than entertainment. As a result, not many of us have plonked our PCs in the comfortable surroundings of our living room. TV still dominates that space.

However, in many areas, Europe has a distinct advantage over the US. We are way ahead in digital TV and wireless penetration. If we can learn from the US broadband experience and add our own creative vision, Europe will become the hothouse for interactive television and "lush programming" concepts.

In the UK, 99% of homes have a TV, and the mobile market is still booming. Crucially, there need not be any seismic shift in culture. If we already have these devices, broadband will merely mean better content on these platforms. Fantastic. Who cares about the technology?

So, the future of TV? Big question. I didn't run into Kofi Annan because he was musing on the Middle East and other worldly matters. If I had spoken to him, I would have certainly asked his opinion. One thing I did hear was that, whatever the device and wherever he is, he likes his internet "over-easy". That'll do nicely for me too.

 Jason George is creative director of Victoria Real

webTitle: Are ad agencies still prejudiced against women?

fields.headline: Creative tension
fields.standfirst:
Are ad agencies still prejudiced against women? Christine Walker looks at a new report that reveals the best and worst of the industry.

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Are ad agencies still prejudiced against women? Christine Walker looks at a new report that reveals the best and worst of the industry.
fields.body:
Debbie Klein's report on women in advertising is valuable and timely - if only to remind us what a fabulous business it is and to congratulate ourselves (women, that is) on doing so well. In terms of numbers, it's a tiny business (13,000); in terms of impact on UK plc, it's really significant.

But her research has found some unappetising examples of laddish culture in creative departments. Bizarrely, there are tales of pool tables being installed by the blokes as a symbol of masculinity. I know there are some ad agencies where the testosterone level hits you at the front door, and you know there will be only one token female inside, but I'm sure this is changing. In my own field of media planning and buying, most of the media owners are men, but the worst incident I have come across was when, in front of a client, an ad agency colleague called me "dear".

Women are hugely influential in the ad business. We make up half the staff in the industry and a third more of us are in professional roles than 10 years ago. We now occupy 22% of the most senior staff positions and 9% of agency management posts. But do these statistics really matter?

During the past decade there was an obsession with the "names above the door" of ad agencies. If women displayed their names more, they might be more visible. Nowadays ad agencies are more collaborative, more into team-working, and call themselves St Luke's, Mother or Circus, rather than Saatchi & Saatchi.

The important thing is to get the right mix of people, qualities and attitudes. At Walker Media, I've got a male partner (and I've managed to keep his name off the door). He's much cleverer than I am, but I've got more energy. We both recognise that. Let's not haggle over numbers.

This report reflects some interesting social trends. Women in the ad business want a better balance between life and work. But so do men. As the author says, "What was once a women's issue is now a human issue." The fact that advertising is no longer the only sexy business in town poses a threat to the ad industry. It risks losing talented women and men - those who are already in the industry and those who might be contemplating it as a career.

When I started, I played the double bass. And hockey and tennis. I soon realised that I didn't have time to pursue them. But I did find time to have two children.

What we've got to recognise is that if we want to attract talent, we must, as far as possible, accommodate the aspirations and ambitions of the people who are drawn to this exciting business. If that means saying yes to flexi-time arrangements and part-time jobs, let's find a way to make it work.

People in the ad business work long hours at full creative stretch. We'd be crazy to lose good people just because they want to work part-time. I believe clients not only understand that but are experiencing the same challenges in their own businesses.

In terms of recruitment and management, the ad industry has to grow up. It shouldn't pretend to clients that someone is working five days a week when they're not. We should say: "This is a fantastic person: they will make a great contribution to your business."

We should offer our people managed careers, not just jobs. Graduates coming on the job market these days are debt-ridden, and already anxious about their financial security. Working in the ad industry is not a difficult sell to new recruits. But those of us who have prospered have an obligation to keep the business healthy. We should improve our involvement with universities. And once we've attracted bright individuals, we should be generous and imaginative about recognising their needs and rewarding their work.

 Christine Walker is a partner in Walker Media. Women in Advertising: 10 Years On, by Debbie Klein, is available from the IPA (www.ipa.co.uk)
