During the past decade there was an obsession with the "names above the door" of ad agencies. If women displayed their names more, they might be more visible. Nowadays ad agencies are more collaborative, more into team-working, and call themselves St Luke's, Mother or Circus, rather than Saatchi & Saatchi. The important thing is to get the right mix of people, qualities and attitudes. At Walker Media, I've got a male partner (and I've managed to keep his name off the door). He's much cleverer than I am, but I've got more energy. We both recognise that. Let's not haggle over numbers. This report reflects some interesting social trends. Women in the ad business want a better balance between life and work. But so do men. As the author says, "What was once a women's issue is now a human issue." The fact that advertising is no longer the only sexy business in town poses a threat to the ad industry. It risks losing talented women and men - those who are already in the industry and those who might be contemplating it as a career. When I started, I played the double bass. And hockey and tennis. I soon realised that I didn't have time to pursue them. But I did find time to have two children. What we've got to recognise is that if we want to attract talent, we must, as far as possible, accommodate the aspirations and ambitions of the people who are drawn to this exciting business. If that means saying yes to flexi-time arrangements and part-time jobs, let's find a way to make it work. People in the ad business work long hours at full creative stretch. We'd be crazy to lose good people just because they want to work part-time. I believe clients not only understand that but are experiencing the same challenges in their own businesses. In terms of recruitment and management, the ad industry has to grow up. It shouldn't pretend to clients that someone is working five days a week when they're not. We should say: "This is a fantastic person: they will make a great contribution to your business." We should offer our people managed careers, not just jobs. Graduates coming on the job market these days are debt-ridden, and already anxious about their financial security. Working in the ad industry is not a difficult sell to new recruits. But those of us who have prospered have an obligation to keep the business healthy. We should improve our involvement with universities. And once we've attracted bright individuals, we should be generous and imaginative about recognising their needs and rewarding their work.  Christine Walker is a partner in Walker Media. Women in Advertising: 10 Years On, by Debbie Klein, is available from the IPA (www.ipa.co.uk)

fields.headline: Next stop the world
fields.standfirst:
The Economist is to revamp. Editor-in-chief Bill Emmott tells Maggie Brown about his global ambition.

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Economist is to revamp. Editor-in-chief Bill Emmott tells Maggie Brown about his global ambition.
fields.body:
The Economist insists it is a weekly newspaper - not a business magazine. Though with its relentless championing of free markets, "viewspaper" is surely more accurate. And from the moment you step inside its London headquarters off St James's Street and hang your coat on a stand crafted from an artful collection of sticks, you know you're a far cry from Grub Street.

The tall, thin and ugly building has amazing views from its goggle-eyed windows, and not of Canary Wharf. From the boardroom, you look due south into the heart of Westminster. From editor-in-chief Bill Emmott's corner eyrie the view is due west over Green Park and into the sunset. A fine contemporary art collection lines the corridor walls (a former chief executive now runs the Royal Academy). Even the mugs in which the amiable, precise Emmott - who earned a cool £586,000 last year - produces afternoon tea are decorated with an Economist cartoon.

Does this breed a master-of-the- universe mentality? Economist salaries are high enough to tempt anyone Emmott wants. And on top of that staffers receive an annual bonus related to performance (last year it amounted to 38% of salaries), and 20% of them own shares in the company. This munificence sugars the pill of the title's celebrated ban on bylines, designed to reinforce its authority and hide its use of freelance stringers.

"I don't think we're arrogant," Emmott insists. "We argue a lot. We're a Marxist-style collective really - we're the most pro-free market collective ever invented. We have a great, argumentative character, and the great thing [as editor] is that you know the argument will go on in front of you and you can pick the winner."

Though best known for its political and economic coverage, the publication which relishes ticking off Gordon Brown and gets excited by the American election photo-finish, also has an eclectic, ideas-driven side. Three weeks ago it ran a feature about British design education. It runs erudite book reviews, and advises you to run along to Sunday morning concerts at the Wallace Collection. Executive editor Anthony Gottlieb popped up last month as a guest on Radio 4's Start the Week, having written a philosophy book, Dream of Reason, while also running the magazine's expanding website, economist.com.

Emmott himself is the author of two respected books on Japan's polit ical economy. After a shy start he amused a packed Media Society dinner earlier this year by jousting with another ex-Economist chief executive, Marjorie Scardino, still the only woman running a FTSE 100 company. Pearson, which she now runs, owns 50% of the Economist.

In the New Year, this great British brand - originally conceived in 1843 to further the cause of free trade during the ferment provoked by the Corn Laws - will undergo its first full redesign since 1987, and Emmott plans to stir up the current affairs weekly sector with a big circulation drive. Banishing its traditional greyness, the magazine will switch in March to full colour throughout, with more emphasis on pictures. The typefaces are being cleaned up. It will also have a brand-new cover look - although a debate about the size of its masthead title, and just how stripped-down and cool it can afford to be, is still raging.

"We have resisted colour for a long time for two reasons," says Emmott. "One is because our readers thought it was downmarket, that we'd be dumbing down like Newsweek. And it was very expensive and disruptive to our schedules."

Also likely is a change to the name of the Economist's "surveys" ("The name tells you nothing," says Emmott, "it undersells the item"), the celebrated extended essays by staffers on subjects ranging from e-commerce and Islam to marine ecology. And starting next month there will be a new quarterly supplement on technology: "The genome was cracked this summer," says Emmott. "I'd be against just an IT section, but the IT wave is added to by biotechnology, changes to fuel, and so on. It will be a broader magazine within a magazine, connecting these trends, how they disrupt and hopefully improve our lives."

Why the shake-up? "Readers' expectations have changed," Emmott replies. "Colour is no longer an automatic sign of dumbing down, though it could have sent the wrong signals five years ago. And the technology is now there. It's designed to make the paper less inaccessible. Sales [up 4% last year] are growing healthily, but readers' letters and our research says there are barriers to entry: it feels a bit dull, the name is a bit forbidding, and a design that suggests grey and technical loses potential readers."

Especially in Britain, which though it accounts for only 18% of sales - worldwide circulation averages 723,000, with around 125,000 in the UK - generates a large percentage of premium advertising, and has a higher proportion of news-stand casual sales than the global average of 70% mailed to subscribers: as the Economist's sister title, the Financial Times, sells 190,000 copies in the UK, Emmott argues: "I don't see why we shouldn't sell 150,000-200,000 in Britain. It's the same sort of people. We compete in editorial terms."

There is no intention, he insists, of changing content. "We think we have carried a wide range of subjects for ever. Our name hides them." Shorter articles, then? "We've always thought length and depth are not the same thing. There won't be less words, but I don't plan to make articles longer."

The Economist Group's annual report for 2000 makes clear that it is setting itself some pretty ambitious new sales targets, ultimately aiming for 1m worldwide. Emmott, 44, and seven years in the post, says he sees no reason why his paper cannot double its current North American circulation of 324,000 ("we're nowhere near Time or Business Week in saturation"), though he will not tie himself to a timescale.

And worldwide there is scope aplenty. "The number of people feeling comfortable in English is growing all the time. Globalisation is here to stay and we are the house magazine of globalisation. We advocate it and report on it in all its aspects. We aren't a business magazine, we're a magazine that looks at the connections between business and politics, economics and social change, technology and the military. We stand for the interest of the informed, educated, curious person in the inter-connectedness of all these things."

Isn't this a long-winded way of saying the magazine is about power? Emmott disagrees. "Our readers who work for Oxfam aren't interested in power, they're interested in world affairs. I think there's an increasing interest in business coverage, but that's not specifically the market we are in. There is an increased market for serious, sophisticated coverage, in print and television. It's a niche, but a growing niche."

In the UK market, where Emmott inherited a flat 100,000 circulation, he has used different covers from the international edition to boost sales. "Big foreign news sells - the Gulf war, the American election fiasco. But normally local sells a bit better than global on the cover.

"Because of its rapid expansion overseas and its need to serve an international readership, the Economist of the 1980s wasn't paying enough attention to British coverage, which means we didn't have enough depth and didn't have enough impact from its British content.

"The crucial thing I did was to expand the number of British pages from six to nine, but cut to four in overseas issues. That meant I could put British stories on the cover more often, and we did big, meaty pieces on the BBC, the health service, reforming the constitution, Charter 88, transport issues, road pricing."

I asked if the Economist's love of free markets had alienated readers during the 1990s as Britain rediscovered values Thatcherism rejected. Squashed again. "Britain became more free market in the 1990s," Emmott counters. "Blair is a continuation of Thatcher in many ways."

Meanwhile, on the online front Economist.com is being expanded as a privileged site for readers to drive subscriptions, with two-thirds of the content available only to print subscribers. Will the internet take over? Emmott answers without missing a beat: "It depends on what readers want. If they want to get international analysis through the internet rather than print, that's the way we will operate. That's the beginning and end of it. An editor's interest is in the message rather than the medium.

"But for the moment readers are buying print in growing numbers but want something different - print plus internet. The internet is not proving to be a substitute so far."

webTitle: Interview: Editor of the Matlock Mercury

fields.headline: The modest crusader
fields.standfirst:
Don Hale, editor of the Matlock Mercury, has faced death threats and derision in his campaign to free Stephen Downing, who served 27 years in prison for a murder he didn't commit. He tells Jeevan Vasagar how he broke the story

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Don Hale, editor of the Matlock Mercury, has faced death threats and derision in his campaign to free Stephen Downing, who served 27 years in prison for a murder he didn't commit. He tells Jeevan Vasagar how he broke the story.
fields.body:
In the Matlock Mercury's cramped newsroom - a converted record shop storeroom next to Allday's in Matlock high street - editor Don Hale's phone rings every few seconds. The Times is clamouring to speak to him, as is the Express and the Mail on Sunday, then Dutch TV wants a word. Yesterday he appeared on an American lunchtime news bulletin, where he was introduced as "editor of the Matlock Mockery".

Hale is wearing his "anti-establishment" tie - a comedy number with cartoon illustrations of men behind bars. The prisoners are captioned "my lawyer", "my accountant" and "my estate agent". He tries to deal with everyone calmly and politely, agreeing to meet the journalists who want to interview him. He has just put to bed this week's edition of his own paper. Its front page splash - "He's coming home!" - explains the media bedlam.

"I could have done with the cavalry a few years ago, but nobody wanted to know," he says ruefully of the current press interest. For six years, Hale has waged a lonely and occasionally dangerous crusade to reverse the conviction of Stephen Downing, a 17-year-old gardener with learning difficulties, for the 1973 murder of typist Wendy Sewell, in Bakewell, Derbyshire.

Downing, who has served 27 years in what is probably Britain's longest running miscarriage of justice, had his case referred back to the Appeal Court last Tuesday and when Hale and I meet on Thursday, Downing was just days away from freedom.

The local newspaper editor has dug up evidence of inconsistencies in the original police investigation - evidence that casts serious doubt on the semi-literate teenager's conviction. He also uncovered an army of potential witnesses who had either not come forward or been dismissed by the authorities, who could clear Downing and pin the blame on another man, who is alive and well and not in prison.

In doing so, Hale has received death threats which have persuaded him to move house and go ex-directory, and there has been at least one serious attempt on his life. Also, the police threatened to sue him soon after he first broke the story. When he ignored this, the police backed down.

Hale expresses only the mildest frustration that at the very end of the campaign a Sunday newspaper has signed a deal with Downing for his exclusive story of life in prison. The tabloid paper has minders guarding Downing's parents and will not let even Hale speak to the family.

Hale's story is even more remarkable in an era when local papers are increasingly run from distant head offices, where profit-driven executives look on editorial as so many school fete reports filling space between the adverts. "Time is the biggest enemy," he says when asked why this kind of journalism is out of vogue. "You've got to have a gut feeling that you're going to get somewhere at the end of the day. But I felt so strongly that this was an injustice, and I wanted to see it through to its conclusion."

Even Hale had doubts about the case to start with. It is hardly the Mercury's usual fare (headlines from the latest edition of the paid-for weekly include "Praise for fire fight ers", "Four months inside for auto-crime man" and "2,000 plus at latest farmers' market").

Hale remembers, "An attractive young lady had been murdered by a local lad and he'd admitted it at the time. My immediate reaction was - don't touch it with a bargepole. But the more I looked at it the more anomalies there were."

Hale has doggedly pursued the truth. He spent five months investigating between the time Downing's parents first contacted him in 1994 and January 1995 when the Mercury first splashed on the story under the headline "Innocent or guilty ?".

The 48-year-old editor, who heads a team of three young reporters, is a former professional footballer (a "promising junior" for Bury, Blackburn Rovers and York City) who got into journalism through commentating for BBC radio, and freelance sports and feature writing for the Manchester Evening News.

When Hale arrived in Matlock in 1985, transferred from a paper owned by the same publishers, he knew nothing about the Downing case and educated himself from scratch for the campaign. He sifted through court records and newspaper cuttings, knocked on doors and lobbied ministers, including then Home Secretary Michael Howard.

He obtained a court order forcing police to release documents which they had previously denied existed. In the close-knit Peak district town of Bakewell, a place with an old-fashioned sense of neighbourliness, he has ruffled many feathers.

On a dark and rainy night soon after the first exclusive, he was out side the local cinema when a sports car with its lights off accelerated towards him as he stood on the pavement. He dived out of the way and landed in a heap as the car sped off.

"The following day I got a call in the office saying: 'That's your last warning'. The first thing I thought was: 'I'm getting somewhere with this because I've upset these characters.'"

He believes another near-miss with a car, when he was out jogging a few weeks before that, was also an attempt on his life. The hit-and-run attack and the malicious calls were duly reported in the paper.

"It has boosted circulation," Hale admits. "People have been wanting to know what's going on - it's like a soap opera." Other people think he is barmy. But the impression Hale gives is quite the contrary; he comes across as a modest, quietly industrious hack who has built up a head of steam over an issue he cares deeply about.

And Stephen Downing is not the end of it, either. Hale has begun to acquire something of a reputation among prisoners, and has become involved in three other miscarriages of justice. He says he has helped to achieve a release in one, a quashing of a conviction in another, and hopes for a result in the third.

He recalls a prison visit to see Downing, when 20 other inmates lined up as he was walking out. Downing had been attacked in prison, and Hale feared trouble. "Then they introduced themselves. They said: 'We're the innocent brigade.'" For the innocent brigade, journalists such as Hale are often the only hope - and there are all too few of them around.

fields.headline: Great white hope
fields.standfirst:
Flagged as the blueprint for the 'third broadcasting revolution', the communications white paper was intended to transform the media. But will it really deliver?

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Flagged as the blueprint for the 'third broadcasting revolution', the communications white paper was intended to transform the media. But will it really deliver?
fields.byline: Matt Wells, David Teather,  Dan Milmo and Maggie Brown
fields.body:
Amazingly, we look as if we are going to get, in the Communications white paper, a genuinely liberal reform. Half a century of bureaucratic censorship, of nanny telling us what we can and can't see on our televisions, may be over.

The signs are that the white paper will propose that, instead of the regulator drawing up a detailed code for programmes and advertisements, the broadcasters will do the job themselves.

Since this is Britain, we won't go the whole hog - the new regulatory authority which will replace the Independent Television Commission will probably have reserve powers. It will be able to impose sanctions on broadcasters and programme-makers who break their own codes. None the less, it will be a significant change - the state no longer needs the elaborate panoply of control erected since ITV was created in the mid-50s.

Why not? There has not exactly been a widespread public campaign demanding freedom of expression for programme-makers. The main reason is that when people in Whitehall looked at the implications of devising legislation which covered everything from the internet to the BBC they saw that technology was rapidly undermining their elaborate "consumer protection" system. When pornography on the internet is only a couple of clicks away, asking the ITC to police a 9pm watershed begins to look pointless.

Instead, the self-regulation of the telecoms industry and internet service providers has become the model for broadcasting. The regulators themselves have argued for change. The broadcasters could scarcely oppose this, though it had not been high on their list of priorities. And the availability of parental control mechanisms in the new digital receiving equipment demolished a large part of the case for existing constraints.

But, in the end, the underlying logic of the situation, together with a much greater common-sense tolerance among the public at large, plus the fact that we would be unlikely to see much immediate change - the broadcasters would probably import the current codes wholesale - should see this kind of reform through.

There is of course another aspect to the existing nanny culture of broadcasting which liberals like me have always supported - the provision of public service programmes. (Heaven forbid that we should let the market on its own determine what we see on our screens.) Here the prognosis is slightly more dodgy.

The white paper will endorse the continuation of public service broadcasting. It will probably propose various sensible reforms, such as the end of detailed supervision of the schedules. It will try to sort out some of the current anomalies in the way the BBC is governed. It may well try to create a long-term framework in which both the BBC and commercial public service broadcasters have a chance of surviving the arrival of subversive new technologies. But however sympathetic the government, it cannot guarantee the commercial success of ITV and Channel 4 in a world of growing choice.

The cultural differences between the over-30s and the 20somethings are wider than ever. Tim Gardam, Channel 4's director of programmes, argues that one of his biggest tasks is to provide young viewers who have grown up in a multi-channel world with a sense of the value of public service television - a concept to which they are largely indifferent.

The different attitudes are beginning to be apparent in programme-makers as well. But then it is not surprising that a generation that has grown up in the casualised and ratings-dominated world of today's television has not imbibed the values that came automatically to their equivalents in the secure broadcasting organisations of the 70s and 80s. Public service television may be hollowed out from within.

It would be ironic if, in a few years' time, millions of pensioners and middle-aged viewers who want public service television can't get it because the people who make the programmes have no idea how to provide it. I'm not sure the white paper can do much about that.

Chris Smith would make quite a good Anne Robinson. The culture secretary might have some trouble with those Armani heels, but we all know he yearns to host a BBC governors' special of her TV quiz just so he can say to the chairman: "Sir Christopher, you are the weakest link. Goodbye!"

The communications reform white paper is hardly in the same league as a gameshow, but the result was designed to be the same. After the BBC's perceived arrogance towards the last licence fee settlement, and an apparent divine belief in an untrammelled right to delve into the nation's pockets, Smith saw the forthcoming legislation as a chance to clip the wings of an organisation that had got too big for its boots.

Unfortunately for those of us who were relishing the playground scrap that would inevitably have followed, the Guardian has learned that spoilsports at No 10 and the Department of Trade and Industry have confiscated Smith's toys. Instead of radical plans to strip the governors of key powers, the white paper will merely state the options and put off further debate until after the election.

But that is not to say that the white paper will be an anodyne fudge. For, while some of the controversial aspects of broadcasting and telephony legislation have been put on the back-burner, this blueprint for legislation is intended to map out the way towards what Smith himself has termed the "third broadcasting revolution". Getting this right is essential now, because there will be no chance to revisit the legislation for at least a decade after it reaches the statute book.

Those who have seen drafts of the white paper, which is nearing completion, say it is indeed a radical document. For the first time it treats all media, including the internet, telecommunications and traditional broadcasting, as merely different channels of the same multimedia world.

This requires, of course, a major reorganisation of the confused and archaic regulatory system that currently governs broadcasting, the press and telecommunications. It requires, too, a redefinition of how the public interest - and the interests of the public - should be served in this new media age. And it requires a legal framework to ensure that creativity and growth are encouraged, not held back.

For the past year, officials at the Department of Culture and the DTI have been working on this momentous document. Some observers suggest that it has suffered because of the relative inexperience of officials at the DCMS, but publication is now scheduled for December 12. Parliament rises two days later, and if there is any further delay, the white paper will not see the light of day until next year.

But as the finishing touches are put to it, a fairly clear picture is beginning to emerge of the likely feel of the final document.

Regulation

The most eagerly anticipated aspect is the nature of the regulatory framework that the white paper envisages. As expected, an over-arching super-regulator provisionally titled Ofcom will replace the plethora of existing bodies. Into it would go the indepen dent television commission, the broadcasting standards commission, Oftel, the radio authority and - interestingly - the radio communications authority, which awards spectrum space.

It will be a formidable body: many observers had predicted it would have distinct arms to deal with the differing demands of content and economic regulation, but the latest drafts simply talk of one jumbo organisation.

The white paper will spell out most of the areas over which Ofcom will have control. It will also specify that the BBC governors will come under the single regulatory umbrella. But the passages in this part of the document will be distinctly "green" - in other words, they will have the vague language of a parliamentary green paper rather than the traditionally more prescriptive basis of a white paper. Clearly, while Smith wants to wreak revenge on Sir Christopher for his brusqueness (the BBC chairman recently dismissed the culture secretary as just another "licence-fee payer"), he has been leaned on to tone down the language in the run-up to the general election.

The BBC has lobbied hard against the imposition of an independent regulator. In private, the corporation concedes the principle and will rub its hands at the extra time that will now be given to haggle over the detail of what influence Ofcom would have. A senior BBC policy-maker says that the corporation will agree that industry-wide standards on content regulation should apply to the BBC and be monitored externally. The BBC will probably also come under more standard economic regulation on issues such as cross-subsidy of services and cross-promotion on air.

"They have been talking for some time about taking more of a non-executive director type role dealing with issues like strategic direction, monitoring the performance of management and making sure the licence fee payers' money is well spent," one source said. But it will fight tooth and nail any attempt to curb the governors' powers as the "first line of defence", answerable to the licence payers on political impartiality, fairness and the corporation's remit. It seems that, despite losing key policy wonks Patricia Hodgson, Dominic Morris and Robin Foster, it has won the argument.

Consolidation

There is no suggestion, however, of any foundation to last week's reports that the white paper will back away from paving the way towards a single ITV company. The suggestion that the maximum 15% of total audience share rule would be abolished, yet the bar on one company holding both London ITV franchises (LWT and Carlton) would remain, seems absurd and does not appear in any of the white paper drafts seen by Guardian sources. "I'd be staggered if they left this anachronism in there because this bill can't be revisited for years," said one ITV executive.

All the noises from Chris Smith and government so far have suggested strong sympathy with the network being owned by a single company - a sentiment which he has repeated privately to the ITV companies.

At the time of the recent deals, which narrowed the field to two, Smith said publicly that he wanted ITV to be a world-beater. In return, however, Smith seems likely to demand some key concessions on commitment to regional programming - an issue about which he is said to care passionately.

So, it is expected that the audience share-limit will be raised to 25%, after which the competition authorities would decide on whether further mergers could take place. The major radio companies are already aggrieved by existing regulation, which they regard as confused and full of anomalies. One senior radio executive says that Janet Anderson, the minister responsible for broadcasting, has "reasonably clear" views that the ownership limits need to change. If the rules are relaxed, it is expected that many companies will take up small stakes in each other to mark their territory before the legislation is eventually passed - in much the same way that the ITV companies did when ownership limits were lifted. GWR, Capital and Emap have all made it clear they are poised to acquire further businesses if allowed.

But while the march to a digital TV world continues apace, it seems that digital radio will continue to be a Cinderella service. Ministers have decided not to make even the vaguest statement about analogue radio switch-off: "There are no votes in it," said one radio industry executive.

One key issue that the new regulator will have to police is the sensitive area of public service broadcasting. At the moment, all five terrestrial broadcasters have public service obligations of varying degrees, without a clear over-arching idea of what all the various rules are meant to achieve. One regulator who has seen the latest draft says the white paper "has a stab" at defining public service broadcasting in the digital age. It seems that while the BBC retains its strict rules, ITV's "box-ticking" days are over. Possibly in return for higher spectrum fees, the rules that force ITV to broadcast certain hours of religious, arts and other programmes every week will be relaxed in favour of more general guiding principles.

The definition of public service broadcasting, while essentially still based on the "market failure" model, will be widened considerably and it is likely that other broadcasters such as Sky and Discovery will be able to apply to a small central fund that would allow them to make a certain amount of public service programmes too.

Clearly, there will be clear obligations placed upon the terrestrial broadcasters for some time. But there will be changes. An influential paper on content commissioned by the DCMS from Damian Tambini of the Institute of Public Policy Research, and Liz Forgan, a former BBC executive, introduced the concept of a regulatory "league table", ranking the degree of control over channels on a six-point scale, ranging from BBC1 at the top end to the internet at the bottom.

The principle has been taken up, and a higher level of expectation will be placed on free-to-air universal services, such as mainstream BBC, Channel 4 and ITV, than subscription services and specialist niche ones directly paid for by consumers. This is an important - and under-reported - concession, for it means that the government is essentially admitting that it is impossible (and perhaps unnecessary) to regulate vast swathes of modern media.

In the emotive area of cross-media ownership, the white paper will introduce an important new principle: "share of voice." The current rules, for example, ban a newspaper owner with a market share of 20% or more from holding an ITV, Channel 5 or radio franchise. The rationale is to ensure the public has access to a diverse range of "voices".

However, the internet, which provides a bewildering array of voices, has thrown doubt on the need for this kind of social policy. It is also impossible to judge the issue of market share on the net. In this new age of pluralism, it makes no sense to have strict, separate rules on the ownership of newspaper, radio and TV interests when the media has become a multi-platform business.

It is likely, therefore, that the white paper will do away with the different ceilings for the TV, radio and newspaper markets and lump them into a "share of voice" system, which will allow a company to straddle all forms of media.

It is a fine principle, but as with the BBC's arguments over regulation, the devil is in the detail. The bigger media players are sure to demand flexibility, while the minnows are likely to object to any system that threatens their precarious existence.

A further problem is how to com bine the factors of broadcast audience and advertising share with newspaper circulation figures. These will have to be blended into a single points system, so a circulation of 500,000 could be worth 2 units in the share of voice tally, and a 10% slice of terrestrial TV viewers could rack up 4 units.

The government can put off the tough decisions, such as putting a ceiling on the amount of points available to a company, by leaving them to Ofcom. Those who argue for tighter cross-media ownership rules cite the Rupert Murdoch principle: he owns over 20% of the national newspaper market through titles such as the Sun and the News of the World, and has nearly 5m people watching BSkyB. But the horse has already bolted in Murdoch's case, as he has a foothold in the future of broadcasting thanks to BSkyB's market leading position in digital TV.

Clearly, ministers are worried about offending the newspaper groups in the run-up to the general election. "Why have any hostages to fortune if you don't intend to pass this until 2002 anyway?" said one senior newspaper executive. "I think they are becoming a bit risk-averse."

In many areas, there are tensions between the DTI and the DCMS. The DTI is keen to sweep away many of the restrictions but Smith's depart ment is determined to uphold traditional public service values.

Public interest

But while Smith may have lost some ground to No 10 and the DTI, his determination to introduce a powerful consumers' voice appears to have won through. Such a "consumer council" would be a focal point for complaints, dealing with issues like pricing and league tables on quality.

To some extent Smith has already shown his consumer credentials by insisting that the current move to digital - driven by BSkyB, OnDigital and cable - is monitored by an advisory group of consumer/lobbyist representatives, to ensure people are not excluded on price and that the government is not bamboozled into announcing an analogue broadcasting switch-off date too early. It has also extended the list of protected national sporting events, and introduced improved public consultation for BBC new service proposals.

But this does not mean lobbyists such as the National Consumer Council have won the case for a stand-alone statutory consumer watchdog. What seems more likely is that the new body will have a major duty to consult, order research and take soundings through devices including citizens' juries. It certainly means that many of the traditional worries about programme content, fairness, impartiality, the provision of high quality news, privacy, protection of children and the citizen's right of access to high-quality programmes reflecting British society will not be abandoned overnight.

Preparation of this white paper has been long and tortuous. Many of its provisions will be distinctly vague, with plenty more tedious "consultation" ahead - conveniently putting off some decisions until after the next election. Much of the battle will be fought out in Commons committees and in the House of Lords. But, fundamentally, this white paper embodies the hopes of those who believe in the advance of the digital age: the revolution, it seems, is nigh.

fields.headline: Broadcasting Act, 1990
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: * Rules introduced on cross-media holdings to prevent ownership being concentrated in too few hands. National newspaper owners prevented from holding more than a 20% stake in TV companies, with similar restrictions on cross-ownership between commercial TV, satellite TV and national radio stations. Loophole controversially protected Rupert Murdoch on basis that Sky was defined as a non-UK service.
fields.body:
* Rules introduced on cross-media holdings to prevent ownership being concentrated in too few hands. National newspaper owners prevented from holding more than a 20% stake in TV companies, with similar restrictions on cross-ownership between commercial TV, satellite TV and national radio stations. Loophole controversially protected Rupert Murdoch on basis that Sky was defined as a non-UK service.

* Continental companies allowed to bid for licences or take over licence-holders. Companies allowed to own more than one licence: holders of one of nine "large" franchises (eg north-west England) also allowed to control one of six "small" franchises (eg south-west England).

* Independent Television Commission (ITC) becomes new "light touch" regulator governing terrestrial and cable-satellite services, with key task of awarding 15 ITV regional licences and national breakfast licence by auction: licence to go to highest bidder, assuming it meets "quality threshold" and ITC does not invoke "exceptional circumstances" to choose an underbidder.

* Radio Authority set up, awarding licences (also by "competitive tender", ie auction) for three new national commercial stations and for many more local commercial stations.

* Broadcasting Standards Council given statutory status, although rulings not binding.

* Channel 5 to be set up, with licence awarded by auction.

* Channel 4 to lose its link with ITV by being allowed to sell its own advertising, but not (as the free-marketeers would have preferred) to be privatised. Advertisers had lobbied for the competition in the sale of air-time this ensured, but no one knew if the channel could generate enough ad revenue without compromising programme standards. Hence the safety net - 14% of all commercial terrestrial ad revenue (the "funding formula") - protecting its funding.

fields.headline: Shopping by numbers
fields.standfirst:
Text messaging is the latest trick to lure shoppers.

MediaGuardian.co.uk

Net news
fields.trailText: Text messaging is the latest trick to lure shoppers.
fields.body:
Visitors to Lakeside shopping centre last weekend could have been forgiven for thinking that young people spend their lives messaging each other on their mobile phones and racing around shopping centres like lunatics.

While this may be true of most of them, the majority of those behaving in this manner last weekend at Lakeside were taking part in the world's first trial of location-sensitive mobile phone advertising. The service, called ZagMe, has begun trials at Lakeside, and plans are afoot to extend it to Bluewater in January, and to other shopping malls and busy high streets as it takes off. The hope is that ZagMe will have registered 50,000 users when trials end in January.

About 150 retailers - or 75% of outlets - at Lakeside, including Pizza Hut, Debenhams, The Gap, Argos and Top Shop, have signed up to take part. Retailers send ZagMe a regular number of store promotions to be logged into a database and "broadcast" at the appropriate times to the appropriate demographic, split by age and gender.

Promotions are aimed at driving consumers into shops with special offers that expire after a certain period. The ads are location-sensitive, meaning they are designed to appeal to people who are close to a retail outlet and like to act on impulse. An example could be Virgin Megastore sending a message telling people that the first 20 to give a certain ZagMe code to staff will get free or discounted CDs.

So far so good. The service is achieving what it set out to do - creating a ruckus among retailers and shop assistants alike and whipping up consumers into a frenzy. Already more than 2,000 people have signed up to use the service, pulled in by field marketers at Lakeside or word of mouth from friends, who get loyalty points for recommending new users.

With retailers desperate to give consumers an incentive to go back into shops after the recession of the past few years, ZagMe could be the solution. While it's still early days, the results have been an eye-opener. Bill Green, chief executive officer of ZagMe, says the service has done wonders for British reserve, with shoppers taken over by greed, unabashed about racing around Lakeside shopping centre screaming loudly. Green cites as an example an offer ZagMe ran on Wednesday which, in his words, practically caused a riot. Messages were sent to consumers to say they could get free CDs if they hot-footed it to the ZagMe stand and shouted at the top of their lungs.

Reebok has already discovered that random text messages to nearby people has the potential to create essential footfall into shops. Even if the said retailer is running a promotion as a loss-leader - by giving away a pair of trainers - it achieves the aim of getting customers into the store, where it can then bombard them with special offers. A spokesperson for Reebok says there are already signs that this could become a key marketing tool: "The fit with the ZagMe audience and the brand is perfect as they're precisely the target market and age group that we want to reach."

Last Saturday, the first real shopping day of the trial, Reebok saw first-hand the potential of ZagMe when it ran the free trainers promotion to the first person to get to the store with the ZagMe message. In four minutes, more than 50 people had sprinted through the door, only to be told they'd have to be faster next time.

Jackie Clarke, assistant manager at New Look, which has been offering 10% off all products via ZagMe, says the response has been promising. She could see it taking off, and thought the fit between New Look customers and the age range of ZagMe users was strong. "I'm sure we're going to be running lots more promotions," she says.

After less than a week of service, ZagMe has already learnt a lot about its consumers and how they want to use the service. Green says the way in which shoppers interact with ZagMe is already developing. For instance when they arrive at Lakeside, they are encouraged to send ZagMe a simple message ("LAK4", for example, to mean "I'll be at Lakeside for the next four hours"), or leave a voice message to activate the service. Instead, says Green, consumers have started treating ZagMe like a friend and sending personal text messages. One example is "Zag Me baby for the next 6 hours".

ZagMe is delighted with this, believing it shows that people think the service is fun and feel comfortable with it and the brand as a whole. Another early perception is that consumers have started to view ZagMe as a shopping agent, something to help them hunt down bargains.

Also likely to be tweaked are the messages sent to shoppers as some have started sending messages such as: "I'm in McDonald's, have you got anything for me?", which is effectively a "pull" rather than a "push" service. Green says there are plans to beef up that side of the service and encourage consumers to ask for offers to make ZagMe even more personalised.

Those worried about being inundated with messages from retailers clogging up their phone inboxes can rest easy, adds Green, as ZagMe promises not to send more than two messages an hour, unless users opt to change their preferences and agree to receive more. Accounts can be managed via a soon-to-launch website, zagme.com, and Zagpoints - points collected when signing up, referring new users and receiving messages - can be redeemed for pre-pay phone or store vouchers.

Given that the penetration of mobile phones in the UK is now reaching 58%, and that 18- to 24-year-olds send an average of 10 SMS messages a day, it is no surprise that marketers are waking up to the potential of SMS marketing.

According to a recent survey from Ericsson and mobile marketing specialist Mediatude, mobile phone- users are receptive to the idea of ads on their phones if they're getting something in return. It doesn't have to be much. The Ericsson survey pushed ads to participants who, in return, were merely given free text messaging. The results were encouraging: almost 40% found the ads compelling, and 20% asked for more information after viewing the ads.

So is ZagMe just another flash-in- the-pan gimmick? Not according to retailers who, understandably, are happy that for once they are not being cut out of the equation because of a new piece of technology.

The fact that Carphone Warehouse is one of the main backers of Spotflash, the start-up behind ZagMe, with a 20% stake, and the company raised £1.9m in the summer in seed funding, should mean that the service is not just a fly-by-night trial that never makes it to a national roll-out.

Green, a 36-year-old Canadian and former partner at Andersen Consulting who set up the company last year, says he is blown away by the response. "It's way ahead of expectations. People love it and retailers are enjoying it as they've already seen it's a powerful mechanism to channel people into stores with simple loss-leaders," he says. "We haven't even had the viral effect kick in yet."

With Christmas just around the corner and retailers at Lakeside bracing themselves for riots, ZagMe is going to have a busy few months.

fields.headline: White paper's key points
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: * A single ITV: two companies dominate ITV, Granada Media and Carlton Communications but they are prevented from merging by legislation which stops them from owning more than 15% of the audience. This restriction should be eased, paving the way for one owner.
fields.body:
* A single ITV: two companies dominate ITV, Granada Media and Carlton Communications but they are prevented from merging by legislation which stops them from owning more than 15% of the audience. This restriction should be eased, paving the way for one owner.

*Cross-media ownership: complex rules governing how much of the TV industry print companies, for instance, can own exist in order to protect plurality of opinion. A wide range of options is expected to replace existing regulation. A popular way forward is "share of voice" instead of strict quotas.

*The structure of regulation: the mass of regulators covering broadcasting and telecoms are expected to be merged into a single organisation - dubbed Ofcom. The fight for the top job is likely to be between Oftel boss David Edmonds and Patricia Hodgson of the ITC.

*The independence of the BBC and the role of its governors: governors are almost certain to be stripped of some power, but a range of options is likely to be presented on how far the BBC will come under the auspices of outside regulators.

*The privatisation (or not) of Channel 4: the DTI and the Treasury would be keen on this, but Chris Smith and the DCMS appear to have vetoed privatisation.

*Restrictions governing ownership in the radio market: currently no single company is allowed to own more than 15% of the share of commercial radio audience. Will be lifted.

*ITN ownership: presently no single company can own more than 20% of the news provider - another restriction which is expected to go.

fields.headline: What's in Chris Smith's dustbin?
fields.standfirst:
The clauses that don't appear in the white paper, but should:

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The clauses that don't appear in the white paper, but should:
fields.body:
* Content regulation: no broadcaster may schedule their nightly news bulletin in the same slot for more than two days running - this only confuses the viewing public.

*Share of voice: no woman called Carol or Anne may appear more than once a week on British television. To be known as the "Vorderman limitation".

*Casebook censorship: tabloid problem pages to be limited to one picture of a scantily-clad woman per week. The same principle will apply to broadsheet mastheads.

*Cross-media promotion: newspaper editors are not permitted to make programmes about walking or church architecture. If they wish to reach a wider public they can appear on Have I Got News for You (with jokes) or Newsnight (no jokes).

*Radio ads: even-deeper-than-Barry-White voices prevented from promoting movies. Voiceover artists with annual income over £1m no longer allowed to impersonate chirpy Cockney cabbies, check-out girls and bargain-hunting shoppers.

*Radio: the word "gold" to improve the standing of cheap archive material is banned from the airwaves. Includes the name of stations, programmes, and links to records. However, Spandau Ballet's Gold may be played.

*Spectrum management: the future allocation of spectrum will be conducted along the lines of the "weakest link model" (cf Vorderman limitation). The last mogul standing will get first pick of the licences. Moderated by Patricia ("the rudest woman in regulation") Hodgson.

fields.headline: Press release: preferred bidder selected
fields.standfirst:
Special report: millennium dome

Department of the environment, transport and the regions
Press release - Detr
fields.trailText: The government today announced that Legacy plc has been selected as the preferred bidder to take over the Millennium Dome after the Millennium Experience has closed, and that arrangements for a new regeneration partnership were under way.
fields.body:
The government today announced that Legacy plc has been selected as the preferred bidder to take over the Millennium Dome after the Millennium Experience has closed, and that arrangements for a new regeneration partnership were under way.

In answer to Parliamentary Questions from Peter Ainsworth, and Lord Dubs, Hilary Armstrong, the minister for local government and the regions, and Lord Falconer said: "Since the withdrawal of the bid from Nomura for the dome in September, we have received numerous unsolicited expressions of interest from parties interested in procuring the dome, including one from PY Gerbeau. These have all been outside the terms of the competition.

"Within the context of the competition, the competition team has been continuing its discussions with Legacy plc, and in the light of progress the government has now decided to grant Legacy preferred bidder status.

"Legacy plc have been awarded preferred bidder status because they have confirmed that they will resolve all outstanding contractual issues within an agreed timetable. Negotiations will continue, and if all goes well we expect to exchange contracts during February. Progress will be reviewed regularly.

"English Partnerships will be working closely with Legacy plc to agree a masterplan for the Dome and associated land.

"In addition, English Partnerships and the London Borough of Greenwich are working together, and are in discussion with the London Development Agency, to put in place a new partnership for the next stage of the regeneration of the Greenwich Peninsula. This will build on the work done so far on the development of the

"Peninsula, including the dome site, the Millennium Village, and retail and commercial investments, and the emerging development framework for East Greenwich Riverside.

"The aim will be to work closely with local stakeholders, including private sector landowners, employers and residents, to establish and implement a new masterplan framework for the peninsula.

"This will maintain the momentum established by the Millennium Experience and the enormous improvements in transport infrastructure that have been made, maximising private sector investment and regeneration benefits for the peninsula. I have asked English Partnerships to consider, in their discussions with other parties, the possible establishment of an Urban Regeneration Company, following the principles set out in our White Paper published last week."

Hilary Armstrong added: "This is good news for Greenwich. I am pleased that negotiations with Legacy plc are going well, and that we have been able to make them preferred bidder. Legacy's proposals for a high-tech business park will deliver a substantial boost to employment on the peninsula.

"The Legacy scheme will ensure a high technology future that is fitting for one of the world's most innovative and identifiable structures. This will have a major knock-on effect on investment across the rest of the peninsula and more widely, and will act as a further stimulus to the development of Thames Gateway.

"I am pleased that discussions are now under way between, English Partnerships and the London Borough of Greenwich to set up a new partnership for the next stage of the regeneration of the Greenwich peninsula. EP and Greenwich will also be talking to the LDA about what role they might play. I think this is a very exciting development, and call upon all the parties involved to put all their efforts into developing the new master plan framework"

Lord Falconer said: "Though much work has to be done before negotiations can be completed Legacy's plans offer a high quality, high-tech and exciting future for the dome, for Londoners and especially the people of Greenwich.

"The dome has proved to be the top pay-to-visit tourist attraction in this country and has acted as a catalyst for the regeneration of what was a poisoned peninsula, scarred by hundreds of acres of wasteland.

"The area has been transformed with new homes, new jobs and new hope. But much more needs to be done. Legacy's plans coupled with today's announcement of a new regeneration partnership will ensure that the long-term regeneration of this part of east London continues."

webTitle: 'Railways not top priority' PM told cabinet

fields.headline: 'Railways not top priority' PM told cabinet
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Downing Street is bracing itself for a spate of embarrassing leaks after more confidential accounts of cabinet meetings were published yesterday.
fields.body:
Downing Street is bracing itself for a spate of embarrassing leaks after more confidential accounts of cabinet meetings were published yesterday.

Tony Blair faced particular embarrassment from the latest instalment which quoted him declaring in 1997 that rail travel was not an issue. "Railways are not a top priority," the prime minister reportedly told the first cabinet meeting after the election.

Downing Street dismissed the lengthy accounts of cabinet meetings in 1997 which were published in the Mail of Sunday, following on from a report last week of a stormy cabinet meeting when the prime minister overruled objections to the Millennium Dome.

A spokesman turned the government's fire on Simon Walters, the newspaper's political editor and thriller writer, who is believed to have compiled the accounts with the help of a former Downing Street civil servant, Mark Adams.

"We think that Simon Walters is in danger of going from fiction to fantasy," the spokesman said. "Like last week's instalment - what the Mail on Sunday publishes bears no resemblance to the official record of cabinet meetings it is supposed to relate to."

The spokesman's remarks were technically correct because the colourful language in yesterday's account would not have made it into the dry official minutes. However, one government aide thought that Walters was providing an accurate account.

"Simon Walters has got piles of stuff," the source said. "This is going to go on for weeks."

The instalments yesterday will provide excruciating reading for the prime minister. In a discussion about press coverage of the government at the first cabinet meeting after the election in May 1997, he demanded that ministerial special advisers should not talk to the press, an edict which has been ignored.

"I don't want to see [special advisers] talking to the media now we are in government," Mr Blair is quoted as saying. "The last government got into great difficulties over special advisers."

In another press discussion a month later, the prime minister is quoted as saying: "I am worried about two kinds of story. One, that we can't handle it, and two, that we are arrogant and drunk with power. I have to say that of the two I prefer the latter."

Downing Street's attempts to rubbish the Mail on Sunday are undermined by the prime minister's complaint at a cabinet meeting in June 1997 of his frustration at leaks. "I am still getting reports of cabinet committee meetings being leaked," he said. "Alastair [Campbell] has been alarmed to get complete read outs from journalists... It's going to be very difficult when the going gets tough."

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, is also embarrassed. At a cabinet meeting in May 1997, Mr Cook was quoted as saying that the merger of the Western European Union with the EU - a demand of the French and the Germans - would undermine Nato. The merger has since happened.

In a discussion on the legislative programme, the then cabinet office minister Jack Cunningham argues for a food standards agency bill. "This is a health and welfare issue, not like freedom of information which is for the chattering classes."

'We must turn the arrogance charge around'

The following are claimed extracts from minutes of cabinet meetings.

May 8 1997

Discussion of changes to legislation.

Clare Short: "On railways, we need to be able to give instructions to the regulator."

Tony Blair: "Railways are not a top priority."

John Prescott: "On rail, colleagues mustn't assume things haven't been bid for. We have many things to do on the railways."

Tony Blair: "Something else may have to be ditched. We need some eye catching stuff for later."

June 5 1997

Tony Blair addresses the cabinet.

"We have to tackle this issue and deal with it, for example the Mail on Sunday story about a snub to the Palace. [A row over Bill Clinton not taking tea with the Queen.] We must meet these head on, and not allow ourselves to be diverted.

Discussion of legislation.

webTitle: Kinnock wades into row on Europe

fields.headline: Kinnock wades into row on Europe
fields.standfirst:
Special report: European integration
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Neil Kinnock entered the cabinet row over Europe yesterday when he threw his weight behind a group of ministers who argue that the issue must form a central plank of Labour's general election campaign.
fields.body:
Neil Kinnock entered the cabinet row over Europe yesterday when he threw his weight behind a group of ministers who argue that the issue must form a central plank of Labour's general election campaign.

Hours after a personal feud erupted again between Gordon Brown and Robin Cook, the former Labour leader warned that Britain's relations with Europe and possible membership of the euro could not be neutralised during the election.

"At election time you can expect the EU and all its implications, including the euro, to be part of an electoral agenda," Mr Kinnock, a European commission vice president, told Sky TV.

His remarks had added punch because they reflected the views of fiercely pro-European cabinet ministers, led by Mr Cook and Peter Mandelson, who believe that the government should step up its efforts to sell the EU.

Tensions between the Cook faction and the chancellor's supporters, who believe that attention on Europe could distract from the government's main achievements, were reignited last week when the foreign secretary rounded on euro-sceptic newspapers. Treasury sources reportedly dismissed Mr Cook's intervention, saying that it would play into the Tories' hands.

Mr Cook's allies struck back yesterday with a ferocious attack on the chancellor for interfering in areas of European policy outside his remit. "Gordon Brown should try to remember he is not the prime minister and does not lead the Labour party," the Sunday Telegraph quoted a spokesman for Mr Cook as saying.

The alleged spokesman added that the chancellor was abusing his position as chairman of Labour's election campaign to "exercise a veto". He said: "As foreign secretary Robin Cook has full authority to speak about Europe and the Nice summit. The only person who can give him instructions is the prime minister."

Mr Cook distanced himself from the remarks yesterday, insisting that he had not authorised them and they did not reflect his views. The Treasury also dismissed the row, insisting that nobody in the chancellor's circle had criticised Mr Cook's speech.

Behind the official responses, however, there is no doubt that the remarks in the Sunday Telegraph did reflect the foreign secretary's frustration with the chancellor for stepping on his toes. One friend of the foreign secretary said: "Gordon Brown's people were running negative briefings against Peter Mandelson and Robin Cook last week. Someone in the Cook camp decided to respond."

Europe will dominate the agenda in the run-up to Christmas as the government prepares for next month's European summit in Nice. Defence and foreign ministers meet in Brussels today to set up a new EU rapid reaction force. Tory criticism of this rebounded yesterday when William Hague was reminded in a television interview that he voted for closer European defence cooperation in the early 1990s.

The government itself was given a taste of the difficulties ahead when France last night signalled a tough stance ahead of the Nice summit, where disagreement is looming over reweighting votes and over national vetos.

Pierre Moscovici, France's minister on Europe, said little progress had been made on introducing majority voting for proposed changes on tax, social security, external trade and immigration and asylum matters. "We hope for maximum progress on qualified majority voting and we are not abandoning anything," he said.

Related special report:
Economic and Monetary Union

webTitle: Europe sets up rapid reaction force

fields.headline: Europe sets up rapid reaction force
fields.standfirst:
Cook insists troop commitment does not mean common army
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The European Union heads into uncharted territory today by announcing the first steps towards mounting its own military operations after decades of relying on Nato and the US.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor,  and Ian Black  in Brussels
fields.body:
The European Union heads into uncharted territory today by announcing the first steps towards mounting its own military operations after decades of relying on Nato and the US.

In a move enthusiastically endorsed by the British government, the member states will add an extra dimension to the EU by lending military muscle to its economic weight.

British ministers, anxious to head off attacks from Tory Eurosceptics, played down the significant implications for the transatlantic alliance by insisting that the policy would not create a European standing army.

Defence and foreign ministers meeting in Brussels will pledge tens of thousands of troops, plus hundreds of planes, tanks, and ships, to a new EU rapid reaction force. Officials say the first, limited, missions could be launched next summer. By 2003 they plan to be able to deploy 60,000 troops within 60 days and sustain such a force on the ground for at least a year.

Today's "capabilities conference" is the culmination of more than two years of often fraught diplomacy in which Britain and France have taken a leading role, albeit driven by different motives.

While Paris wants to show that Europe can act independently of the US, London is keen to show a positive attitude towards the EU. "Our intention is to make a contribution to any EU-led operation commensurate with our military weight and the leading role we've taken in European defence," a senior British military official said.

Britain has pledged over 12,000 troops, from an available pool of about 20,000, to a joint European force backed by 72 combat aircraft and 18 warships. Although there will be a permanent headquarters in Brussels. there will be no standing army and the multinational chain of command remains tortuous.

No member state - least of all Britain - is talking about a "European army", or even a joint "standing force", although soldiers on EU missions are likely to wear the EU symbol beside their national and regimental insignia.

"Lurid claims that we will set up a Euro-army this week are a vivid example of Euro-scare tactics," the Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, said yesterday. "There is not going to be a Euro-army. All decisions on whether British forces take part in any operation - and how much they contribute - will be taken by the British government.

"The European Union is not going to take on collective defence. That is the job of Nato," he added.

The Franco-British initiative was given added impetus by last year's Kosovo conflict which demonstrated, almost to the point of humiliation, how dependent the European allies were on the US.

The conflict proved to be the catalyst in what hitherto had been a slow-moving process, beset by suspicion in Washington and reservations in European armies.

The Clinton administration had made it clear that Europe must contribute more to its defence. Today's pledges will signal such an intention to the new US president, whoever that turns out to be.

Though Washington remains wary of French intentions and concerned about the role of non-EU European allies, notably Turkey, it now appears to be reassured that the EU is prepared to take a greater share of the burden.

European officials say that despite arguments to the contrary, notably from British conservatives, the EU's ambitious move towards a common defence and security policy is much less likely to encourage isolationism in the US Congress. Nevertheless, the EU wants an insurance policy if, one day, the US no longer wants to send its troops abroad.

But a huge gap remains between the military assets of the US and the EU, especially in heavy airlift, logistical support, electronic warfare, communications technology, and intelligence gathering.

The last could prove to be a troublesome issue given the unique intelligence relationship between Britain and the US.

"The French would like to see a greater emphasis on an autonomous intelligence-gathering capability," a British source said.

Such EU ambitions have made it easier to convince parliaments and public opinion to back investment in expensive equipment more relevant to future expeditionary forces than to the static defence assumptions of the cold war. Germany, Italy and the Netherlands are among the European allies which have agreed to reverse the downward trend in defence spending.

The rapid reaction force will be used for tasks ranging from combat "peacemaking" to humanitarian missions: something which appeals to neutral countries such as Sweden and Finland. British officials say a joint force could be sent to rescue EU citizens from a crisis in an African country or for peacekeeping operations in Bosnia.

Whitehall insists that the force would not get involved in "fighting wars". One senior British defence official said: "We do not envisage the EU taking on a nation state." European officials talk about giving Nato "first refusal".

Building EU defence structures is a politically sensitive matter and complex procedures involving interlocking committees of diplomats and military officers have been put in place. Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo, who works for the 15 governments, not the European commission, is in overall charge. General Graham Messervy-Whiting, a British army officer, plays a key role as head of the military staff committee.

webTitle: Comment: The next US president and global warming

fields.headline: Driving to doom
fields.standfirst:
Unless the winner, whether Bush or Gore, wakes up to global warming, we'll all be the losers

Special report: the US elections
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Unless the winner, whether Bush or Gore, wakes up to global warming, we'll all be the losers.
fields.body:
Let us for the moment leave chads, whether pregnant or dimpled, twisting in the wind. The supreme court of Florida is welcome to them. Something rather more serious - no, literally apocalyptic - lurks behind these frenzied American revels; something that, this week links Palm Beach and the Hague. A simple question: can democracy save the world?

Guardian readers know that teams from 180 countries have gathered in Holland to try, one more time, to secure an agreement which reduces the greenhouse gas emissions that threaten the future of our globally warmed globe. Three years ago, in Kyoto, the leaders of those 180 countries solemnly promised to cut these emissions. They have not, however, been cut: they have risen.

Even Kyoto, with the modest reductions it set, hasn't held. And, in particular, the US - with 5% of world population and 25% of emissions - has not kept to its word or the puny, insufficient targets it accepted in Japan. Unless the new rulers in Pennsylvania Avenue, whoever they turn out to be, can be persuaded to wake up and shape up, then we might as well not bother. A world environment policy without the polluter-in-chief is a hole in the head and a hole in the ozone layer. There will be no more important conference - for America or any of us - this year.

Guardian readers know this because the Guardian reports it. American readers are less well served. In the US you may wade through dead forests of newsprint this morning without finding mention of the Hague. It might as well be happening on another planet, not the other side of our planet. And, anyway, George W Bush says he does not believe in global warming. He doesn't think it exists. Al Gore believes all right, yet he hasn't managed, over eight years in power, to do much about it.

Hang on though! Isn't there, at last, a strong, growing American Green party now? And didn't it, in many ways, shape the whole presidential debate, raising causes that others feared to touch? Ralph Nader made the death penalty and privatised prisons and failed drug wars real issues. He put his old enemy, corporate power, in the firing line. It would have been a far poorer election without him.

The thing that haunts me, 12 days on, is that it would also have been a different election. Without the irate grey panthers of Palm Beach waving their butterfly ballots, George W would already be far into his triumphant transition - and the clear divide between his victory or defeat was, and is, Nader's Green vote. We're talking 80,000-plus, not a frail 930. Nader, taking Florida Democrat votes quite disproportionately, filled out Bush's White House pass.

Democrat bosses are bitter about that, but Nader just shrugs. Without him, he says, there was only a choice of two evils. Evil, whatever its shade, is still evil. President Gore would be an evil, too. "Al Gore lost this election for Al Gore." Nader, with his calm fury and idealism, brought in hundreds of thousands of young people turned off by standard campaigning. He was an energising force (and a prophet his supporters keep comparing with Gandhi).

Fair enough. But I went to Nader's last great Washington rally, almost as the polls opened a fortnight ago, and sat through four hours of oratory and ambition. I did not once hear the words "global warming" uttered. Nor "ozone layer". These were Green warriors who seemed more anxious to talk at length about statehood for the district of Columbia. These were environmentalists reserving their biggest cheers for legalising pot smoking.

Now, of course, Nader does have the requisite policies somewhere in the greenhouse. Leaf through his position papers and you'll find him endorsing the standard Ozone Action programme and shredding Gore as an "environment poseur" playing a cynical con game. But he made precious little of it, one brick amongst many, at the close. The "uncompromising political force" he aimed to create was more interested in enfranchising Washington voters.

Which is why I worry so deeply about what democracy can address, and what it can achieve, in a true environmental crisis.

There are 90 or so Green parties around the world. Some rise and rise - to a share of government in Germany (where they embrace the European federal state). Some, like our own Greens, rise and fall again. There is no pattern to the way they bring their urgent message, the most urgent message of all. The end-of-the-world message. They don't know whether to be part of the process, or the heart of the process or standing outside it, proclaiming doom.

"Where were they when the petrol tanks ran dry?" one Labour cabinet minister asked me privately the other day. Strangely silent, he thought. When the case for higher fuel taxes had to be made, he didn't hear much cheeping from the British Greens. They only surfaced to denounce Tony Blair's big environmental speech as - of course - not enough.

There must, I think, be a parallel staring at boots in America today. Ralph Nader's presidential run, in all likelihood, will cost Gore the White House. That is not a value judgment, but a statistical one. If that's the way the next few days turn out, then there will be no action of any meaningful kind through Bush's Oval Office years. The pollution of the US, like the pollution of Texas, will proceed without let or hindrance. The failure of the Hague talks is foredoomed.

How do you trade off four or eight years of that against vote-splitting and future party building? Where is the equation between some small progress now and no progress at all? These are terrible conundrums, but they can be put in hard terms.

Bush and Cheney - as they would - want to license oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, America's last great wilderness. They'll get that through Congress. Why rely on Arab oil, when you've got more of your own? Gore - for all his trimmings - is committed to stop that. If I were a porcupine caribou in that last great wilderness, what would I vote for - death today or life tomorrow?

Here's the inescapable dilemma. If profligate energy use, low petrol prices, the whole bent of this consumer society, is ruining the earth today, then it needs an answer today. There is no tomorrow if you don't talk greenhouse gases today. But the voters don't want to listen and even prophet-politicians like Nader who seek their vote don't tell them in terms. Less petrol at a greater price? Forget it. When gun holders vote Bush, as they did, to hang on to their guns, what chance that car owners will vote to make their own lives more difficult?

George W smirks: Florida's lawyers pound on: and democracy shies away because the hard questions can't be put.

Nader, with his calm fury and idealism, brought in hundreds of thousands of young people turned off by standard campaigning. He was an energising force (and a prophet his supporters keep comparing with Gandhi). Fair enough. But I went to Nader's last great Washington rally, almost as the polls opened a fortnight ago, and sat through four hours of oratory and ambition. I did not once hear the words "global warming" uttered. Nor "ozone layer". These were Green warriors who seemed more anxious to talk at length about statehood for the district of Columbia. These were environmentalists reserving their biggest cheers for legalising pot smoking. Now, of course, Nader does have the requisite policies somewhere in the greenhouse. Leaf through his position papers and you'll find him endorsing the standard Ozone Action programme and shredding Gore as an "environment poseur" playing a cynical con game. But he made precious little of it, one brick amongst many, at the close. The "uncompromising political force" he aimed to create was more interested in enfranchising Washington voters. Which is why I worry so deeply about what democracy can address, and what it can achieve, in a true environmental crisis. There are 90 or so Green parties around the world. Some rise and rise - to a share of government in Germany (where they embrace the European federal state). Some, like our own Greens, rise and fall again. There is no pattern to the way they bring their urgent message, the most urgent message of all. The end-of-the-world message. They don't know whether to be part of the process, or the heart of the process or standing outside it, proclaiming doom. "Where were they when the petrol tanks ran dry?" one Labour cabinet minister asked me privately the other day. Strangely silent, he thought. When the case for higher fuel taxes had to be made, he didn't hear much cheeping from the British Greens. They only surfaced to denounce Tony Blair's big environmental speech as - of course - not enough. There must, I think, be a parallel staring at boots in America today. Ralph Nader's presidential run, in all likelihood, will cost Gore the White House. That is not a value judgment, but a statistical one. If that's the way the next few days turn out, then there will be no action of any meaningful kind through Bush's Oval Office years. The pollution of the US, like the pollution of Texas, will proceed without let or hindrance. The failure of the Hague talks is foredoomed. How do you trade off four or eight years of that against vote-splitting and future party building? Where is the equation between some small progress now and no progress at all? These are terrible conundrums, but they can be put in hard terms. Bush and Cheney - as they would - want to license oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, America's last great wilderness. They'll get that through Congress. Why rely on Arab oil, when you've got more of your own? Gore - for all his trimmings - is committed to stop that. If I were a porcupine caribou in that last great wilderness, what would I vote for - death today or life tomorrow? Here's the inescapable dilemma. If profligate energy use, low petrol prices, the whole bent of this consumer society, is ruining the earth today, then it needs an answer today. There is no tomorrow if you don't talk greenhouse gases today. But the voters don't want to listen and even prophet-politicians like Nader who seek their vote don't tell them in terms. Less petrol at a greater price? Forget it. When gun holders vote Bush, as they did, to hang on to their guns, what chance that car owners will vote to make their own lives more difficult? George W smirks: Florida's lawyers pound on: and democracy shies away because the hard questions can't be put.
