fields.headline: Survey reveals widespread child abuse
fields.standfirst:
Charity calls for government action to protect youngsters as comprehensive study shows perpetrators are often siblings
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: More sexual abuse of children is perpetrated by siblings than by fathers or stepfathers and violence towards children is more likely to come from mothers than fathers, according to a survey for the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.
fields.body:
More sexual abuse of children is perpetrated by siblings than by fathers or stepfathers and violence towards children is more likely to come from mothers than fathers, according to a survey for the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

The charity, which last night demanded urgent government response to its findings, published the most comprehensive survey so far of child abuse in the UK, showing 6% suffered serious physical neglect, 6% were emotionally maltreated and 1% were sexually abused by a parent.

Mary Marsh, the charity's director, called on the government to rethink its opposition to the appointment of children's commissioners for England, Scotland and Northern Ireland.

"The appointment of such watchdogs, as is being advanced in Wales and across Europe, must be the government's first response to this report."

The charity's findings come from a UK-wide survey of the childhood experiences of 2,869 young people aged 18-24 by the research company BMRB International.

By asking a large representative sample of young adults to give their recollections confidentially on computer terminals, the charity thinks it obtained the most accurate picture so far of the extent of abuse. It says it would have been ethically wrong and difficult to survey children directly.

According to the findings, published today on UN Children's Rights Day, one in 14 suffered serious physical abuse at the hands of parents or carers, including being hit with a fist or implement, beaten up, or burned and scalded on purpose.

That proportion is equivalent to nearly 1m of the children in Britain today. The NSPCC said 49% of the victims were treated violently by their mother, 40% by their father and 8% by a step-parent.

One in 12 suffered bullying and discrimination regularly and more than four in 10 experienced it at some point. In the first polling research into the prevalence of emotional maltreatment, the charity found 6% experienced multiple attacks on their self esteem, including terrorising, humiliation, withdrawal of affection and harming of possessions or pets. Girls were twice as likely as boys to suffer from this type of cruelty.

One in 10 - mostly girls - have been forced into sex acts under the age of 16 and involving people known to them. In 43% of cases, the perpetrator was a brother or stepbrother, compared with 19% saying a stepfather and 14% naming their father.

The survey found more than nine in 10 young people said they grew up in a loving family, but one in four said there were childhood events that they found difficult to talk about.

Ms Marsh said: "For many young people, serious stresses and unhappiness cast a dark shadow over what should have been an otherwise happy childhood.

"Some young people interviewed in this research suffered serious forms of abuse during their formative years, often on a regular basis and often in silence. For many, the damage done will last long into adulthood."

She repeated the charity's call for independent commissioners to protect children, similar to the statutory bodies for women, ethnic minorities and disabled people. This was Labour policy in its 1992 election manifesto, but was dropped in 1997.

A Department of Health spokesman said: "Any type of child abuse is unacceptable and the government has already taken steps to tackle this. This includes a national care standards commission by April 2002 with 70 officers around the country.

"It will have a national director for vulnerable children who will understand the new standards for those in care or at risk of abuse."

But David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health committee, said: "The time is ripe for the government to follow the example of other European countries by introducing an independent children's rights commissioner... There are now no excuses for putting off such a move."

Julian Brazier, president of the Conservative Family Campaign, said: "I'm very much in support of the campaign for a children's commissioner. I strongly believe that politicians and the public must unite to help the NSPCC rid society of cruelty to children."

webTitle: BT hots up tech firm incubator

fields.headline: BT hots up tech firm incubator
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: BT is launching a technology incubator arm with the aim of helping set up dozens of businesses that will be sold or floated on the stock market.
fields.body:
BT is launching a technology incubator arm with the aim of helping set up dozens of businesses that will be sold or floated on the stock market.

The heavily debt laden company believes its new division, known as Brightstar, is a potential money spinner which could be worth £2bn over the next three years.

It is understood to be in talks with at least five private equity firms - one of which is known to be 3i - over setting up a group of backers to provide funds for start-ups.

The idea behind Brightstar, which has been in the planning stage since July, is to invest in up to 10 new ventures at any time. It is thought each one would spend up to four months with the incubator.

The company will provide accommodation, support and management advice at a site named Adastral Park, near Ipswich, which was previously known as Martlesham.

BT, which is expected to formerly announce Brightstar as early as next month, will then take minority stakes in the companies to ensure a longer term share in those which become successful.

It is thought the move may help silence City critics who have accused BT of failing to make full use of its technology and claimed it is suffering from a brain drain.

BT - which will only incubate companies which use its own patents and intellectual property - is said to have 14,000 patents based on almost 2,000 inventions.

Separately, weekend reports also suggested that Sir Peter Bonfield, BT's chief executive, was forced to abandon plans for a full break-up of BT because of the company's mounting levels of debt.

It is thought he wanted a more "radical restructuring" than announced a fortnight ago, but this would have prompted debt rating agencies to put BT on credit watch.

A BT spokesman refused to comment, saying only that many scenarios had been discussed.

fields.headline: Parents 'not told' of hospital errors
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Many parents are never told about errors in their children's hospital treatment, a study suggests today.
fields.body:
Many parents are never told about errors in their children's hospital treatment, a study suggests today.

Nearly half the families of patients who were administered the wrong medicine, given or prescribed the wrong dose, or drugged by the wrong route, were not informed of the mistakes, according to a review of errors over five years at the Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Glasgow.

Although the overall error rate was low - one per 662 admissions - 40% of the botched treatments involved children under two. Eight per cent of incidents, 15 out of 195 errors, involved drugs given in doses 10 times too high or too low.

No patient died as a result but two cases, involving the wrong concentration of an anti-cancer treatment and the intravenous infusion of a sedative that was 100 times too high, were said to have had the potential to cause serious harm. Three others could have had moderately serious consequences.

Nearly 10% of the patients needed extra treatment or investigation, including, in four cases, an extra drug to mitigate the effects of the errors.

The authors of the study, published in Archives of Diseases in Childhood, said those responsible for recording errors sometimes thought it was not worth telling parents about labelling errors noticed before drugs were given. In other cases, it was considered unnecessary to cause "undue stress" when the child had come to no harm.

The researchers, from the department of child health at Glasgow University and the hospital's pharmacy department, say many hospitals have no system for reporting errors, unlike the Royal where there has been a mandatory scheme for years. This is to change soon when the NHS introduces compulsory national arrangements.

More than half the mistakes involved intravenous treatments, including antibiotics, anti-viral medication, anti-cancer drugs and feeding fluids and a third involved oral medication. Most errors happened on the medical wards and were reported by nurses.

The authors say it is important for staff to check calculations and avoid decimal points. Most errors were not down to negligence but organisational failures.

In a commentary on the study, Terence Stephenson, of the Queen's Medical Centre, Nottingham, suggests that, extrapolating the figures, there would be at least 1,675 avoidable medication errors a year involving children under 16 in English hospitals. Of those, 85 might involve moderate or severe reactions. The true figures were probably higher and although there had been no deaths in the Scottish study, fatalities did occur because of medication errors.

Improvements could include standardisation of infusion pumps regulating intravenous treatments and more thorough checking of prescriptions and calculations.

webTitle: Prescott sends his man into Railtrack

fields.headline: Prescott sends his man into Railtrack
fields.standfirst:
New chief executive faces grilling from troubleshooter over link between punctuality and safety
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is sending his senior rail official into Railtrack today as the crisis of confidence in the company mounts.
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is sending his senior rail official into Railtrack today as the crisis of confidence in the company mounts.

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority, will meet Railtrack's chairman, Sir Philip Beck, today and has another meeting planned with the new chief executive, Steven Marshall, for tomorrow.

Mr Marshall, formerly Railtrack's finance director, was appointed on Friday after the unexpected resignation of Gerald Corbett a month after he first offered to go following the Hatfield crash.

Although Mr Corbett insisted that his decision to quit was personal, speculation was growing that Mr Prescott had been angered by Mr Corbett's assertion that there was a conflict between safety, punctuality and reliability.

The SSRA chief has been asked to find out if the new chief executive shares that view and will report to Mr Prescott in time for the weekly rail crisis meeting, now held by the government each Thursday.

Mr Prescott told the BBC yesterday: "My obligation is to see that Railtrack, whoever is the chief executive or chair, carry out their obligations."

Sir Alastair, the former chairman of Eurotunnel who has a reputation as one of the toughest men in British business, is also understood to have been charged with ensuring that Railtrack recruits the right person as its next chairman.

The authority is said to have little faith in the current board and could force a wholesale clearout. Sir Philip, who is to quit next year, has been widely criticised for his low profile.

Yesterday Railtrack was continuing to insist that the government was not involved in the running of the company or the make-up of its boardroom. A spokesman said that this week's meetings had been arranged for several weeks, but he admitted that the agenda would have changed since Mr Corbett's departure. And Mr Prescott made it clear he was monitoring the company closely. "Who they choose to run it is their decision. What they do and how they do it I have some responsibility for," he said.

Several possible candidates for the chair have already emerged. They include David James, the company troubleshooter brought in to oversee the final months of the Millennium Dome, and the Conservatives' London mayoral candidate, Steve Norris. The fate of the new chief executive would lie in the hands of a newly appointed chairman.

Last night Mr James was unavailable for comment, but sources close to Mr Norris suggested he would be keen to take over. Mr Norris is a former transport minister and is a member of Transport for London, the body set up by Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, to oversee plans for the capital's transport system.

Other names linked with the job, now viewed as probably the toughest in British business, include John Devaney, the former head of Eastern Electricity, and David Varney, the former boss of BG. Mr Varney is head of the New Deal London Taskforce and has close links to Labour. There is also the possibility that Sir Alastair could take over.

Details of the Railtrack meetings came as the Rail Passengers Council demanded up to a month's free travel for season ticket holders hit by the delays affecting much of the network.

Stewart Francis, chairman of the council, said: "First you have to deal with season ticket holders, who have borne the brunt of this. We are looking, on average, to three to four weeks' compensation."

He said occasional rail users should also be compensated - possibly with a free rail travel day, or a buy one ticket, get one free offer. "We have got to get people back on the railway, and the only way we are going to do that is to build confidence again in safety and performance," Mr Francis told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost.

Railtrack has offered the train companies £150m to pay for compensation packages for rail users; the train companies are understood to be demanding twice that.

fields.headline: NHS phone service rolls out
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The government's NHS Direct telephone service will be formally rolled out across England today as ministers step up their efforts to ensure that it becomes the main "gateway" to the health service.
fields.body:
The government's NHS Direct telephone service will be formally rolled out across England today as ministers step up their efforts to ensure that it becomes the main "gateway" to the health service.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will announce that the service, which is staffed by nurses, will handle 5m calls a year by 2004, turning it into the national telephone line for the NHS.

All patients, except those in need of emergency care, will be encouraged to telephone NHS Direct as a first step in their treatment.

Ministers hope that this will improve efficiency by reducing the number of telephone calls to local GPs or to accident and emergency units.

NHS Direct staff make an assessment of a patient's need before offering advice which can range from encouragement to stay in bed for minor conditions to making an appointment to see a GP or to go to hospital. Under the new plans, NHS Direct will handle initial telephone inquiries on behalf of GPs' surgeries.

Ministers are bracing themselves for a confrontation with GPs who are said to be nervous about NHS Direct taking on their work.

Tony Blair will today hail NHS Direct as one of the greatest examples of how Labour has modernised the NHS.

Since NHS Direct was launched in March 1998 it has handled 3.5m calls, and it is hoping to be taking an average of about 100,000 a week by the end of this year. The service has been particularly popular among young mothers - 61% use the service regularly.

Mr Milburn is expected to say today that the NHS Direct telephone number - 0845 4647 - "looks set to become as well known and as well used as the emergency 999 number".

webTitle: Inquiry as lax airport security under fire

fields.headline: Inquiry as lax airport security under fire
fields.standfirst:
Reporter posing as pilot infiltrates restricted areas and boards jet

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Reporter posing as pilot infiltrates restricted areas and boards jet.
fields.body:
The government launched an urgent inquiry yesterday after an undercover reporter was allowed to walk unchallenged into secure areas at two busy airports.

Wearing a pilot's uniform and carrying a genuine airside pass obtained for £10, the reporter was able to get into the cockpit of a British Airways plane at Birmingham and pose for photographs at the steps of another jet at Gatwick.

The reporter claimed that his bag - which was packed with tools - was not even X-rayed at Birmingham and as he got on to the plane, an engineer had asked him if he wanted the plane powered up.

A spokeswoman for the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, which is responsible for setting security standards and assessing safety measures at airports, said an investigation was under way. She added: "We take security matters very seriously. Allegations will be checked and loopholes closed."

The News of the World said its reporter bought the pilot's uniform from a London outfitter used by the airline for £140 without checks being made on his identity. He told staff he was a "freelance pilot".

Using a fictitious company name, it is claimed the reporter then applied for an ID card which allowed him airside access from Crawley-based Baseops Europe Limited. He gave his real name and address but a false date and place of birth. Two weeks later the pass, which cost £10, arrived in the post. The newspaper claimed it was easier than getting a card for a video shop.

The reporter visited Birmingham international airport, the country's fourth busiest, used by more than 7m passengers a year, and was waved through security when he flashed his airside pass. His briefcase, holding screwdrivers, spanners and tools which could have been used to sabotage a plane, was not passed through an X-ray machine.

It is claimed the reporter was able to walk into a British Airways hangar and board a BA jet. As he climbed aboard, an engineer asked: "Would you like me to power her up?" The newspaper claimed that six hours later the plane was to fly 90 passengers to Edinburgh.

Next he visited Gatwick where his bags were put through an X-ray machine. But again he was waved through after a security officer checked the airside identification and was able to pose for a photograph next to a jet.

The investigation will focus on the apparent ease with which the reporter obtained the airside pass. Based in Crawley, the company which issued the pass is a subsidiary of an American firm. It was making no comment yesterday.

A spokeswoman for Birmingham international airport said the reporter had gained access to a "controlled area" - but not one which passengers used. She said the airport complied with DETR security rules and added: "Had the individual attempted to enter a restricted area where passenger movements take place, he would have been subjected to a full search to prevent any prohibited items getting through."

webTitle: Passengers in vibrating plane scare at 11,000ft

fields.headline: Passengers in vibrating plane scare at 11,000ft
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Passengers on a flight from Newcastle to Paris were asked by their captain to leave their seats and gather at the front or the craft would lose balance and crash, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Passengers on a flight from Newcastle to Paris were asked by their captain to leave their seats and gather at the front or the craft would lose balance and crash, it emerged yesterday.

The 78 passengers and crew on Gill Airways flight AF5105 suspected a problem when the Fokker 100 began to vibrate around 90 minutes into its journey.

As it prepared to land at Charles de Gaulle airport, the passengers were assured the shaking would stop and the plane would land safely if they and the five cabin crew took seats at the front of the plane to balance it out.

The plane was travelling at 11,000ft but could not maintain its height. Passengers sat at the front for 15 minutes until it landed.They had been asked to occupy the few empty front seats on a flight that was around 80% full.

Executives at the Tyneside airline, which operates an Air France franchise, had not identified the cause of the problem yesterday. However, nine days after the incident on November 3, the plane was back in service.

Stan Abbott, a spokesman for Gill Airways, said: "Passengers at the back of the plane were asked to go to sit in the empty seats at the front of the cabin. It was to assist with weight distribution, basically. I don't want to speculate with an investigation still ongoing, but the crucial thing is that the aircraft is back in service."

He said the plane was back in use with the endorsement of the manufacturer and the air accident investigation branch of the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions. Fittings such as the flight control computer had been replaced and Gill Airways continued to operate its fleet of three Fokker 100 aircraft in Air France colours.

Mr Abbott added: "The plane has operated without incident since."

The department is investigating the incident, and a company insider said yesterday: "I am concerned. There was no fault found by engineers, so the aircraft was sent flying again with passengers on board and still is.

"At the same time, teams of investigators are still trying to find out what caused it by going through the flight data recorder and flying the simulator."

webTitle: New body may let BNFL off the hook

fields.headline: New body may let BNFL off the hook
fields.standfirst:
Government plans to move management of nuclear liabilities under one roof

Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
fields.trailText: The government is considering plans to set up a new body responsible for decommissioning the bulk of Britain's nuclear power plants in a move to give fresh impetus for the delayed partial privatisation of British Nuclear Fuels.
fields.body:
The government is considering plans to set up a new body responsible for decommissioning the bulk of Britain's nuclear power plants in a move to give fresh impetus for the delayed partial privatisation of British Nuclear Fuels.

The body, known within Whitehall as the liabilities management authority, would take over and manage the liabilities associated with decommissioning ageing nuclear plant owned by BNFL, the Ministry of Defence and the UK atomic energy authority - now estimated at £34bn.

Effectively, taxpayers would foot the bill for the liabilities rather than, as originally planned, handing much of these over to the private sector in the government's 1998 proposal for selling off up to 49% of BNFL and raising about £2bn.

Senior government sources admitted yesterday that the idea of bringing responsibility for the country's nuclear liabilities under one roof was being canvassed and could bring benefits as the process of decommissioning older plants gathered speed.

"It's attractive because it gets BNFL off the hook," they said. "It's a bit premature to say this is the body that will be adopted, but it would have the benefit of making BNFL more attractive as a proposition to private investors."

A spate of problems, including the falsification of data concerning the quality of reprocessed mixed oxide fuel rods for Japan and losses last year of £337m, has caused the planned public-private partnership model for BNFL to be shelved until the end of 2002, at the earliest.

But ministers are also acutely aware that any decision to burden taxpayers with billions of pounds of nuclear liabilities is politically dangerous. "So far the idea is being discussed by senior civil servants, but the charge is a huge downside so it may not work," the sources said.

The arithmetic of Britain's nuclear liabilities is notoriously complex, but BNFL has said it is responsible for £23bn of the estimated £34bn total, with the bulk of the rest due to the MoD and UKAEA and a small amount to other BNFL customers at its Sellafield site.

But BNFL's "bill" is undiscounted - what it is liable for if it had to pay it all at once. Its "discounted" liabilities, to be paid for during up to a century of decommissioning work, are understood to be about £10bn, and 88% of that has been set aside already. So the eventual burden on the taxpayer would be substantially less than the global £34bn.

The new plans have come to light as ministers consider afresh the issue of managing nuclear waste, partly prompted by British Energy's decision to seek renegotiation of its £300m contract with BNFL to reprocess spent fuel from its nuclear power stations and opt for final storage instead.

Nuclear operators are also pressing ministers to reconsider building new atomic power stations to help Britain meet its ambitious targets for cutting greenhouse gases, an idea that has found favour with the opposition front-bench and some senior Labour politicians.

But it finds little favour with government ministers who cannot see the commercial logic of commissioning new plant while decommissioning ageing stations. The industry acknowledges that an answer to the problem of nuclear waste will have to be found before any new plants can be considered.

webTitle: Comment: Jonathan Steele predicts more revolutions

fields.headline: Serbia is just the first of the postcommunist states to fall
fields.standfirst:
Belarus, Azerbaijan and Georgia could all follow in Belgrade's steps
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia is gradually coming back in from the cold and restoring relations with Britain and the Nato states which bombed it last year. But, as normality resumes, a strange myth still hovers around the popular uprising which overthrew Slobodan Milosevic.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia is gradually coming back in from the cold and restoring relations with Britain and the Nato states which bombed it last year. But, as normality resumes, a strange myth still hovers around the popular uprising which overthrew Slobodan Milosevic.

It was "the last of eastern Europe's great anti-communist revolutions", according to Michael Dobbs of the Washington Post, a seasoned reporter of European communism. "If the Solidarity revolution in Poland was the beginning of the end of communism, this was the end of the end of communism," writes the academic Timothy Garton Ash.

Wait a minute. Wasn't the distinguishing mark of the Stalinist systems which collapsed in the late 1980s in eastern Europe the fact that they were one-party states? Independent media were banned. Freedoms of assembly and speech were tightly constrained. And of course there were no contested elections.

So where's the similarity with Serbia in the year 2000? Didn't Milosevic call an election and lose? Wasn't his victorious opponent, Vojislav Kostunica, the head of an 18-party coalition? Didn't opposition parties run local government in a dozen Serbian cities, backed by scores of independent radio stations and newspapers?

Long after communism in Europe has gone, it is as though the anti-communist triumphalism which reached its peak at the end of the cold war blindly carries on. People hoped Milosevic, who was once a communist, would be forced out of power a decade ago. It did not happen. Too bad. But he has gone now, so this was just a triumph delayed.

It is a good try but it will not wash. Ten years is a long time in politics and Serbia has changed enormously since the late 1980s. It became a typical example of a postcommunist state.

By 1987, when he seized the leadership of the Socialist Party of Serbia, Milosevic was already more of an opportunist than a communist. He became a nationalist and co-opted the Greater Serbian agenda of the country's second world war monarchists and anti-communists.

Economically the system Milosevic created was a hybrid, similar to the flawed privatisations well-known elsewhere. Cronies of the political leadership ran state companies or held lucrative posts in businesses whose exact ownership was obscure.

Serbia had a multiparty system, but with elections that were "free but unfair", because of the influence of Milosevic's monopoly control of state television. People could march and rally against him. Only when they seemed to be gaining sufficient strength to challenge him did he call out the police. By Stalinist standards his approach to dissidents was mild. His favourite weapon of repression - contract killing - was borrowed from the mafia rather than eastern Europe in the 1980s. The parallel is with the authoritarian postcommunist former Soviet states, including Yeltsin's and Putin's Russia, with their mysterious murders and unfair elections.

The crowds who swarmed into Belgrade last month were not shouting slogans against communism. They were angry about corruption and a collapsed economy. The freedom they wanted was not freedom from one-party rule but freedom from one-man rule, or, more accurately, from one-family rule. Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic, is as hated as he was.

We have to look to Asia rather than Europe for similarities to this aspect of Serbia's revolution. The Belgrade Autumn's antecedents can be found in the Philippines in 1986 when crowds rose up against Ferdinand Marcos and his wife Imelda after they, like Milosevic, tried to fiddle election results. Serbia also had echoes of Tehran in 1979, when mass demonstrations and a mutinous army forced the Shah and his wife to leave. Most recently it recalls Jakarta in 1998 when another corrupt dictator at the head of a flawed multi party system, President Suharto, had to resign.

What happened this autumn in Serbia was not the last anti-communist revolution in Europe. It was Europe's first postcommunist revolution. We may see the next ones in Belarus or more probably in Azerbaijan, where there is a similar mixture of disappointed nationalism, thousands of refugees, catastrophically declining living standards and rising anger over corruption amongst the elite.

In Serbia, the main issue which prompted the uprising was betrayal. After 13 years Milosevic had broken all his promises. His claim to defend Serbs throughout the former Yugoslavia had ended with more than a million Serbs as refugees from Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo. His defiance of the world led to sanctions and a ruined economy, from which only the big-time smugglers and their friends in the regime grew rich.

Most revolutions contain an element of restoration. They are not only about creating a better future but restoring the best aspects of the past. Nostalgia for the stability of communist times is common throughout the former Soviet Union as well as eastern Europe. So it is not surprising that in this first postcommunist revolution in Europe many middle-aged Serbs remembered the days when Yugoslavs could travel freely throughout western Europe as a golden age. Yugoslavia was the most liberal communist country in Europe, and some had worked in their youth as guestworkers in Germany, Austria and Switzerland when Poles, Hungarians and Czechs were still locked behind the iron curtain.

In the hours after Milosevic's defeat it was fascinating to see how dozens of Serbian companies were taken over by their staff. Within the bigger political uprising, a series of economic uprisings was going on as employees forced their way into managers' officers, prevented them from taking away the companies' financial documents, and ordered them to leave. Tito's system of workers' self-management briefly revived.

The states of central Europe have managed the transition to a market economy more or less smoothly and even though inequalities have widened the fallout has been contained by a general upsurge in growth. Their political systems offer a genuine opportunity for removing the government, and there has been regular alternation of parties in power without electoral fraud.

The same is not true in Belarus, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan or Georgia, or indeed Russia. Serbia's revolution was prompted by special factors, in particular 10 years of pointless and lost wars. That may make Serbia a unique exception which will not be repeated elsewhere. But the higher probability is that Europe's first postcommunist revolution against corruption, crony capitalism and flawed democracy will not be its last.

webTitle: Comment: US elections; at last, the endgame

fields.headline: At last, the endgame
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: I was up against Garry Kasparov, for 15 years the world chess champion. I captured the pawn offered in his opening gambit. It was a trap. We were on television debating the great Florida fiasco, and he had layers of argument in his arsenal.
fields.body:
I was up against Garry Kasparov, for 15 years the world chess champion. I captured the pawn offered in his opening gambit. It was a trap. We were on television debating the great Florida fiasco, and he had layers of argument in his arsenal.

I pointed out to him that all America's institutions were working as they are supposed to work - more or less. Yes, there were 57 varieties of screw-ups leading to the great chad hunt. The combination of the "butterfly" ballot in Palm Beach county, which confused the choice between Gore and Buchanan, and the local Democratic party's inept instructions to black voters in Duval county, had probably cost Gore upwards of 50,000 votes. There is no glossing over this. It is a disaster in terms of helping the lesser man to win, in terms of the implication of racial discrimination, in terms of getting rather more than half of the nation's registered voters to turn up at the polls next time.

And, yes, Secretary of State Katherine Harris's hairstyle was as dated as her impersonation of Mayor William Hale Thompson shutting down the vote-counting in Al Capone's Chicago when things weren't going right. But she hadn't got away with it. The press had exposed her political connections and her rum record.

Kasparov advanced a knight to a troubling square. America, as the leader of the free world, had always been able to point to its own elections as a model other countries could follow. How could it do that in future when both parties had taken the nation into the fog of litigation, when they were calling each other thieves? He echoed James Baker, for Bush, that every passing day heightened the crisis.

I castled. There is no crisis. The people who have gone on the streets have been like choirboys on a church outing. President Clinton - whom so many now would like to stay on for a third term - is running the country well enough without a president-elect bothering him.

Kasparov had a bishop he brought into play in the form of Griffin Bell, a former judge of the US court of appeal and attorney general under President Carter. "The election of a president requires speed, finality and certainty," argues Bell. But isn't legitimacy a higher priority than speed? What's the rush? The country has had these hiccups before. In the famous 1960 election, the Republicans argued against John Kennedy's legitimacy right up to the moment the men and women from the states took off their overcoats at the doors of the electoral college in December.

The idea that litigation is ominous would carry more weight, I argued, if Gore, with a 200,000 lead in the popular vote, were in any way challenging the legitimacy of the electoral college, trying to change the rules midway in the game. But he isn't and he won't. He is just asking for a fair and accurate vote. That would be vexatious if the rivals were separated by thousands, but they are not. It comes down to a matter of hundreds or scores and a system that is no advertisement for American technology. Machine voting is admitted by the manufacturer to have a margin of error.

Safety-first hand counts are provided for in Florida election law, and have been used by both parties in other squeakers. And they are in the election rules signed into law by Governor Bush himself. Gore wants to win, but he is not being as cynical as his critics maintain when he says the argument is as much about democracy as winning. Both men have a duty to protect the integrity of the single ballot. The right of every citizen to vote and to have his or her vote counted was won by ordeal too recently in this country for disenfranchisement by any means to be regarded as a trivial matter.

But Kasparov produced a check. These bits and pieces of argument I had advanced might satisfy a sophisticated electorate in the great American democracy. The people were used to playing on both black and whites squares with certain rules. What I was failing to consider was how it all might appear in convalescent Russia, in Africa and Latin America, and how easy it would be for the enemies of democracy to exploit the Florida fiasco as typical of the corruptions of bourgeois freedoms. He has a point.

I expect to get out of check with the help of the Florida supreme court which begins its hearings today. I hope that in this endgame the judges will come to the rescue with a ringing declaration that the people's right to the vote is not to be denied by contrivances of speed and bureaucracy and ambition. In the witch-hunts of the cold war, in Watergate, and in the Vietnam war, the judiciary has well served the constitution and American democracy. I think it will do so again.

fields.headline: Arshad Mahmud @Dhaka
fields.trailText: They're a nice lot, the harijans (untouchables) of Bangladesh. Quiet, shy and uncomplaining, seemingly content with whatever little they have. They're not normally seen much outside their designated colonies, where they have lived cheek-by-jowl since their forefathers arrived here from the United Provinces in India (now Uttar Pradesh) more than 100 years ago. The British administrators brought them to what is now Bangladesh because they couldn't find local people willing to sweep the streets and clean the toilets.
fields.body:
They're a nice lot, the harijans (untouchables) of Bangladesh. Quiet, shy and uncomplaining, seemingly content with whatever little they have. They're not normally seen much outside their designated colonies, where they have lived cheek-by-jowl since their forefathers arrived here from the United Provinces in India (now Uttar Pradesh) more than 100 years ago. The British administrators brought them to what is now Bangladesh because they couldn't find local people willing to sweep the streets and clean the toilets.

Unlike in neighbouring India, the harijans here never attracted much attention until they held their first national conference in Dhaka a couple of months ago. Aimed at highlighting their various demands (for job security, better education and medical facilities), the conference not only unmasked accumulated grievances but also revealed the staggering number of harijans scattered over Bangladesh - more than one million.

"We didn't have much chance to complain before as we weren't expected to do anything else except sweeping and drinking," says Ram Kumar Das, 23, who lives with his extended family in Miranjilla, the country's biggest sweeper colony - a collection of brick and tin shacks in old Dhaka that is home to more than 5,000 people. He works as a cleaner at the Dhaka city corporation, a job he landed automatically after his father's retirement five years ago.

It was a sense of job security, coupled with free housing and medical facilities, that apparently kept the community relatively happy. But now those privileges, once taken for granted, are under threat as spreading poverty and shrinking job opportunities have forced members of the majority Muslim population to vie for the "dirty work" they once considered demeaning.

"I had a great time when I used to do four jobs," says Bihari Lal, 75, who has now become a sadhu (Hindu priest) and wears saffron clothes and rosary beads. "I earned enough to indulge in boundless boozing. But our condition began to deteriorate when the Muslims started doing our work."

Today, out of the 5,000 permanent sweepers employed by Dhaka city corporation, the harijans make up just over 40%, and the proportion is dwindling. The situation with other employers is similar.

"We thought we could no longer keep quiet as this is a question of our existence", says Krishna Lal, 42, president of the Bangladesh Harijan Unity Council, created 10 years ago to bring all members of the community under one banner. He says that the conference was a huge success, especially in terms of publicity.

Mohammad Hanif, the city mayor, who was the special guest, declared he would henceforth reserve 70% of cleaning jobs for the harijans. But that is not good enough for Mr Lal. "We want the authorities to give us the full quota," he says. "That was the undertaking given to our forefathers when they were first brought here."

The city corporation dismisses the demand as absurd. "It simply cannot be done," says Jahangir Hossain, spokesman for the mayor. Moreover, he says, Bangladesh is under no obligation to honour a commitment made by the British colonial masters.

"When we think of our community in India we are gripped by a sense of deprivation," says Arjun Lal, 48, vice president of the Harijan Unity Council. "Some of our kith and kin have risen to become administrators and even ministers." By contrast, only a handful here have broken the mould - and then largely by suppressing their harijan identity. Education beyond primary level is practically nonexistent.

Nevertheless, most harijans here do not consider moving back to India, although some of them have relatives living there. "This is our home," says Arjun Lal. "We were born and raised here. We do not know any other country we can call ours."

webTitle: 2,000 jobs at risk in Barings review

fields.headline: 2,000 jobs at risk in Barings review
fields.trailText: More than 2,000 City jobs were under threat last night after the Dutch owner of the former Barings bank signalled its intention to pull out of investment banking.
fields.body:
More than 2,000 City jobs were under threat last night after the Dutch owner of the former Barings bank signalled its intention to pull out of investment banking.

The precise job toll was unclear but the highly paid traders, analysts and investment bankers of the ING Barings unit are expected to arrive at their desks this morning shocked by the revelation that the business's future is being reviewed.

In a complete reversal of its strategy, Amsterdam-based ING last night appeared to signal the end of the operation it bought in 1995 for £1 after "rogue trader" Nick Leeson ran up millions of pounds in losses in Singapore. Less than six months ago, ING bought stockbroker Charterhouse Securities in a move that was re garded as sign of commitment to the ING Barings operation by the Dutch bank.

Last night, in a hastily prepared statement, the bank said: "ING is reviewing the future position of its investment banking activities."

It has appointed Goldman Sachs to find a buyer for its US operation while its European business is to be integrated into its "wholesale" banking business. The Asian, central European and Latin American businesses, however, are expected to emerge relatively unscathed.

City sources said the new chairman, Ewald Kist, had been shocked by the wage bill of the investment bankers.

A review had already been under way under the auspices of David Robins, the head of ING Barings, which took a knock during the Asian crisis three years ago.

This latest review appeared deeper, however, even though ING tried to insist last night that the decision to review the future of the investment bank was one of its "normal business assessments".

"An update on the review process will be provided early next year at the latest," the bank said.

Speculation about the long-term future of ING Barings is expected to prompt a swath of departures, even ahead of the annual bonus round. "The big boys will just walk out," one senior source said.

ING indicated that the decision to review the investment bank had been motivated by the recent spate of takeovers in the industry where a number of firms such as Donaldson Lufkin Jenrette, Robert Fleming and PaineWebber have been bought by larger investment banking players.

webTitle: Jupiter founder's unfair dismissal fight may shed light on City pay

fields.headline: Jupiter founder's unfair dismissal fight may shed light on City pay
fields.trailText: A £15m court case which could lift the veil of secrecy over lucrative City pay deals was on a knife-edge last night.
fields.body:
A £15m court case which could lift the veil of secrecy over lucrative City pay deals was on a knife-edge last night.

John Duffield, the former head of fund management group Jupiter - one of the biggest sellers of Isas to small investors - was last night trying to thrash out a settlement with German Commerzbank over an unfair dismissal claim due to start in the high court this morning.

Mr Duffield, who founded Jupiter in 1985, was ousted in May this year following a row over pay and bonuses. He is suing Commerzbank for £15m.

But last night both sides were trying to reach an agreement which would keep secret the details of the way City salaries work.

There is speculation that if he wins the case, Mr Duffield may attempt to lure away his former colleagues at Jupiter to New Star, an investment management firm he is setting up.

While the case is expected to last several weeks, neither side has ruled out the possibility of reaching a settlement.

Mr Duffield, who was chairman of the company, was dismissed following negotiations about the structure of the operation, and in particular about new pay and bonus arrangements, after Commerzbank took full control of the business early this year.

It had owned 75% of the business and paid £500m for the remaining 25% owned by the Jupiter fund managers.

Mr Duffield, who has a reputation as a tough negotiator, was said to have received £175m for his stake. He built up Jupiter from little more than a one-man operation into what was until recently Britain's most popular fund manager, known for its ubiquitous bill board advertisements depicting the planet Jupiter.

The group manages more than £15bn in funds. Its best known product is the £1.5bn Jupiter Income unit trust, held by more than 200,000 investors and managed by William Littlewood from 1991 until this year - when he quit because of problems with his health.

webTitle: Duffield's nice littler earner puts him into the top five

fields.headline: Duffield's nice littler earner puts him into the top five
fields.standfirst: The £175m Fund Manager John Duffield received from Commerzbank earlier this year has catapulted him into the top five of the UK's biggest earners.
fields.trailText: The £175m Fund Manager John Duffield received from Commerzbank earlier this year has catapulted him into the top five of the UK's biggest earners, writes Julia Finch.
fields.body:
In a new survey of the country's top 500 earners Mr Duffield is ranked fourth, behind Formula One chief Bernie Ecclestone, Matalan discount clothing millionaire John Hargreaves and internet entrepreneur Peter Harrison.

Edward Bonham Carter, who took over from Mr Duffield as chief executive of Jupiter, is ranked 45 in the pay list with his £20m from the Commerzbank deal.

Mr Ecclestone, 70, raked in £617m during the last year, selling 50% of his holding company to venture capitalists. John Hargreaves, 56, banked £237m when he sold a tranche of shares in his firm, although he still owns more than half the business. Mr Harrison, 63, made £177m selling selling 49% of his firm to a South African company.

Ten of the top 25 earners in the Sunday Times survey made their money out of computing and telecoms. Harry Potter novelist J K Rowling is the highest ranked woman at £25m.

The highest earning sportsman is Lennox Lewis, who picked up £30m, and the best paid celebrity is DJ Chris Evans, who sold his Ginger Media Group to SMG for £75m, £35m of it in cash.

fields.headline: Swim like a swan, peddle like a winner
fields.trailText: Sometimes we talk big - investor events in Paris, meeting celebrities, European expansion, and so on. This week we are setting our sights a little lower - the Rools "join form".
fields.body:
Sometimes we talk big - investor events in Paris, meeting celebrities, European expansion, and so on. This week we are setting our sights a little lower - the Rools "join form".

Our site is constantly developing, but most visitors to www.rools.com will not be aware of changes. It sometimes seems akin to a swan in water - the apparent ease of progress masking a flurry of rather less elegant movement below the surface.

The development work focusing on the core database and systems - the "back end", to use inspired industry terminology - is hidden away. It is not necessarily reflected in differences in the user's experience of the site - the "front end", following the same impeccable logic.

A good example of this is online "join forms". They are generally easy to fill in and appear easy enough to develop. But it can be a genuinely complex task, and behind the scenes some clever things happen.

We obviously want to capture as much valuable information as possible from the customer. But we need to balance that requirement with the need to make our site easy for customers to use. If we make the form too complex, too long or simply too intrusive, people will not bother spending time filling it in - and then we risk losing those customers.

As an online payments service our transaction security is absolutely crucial. Our "join form" asks more questions than it would, say, if Rools were a news service that simply wished to send out daily news updates by email, where just an email address suffices.

We also need to be far more particular about the quality of the data we receive; therefore we have tight rules specifying what can and cannot be entered in different parts of the form. For instance, you cannot have sequential letters or numbers within your password and must have a combination of letters and numbers.

The challenge lies in producing a "join form" that meets these requirements and is also still usable from the customers' point of view.

The Rools "join form" we introduced a couple of weeks ago appears to do this, although it is tougher than the average to complete. Although it sometimes means customers having more than one attempt at correctly completing it nobody has yet given up on the process.

Given the tone of some of the registrations we have received many people have had fun completing our form. Among the user names submitted just last week were JustAPintPlease, vertically-challenged ShortAlex, his more substantial friend BigFella and JesusChrist - from Huddersfield. We are not sure whether we are going to accept the last one yet.

In general the quality of information we have so far obtained from customers has been excellent. It appears, therefore, that the systems supporting the form, the legs kicking furiously away, as with the rest of the back end, seems to be working pretty well. The focus of the next month is on making the bit above the surface, what the user sees - far more elegant and swan-like.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools, a payment service allowing teenagers to make online purchases

fields.headline: Leave something in the invisible hand
fields.trailText: High street banks that abandon the high street, energy firms that shut showrooms and supermarkets that march out of town deny they are deserting their customers. Merely responding, say the marketeers, to evolving public preferences for queueing online rather than in line, writes Alan Shipman.
fields.body:
High street banks that abandon the high street, energy firms that shut showrooms and supermarkets that march out of town deny they are deserting their customers. Merely responding, say the marketeers, to evolving public preferences for queueing online rather than in line. Cost savings from branch closures will, rejected personal callers are promised, more than reward them for the traipse to the next town, or the endless Vivaldi in place of real voice at the end of the telephone.

But if snubbed customers close accounts or switch supplier the losers are likely to delete them from the database more with rejoicing than remorse. Banks long ago discovered that 20% of clients provide all the profit, whether saving or borrowing. The rest cost so much to recruit and retain and stick to such basic services that their disappearance actually helps the bottom line.

Other sectors are now making the same discovery as they "mine" transaction data to pinpoint differences in customer profitability.

Broad geographic and demographic categories are used to vary products' pricing and specification for maximum return, pushing the least lucrative out of the market. Now the categories are closing in. Buying records are digitally pooled and relentlessly probed for predictors of future purchase profitability.

The result is further to enrich those the market already rewards. Easy attraction, prompt payment and regular spending on higher margin items beget loyalty bonuses. Those who choose only the loss leaders, spurn fancy follow-up offers, overdose on after sales service, or take the free advice and shop elsewhere, find the offer terms tilted against them.

Twentieth century mass production had its counterpart in mass consumption. Corporate success lay in growing shares of a growing market, by having a product or service for everyone. The Mini driver might envy the Jag but all drivers were supplied, not unusually from adjacent assembly lines.

With re-customisation of production comes selective consumption. Premium products are rationed, as always, by waiting list or price tag, to maintain exclusivity.

But now, lines that are too popular are being "repositioned" upmarket and bargain brands dropped.

Even the net now has its password protected areas accessible only to owners of high speed connections.

Too blatant a culling of low margin customers invites low budget retaliation.

BA's business class focus clears the runway for EasyJet; pop musicals oust the opera house. But while more inclusive, these mass market operations still draw on data which can single out those who "churn" too frequently.

The social impact of customer deselection is heaviest for goods and services traditionally offered to all.

Prime examples are retail financial services, utilities, basic health care and insurance, which is why welfare and pension benefits once came via national insurance, phones and energy supply were state-owned or regulated, and banks could abstain from competition - for staff or savers - provided they made loan and deposit facilities available to all but the obvious non-payers.

UK utilities have now been sold off, financial services deregulated, and national insurance is shrinking to a means tested core. Rollout of stakeholder pensions and "basic" bank accounts are constrained by the banks' reluctance to cannibalise present higher margin versions. Freed of universal service obligations, private providers rarely hesitate to cut out their least profitable clients.

Logged-on customers now have the scope to trawl for bargains, haggle for discounts, and pool their buying power. But doing so risks a rapid ejection from the data warehouse, while those starved of computer access and credit limits find the discount wars fought above their heads. We can always move to escape postcode prescriptions. Fleeing a miserly purchasing record may not be so easy.

Low pay and lack of employee protection during industrialisation led to demand for public control of the means of production. Post-industrial precision marketing may soon bring matching calls for public control of the means of consumption, if the invisible hand pick snatches too much from the invisible hand.

 Alan Shipman is an independent economist and author of The Market Revolution and its Limits; Routledge

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: The Observer
fields.body:
The Observer

The Department of Trade and Industry has extended its inquiry into share dealings at the Mirror to cover alleged hacking into the newspaper's City share tips pages by certain of the newspaper group's staff.

Troubled engineering group Invensys is expected to announce the £4bn spin-off of its fast-growing power systems division this week.

Sunday Times

The chairman of Vivendi, Jean-Marie Messier, has drawn up plans to scrap the £5bn auction of Seagram's drinks business. He plans to engineer a sale to Pernod Ricard of France and its British partner, Diageo.

Executives at MG Rover are talking to at least three motor manufacturers over sharing a new medium-sized car production platform at their Longbridge site.

The Earl of Sandwich and Orlando Montagu, his son, are resurrecting the family business. They are being backed in their first sandwich-retailing venture by Robert Earl, the founder of Planet Hollywood, who has taken a board position.

Sunday Business

Office rents in London have breached the £100 per sq ft level for the first time. Morgan Grenfell private equity has paid the record rent to secure space at a plush development in St James's Square in the heart of Mayfair.

Virgin Sun, Sir Richard Branson's Mediterranean package holiday operation which was launched 18 months ago, is to cease winter operations and may be sold.

Sunday Telegraph

An Italian bank is believed to be preparing a £500m bid for Countrywide Assured, Britain's biggest owner of estate agents. Bankers say Mediolanum, the fast growing Italian insurance and banking group, is prepared to offer between 140p and 150p a share for Countrywide valuing the business at up to £540m.

Shell, the Anglo-Dutch oil group, is preparing to break with tradition by extending the chairmanship of Sir Mark Moody-Stuart beyond his June retirement for up to two years.

Henry Lane Fox, one of the founders of Lastminute.com and younger brother of Martha, has quit the beleaguered internet company to set up his own business.

Mail on Sunday

Abbey National is preparing to launch a hostile bid for Bank of Scotland - even though Abbey's top executives know this could put at risk its own independence if it fails.

Airtours chairman David Crossland has quietly raised a for sale sign above Britain's biggest travel company. According to sources, Crossland and other senior executives have been indicating they would be willing to sell for 400p a share, valuing the company at about £2bn.

Sunday Express

Sainsbury, Britain's second biggest supermarket chain, has expressed an interest in embattled convenience store group Alldays which put itself up for sale this month.

Privatisation of the Royal Mint is set for a dramatic return to the political agenda in the new year. A high-powered committee of MPs is to hold the first Commons inquiry into the Mint's work and future status.

IoS

Sir Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority, is understood to have ruled out a rescue plan for Equitable Life if, as many in the industry now expect, the troubled life and pensions group fails to find a buyer.

BP Amoco, the energy giant, is working on a bid for exploitation group BG International which would value the demerged half of the old British Gas at £12bn.

Interims 600 Group, Burtonwood Brewery, DCC, Highams Systems, Majestic Wine, nCipher (Q3), Torotrak. Finals Deltron, RM. AGMs Channelfly.com, Eleco, Murray TMT.

EGMs Evestment.

AGMs Frogmore Estates. EGMs Jupiter European.

Wednesday

Interims CML Microsystems, De la Rue, Invensys, IQE, J Sainsbury. Finals L Gardner. AGMs Primary Health Properties, Profile Therapeutics. EGMs Laird Group.

Thursday

Interims 3i Group, Abbeycrest, BTG, FKI, J Latham, Mothercare, New Look, Safeway, Scapa Group, Teamtalk.com, Victoria. Finals Fibernet Group AGMs Waterman Partnership. EGMs Tullow Oil.

Friday

Interims Black Arrow Group, Prelude Trust. Finals None scheduled. AGMs Allied Leisure, Baille Gifford Japan, Marylebone Warwick, Manganese Bronze, Northern Recruitment. EGMs None scheduled.

Today

UK CBI SME survey (Q). UK PSNCR (Oct). UK Provisional M4 (Oct). UK M4 lending (Oct). UK BSA building society lending (Oct). UK CML mortgage lending (Oct). JP Trade surplus (Oct). EU ECB's Padoa-Schioppa speech.

fields.headline: Come fly with me
fields.standfirst: From both inside and above, Bilbao's magnificent new airport resembles a bird about to take flight.  Jonathan Glancey  on a design that puts the mystery and magic back into air travel
fields.trailText: From both inside and above, Bilbao's magnificent new airport resembles a bird about to take flight. Jonathan Glancey on a design that puts the mystery and magic back into air travel
fields.body:
It is a delightful conceit. As it yaws into view from the window of your incoming jet, the new Bilbao airport looks like a giant bird or plane that has made it to the ground shortly ahead of you. Perched on a virgin hillside site, untainted by the usual miasma of support buildings, Santiago Calatrava's operatic design, known locally as la paloma (the dove), is as precious as it is special. It has been designed - unlike, say, Heathrow or Gatwick, which have grown as if organically - as a gateway to the Basque capital, which in recent years has become a showcase for show-off contemporary architecture.

The old airport was a low-set, dour affair. But then, although a fascinating city, the Bilbao of just 10 and 15 years ago was known (by those who didn't know it) for little more than oily docks, ETA, salted cod, failing heavy industry and a mysterious language as old as the taut muscle of stubby mountains that hides Euskadi from the rest of mainland Spain.

In fact, Bilbao has never been less than fascinating, if a little secretive, in the past. The old city centre is a haunting gridded canyon of handsome stone buildings, of deep arcades sheltering coffee drinkers from the rain that falls in bucketloads. How there can be any left for the plains of Spain is quite beyond me.

But, boy, when Bilbao got the modern bug and crept out from behind its defensive carapace a little more than a decade ago, it attracted some of the most magnetic new architecture anywhere in the world. The global tourist industry can't get enough of Frank Gehry's titanium-clad Guggenheim Museum; the new metro, an engineering marvel in a city dug into high rocks, has been given the Norman Foster treatment and is one of the finest and easiest to use anywhere in the world; restaurants and bars have smartened up their acts. Cesar Pelli, the architect who brought the Canary Wharf tower to London's Docklands, is designing a skyscraper for this groundscraping city, and Michael Wilford, architect of the Lowry centre in Salford, is to design the new railway station. And there's more to come.

Spain has consistently produced some of the very best new buildings of the past 20 years, and remains the single most rewarding country for students of modern architecture. Much of the finest work, however, is, if not reserved, then quite severe and intellectually rigorous as befits the country that produced the cool magnificence of the Escorial, Philip II's palace outside Madrid. Bilbao, as usual, is slightly out of step: its new architecture is exuberant, and none more so than Calatrava's airport.

Bird-like imagery has been used before, by Calatrava himself, as well as Eero Saarinen in his gull-wing TWA terminal (1962) at what was soon to be renamed John F Kennedy Airport, New York. Getting an airport to look like a bird or plane taking off or coming in to land could be a corny thing to do 40 years on from Saarinen, yet the conceit works well. It promises a poetic ascent into the realm of the sky gods, even if we know that the reality, sadly, is closer to a thrombosis- inducing trip in a bus with wings, with food that is neither ambrosia nor honey-dew, and with singed coffee and tea that tastes like tin.

In this sense, Calatrava's airport is a brilliant lie: the building offers such things as dreams are flown on but that the airlines themselves cannot deliver, when so many people want to fly as frequently and as cheaply as possible. The airport, though, does its engaging best to redeem at least a part of the banality of modern air travel. It has a purity of vision that is rare in airport complexes: the four-storey car park, for instance, is tucked into a grassy embankment, out of sight and mind once the car has been abandoned. The departure hall - in the shape of a giant bird about to take flight - is a spectacular space that tries its best to lift passengers into the sky even before they have reached their plane.

Unlike British airports, there are no shabby carpets with eye-jarring patterns: the floors are of shining marble. And, also unlike British airports, with their stink of burgers, lavatories and fetid, mechanically cooled air, Bilbao is clean: clear of visual clutter and awash with daylight. There are those working in the airport who say that the famous Spanish engineer has been given too much of a free hand, that the airport's architecture is so deterministic that it may prove to be incapable of adapting readily to change.

Maybe. Yet, if change means - as it usually does in airports - more shops selling things you wouldn't normally want in a month of dumb days, more fast-food joints, more signs indicating even more exciting retail opportunities and generally more ways of making your journey longer and bittier, then it is rather comforting to know that Calatrava's all-of-a-piece design may yet resist such spoilsport developments. We'll see.

The ribbed concrete wings of the departure hall roof lead the eye up, up and away into the sky beyond its lofty apex. On the ground, passengers reach the sky by way of the departure hall and the four-storey departure gallery that lies beyond it, connected to the aircraft by beaky steel gangways. The departure gallery is a triumph, a kind of racetrack grandstand where passengers can watch planes swoop up and out between green hills. Although the £130m airport is designed to handle 6m passengers a year, it may soon be coping with as many as 10m, and its light and airy design should enable it to deal with Bilbao's increasing importance as both a tourist attraction in its own right and as a junction box for crisscross European travel.

Best of all is the sense all around you that this is a special building, designed to put a little mystery and magic back into air travel, even after you land: the baggage reclaim hall, with its mesmeric roof of arching concrete ribs, is like an air industry Aladdin's cave. Special, too, is the journey by road into the airport. You drive down towards it and can see quite clearly how Calatrava and his team have woven the building into its landscape in a way that actually enhances rather that detracts from the hillside scenery. For an airport this is quite something.

Calatrava's designs can seem a bit over the top, especially in photographs; yet in reality they have a kind of 3-D cinematic quality that redeems them every time. His many bridges - such as the Almillo over the Guadalquivir, Seville (1992) or the Lusitania spanning the Guadiana, Merida (1991) - resemble giant musical instruments: harps, lyres. And his best buildings - Lyon-Satalas TGV station (1994) and the Wohlen High School, Aargau, Switzerland (1988) - have an anthropomorphic power brimming with barely restrained energy. The British have yet to take Calatrava to heart; his design for the Dartford river crossing, linking Kent and Essex, was rejected some years ago for a design that singularly fails to stir the imagination; and a sensational revamp of a tall, if dreary, City of London office block was watered down and then effectively abandoned.

Calatrava's is a kind of Gotham City or Metropolis architecture, sometimes almost cartoony, yet never less than distinctive and stirring. As your jet makes its final approach, you can't help but look down on the new Bilbao airport and think: is it a bird, is it a plane?

fields.headline: Queen of the castle
fields.standfirst: Enya may not act like a star, but you can't argue with the figures - a staggering 44m albums sold over the past 10 years. She tells  John Aizlewood  the secret of her success
fields.trailText: Enya may not act like a star, but you can't argue with the figures - a staggering 44m albums sold over the past 10 years. She tells John Aizlewood the secret of her success.
fields.body:
Beneath the Wicklow Mountains, behind electric gates at the end of a mile-long driveway, lies Humewood Castle. Eithne Ni Bhraonain, better known as Enya, has come here to talk about A Day Without Rain, her first new album since 1995's The Memory of Trees. She lazes in front of a log fire, a velvet-clad, sparrow-like figure. She promptly ruins the effect by hacking a piece of well-worn chewing gum into a tissue. Enya, 39, is not one of life's natural gigglers, but she giggles anyway.

Castles are so Enya that she has purchased one herself, Ayesha Castle in Killiney, south Dublin. On one side she overlooks the Wicklow Mountains, on another, the Irish Sea. "It's very castle on the exterior," she says, "but it's very much a home inside. It's actually a very small castle and I fell in love with it."

Enya's fortress - still being renovated three years after she purchased it for £2.5m - towers over Bono's compound, in much the same way as her sales have towered over U2's since she sold the first of 44m non-soundtrack albums in 1988. "When I first walked in, someone said it overlooked Bono's," she smiles wryly, eyebrows slowly rising. "I thought, 'Hmm, so it does.' "

Enya's operation is tight-knit. Enya herself composes. Her manager Nicky Ryan arranges and produces. Ryan's poet wife Roma - who so closely resembles an older Enya that in some circles she is referred to as the "stunt double" - is responsible for the lyrics. Outsiders are unwelcome. "I don't like anybody else's opinion," she states firmly.

Enya is shy, but she is also not to be trifled with. Last month, in a move that harked back to more extravagant days, her record company stopped river traffic on the Thames to launch A Day Without Rain with a fireworks display. Enya was heard to remark how spectacular it all was, but that the money would have been better spent on point-of-sale displays in record shops.

From the very beginning, she has been an aloof, mysterious figure, untarnished by scandal. She is simply there: the blankest of canvases, rather quietly selling millions of albums (her publicity material claims that total sales of her recordings rival those of Cher, Tina Turner, Madonna and Whitney Houston). If the plan was to ensure that the artist's personality never obscured the artist's music, it has worked spectacularly well. "My private lifestyle bothers a lot of people," she sighs. "It's not a hanging offence not wanting to go to nightclubs. What happened to choice? My choice is that after a certain amount of promotion, I feel it gets very false and then I'm not interested. When the album has been out for, say, 10 months, people will start focusing on me and I really don't want that. I love the music to be known, but I'm not after fame for myself."

Enya's life was always musical. Her father, Lee O, was a Donegal showband leader, while her mother Marie was a music teacher. In 1970, two of her four older brothers, one of her four older sisters and two cousins formed Clannad, who enjoyed moderate suc cess in Ireland and abroad. A decade later, Nicky Ryan, Clannad's manager, soundman and producer, invited Enya, now classically trained, to join Clannad. Two years, two albums and several tours later, Ryan quit Clannad with his protegee.

"He loved the way Clannad harmonised," recalls Enya, "but he had this idea about recording a voice and layering it. He suggested I harmonise with myself and build it up spontaneously." It sounded vague, but Enya intuitively understood what Ryan was searching for. Roma Ryan enticed David Puttnam to use Enya on his 1985 film The Frog Prince. The BBC commissioned her for an episode of The Celts in 1987. On hearing the results, they commissioned her for the remainder of the series. I'm not thinking about what people would like to hear; that's dangerous, it's cheating myself. If I did that, I'd have to call it a day. What does come with me is inspiration from people, memories, landscapes, people I love. I would never be able to work anywhere else, certainly never at home. It's a very, very, peaceful, calming place."

She sits at her desk or piano, gazing across the Wicklow Moun tains, "just fishing", waiting for a song's basic melody to bite. When it does, she extends it and presents her work to Ryan. He then begins to build. Without sampling and without losing sight of the central melody, Enya wails over herself and her myriad instruments as many times as Ryan sees fit. She is the perfectionist, searching for the perfect emotional timbre. He is the pragmatist who sees the big picture, the one who knows when to stop. Meanwhile, Roma Ryan has been following the track's evolution and provides the lyrics.

"Myself and Roma don't sit and discuss. It's more the doing than the discussing that's important. After working together for all these years, Roma can sense the emotional feeling. For example, when I read her lyrics to Fallen Embers, they were exactly how I felt when I wrote the melody. Perfect." The process is not a speedy one. "You have to believe in what you're doing," she explains, "but the only way to feel you're going in the right direction is time. That's why there aren't 10 Enya albums out there." In fact there are three, not including her "best of" collection.

"This album is positive because that's where I'm at in my life," she continues. "Three years ago, I was asking whether I should take time out to have a family. I was putting pressure on myself and it was a terrible thing to do. Then I decided I wasn't going to pressurise myself and I've gone the route I wanted to go.

'I wouldn't change anything I've done over the past few years. That I'm not married and don't have children has been my choice. I don't feel I've missed out in any way. At school other girls talked about getting married, but it was never on my list of things to do. I was looking at something else."

Then she stops herself. "Actually what I went through wasn't as traumatic as I'm making out. I didn't think that much about it. I had to stop putting the pressure on myself, because of relationships coming and going, but if relationships aren't working that means they're not right. That's what the single Only Time is about."

She is at a loss as to why she is so successful internationally (Watermark went platinum in 14 countries). "It's very difficult. The only connection I have with my audience is a signing session or through letters. What comes across to me is the fact that when I sing in Gaelic they can still sense the emotional feeling in my performance."

Criticism and negativity are there to be spurned. "Anything that's negative I'm good at turning around and making positive," she says, sternly. "In the early days, I would be hurt and would believe everything I read. Nowadays, I don't expect everybody to listen to the music. I'll read good or bad criticism and neither bothers me. Within ourselves - myself, Nicky and Roma - we are really happy."

fields.headline: Art review
fields.trailText: Impression National Gallery, London *****
fields.body:
Impression National Gallery, London *****

This is the first exhibition ever to try to bring together the paintings the Impressionists themselves regarded as true "impressions": pictures that either really were painted quickly and in direct response to what the painter saw, or do their damnedest to look that way. Too many exhibitions and art histories today chip away, with boring destructiveness, at the idea of modern art. By concentrating on the physical, painterly nature of Impressionism, this one reminds us that art really was revolutionary once.

Impressionism was an attempt, perhaps the most radical and honest there has been, to accept the rapidity and depthlessness of modern life into art. Later modernists were more bombastic about it, but no painting suggests the casual, brutal vacancy of the modern world more economically than Claude Monet's La Gare d'Argenteuil (1872). A telegraph line hangs slackly, ruining the sky, over waste ground cut by railway lines; locomotives cough steam; in the distance is a solitary house. There is something truly empty about this scene, something truly modern.

The poet and critic Jules Laforgue said that an impression should take just 15 minutes to paint. La Gare d'Argenteuil is an authentic "impression", defined in 1870s France as a painting done rapidly and spontaneously, perhaps in a few hours, ideally less. You can see the rough rapidity of the brushing. Alfred Sisley's Boats on the Seine (1877), with its panoramic outdoor gusto, is equally obviously planned in the studio.

But in a way it didn't matter if one painting was a genuine impression and another took months. The myth of instantaneity generated the first modern painting.

By getting to the core of what this style of painting was, this exhibition tears some of the greatest artists of the modern era out of the blockbuster-exhibition ghetto. The Impressionists were the first to paint the new world of industry. In Manet's great urban scenes the modern world imposes itself brutally on to canvas; an early oil sketch for Bar at the Folies-Bergère captures the chaotic glitter of Paris nightlife as a maelstrom where the individual disappears. Later artists rebelled against Impressionism; they saw it as vacuous. But there's something about Impressionist vacancy that chills your spine. Berthe Morisot's Summer's Day (c 1879) is a painting of a trivial moment, two women in a boat in a park, one looking at the ducks, the other lost in thoughts. Of what? It's impossible to know.

The National Gallery has managed to put on an Impressionist exhibition that is a provocative new look at the beginnings of modern art. It deserves to pull a few of the crowd from Tate Modern.

 At the National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885), until January 28.
