webTitle: Analysis: Apathy on the march as voter turnout continues to fall

fields.headline: Apathy on the march
fields.standfirst: As voter turnout continues to fall across most of Europe, we have little to feel smug about in relation to the US election results
fields.trailText: According to a poll taken during the chaos of the American presidential election, some two-thirds of those who did not participate now regret not having cast their vote.
fields.body:
According to a poll taken during the chaos of the American presidential election, some two-thirds of those who did not participate now regret not having cast their vote.

That is a lot of voters. Turnout in US presidential elections has been falling more or less steadily since 1960. When Bill Clinton was challenged by Bob Dole in 1996, slightly fewer than half of those eligible bothered to take part. This time, turnout was some 51%, but even with this small increase American electoral participation remains lower than that in almost every other democracy in the world.

It seems yet another reason for Europeans to be smug. Not only does the world's leading democracy make a mess of counting votes, it also fails to engage the attention of almost half its citizens. Here in western Europe turnout levels average close to 80%. On this side of the Atlantic, democracy is alive and well.

It is a comforting myth but myth it is. Take European-level elections. In the 1999 contest for the European parliament, turnout in one ward in the north of England was 1.7%: of the 1,000 or so registered voters 17 actually took part. Although an extreme example, this was indicative of lack of interest in the European polls.

Across the UK as a whole, turnout in 1999 reached just 24%. In the Netherlands it was 30%, in Germany 45%. No other election in any of these countries had ever met with such popular indifference.

European elections are unique, of course. They choose representatives with little control over the European executive, whether in the form of commission or council of ministers. They are held simultaneously in 15 countries, each of which is busy with its own particular national agenda. They are contested by parties that take their terms of reference from national politics, often scarcely making reference to issues that will be dealt with in the European parliament. Finally, they involve candidates who seek to assign legitimacy to an institution that has become notorious, perhaps unjustly, for feather-bedding its occupants. That voters should prove indifferent is hardly surprising.

Elections inside the nation states of Europe are a different matter, of course. But even here there is less and less reason for democrats to be complacent. For although levels of turnout in national elections in most European countries might still be regarded as impressively high, they are also tending to fall. In their most recent national elections many European countries registered record low levels of participation. In 1999 Austria, Finland and Iceland recorded their lowest ever postwar turnouts. The Netherlands and Sweden reached their nadir in 1998, as did the UK and Ireland in 1997. Italy did so in 1996.

Nor are these simply one-off exceptions. Average turnout in national elections in western Europe has been falling slowly but consistently since the 1960s. Then, an average of more than 85% of eligible voters in the countries of Europe cast their votes in national elections - nearly 90% in Germany and more than that in the Netherlands. In the 1970s, this fell very slightly to just under 85% and then to just under 83% in the 1980s. In the 1990s, the drop was even bigger, falling noticeably below 80% for the first time in postwar history. Look at the Netherlands again - a drop of nearly 20%. The UK has, by contrast, proved relatively stable over the 40 years. (But note how European averages in the 90s are still high by comparison with the US.)

It is also noteworthy that the fall has been reasonably consistent across the different countries. In other words, not only do the 1990s record the lowest average turnout across western Europe as a whole, they also record the lowest average turnout in the vast majority of the individual countries. This itself is unusual, if only because it has usually been impossible to find trends that are common across so many different countries. Yet we see turnout hitting decade lows in the 1990s in polities as diverse as Austria, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Luxemburg, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland - countries where the ideological profile of the parties are quite different.

The only countries to buck the trend are Belgium, where voting is compulsory and almost invariant; Malta, which now records the highest turnout of any democracy; and the UK itself, where the record decade low was recorded in the 1980s, during the halcyon years of the Thatcher government.

Switzerland is the one country that comes anywhere near the levels of disengagement in America - not much more than 40% participated in national elections in the 1990s. But there referendums are a key instrument of democratic control.

So are we in Europe following the American way in electoral behaviour? In the context of what John Kenneth Galbraith called the culture of contentment, in a world in which competing political leaders seem less and less easy to differentiate, citizens appear to be becoming increasingly indifferent to politics. But won't they then also become increasingly indifferent to democracy itself? Whatever they do in the US, here in Europe there is little to be smug about.

 Peter Mair is professor of comparative politics at Leiden University in the Netherlands.

Mair@fsw.leidenuniv.nl

fields.headline: Bach lives!
fields.standfirst: Erica Jeal  is wooed by the violinist formerly known as Nigel
fields.trailText: Erica Jeal is wooed by the violinist formerly known as Nigel.
fields.body:
In a year of diverse tributes to Bach, last week's concert by Kennedy and the English Chamber Orchestra at London's Barbican Centre was as worthy as any, if only for the sheer sense of enjoyment emanating from the players and audience alike. "Bach lives!" shouted one fan during one of Kennedy's interminable preambles, and all but the most cynical listeners would have to admit they knew why. For Kennedy, the violinist formerly known as Nigel, was presenting these concertos as working music rather than a sacred memorial - music to be messed around with, appreciated and enjoyed.

He's getting on a bit to be called an enfant terrible, but Kennedy is as hard to place as ever. He's still the little boy who won't play nicely by himself in the corner. Visually he's stuck in the 80s, and it's mind-boggling that there is a hairdresser who is still prepared to deliver that New Romantic/mohican style. On the other hand, let's not forget that he has made some of the best recordings by a British artist.

The ECO had already settled down with a solid account of the first orchestral suite before Kennedy entered to play both of Bach's violin concertos and both double concertos - a challenge of endurance more than technique. Whenever he was truly concen- trating, for example at his first, sweet-toned entry in the A minor concerto, Kennedy really did sound like the world-class player he is. At other times, particularly during the final movements, the thrill of playing fast and loud took over. In the double concertos, with oboist John Anderson and violinist Barbara Doll, he seemed content to leave his ego aside. Yet he stamped his personality on the solo concertos, even squeezing in a mercifully brief imitation of a prog-rock guitar solo into one of the cadenzas.

Eight years ago Kennedy flounced out of the classical music "scene", announcing that he wasn't going to play dead men's music any more. Yet now he's preaching the genius of a man who departed 250 years ago. And he has been recording Bach with the Berlin Philharmonic - an orchestra that doesn't make discs with just anyone.

Could this be the start of a full rehabilitation into the world of the classical elite? Hardly - the Berlin Phil's audience (and players) are unlikely to tolerate the quirks of a soloist who leaves them to talk among themselves while he pops out of the hall for a quick pee.

Quite deliberately, Kennedy gets up lots of people's noses by refusing to play by the rules. But then he does makes it all look refreshingly like a game.

Hardly - the Berlin Phil's audience (and players) are unlikely to tolerate the quirks of a soloist who leaves them to talk among themselves while he pops out of the hall for a quick pee. Quite deliberately, Kennedy gets up lots of people's noses by refusing to play by the rules. But then he does makes it all look refreshingly like a game.

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst:
Pierre-Yves Gerbeau

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Newspapers: I read all the papers since my job is a little bit to do with the media. When I worked at Disney it used to take me about 10 minutes to read my press cuttings. Now it takes over an hour. I also read the FT, Les Echos and USA Today.
fields.body:
Newspapers: I read all the papers since my job is a little bit to do with the media. When I worked at Disney it used to take me about 10 minutes to read my press cuttings. Now it takes over an hour. I also read the FT, Les Echos and USA Today.

Magazines: I take Private Eye to relax. They've always got a good line on PY the Gerbil and his millennium tent. They've got a really good sense of humour, I think. I read golf magazines because I'm a crazy scratch golfer. I also get Newsweek and the Economist.

Books: The Art of War by Sun Tzu is my favourite. It was written in the 14th century and tells you everything about management. Every manager should read it - business is such a war. I'm also fascinated by history books. If I hadn't become a professional ice-hockey player, I would have been a history teacher.

Radio: I like the Today programme for my favourite nastiest man, John Humphrys. He made me say this week that I was going to buy the Dome. I'm a big fan of Jimmy Young. He asked me on his show and it went very well.

TV: I'm a big fan of GMTV. I watch Sky News and BBC1 in the morning, but that's all I have time for.

Films: My all-time favourite movie is Once Upon A Time In America.

Ads: Of course I love the Dome advert with the sheep. It has been a big success - there was no point in saying that the Dome was fine and lovely. My other favourite is the Whassup? advert. It's an incredible phenomenon.

New Media: The internet is firstly for pleasure, second for information and third to keep up to date. It's a very clever way to do business, but it won't change the face of the world. I'm into toys and have just bought the new Ericsson Wap phone and the 3Com Palm Pilot organiser. 3Com are sponsors of the Dome and I use it quite a lot. I haven't found a personal sponsor yet.

 Pierre-Yves Gerbeau is chief executive of the New Millennium Experience Company

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: End is nigh for Japan's leader
fields.body:
End is nigh for Japan's leader

The Japanese prime minister Yoshiro Mori's chances of remaining in power diminished yesterday when two deputy ministers resigned on the eve of a no-confidence vote to be moved by opposition parties, the Kyodo news agency said.

The ministers resigned so that they could vote for the motion, which threatens to split the ruling Liberal Democratic party.
Reuters, Tokyo

Dhaka wary of Burmese troops

Bangladesh has put its forces on high alert a week after Burma started deploying troops in the border province of Arakan to crush what it called an upsurge of rebel activity, reports said.

Burmese stepped up its operation after 32 soldiers died in clashes with rebels fighting for an independent state in the Muslim-dominated province.
Arshad Mahmud, Dhaka

Immigrants' fingerprints

European justice and interior ministers are to consider a controversial Italian proposal to fingerprint immigrants.
Philip Willan, Rome.

fields.headline: 'Ideal' snow claims four lives
fields.trailText: Four people died in two avalanches in the Austrian Alps yesterday.
fields.body:
Four people died in two avalanches in the Austrian Alps yesterday.

Two, a man and a woman, were buried alive under the mass of snow which swept down the mountain at the ski resort of Obergurgl in Tyrol province. Another man was pulled from the snow alive but died on his way to hospital.

The three were members of a ski club from Mannheim in Germany. Five other members of their party were only partly buried and were able to free themselves.

Hours later seven skiers were swept away by another Tyrolean avalanche, at Goelbner, 240 miles south-west of Vienna. An Austrian from the nearby town of Leinz was dug out alive by others in his party but died shortly afterwards at the site of the incident.

Police and rescue workers from Obergurgl, a tiny isolated resort south of Innsbruck near the Italian border, concentrated their search for for survivors on the Rosskar ski area, where witnesses said skiers had ventured on to runs which had been closed because of avalanche warnings.

The resort lies more than 3,000 metres (nearly 10,000ft) above sea level.

Within hours of the first slide, a second occurred several miles away. Several hours of searching failed to reveal any victims.

About 100 people from the regional mountain rescue service, together with trained mountain dogs, were involved in the searches in snow up to six metres (nearly 20ft) deep. Tourists and skiers were reported to be helping them in conditions described as "extremely difficult".

Visitors were attracted to the resorts yesterday by skiing conditions reported to be near-perfect, but immense quantities of newly fallen snow had raised the danger of avalanches.

The identities of the victims have been withheld.

webTitle: Shooting of Israeli consul spurs fear of wider conflict

fields.headline: Shooting of Israeli consul spurs fear of wider conflict
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: An Israeli diplomat was wounded by a gunman in the Jordanian capital, Amman, yesterday, reawakening fears that the violence in the West Bank and Gaza may spread.
fields.body:
An Israeli diplomat was wounded by a gunman in the Jordanian capital, Amman, yesterday, reawakening fears that the violence in the West Bank and Gaza may spread.

Foreign ministry officials in Jerusalem said the Israeli deputy consul Yoram Havivian was injured when a man opened fire on his car with an assault rifle yesterday morning. He was treated for cuts and returned to Israel.

Jordan promised to catch his assailant.

It was the first attack on an Israeli envoy in Jordan for a year, although there have been weeks of violent demonstrations by the kingdom's large population of Palestinian refugees. Jordan has come under pressure from other Arab states to cut its ties with Israel, with which it signed a peace treaty in 1994.

Two previously unknown groups, the Jordanian Islamic Resistance Movement for Struggle and the Group of the Holy Warrior Ahmed al-Daqamsah, called after the Jordanian soldier who killed seven Israeli schoolgirls three years ago, claimed responsibility.

The shooting threatened the mood of cautious optimism which has grown in Israeli officials with the reduction in violence since the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, issued a call for restraint.

On the same day Israel plucked the former president Ezer Weizman from retirement for a meeting with the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, who exerts a great deal of influence over Mr Arafat.

Mr Weizman, who shepherded Israel to a peace treaty with Egypt in 1979, spent more than two hours with Mr Mubarak at the resort town of Sharm el-Sheikh. Mr Arafat is to visit Sharm tomorrow.

Mr Weizman said he hoped Mr Mubarak could prevail on Mr Arafat to enforce his ban on opening fire from areas under full Palestinian control, such as Beit Jalla, from where gunmen regularly fire on the Jewish settlement of Gilo, outside Jerusalem.

Israel has unleashed harsh retribution for the gunfire against the residents of Beit Jalla, an easier target than the mobile, lightly armed gunmen.

Yesterday, Palestinian officials outlawed gunfire at demonstrations and funerals and banned schoolchildren from taking part in protests. Shops were ordered to resume normal hours.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, responded by telling his weekly cabinet meeting that the army would not retaliate for Saturday's ambush in the Gaza Strip, which killed one soldier and wounded two others.

webTitle: High price of speeding on the slopes

fields.headline: High price of speeding on the slopes
fields.trailText: Skiers in the US are preparing for the Thanksgiving holiday this week, aware that for the first time dangerous skiing could result in a charge of homicide.
fields.body:
Skiers in the US are preparing for the Thanksgiving holiday this week, aware that for the first time dangerous skiing could result in a charge of homicide.

Last week a skier was convicted of killing someone with whom he collided, and now faces up to six years in prison.

The verdict by a jury in Eagle, Colorado, raises the spectre of further criminal charges and civil action against skiers considered by juries to have acted in reckless ways.

Lawyers say the case has ramifications for surfers and others who take part in sports where collisions are not uncommon.

The death of such celebrity skiers as the singer and politician Sonny Bono and the Kennedy heir Michael on the American slopes in recent years heightened the need for improved controls on the millions who head for the slopes each season. But last week's verdict has taken the skiing world by surprise.

Nathan Hall, 21, of Chico, California, was convicted of the criminally negligent homicide of Alan Cobb, 33, from Denver, Colorado.

Hall, who worked as a lift operator at the resort of Vail in Colorado, collided with Cobb when he was skiing very fast in what witnesses described as poor conditions in 1997. Cobb died of head injuries.

"Today our ski slopes in Colorado and the world have been made safer," the prosecuting attorney, John Clune, said after the verdict.

"You can't recklessly ski and hurt somebody. I think the whole world should pay attention to this. He [Hall] was bombing down the mountain. He was reckless. That is why Alan isn't with us."

Hall was charged with reckless manslaughter, which carries a maximum jail sentence of 16 years. The lesser offence of criminally negligent homicide carries a penalty of six years. He will be sentenced at the beginning of next year.

Hall said he had a "lot of strong feelings and comments I want to make, but not at this time".

The jury heard a tape recording made after the accident in which Hall said he was "out of control" and unable to stop. The fact that he was an expert skier and thus aware of the risks of skiing at such high speed may have counted against him.

Civil actions are not uncommon after such incidents, and Cobb's family have reached a $300,000 (£210,000) settlement with the Vail resort. But lawyers say this is the first criminal trial of a skier for killing someone.

Last year, 30 people died on the American ski slopes, 23 skiers and seven snowboarders, down from 39 the previous year. The average annual death toll is around 34.

In a message on its website, the National Ski Areas Association says the risks of skiing should not be over-estimated.

"Skiing and snowboarding are no more dangerous than other high-energy participation sports."

It says last year's death toll was not high, considering that 7.4m skiers and 3.6m snow-boarders were engaged in the sports.

fields.headline: Ski disasters empty Austrian resorts
fields.standfirst: Fear grows of slump in the country's economic base
fields.trailText: Fear grows of slump in the country's economic base.
fields.body:
Austrian tourism is facing its toughest winter after a disastrous start to the skiing season. Four deaths in Tyrolean avalanches yesterday added to the fears generated by the mountain train inferno near Salzburg which killed 155 skiers and snowboarders a week earlier.

Tourist chiefs throughout the country are reeling as an increasing number of holidaymakers cancel their Austrian bookings and choose to ski elsewhere.

In and around Kaprun, the all-year skiing resort where the train caught fire last weekend, tour operators and hoteliers say that up to 90% have cancelled. The area is a jewel in the crown of Austrian winter sports, generating an annual turnover of about £175m.

Tourism officials met in Salzburg last week for crisis talks on how to cushion the blow to the industry, which has suffered a large number of disasters in recent years.

Their most significant decision was to cancel all tourism advertising for the rest of the season as a "sign of piety".

"It is a nationwide tragedy," the tourism minister, Mares Rossmann, said. But she added that the industry was "resilient" and would "bounce back fast".

Now empty of tourists and journalists, Kaprun is beginning to feel the weight of a burden it will probably carry for years.

The town has 3,000 residents and more than twice that number of beds to fill, and its tourist office is on the defensive.

"The tourist industry accounts for 75-80% of our economy," said Christian Pfeffer, the deputy tourism director.

"What's now important is to give visitors a sense of security and to be upfront about what's happened."

So what does he tell the many thousands of people who have been calling in with enquiries?

"We tell them there has been a tragic fire, a tragedy in a tunnel and not outside. The skiing area is totally safe. Kaprun is safe. You are safe in your hotel."

The Kitzsteinhorn pistes are due to reopen this Friday. The journey to the top will be a slower one, on a gondola ski-lift with eight-person cars capable of carrying 2,200 skiers to the glacier every hour.

Mr Pfeffer said plans were being considered to send tourism ambassadors to try to repair the damage done by the horrific pictures that went round the world of the burning alpine station, bloodied survivors and body bags.

"The fact is, the people didn't come here because of the train. They came because of the ski area, where the train brings them," he said.

"That remains as attractive as before."

But the train's safety precautions remain a matter of concern. The fire extinguishers were operable only by the driver; there were no sprinklers in the tunnel; the train's doors could not be opened from inside the carriage and there was no emergency hammer to smash windows; the tunnel had no emergency exit.

Most locals regarded the train as everything. Many held shares in the company, Gletscher Bahnen AG. It could carry 180 passengers up the mountain in under 10 minutes. When it opened 26 years ago, it was hailed as a world first.

Their belief in its invincibility - no fire drills were carried out because, the managers said, "we never thought a fire was possible" - is comparable to that of the builders of the Titanic.

Outside Kaprun's church, a local woman approached journalists last week. "Our livelihoods are ruined without the train," she said.

The opening of the service in 1974 transformed Kaprun from a sleepy village into a resort with an international reputation, particularly among snow-boarders.

Now Kapruners face a dilemma. The death of five locals, the youngest a boy of nine, has left deep wounds, but lawyers are knocking on their families' doors offering to represent them in a criminal liability case against the train company. Many realise that if they take up the offer they will be hurting their own.

It was as if a vow of silence had been made by locals last week. On my entering a ski-shop, before I had even asked a question, the shop assistants chimed in unison: "We know nothing."

Alpine tragedies

February 1999

Avalanche flattens village of Galtür in Tyrol, almost 40 die.

Two people die in an avalanche in Gargellen, Vorarlberg. Other resorts evacuated; 20,000 tourists stranded

May 1999

Twelve people killed after fire in Tauern tunnel, which runs between Salzburg and Villach. Salzburg's provincial leader, Franz Schausberger, admits: "We knew well that the tunnel was a time bomb"

June 1999

Four British tourists die in a white-water rafting accident on Salzbach mountain river

December 1999

Ten British tourists injured when their coach careers off a mountain pass in east Tyrol.

Nine German mountaineers die in an avalanche outside the village of Galtür near the Swiss border.

Avalanches in the following days injure dozens more

November 2000

155 people die when an alpine train carrying skiers up the Kitzsteinhorn glacier near Kaprun catches fire.

Avalanches at Tyrolean resorts claim four lives

webTitle: Greek culture minister in charge of Olympics fired

fields.headline: Greek culture minister in charge of Olympics fired
fields.trailText: Preparations in Athens for the 2004 Olympics ran into more problems yesterday after the prime minister, Costas Simitis, fired his outspoken culture minister, Theodoros Pangalos, who was in charge of overseeing the games.
fields.body:
Preparations in Athens for the 2004 Olympics ran into more problems yesterday after the prime minister, Costas Simitis, fired his outspoken culture minister, Theodoros Pangalos, who was in charge of overseeing the games.

The sacking, for characteristically blunt remarks made in a newspaper interview in which he criticised government labour reforms and cabinet colleagues, comes just three days ahead of a crucial visit to the Greek capital by a delegation from the International Olympic Committee headed by Jacques Rogge, the IOC vice-president.

Mr Rogge will be looking for assurances that Athens is back on track after a catalogue of delays and personnel changes that have put the city's ability to stage the games into serious doubt.

In April, the IOC president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, said that Greece was so far behind in its preparations that it was heading towards the "danger zone", where the Olympics could be given to another city. Mr Simitis then appointed himself head of a new government co-ordinating committee and brought in the flamboyant Gianna Angelopoulos-Daskalaki, who had fronted Greece's winning bid in 1997, to head the organising committee.

IOC leaders meeting in Warsaw last week acknowledged the progress made since then and said Athens could hold "excellent games".

But the bickering among Greece's ministers - many of whom were suspicious, even jealous, of Angelopoulos's role - did not stop, prompting the IOC to call for a truce.

With the IOC team about to arrive in Athens, an increasingly exasperated Mr Simitis was determined to show that his government was unified, sources said last night.

"A minister cannot hold a public dispute with the government, and cannot use reprehensible language against his colleagues," Mr Simitis said.

In an interview with the Sunday paper Ethnos, Mr Pangalos had questioned the socialist government's proposed labour reforms - which have sparked a wave of strikes across the country - and charged the foreign minister, George Papandreou, with naivety for his dealings with Turkey.

It is the second time that Mr Simitis has sacked Mr Pangalos. In 1999, the veteran politician was removed from his post as foreign minister for his part in a bungled attempt to offer sanctuary to the fugitive Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan.

The burly 62-year-old has an impressive record of gaffes and his appointment as culture minister following national elections in April raised more than a few eyebrows.

Despite his capriciousness, Mr Pangalos, a popular figure in Greece, was known for possessing a keen mind and for being a competent minister. "His loss will be felt," one cabinet colleague, who asked not to be named, said last night. "He must take some of the credit for upping the rate of progress for the Olympics."

The minister also raised questions about Mr Pangalos's successor, Evangelos Venizelos, and the sort of signal his appointment would give to the IOC. "It was under Venizelos's previous tenure at the culture ministry that many of the delays we face today occurred," said the minister.

The sacking, for characteristically blunt remarks made in a newspaper interview in which he criticised government labour reforms and cabinet colleagues, comes just three days ahead of a crucial visit to the Greek capital by a delegation from the International Olympic Committee headed by Jacques Rogge, the IOC vice-president. Mr Rogge will be looking for assurances that Athens is back on track after a catalogue of delays and personnel changes that have put the city's ability to stage the games into serious doubt. In April, the IOC president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, said that Greece was so far behind in its preparations that it was heading towards the "danger zone", where the Olympics could be given to another city. Mr Simitis then appointed himself head of a new government co-ordinating committee and brought in the flamboyant Gianna Angelopoulos-Daskalaki, who had fronted Greece's winning bid in 1997, to head the organising committee. IOC leaders meeting in Warsaw last week acknowledged the progress made since then and said Athens could hold "excellent games". But the bickering among Greece's ministers - many of whom were suspicious, even jealous, of Angelopoulos's role - did not stop, prompting the IOC to call for a truce. With the IOC team about to arrive in Athens, an increasingly exasperated Mr Simitis was determined to show that his government was unified, sources said last night. "A minister cannot hold a public dispute with the government, and cannot use reprehensible language against his colleagues," Mr Simitis said. In an interview with the Sunday paper Ethnos, Mr Pangalos had questioned the socialist government's proposed labour reforms - which have sparked a wave of strikes across the country - and charged the foreign minister, George Papandreou, with naivety for his dealings with Turkey. It is the second time that Mr Simitis has sacked Mr Pangalos. In 1999, the veteran politician was removed from his post as foreign minister for his part in a bungled attempt to offer sanctuary to the fugitive Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan. The burly 62-year-old has an impressive record of gaffes and his appointment as culture minister following national elections in April raised more than a few eyebrows. Despite his capriciousness, Mr Pangalos, a popular figure in Greece, was known for possessing a keen mind and for being a competent minister. "His loss will be felt," one cabinet colleague, who asked not to be named, said last night. "He must take some of the credit for upping the rate of progress for the Olympics." The minister also raised questions about Mr Pangalos's successor, Evangelos Venizelos, and the sort of signal his appointment would give to the IOC. "It was under Venizelos's previous tenure at the culture ministry that many of the delays we face today occurred," said the minister.

webTitle: Clinton leaves deep footprints on Vietnam

fields.headline: Clinton leaves deep footprints on Vietnam
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton ended his three days in Vietnam last night with the tide of popular support for his visit still apparently surging. But the enthusiasm masked dangerous undercurrents which suggested that the trip had been less than a total triumph.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton ended his three days in Vietnam last night with the tide of popular support for his visit still apparently surging. But the enthusiasm masked dangerous undercurrents which suggested that the trip had been less than a total triumph.

Mr Clinton spent yesterday in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, once the capital of South Vietnam and now the country's business hub. Had the security men allowed it, he would have been mobbed once more by delighted crowds.

But, as Air Force One took off for Washington, the response of his official hosts was somewhat colder.

Local television did not show the delighted crowds in the streets. And Mr Clinton's earlier calls for greater democracy have left some bruises on Vietnam's Communist leaders. Le Kha Phieu, the party secretary general, who is regarded as the most powerful figure in the country, resurrected the word "imperialists" to describe the Americans. He is reported to have told the president: "We respect other nations' way of life and political systems. We also demand that other nations respect our country's political system and choices." Mr Clinton called their discussion "a nice little debate".

He leaves Vietnam heading joltingly towards economic, if not political, liberalisation. But the tone adopted by his hosts suggests that the process is not necessarily helped by American hectoring.

"There is no question there is still a different vision of economics at the highest level of government," Mr Clinton's chief economic adviser, Gene Sperling, said.

"There is a notable difference of philosophy."

Several smaller incidents suggest that the Americans are as indelicate about Vietnamese sensibilities as they were in the old days.

Mr Clinton was horribly late for his night at the Hanoi opera house on Friday, keeping everyone waiting. The tableau on Saturday night when he solemnly presided over the return of some bone shards wrapped in the Stars and Stripes seemed merely to emphasise the difference in weight accorded to the 58,000 American war dead compared to the millions of dead Vietnamese.

And there was a little argument between two security men about some detail of crowd positioning that seemed to sum up everything. It ended with an American shrug. "It's your country," the American said to the Vietnamese official, before adding: "But you're wrong."

That is the US view of Vietnam in a nutshell.

As in Hanoi, most of Mr Clinton's fans on the streets here were under 25, and thus born after the war. But northern youngsters grew up being told that the Americans were bombers, killers. Many southerners fought alongside them in what was, after all, primarily a civil war. Their folk memory is tinged with nostalgia, handed down by parents who saw the GIs as friends and patrons.

"My father fought with the Americans," said Cheong, a T-shirt seller, as he waited for the motorcade. "Good people, good people." He sounded wistful.

Many of the older generation in the south died; many have emigrated; the rest keep their heads below the parapet. But the entrepreneurial spirit remains strong here, and the president devoted most of the day to economic themes, backed by a little light shopping.

He certainly could not have done much sightseeing. The Museum of Chinese and American War Crimes has changed its name to the War Remnants Museum, but the principle is the same: captured tanks and reproachful messages.

Other guidebook suggestions are the Revolutionary Museum, the Ho Chi Minh Museum, the No 7 Army Museum, the Cu Chi tunnels (a Viet Cong stronghold which the US could never overrun), the People's Committee Building and the Binh Soup Shop, which was the Viet Cong's secret wartime headquarters.

Instead, Mr Clinton made his setpiece appearance far from the city centre, at the new freight terminal as the guest of the US shipping company APL: American President Lines. This was the new Vietnam that the White House wants to foster. The audience comprised government officials, businessmen and APL staff. On a stifling day, almost all of them sat in the open air wearing uniform white shirts and APL baseball caps. It could have been a Japanese sales conference, the sort of gig Mr Clinton might have to play regularly if nothing better comes up after he loses his current job.

It was certainly an occasion that made Le Kha Phieu's protestations of continuing socialist purity hard to believe. The president noted that Vietnam's exports had increased sixfold in a decade. "You will grow even more as your economy becomes more open and the rule of law develops."

He also praised the high literacy rate. "Imagine how much more you will achieve," he went on, "as even more young people gain more freedom to shape the decisions that affect their lives."

Mr Clinton insisted: "The years of animosity are past. We have a stake in your future and we wish to be your partners."

But that partnership may be a bad-tempered one as long as the two political cultures remain so distinct. In a country of delicate sensibilities, the Americans still insist on marching in with heavy tread.

fields.headline: Franco rallies
fields.standfirst: Friend and foe mark anniversary
fields.trailText: Friend and foe mark anniversary.
fields.body:
Police using batons charged and fired rubber bullets to break up a demonstration in Madrid staged to counter another rally commemorating the death of the late Spanish dictator General Francisco Franco.

After taunts and chants of "police are killers" and "police are fascists", some 100 officers in riot gear waded into the crowd of an estimated 1,000 demonstrators, eyewitnesses said.

They said at least 10 people were treated for injuries and about five were detained.

The demonstration, called by small anti-fascist and leftist groups, is staged each year to counterbalance rallies held by ultra-right groups on the Sunday closest to the anniversary of Franco's death on November 20 1975.

The pro-Franco rally was without incident.

fields.headline: Kohl attacks colleagues who 'ousted' him
fields.standfirst: Special report: the German corruption scandal
fields.trailText: The discredited former German chancellor Helmut Kohl made an unprecedented attack on the leadership of his own conservative Christian Democrats yesterday, accusing it of arranging a behind-the-scenes "game" to oust him from politics.
fields.body:
The discredited former German chancellor Helmut Kohl made an unprecedented attack on the leadership of his own conservative Christian Democrats yesterday, accusing it of arranging a behind-the-scenes "game" to oust him from politics.

His criticism is contained in excerpts from his diary published in the newspaper Welt am Sonntag. They provide the first written account of Mr Kohl's reaction to the unfolding of the illicit party funding affair that led to his resignation as honorary party chairman last year.

Showing only mild remorse for the fact that he had illegally channelled more than £600,000 in undisclosed donations into party funds, Mr Kohl denied allegations that he had accepted cash in return for political favours.

Instead, he lashed out at his critics, the media and senior CDU members.

"They are engaged in an attempt to portray me as a corrupt and power hungry politician. The aim of this campaign is to criminalise me and to discredit my 16 years as chancellor," he wrote.

"I will not permit this. I will fight with every means at my disposal to defend my domestic and foreign policy successes and our struggle to find the best political solution for Germany and Europe."

Some of the most damaging criticism was reserved for his two successors as CDU leader, his former close adviser Wolfgang Schaüble, and the current CDU leader Angela Merkel, who was appointed early this year in an attempt to show that the party had made a clean break with the Kohl era.

At the height of the scandal last December Mrs Merkel, who was then CDU general secretary, published an attack on Mr Kohl in the daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, demanding his resignation from political office to prevent the party's image being further tarnished.

In yesterday's diary account, Mr Kohl accused both Mr Schaüble, then CDU party leader, and Mrs Merkel of in effect plotting his downfall.

In an entry dated "Christmas 1999" he wrote: "It is becoming increasingly clear that this is a prearranged game with separate parts being played by the general secretary and the party leader."

Mr Kohl made several bitter comments about Mrs Merkel, a former east German politician who was brought into Mr Kohl's cabinet after reunification in 1990.

"If I had not voted clearly in her favour, this woman from the political fringe would not have been able to make her exemplary political career," he wrote.

"I supported her for years and to such an extent that cabinet colleagues would say behind my back that Mrs Merkel could do anything because I was besotted by her."

Mrs Merkel made no comment about Mr Kohl's revelations yesterday.

The publication of the diary, which is due to be serialised daily by Die Welt this week, has come at an awkward moment for Germany's main opposition party and Mrs Merkel herself.

The CDU has not fully recovered from the Kohl scandal and is still lagging six percentage points behind the ruling Social Democrats in the opinion polls.

Mrs Merkel's inability to reverse her party's popularity slide have diminished her chances of becoming the CDU's chancellor candidate for the 2002 general election. The party is expected to select a candidate early next year.

In an attempt to restore its relations with Mr Kohl, the CDU allowed him to return to his seat in parliament in September.

The slush fund affair is far from being resolved, however. The parliamentary committee investigating it has yet to establish whether bribes influenced the Kohl government's decision to sell tanks to Saudi Arabia in 1990.

It also wants to find out whether backhanders were paid during the 1993 sale of the giant east German Leuna oil refinery to the French petrochemical concern Elf Aquitaine.

webTitle: Recount leaves bad taste as tempers rise

fields.headline: Recount leaves bad taste as tempers rise
fields.standfirst:
Election workers accused of ballot paper abuses

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Election workers accused of ballot paper abuses.
fields.body:
Any number of pundits have been obliged to eat their words since the US post-election fiasco became the most closely watched event since the death of Princess Diana. But only one person, so far, has been accused of consuming cardboard to work an advantage for his candidate.

George W Bush's campaign, which fears that the recounts in three overwhelmingly Democratic Florida counties could cost it the White House, claims a myriad abuses: ballot papers punched for the Texas governor with their holes taped over; Bush papers placed on piles of votes for Al Gore; ballots dropped on the floor, picked at by fingernails and altered by impact with jewellery.

Now the Republicans say that an unnamed Democrat in Broward county ate some chad - pieces of cardboard punched out of ballots by a machine.

Jim Rowland, a Republican observer, said he was guarding ballots during a break when a Democrat licked a finger, stuck it into a pile of chad and swallowed several pieces.

"I said, 'Please don't, sir, we're trying to keep them all together'," said Mr Rowland. "We wanted to know how many there were and have a record of them rather than throw them away."

Undaunted, Broward county continued with the fifth day of its manual recount yesterday and hoped to have more than half of its 588,000 ballots dealt with by the time counters return to work today. The Florida supreme court meets this afternoon to hear arguments on whether the manual recounts should be included in the totals for Mr Gore and Mr Bush.

Miami-Dade county, which starts its manual recount of 654,000 ballots today, might not be finished for almost two weeks. David Leahy, supervisor of elections there, said: "If there are no objections we expect to begin manually recounting ballots this Monday and our goal is to complete counting by Friday, December 1."

Then there was an objection. Republicans tried to persuade a judge to stop the county from using machines to weed out 10,000 "undervotes" - ballots with no punch for any candidate. "The more a paper ballot is mechanically or manually handled, the less reliable it is," said Bob Martinez, a lawyer for the Republicans. The judge declined to order a halt and the machines were put to use after a one-hour delay.

Palm Beach county, the cradle of Floridian electoral improvisation, carried on as usual. Judge Charles Burton, the Democratic chairman of the canvassing board there, appealed to counters and observers from both parties to be nice to each other.

A counter had accidentally put one of the county's 462,500 ballots on the wrong stack and been challenged by an observer. "You would have thought she'd killed 14 people," said the judge.

One Republican observer had seen a misplaced chad. "I'm telling you, the observer went crazy," said Mr Burton. "There's a chad on the floor. Help! Some of them are going to fall off, and that's fine."

Jeff Kahrs, another Republican observer in Palm Beach, said he had seen up to 10 papers punched by Bush supporters with the holes taped over.

"The pieces of Scotch tape had been carefully cut with scissors and were meant to cover a precise amount of space on the ballot," he said. "Obviously the ballots have been tampered [with]."

With the identity of the next president perhaps hanging on these events, Judge Burton stepped outside the West Palm Beach emergency operations centre for a cigarette and said: "We've not seen a big swing either way, to be quite frank."

webTitle: Florida tug-of-war could drag into the new year

fields.headline: Florida tug-of-war could drag into the new year
fields.standfirst:
Congress could be left to make final decision

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Congress could be left to make final decision.
fields.body:
Nearly two weeks after American voters went to the polls to elect a new president, it is becoming clearer by the day that the dispute between George W Bush and Al Gore over which of them is entitled to the White House may not be solved until after the new year, shortly before one of them is inaugurated to succeed Bill Clinton.

Whatever the outcome of today's hearing in the Florida supreme court, lawyers on both sides of the argument now think further litigation about Florida's disputed election is likely, possibly delaying the final award of the state's 25 electoral college votes. The Florida state legislature could even become involved. And if the issue is unresolved by December 12, the US Senate and House of Representatives could also become embroiled.

"It's a very scary thought, but I'm getting a sneaky feeling in my gut that Congress may get involved in it," Democratic senator John Breaux of Louisiana said yesterday.

"I have become an extreme pessimist. I've wondered in the last day or two if we haven't crossed an important point where it's too late for anybody to step back," said former congressman Vin Weber of Minnesota, a Republican. "I think we're doomed to play this out to the bitter end."

In the short term, the key moves will come in the Florida supreme court, where the parties filed their written arguments over the weekend and will make oral presentations in Tallahassee today.

Three possible outcomes seem likely. First, the court could order that the manual counts under way in three counties should be allowed to continue and their results included in the official Florida returns, as Mr Gore wants.

Second, the court could uphold Friday's lower court ruling by Judge Terry Lewis in Tallahassee to permit the Florida secretary of state, Katherine Harris, to certify the state's results, the course the Bush camp would prefer.

There is a third possibility, under which the court allows the hand counts to continue, but defers a decision about including their new numbers in the certification. That would give both sides something less than outright victory.

Certification is by no means the end of the road, however. Depending on the numbers, the loser could go back to court to challenge Ms Harris's decision, something which Mr Gore's lawyer, David Boies, clearly signalled last week was a possibility.

In addition, several other law suits are under way in different parts of the Florida court system, some of which challenge the entire legality of voting procedures on November 7, notably a Palm Beach county challenge concerning the infamous "butterfly ballot".

Outside the courts, some elected Florida politicians are also rattling their swords in another move which could extend the timetable. The same federal law which decrees that members of the electoral college must be appointed by December 12 to cast their votes on December 18, also provides that "the legislature of each state" has the power to appoint members of the college "on a subsequent day" if these deadlines have not been met.

Florida's Republican speaker-elect, Thomas Feeney, said at the weekend that the state legislature - in which the Republicans have majorities of 10 in the upper house and 34 in the lower - has "the power, authority and responsibility to intervene". Those comments raise the possibility that Florida Republicans could select their own electoral college members if the court process hands the state to Mr Gore.

If Florida's 25 votes remained in question after December 18, the focus would then shift to Washington, where the newly elected Senate and House are due to meet on January 5 for what is normally a routine joint session to count the electoral college returns. By law, the session is chaired by the vice-president, Al Gore.

An objection to any state's returns from any one of the 100 senators or 435 Congress men is sufficient to interrupt the process. Each house then debates separately the validity of claims before voting to accept or reject. The two houses must concur, which means that the Republicans' nine-vote majority in the House could be critical. The make-up of the Senate is still uncertain, pending the still undeclared contest in Washington state.

Depending on whether Florida's votes are accepted or not, the election would then go into the House, where each state would cast a single vote, based on a majority vote in each state's delegation. Republicans would control 28 of the votes - assuming everyone votes along party lines - giving the White House to Mr Bush two weeks before Inauguration Day on January 20.

There is a third possibility, under which the court allows the hand counts to continue, but defers a decision about including their new numbers in the certification. That would give both sides something less than outright victory. Certification is by no means the end of the road, however. Depending on the numbers, the loser could go back to court to challenge Ms Harris's decision, something which Mr Gore's lawyer, David Boies, clearly signalled last week was a possibility. In addition, several other law suits are under way in different parts of the Florida court system, some of which challenge the entire legality of voting procedures on November 7, notably a Palm Beach county challenge concerning the infamous "butterfly ballot". Outside the courts, some elected Florida politicians are also rattling their swords in another move which could extend the timetable. The same federal law which decrees that members of the electoral college must be appointed by December 12 to cast their votes on December 18, also provides that "the legislature of each state" has the power to appoint members of the college "on a subsequent day" if these deadlines have not been met. Florida's Republican speaker-elect, Thomas Feeney, said at the weekend that the state legislature - in which the Republicans have majorities of 10 in the upper house and 34 in the lower - has "the power, authority and responsibility to intervene". Those comments raise the possibility that Florida Republicans could select their own electoral college members if the court process hands the state to Mr Gore. If Florida's 25 votes remained in question after December 18, the focus would then shift to Washington, where the newly elected Senate and House are due to meet on January 5 for what is normally a routine joint session to count the electoral college returns. By law, the session is chaired by the vice-president, Al Gore. An objection to any state's returns from any one of the 100 senators or 435 Congress men is sufficient to interrupt the process. Each house then debates separately the validity of claims before voting to accept or reject. The two houses must concur, which means that the Republicans' nine-vote majority in the House could be critical. The make-up of the Senate is still uncertain, pending the still undeclared contest in Washington state. Depending on whether Florida's votes are accepted or not, the election would then go into the House, where each state would cast a single vote, based on a majority vote in each state's delegation. Republicans would control 28 of the votes - assuming everyone votes along party lines - giving the White House to Mr Bush two weeks before Inauguration Day on January 20.

webTitle: US agencies paid millions to prop up Pinochet

fields.headline: US agencies paid millions to prop up Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: The release of 16,000 secret documents from US intelligence agencies has set Chile's Christian Democrat government coalition scrambling to explain the millions of dollars in covert support it received from the agencies between 1964 and 1974.
fields.body:
The release of 16,000 secret documents from US intelligence agencies has set Chile's Christian Democrat government coalition scrambling to explain the millions of dollars in covert support it received from the agencies between 1964 and 1974.

Many party leaders from that era are still in powerful government positions.

President Ricardo Lagos, a socialist, who is not implicated in the scandal, is under pressure from congress to investigate current CIA activities in Chile.

"I'm not naive. I know that intelligence practices - to put it elegantly - or spying are as old as humanity," he said. "But I would hope that this is a throwback to the cold war, and it doesn't happen any more, because it can affect relations between countries."

The documents are allowing historians to piece together the secret diplomacy used by the US to set the stage for a coup, then to prop up the military junta leader Augusto Pinochet throughout his 1973-1990 rule. They include previously unknown details about the workings of the Pinochet regime, including the dictator's role in foreign assassinations and his troubled attempts to travel abroad as the legal net tightened around him in the early 1990's.

The Chilean government says it will formally protest at the US interference, and the leading newspaper El Mercurio has tried to limit the fallout from the revelation that it received about $1.6m (£1m) in covert support from US agents.

El Mercurio was a leading critic of the government of Salvador Allende, and a crucial cog in the CIA's propaganda machine.

The documents - many of them heavily censored - released by the US state department, the defence intelligence agency, the CIA, the FBI and the justice department are the fourth and last round of disclosures ordered by President Clinton.

They cover US activities in Chile in 1968-1991. Approximately 1,400 CIA documents were released after the Clinton administration spent months overcoming the reluctance of the agency's director, George Tenet.

"The CIA as an institution suffers form a pathology of secrecy," said Peter Kornbluh of the National Security Archives, a research institution in Washington. "It is as difficult for them to give up a document as it is for a child to share a toy."

Gen Pinochet is under court supervision in Chile, where he is being investigated for nearly 200 criminal offences. The new documents may also prompt the US to request his extradition, since they include evidence of his direct role in the car bombing of the Chilean diplomat Orlando Letelier in Washington in 1976.

While the US efforts to overthrow the democratically elected Allende and support Gen Pinochet are hardly secrets, the details show the extent to which US officials were willing to abuse Chilean sovereignty.

A CIA memo prepared three years before the 1973 coup states: "If civil disorders were to follow from a military action, the USG [US Government] would promptly deliver necessary support and material, (but not personnel)."

In a state department memo written weeks after the coup that put Gen Pinochet in power, Jack Kubisch wrote: "The junta does not appear to represent a threat to our major national interest. No overriding national objective seems to me to be served by supporting opposition to it."

The documents' declassification was a result of Gen Pinochet's arrest in London in October 1998. The Spanish investigating judge Baltazar Garzon had compiled evidence that Gen Pinochet and other Chilean army officers had organised a transnational hit squad known as "Operation Condor". The US response was to declassify thousands of documents and let Mr Garzon and other foreign magistrates peruse the information.

fields.headline: Embattled Peruvian president resigns
fields.trailText: Pursued by a snowballing corruption scandal involving his disgraced spy chief, President Alberto Fujimori of Peru confirmed early today that he would resign.
fields.body:
Pursued by a snowballing corruption scandal involving his disgraced spy chief, President Alberto Fujimori of Peru confirmed early today that he would resign.

He told ministers of his decision from Tokyo, where he arrived on Thursday. A statement issued from his hotel room, which was guarded by the police, said he would resign within 48 hours.

He said he was acting in response to "the new composition of the forces in congress". The Peruvian congress reverted to opposition control on Thursday for the first time in eight years and reinstated three constitutional court judges sacked in May.

Mr Fujimori's immediate future remains unclear. He refused to say if he would return to Peru after his resignation is submitted, or seek political asylum in Japan, the homeland of his parents.

Since taking office in July 1990, when he was the almost unknown rector of an agrarian university, Mr Fujimori has been both hailed and reviled for ruling Peru with an iron fist.

His maverick style, a mixture of populism and authoritarianism, prompted him to carry out a coup in April 1992, when he dissolved congress and sacked supreme court judges.

His tough treatment of suspected rebels was credited with quashing a bloody insurgency, and he was lauded for putting Peru back on an economic even keel by slashing hyperinflation with tight fiscal policies. But he was increasingly criticised for giving free rein to what critics called "the obscure power" of the secret service.

He also pushed through constitutional reform to allow his third, controversial election in May 2000 in a dubious polling process marred by dirty tricks and claims of fraud.

His government has been falling to pieces since his former spy chief and key personal adviser Vladimiro Montesinos was exposed as the alleged chief of a vast money laundering ring involved in arms-trafficking, blackmail, corruption and fleecing drugs traffickers.

The special prosecutor for the Montesinos case, Jose Ugaz, has said there is no evidence incriminating Mr Fuji mori, but he will investigate claims by Roberto Escobar, brother of the late Colombian drugs baron Pablo Escobar, that he gave Mr Montesinos £700,000 to fund the 1990 campaign.

The crisis was triggered by the release on September 14 of a video that showed Mr Montesinos handing a congressman a wad of dollar bills, apparently to seal his defection from the opposition to the government benches.

During the 1990s Mr Fujimori ceded to Mr Montesinos control of appointments in the armed forces and of the all-pervasive secret police.

His adviser built up a spider's web of influence in the courts, the media, the cabinet and congress through a mixture of favours and blackmail.

But in the past two months Mr Fujimori's grip on power slipped.

The crisis came to a head when Mr Montesinos flew back to Peru, prompting Mr Fujimori to embark on a showy but failed manhunt for his ex-adviser.

It looks likely that the second vice-president, Ricardo Marquez, will assume the presidency if the first vice-president, Francisco Tudela, who resigned in protest at Mr Montesinos' return, declines the post.

Fernando Olivera, leader of the Independent Moralising Front, the opposition party which leaked the fateful video, said Mr Fujimori's resignation was "great news for Peru" and served to confirm Mr Fujimori's responsibility for the mafia-style management of Peru in the past 10 years

But an opposition MP, Absalon Vasquez, said that Mr Fujimori was "the greatest president Peru ever had".

fields.headline: Lawyers take centre stage
fields.standfirst:
Two great legal minds square up in court

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Two great legal minds square up in court.
fields.body:
David Boies, the grinning lawyer with the frayed edges whose job it is to talk Al Gore into the White House, likes to gamble in casinos.

The 59-year-old advocate for mostly liberal causes is out of luck in Tallahassee, Florida's state capital: it just isn't that sort of place. But he gets to indulge his instincts today as the lead lawyer for the Democrats in the state supreme court, where the Gore campaign is fighting to have recounted votes added to the final tally.

Mr Boies is something of a contradiction. He headed the legal team in the US government's anti-trust case against Microsoft, yet before that he acted for the defence when the government brought an anti-trust case against IBM.

He represented Napster, which allowed people to trade music on the internet for free, yet he does not use a personal computer and has his family and secretary check his emails.

His appearance barely reflects his fees of about $700 an hour. The blue suits come off the peg at $200 a piece, the knit-tie is wound into a big knot, sports shoes are on his feet and his wispy hair sticks out at the back. This leaves the man with the Timex watch worn over his sleeve with plenty for the craps table.

"It is the casino game that you have the best chance of winning," he says of the pastime that helps him to relax. "The second thing is that, perfectly played, it's pure luck. It's literally a roll of the dice."

Mr Boies, a Yale graduate whose team will have an hour to make its case in the supreme court today, labours under what might to others be an insurmountable handicap: he is dyslexic. "He overcompensates with an overwhelming memory," says his wife, Mary, who is also a lawyer.

He will need it if the legal aspects of the post-presidential deadlock endure for as long as he suggests. "You don't call the end of the game after the first innings or the second innings," he says.

Mr Boies's main opponent today is likely to be Barry Richard, whose tongue is reputed to be as silvered as his generous mane of hair. Even though he is the lead advocate for the George W Bush campaign, the 58-year-old Tallahassee attorney is a registered Democrat.

Mr Richard's strength is in his local Florida connections. He is the son of a former mayor of Miami Beach, was a member of the state legislature for four years in the 1970s and is considered an expert in open meetings and public records law. But he has also won three cases in the US supreme court.

"He's one of the sharpest people I know," says Dick Shelton, director of the Florida Press Association, for which he has long been a lobbyist. "He's brilliant and has a great analytical mind. If I was in trouble, he's the one I'd hire to represent me."

Whatever happens in court today, somebody will still be in trouble. Perhaps, if it is Mr Boies, he will seek solace in his love of country music, specifically Hank Williams, Waylon Jennings and Willie Nelson. Somewhere in his photographic memory will be lodged one of Nelson's greatest songs: Angel Flying Too Close To The Ground.

webTitle: Death in Venice is big tourist attraction

fields.headline: Death in Venice is big tourist attraction
fields.trailText: Romantic spirits have been falling under the melancholy spell of Venice for centuries, but young foreigners are now choosing the Italian city as a place to commit suicide.
fields.body:
Romantic spirits have been falling under the melancholy spell of Venice for centuries, but young foreigners are now choosing the Italian city as a place to commit suicide.

In many cases tourists have fallen prey to what Venetian psychologist Diana Stainer calls "the Venice syndrome".

Dr Stainer studied 25 cases of attempted suicide by foreign tourists between 1988 and 1995 and concluded that it was no accident that they opted for "death in Venice". Her report is to be published in the Italian medical journal Minerva Psichiatrica.

Britons, Germans, French, Spanish and Americans have all chosen Venice as a spectacular backdrop for their last moments. With an average age of 36 and evenly split between the sexes, the subjects generally took drug overdoses or attempted to drown themselves in a canal. One Frenchman cut his wrists in the midst of a crowd of fellow tourists.

Nine German speakers - who are most likely to be exposed to the influence of Thomas Mann - tried to end their days in Venice during Dr Stainer's study, while the footsteps of the ailing Dirk Bogarde were followed by eight Frenchmen and two Britons, Dr Stainer said.

A further 10 attempted suicides were not considered in the study and another 16 people killed themselves during the period in question. "This phenomenon is almost certainly underestimated. What we have seen is just the tip of the iceberg," Dr Stainer said.

"Some of the suicides clearly wanted to make a theatrical gesture, perhaps a plea for help. What better choice than an oneiric city like Venice. Water is traditionally the symbol of motherhood, taking us back to the amniotic fluid in the womb. Venice is often linked to maternal symbols because it is a city built upon water and invaded by water. The suicides may have been looking for a reunion with a mother figure..."

Cities of artistic or historical importance such as Florence and Jerusalem are known to generate psychic disturbances akin to that of Venice.

Visitors down the ages have been fascinated by the link between Venice and death. For the art critic John Ruskin even the gondolas looked like "floating tombs". Composer Richard Wagner felt as though he was in a funeral procession for plague victims when he ventured out on one of the distinctive black-painted boats.

"Venice is a jewel case that encloses an important part of European art and religion," Annibale Crosignani, a psychiatrist, told La Repubblica newspaper yesterday. "It is a city of ghosts and fantasies, outside time and space. That is why people of exceptional sensibility such as artists can become overwhelmed, passing without pause from life to death. For them, sensitive to the appeal of aesthetics, it is deadly beautiful and beautiful to die in."

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Lake District
fields.trailText: Lake District
fields.body:
How many of you, I wonder, have a home called Silver How? Dozens, perhaps? Three of my friends have, and another friend, a nationally known outdoors man, tells me Silver How is his favourite place in all Lakeland - and so, rather surprisingly, do many other people. And yet, Silver How - the Ordnance Survey called it Silver Howe until their most recent maps - is just a smallish, sprawling fell (1,292 ft) that shades Grasmere, the very heart of tourist Lakeland, from the setting sun. Wordsworth had a home on its lower slopes for about three years. But it has no striking shape, its summit is undistinguished and there are no great crags or well-known tarns on its shoulders. And, as an object in the sky or an easily remembered and well-known eminence, it cannot be compared with Helm Crag, Grasmere's other local hill. But, despite all this, Silver How - a lovely name for a lovely hill - is treasured and held in the highest esteem by very many people, including, no doubt, several marooned in towns and cities, who sigh for well-remembered holidays in the fell country.

The reason, I can only suppose, is the perfection of its wooded slopes, natural or planted, the varied colours, the beauty of the landscaping and the way the whole picture, especially when viewed from Grasmere, conjures up peace and serenity. A lovely, undemanding walk for a short winter's day, especially if combined with its more popular neighbour, Loughrigg - preferably in the snow. 0r you can continue along the ridge in the other direction to High Raise, usually considered the most central fell in Lakeland.

The Coniston Tigers - published by Sigma Press

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Composer Of The Week / Growing Science
fields.body:
It's hard to imagine Arthur Sullivan contemplating any calling but music. Son of a professional bandmaster, he could play every brass instrument by the age of eight.

At 12, he joined the choir of the Chapel Royal, at 13 wrote his first composition, and at 14 won a much coveted musical scholarship. On the centenary of his death (from pneumonia, aged 58) Sullivan figures as Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3), with Donald Macleod resurrecting some of his less familiar works.

Gardening guru Pippa Greenwood (pictured) rounds off her horticultural series Growing Science (9.0pm, Radio 4) with some comfort for those who have turned to a herbalist or natural healer to deal with any ailment. Greenwood's research shows there is more than folklore on their side. She talks to experts at the Royal Botanic Garden in Edinburgh, who have just completed a mammoth Flora Celtica. They are convinced their work will increase the evidence for plant therapy.

fields.headline: Virgin territory
fields.standfirst: For television dramatists, finding new ways to crank up sexual tension is increasingly tough. But BBC1's adaptation of Take A Girl Like You, trembling with 50s repression, does it effortlessly, says  Mark Lawson.
fields.trailText: For television dramatists, finding new ways to crank up sexual tension is increasingly tough. But BBC1's adaptation of Take A Girl Like You, trembling with 50s repression, does it effortlessly, says Mark Lawson.
fields.body:
Cautious in interviews, authors tend to reveal in their diaries or letters their true view of their work. And in this year's The Letters Of Kingsley Amis, we can follow the gestation and reception of the 1961 novel now adapted for television: Take A Girl Like You, a story of male erotic offence and female sexual defence in the 50s.

In 1958, in the early stages of writing, Amis tells Philip Larkin that he has "devised a character who can say more of what I think than any previous". This is intriguingly candid as the narrative-driving chap - Patrick Standish - is a remorseless philanderer who treats a provincial virgin, Jenny Bunn, like ground to be seized in a war.

In 1960, he deals with objections from his American publisher to the novel's tone. Two key scenes - Standish's fling with another woman while courting Jenny and Miss Bunn's eventual submission while drunk - are regarded by the Manhattan book-man as "more depressing than comic" ... "turned my stomach a bit". Amis's reply is that "he hoped for some pretty dark places in the comedy".

Four decades later - with the English novel's trip to those dark places completed by Kingsley's son, Martin - it's a measure of how laughter has darkened in contemporary fiction that Take A Girl Like You now serves on television as genteel nostalgia.

There's American money in this, and so perhaps rather too much is made of Julian the toff in his country house (the Letters reveal that a friend of Amis's thought this the weakest part of the book), but the delineation of class and accents is in general subtle, and the picture of England in the 50s feels as if it would satisfy historians as well as American viewers who know the country through Agatha Christie and Princess Diana.

Take A Girl Like You is the kind of series in which the set-dresser is as important as the director. Most scenes depend on a period detail: Morgan sports cars, scratchy lavatory paper, a needle skidding on the shellac of a 78 record, French films being chic or an English cuisine still shaped by rationing. With its sax-and-drum jazz soundtrack, it also deliberately has the feel of a 50s film.

But the book and the adaptation are most interesting as erotic history. Take A Girl Like You has the feel of a brother-piece to the Larkin poem in which he envies the sexual freedom of his students and laments that "sexual intercourse began in 1963... rather late for me".

David Lodge once said that the advantage of writing Catholic novels in the 60s was that, post-Chatterley, this was the last area of fiction in which the stakes remained high in sexual encounters: virginity, contraception and adultery were still an issue. With even many adherents of Rome now lax in these matters, writers must travel to the past in the hope of sexual tension.

Take A Girl Like You trembles with bottled-up longing. In a TV environment in which the characters usually travel from first kiss through ripped-off clothes to orgasm in about half a minute, there's a novelty in seeing sex scenes in which the foreplay resembles chess. Fingers inch towards a move and then rethink it or are checked by the opponent. The lingo of sexual negotiation - the woman wanting "it" to be "special", the man apologising for "making a complete fool of myself" when he makes a touch too far - are captured with anthropological relish in the script by Andrew Davies, who previously adapted Amis's The Old Devils for TV with some success. The sexual tension is helped by deliberately provocative casting.

Rupert Graves as Patrick and Sienna Guillory as Jenny are both so attractive that viewers may be smashing through the screen to get at them.

Like his son, Kingsley Amis often called on broad comic characters - Take A Girl Like You has a nerdy socialist, a French bird, a shy plodder - but makes them special through the crackle of the narrative description. For a novelist, television adaptation is a choice between laryngitis and strep throat. It's bound to hurt - the only question is exactly how much of your voice you lose.

In this case, the production employs an unusual technical device to give the novelist a presence. Rather than the conventional voiceover of passages from the book, this series freezes the action during a scene, like football on TV, but, instead of Alan Hansen, the analysis comes from the character, as if speaking inner thoughts.

Like most other aspects of the version, this works. The shifting of long-established television news bulletins would almost certainly have drawn from Amis, if still alive, Garrick Club harrumphing or letters to The Times.

But his novel now makes him a posthumous warrior in the battle of the moved-news schedules. But, however Sir Kingsley's shade might hate the idea of being a beneficiary of change, this adaptation of Take A Girl Like You - redolent of the 50s, sexy because of the absence of sex - rewards the sharp attention brought to drama by the new programming.

 Take A Girl Like You, Sunday, 9.05pm, BBC1

fields.headline: Funny peculiar
fields.trailText: If the increasing acceptability of Amis's tone shows how cruelty has become an accepted ingredient of humour, television comedy in general establishes the extent to which surrealism has gone mainstream. This column has already commented on the Beckettian ambitions of One Foot In The Grave (tonight, 9.15pm, BBC1), this week reaching its final episode.
fields.body:
If the increasing acceptability of Amis's tone shows how cruelty has become an accepted ingredient of humour, television comedy in general establishes the extent to which surrealism has gone mainstream. This column has already commented on the Beckettian ambitions of One Foot In The Grave (tonight, 9.15pm, BBC1), this week reaching its final episode.

And there's also the return of the astonishingly odd Stella Street (Thursday, 9.50pm, BBC2), the brilliant 10-minuters in which John Sessions and Phil Cornwell people a Surbiton street with television and cinema legends. The joke of Michael Caine, Joe Pesci, Jack Nicholson and others living as neighbours in Surrey semi-detacheds might have been a brief one, but the show, like all successful comedy, ruthlessly inflates the initial situation.

The new series begins with Marlon Brando moving in to No. 56 and ends with a trip to a seaside B&B, in which Jimmy Hill enthusiastically takes the landlord's wife from behind on a divan and Al Pacino contravenes an English coastal by-law by lighting fires on the beach. In these scenes, the ridiculous becomes sublime.

Critical consensus is that impersonators work best on radio because television points up the difficulty of an exact physical match. In Stella Street the gap matters less - once Mick Jagger is a corner-shop owner, the setting's improbability lessens the need for a realistic likeness.

The surrealism also seems to bring legal protection. While those celebrities shown as sexual predators do not have choirboy-biographies, the depictions of philandering are more vicious than anything in Spitting Image.

But the completely improbable collisions of celebrities - Jimmy Hill and Marlon Brando in the same cast - presumably allows the defence that no viewer could take these events as real. Stella Street achieves in flesh the kind of satirical half-lives only previously done in rubber.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Moonfleet / Batman Returns / Blade / Romance
fields.body:
Moonfleet

(Fritz Lang, 1955)

1.45pm, TCM

Fritz Lang's atmospheric adaptation of J Meade Faulkner's tale of 18th-century smugglers positively reeks of skulduggery. It's told through the eyes of a 10-year-old orphan (Jon Whiteley) who arrives in the Dorset village of Moonfleet in search of his late mother's lover and smuggler's captain Stewart Granger. It needed a less genteel presence as the roguish hero, but Joan Greenwood and George Sanders are much better value.

Batman Returns

(Tim Burton, 1992)

8pm, Sky Cinema

Michael Keaton's rubber-suited and humour-free Batman is consistently upstaged by Michelle Pfeiffer's Catwoman (pictured) and Danny DeVito's Penguin in Burton's caped crusader sequel. They prowl and waddle through Gotham's mean streets to good effect, and Christopher Walken's Max Schreck completes a triumvirate of villainy.

Blade

(Stephen Norrington, 1998)

10.10pm, Sky Premier

More comic-book capers in this stylish screen version of Marvel's superpowered vampire slayer. There are some enjoyably modern-gothic set-pieces, although the limp story hardly grabs you by the throat. Wesley Snipes is athletically efficient as the half-human, half-vampire hero, who with grizzled sidekick Kris Kristofferson is pitted against Stephen Dorff's Frost, would-be leader of a new dawn of the undead.

Romance

(Catherine Breillat, 1999)

1.15am, FilmFour

The story of Caroline Ducey's schoolteacher Marie (Caroline Trousselard) who, confronted by her partner's sexual indifference (he has imposed a vow of celibacy on their relationship; she is deeply in love with him) sets off on an erotic journey that grows increasingly masochistic. Italian porn star Rocco Siffredi's presence as one of Marie's new lovers signals how cleverly Catherine Breillat's exploration of female sexuality treads the fine line between arthouse and pornography.
