fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous.
fields.body:
Brendan Fraser in Presumed Guilty (Paul Wendkos, 1990)

Who? A talented actor who seems to have abandoned any artistic pretensions for a career full of cartoon adaptations. He may have starred in religious fable The Passion Of Darkly Noon (1995) and the Oscar-winning Gods And Monsters (1998), but he's also done George Of The Jungle (1997) and Dudley Do-Right (1999), and made his first big splash as a thawed-out caveman in the woeful comedy California Man (1992). Surprisingly, he revealed a talent for light comedy in the charming Blast From The Past (1999) with Alicia Silverstone. And sometimes the dumb stuff works, as evidenced by the highly enjoyable The Mummy (1999). Even Fraser couldn't save Bedazzled from Liz Hurley, but he'll be back fighting ancient Egyptian evil in the forthcoming The Mummy Returns.

The role: Bobby McLaughlin, a Brooklyn layabout who is wrongly accused of murder. The worst part is, even his own dad (Martin Sheen) thinks he might have done it. (He didn't).

Best line: When his father visits him in prison, an enraged Bobby says "Do you want the truth about every lie I ever told? Fine. I dropped out of high school because they were going to kick me out anyway, I've been having sex since I was 14 years old but I never got nobody pregnant, I've bought drugs before but I never sold any, and I stole stuff when I was a kid, y'know, candy and cigarettes."

Cringe factor: Moderate. Fraser has done far more embarrassing things than this.

Other wannabes: Mark Metcalf, playing a cop, went on to appear as The Master, chief villain in the first series of Buffy The Vampire Slayer.

Also not starring in: Child Of Darkness, Child Of Light (1991), as John's Friend, and as Sailor Number One in Dogfight (1991).

Presumed Guilty, 11pm, Mon 20 November, Carlton Cinema

fields.headline: Sex in the city
fields.trailText: Amsterdam: City of Sin / Days in the Life
fields.body:
It's a hard life being a TV critic, God knows, but just when the prospect of another series of Children's Hospital is enough to send you screaming from the couch, along comes a timely reminder that things could really be a lot worse. One could, for example, be one of Amsterdam's 8,000 "window prostitutes", the girls who have to negotiate with drunk English tourists in the red light district and then get top rate of 1,000 guilders - that's about £30 - per trick.

This salutary lesson was delivered by Channel 4 (of course) in the first part of Amsterdam: City of Sin (Sat), a lightning tour of the sex industry in our most liberal of neighbouring capitals. In prostitution, as in life itself, there's a distinct hierarchy - everyone knows their place, aspires to better themselves and looks down on the poor suckers beneath them. At the top of the tree in Amsterdam are successful couples like Werner and Claudia, who run Interclimax, an internet voyeur house where girls arrange themselves indelicately at the bidding of their unseen web-punters. Claudia and Werner don't do the business themselves any more - they just count the profits. "We were doing this three years before Big Brother came along," said Werner, rather sniffily - but there was something eerily familiar about the house with its ubiquitous cameras. Mercifully, we never saw Mel perched on a glass coffee table with no knickers, nor was Craig introduced to "Uncle Charlie" and "Godzilla", two of the larger inanimate objects in the newly-opened gay S&M room. Perhaps in the next series.

A little less sanitised was Elene's escort business, which she runs with her 16-year-old son Robert. She used to run it with her husband, until he was stabbed 21 times in a raid on the office. Elene was philosophical. "This isn't the only business in which people kill each other," she said. Mother and son were the souls of professionalism, both brilliant salespeople. "Hello, Oriental Girls!" chirped Elene. "I'm afraid the only girl we have tonight is not actually an oriental, but she looks like one." Was the customer satisfied? We'll never know.

In another part of the forest, English couple Lulu and Boots lost their job in a booming internet sex cinema, where Boots was known as "The Cum King", and were forced to seek stage work. "Theatre's more prestigious," said Lulu, like any actress who can't get telly. Their routine - caveman and cavewoman - was marred only slightly by Boots's rare inability to maintain an erection. Stage fright, one assumes.

From there it was a short, brutal slide downwards through the window trade to the most desperate level of Amsterdam prostitution, the seedy drama of need and addiction that's played out behind Central Station. Elisabeth was a ravaged soul who turned tricks for about £3 a time - just enough to feed her crack habit. In between times she hid in the left luggage lockers and smoked herself into numbness.

Amsterdam: City of Sin was impressively objective, focusing on characters rather than trying to whip up any sense of naughtiness. It was hampered, as all these programmes are, by the inability to show anything much, and there was much nervous use of the pixelation button. We saw Boots waving his unwilling willy around at the end of the show, but he looked strangely innocent in his fun-fur Neanderthal costume.

There was little sex, plenty of drugs and occasional rock 'n' roll in BBC2's Days in the Life (Sat), a meticulously researched account of 1970's Isle of Wight Festival. What set out to be the British Woodstock soon became a battle of ideologies: locals v invading hippies; promoters ("breadheads") v anarchists, who turned their unwillingness to pay £3 to see Hendrix, The Who, etc, into a political issue. There were some fine upstanding citizens remembering how shocking it all was; two of them, a male and female shop owner, were reminiscent of Tubs and Edward. The usual hippy suspects were all dragged out - Mick Farren, Caroline Coon and Rikki Farr told the tale from their widely differing viewpoints, each believing the festival had been a personal victory in one way or another. What's astonishing is that the divisions and resentments of 30 years ago still seem to burn so brightly for these people. Clips of Free, Joni Mitchell and The Who seemed almost incidental to the overblown, self-regarding dramas within the audience.

fields.headline: Media monkey
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: * Digital remastering of photos is all too prevalent these days, but Monkey was horrified by a needless piece of censorship in last week's News of the World. A perfectly charming portrait of Radio 1 DJ Sara Cox and her boyfriend, taken by everyone's favourite pap Jason Fraser, was ruined by the corruption of the boyfriend's T-shirt. Monkey knows because he, too, received the freebie from the Sci-Fi Channel to promote its self-styled "headf**k" weekend. Why the NoW thinks the letters F and K will offend its readers is beyond Monkey though.
fields.body:
* Digital remastering of photos is all too prevalent these days, but Monkey was horrified by a needless piece of censorship in last week's News of the World. A perfectly charming portrait of Radio 1 DJ Sara Cox and her boyfriend, taken by everyone's favourite pap Jason Fraser, was ruined by the corruption of the boyfriend's T-shirt. Monkey knows because he, too, received the freebie from the Sci-Fi Channel to promote its self-styled "headf**k" weekend. Why the NoW thinks the letters F and K will offend its readers is beyond Monkey though.

* Millions of viewers watched the poignant end of Inspector Morse last week as Kevin Whately's Sgt Lewis trooped away from his beloved dead boss and disappeared down the hospital's corridor to the sound of the show's mournful theme. However, what they did not see - but Monkey's friends have - was Carlton's alternative, not-for-broadcast version, where Lewis suddenly leaps into the air, kicks his heels and starts celebrating like a madman, wheeling down the corridor in glee. The joke is that Lewis, who had been taking his inspector's exams, has just landed himself a dead-man's-shoes promotion.

*The email traumas of Piers Morgan part III: Monkey read with interest the Mirror's leader column on Friday. "Bosses who sneakily read private memos sent by their employees to friends or family when there is no commercial sensitivity involved are the lowest form of officious little creeps," it began. "If your boss gets his kicks out of leering at your personal emails, resign," it concludes. Who can possibly have written that?

*Monkey is indebted to art critic Matthew Collings for his frank assessment of this year's Turner Prize, coverage of which he is presenting for Channel 4 next week. "This year there are no shocks and there's no controversy," Matthew tells Channel 4's programme publicity bulletin. "It's the most boring one ever. It's so boring it's almost shocking." A glowing endorsement.

*Star TV writer Kieran Prendiville was in confessional mood at last week's Foyle Film Festival, deciding to bare all about his furry animals drama Badger, which - along with Harbour Lights - took the worst hammering of BBC1's year of hell. "If you're going to write for television, don't be cynical," he told a Belfast BBC-hosted writers' forum. "You really have to believe in the world you're creating. fields.headline: David Rubio
fields.standfirst: Eminent instrument maker inspired by a lifelong passion for guitars
fields.trailText: David Rubio, who has died aged 65, was an instrument maker of guitars, lutes, harpsichords, violins, violas and cellos, and was particularly associated with the early music movement.
fields.body:
David Rubio, who has died aged 65, was an instrument maker of guitars, lutes, harpsichords, violins, violas and cellos, and was particularly associated with the early music movement.

Born in Kensington, west London, he was educated at Whittingham College, Brighton, and then studied medicine at Trinity College, Dublin, but gave it up because of colour blindness. He briefly spent some time working in his stepfather's delicatessen shops, but this did not work out and he turned to his other passion, the guitar. Self-taught - he had spent time playing in London coffee bars - he went off to Spain and for three years worked as a flamenco guitarist, playing with traditional singers and dancers. It was there that he became known by the name "Rubio" after his red beard.

He was invited to go with the Rafael de Cordoba ballet company on a tour of New York. But when they left, he stayed on. It was there he met his wife, Nest, while playing at the restaurant El Gitano. It was also in New York that he started to make and repair guitars based on what he had learned "while shooting the breeze at the back of guitar-makers' shops in Spain".

Everything in his life involved precision - careers guidance had come up with the suggestion that he become a surgical instrument maker - and his business soon took off. A stroke of good fortune occurred when Julian Bream brought him a lute for repair, and was much impressed when he saw the one finished flamenco guitar David had made.

This connection led to an invitation from Bream for David to set up a workshop at Bream's home in Semley, Wiltshire. David and Nest left New York in 1967. The space at Semley, however, was unsuitable. They had to look elsewhere and, in 1968, bought a derelict Tudor farmhouse in the Oxfordshire village of Duns Tew. David had already developed an interest in making copies of earlier string instruments, such as lutes, theorbos and baroque guitars, so it was a natural progression to move into harpsichord making as well.

At that time, the early music scene was burgeoning, and there was much demand for good copies of historical instruments. In the 1970s top players, including Howard Schott, David Lumsden, Trevor Pinnock and Gustav Leonhardt, were among his customers. He was associated with making baroque violins as well as harpsichords, and latterly many modern violin-family instruments, including a number of complete "quartets". This was after a move to Cambridge in 1979, which also coincided with a period of intense research into the techniques of makers such as Stradivari, Amati and Guarneri, which he pursued in collaboration with scientists at Cambridge University.

On one visit to his house and workshop, David showed me, with an almost boyish enthusiasm, electron microscope pictures of the structure of violin varnish, and explained to me his machine for checking the vibrations of a violin soundboard. This delight in all aspects of his work was typical, and also infectious: many of the earlier workers at Duns Tew went on to set up workshops of their own.

A year ago, at David's request, I finished his last harpsichord, an instrument originally made in the late 1980s but never completed. At the time he was already very ill with cancer, and it was fitting that, in February, Cambridge University conferred on him an honorary master's degree. The day after the degree ceremony, a concert was held in his honour on the newly finished last harpsichord, which David and his brother Peter Cohen have given on loan to the university's music faculty. I was playing another of his harpsichords in a concert at Trinity College, Cambridge, on the day he died.

David also leaves a collection of teddy bears, among whom a bear named Spencer was the first and most famous. Spencer, who became almost as well known as David in the music world, owned a cello - made to scale by David - along with an immaculate case and bow. David's bears sat on his workbenches overseeing the making of the thousand or so superb musical instruments that will be his greatest legacy.

He is survived by Nest, and his daughter, Benita, from an earlier marriage.

fields.headline: Ilse Lasnitzki-Glücksmann
fields.standfirst: Exploring the link between cancer and smoking
fields.trailText: Scientist Ilse Lasnitzki-Glücksmann, who has died aged 91, did pioneering research into the effects of tobacco smoke on lung tissue and worked with leading scientists internationally.
fields.body:
Scientist Ilse Lasnitzki-Glücksmann, who has died aged 91, did pioneering research into the effects of tobacco smoke on lung tissue and worked with leading scientists internationally.

During her long career she also published more than 100 scientific research papers. She had fought hard to become a scientist at a time when there were few women going into the field and during a period of great upheaval in Europe, which led her to spend much of her early life as a refugee.

She was born in Berlin to Adolf and Jenny Lasnitzki. When she was eight years old her father, an unsuccessful businessman, died. Her mother took in lodgers but the family remained poor and Ilse would recall that, as a child, she was constantly hungry and cold. During the first world war, when her two brothers joined the army, she was left to look after her mother and, from the age of 12, earned money by giving lessons to younger children. As a teenager she continued to coach school pupils so that she could fund trips to the theatre and buy her favourite Russian novels.

Ilse was expected to leave school at 16 and do a secretarial course. Instead she insisted on going to university to study medicine, supporting herself by giving private lessons and working for a rabbi. Around this time she joined a communist youth organisation and went to meetings attended by Wilhelm Reich and Einstein.

By 1933 she was a medical student working in a hospital in Berlin. In April all Jewish students there were expelled. Although she was agnostic and secular, she was summoned by the director of medical studies and told to leave. Her mother had died in 1931, and in 1935, with increasing restrictions imposed on the Jewish community, Ilse moved to Copenhagen. When she left Berlin for the last time on New Year's Eve she was seen off by her closest friends and her favourite brother. He, his wife and daughter did not survive the Holocaust; nor did most members of her family.

In Copenhagen Ilse worked, unpaid, in Albert Fischer's laboratory and learned tissue culture before moving, first to Switzerland to continue her medical training in Basle, then to Antwerp. In 1937 she went to Turin and was offered a job, but turned it down to complete her MD. It was a fortunate decision. Mussolini took power in Italy and her prospective employer was thrown into prison. At this time she was forced to rely on refugee committees for housing and meals. Many of her friends either became victims of the Nazis or were casualties in the Spanish civil war.

At the end of 1938 Honor Fell, director of the Strangeways research laboratory in Cambridge, arranged a grant for her from the Society for the Protection of Science and Learning. Among the other scientists at the Strangeways was Alfred Glücksmann, an embryologist from Heidelberg, whom Ilse worked alongside. During the second world war he was interned and sent to the Isle of Man, and then to Canada. When he returned he and Ilse married. During this period the Strangeways was out of bounds for aliens, so Ilse was again unemployed. She registered for a PhD at Newnham College, Cambridge, based on the experiments she had done in Antwerp, and completed her degree in 1943.

After the war she returned to the Strangeways; she first worked on radiation biology, then in branches of cancer research, cell biology and endocrinology. In the 1950s and 60s she did pioneering experimental research on the carcinogenic effects of tobacco smoke on lung tissue, and collaborated with professors Paul Robel and Etienne Bealieu in Paris. In the 1970s and 80s she worked on the effects of other carcinogenic agents, steroid hormones and vitamin A, on the prostate and bladder. She also developed new techniques of tissue and organ culture.

In 1968 she become a fellow of Lucy Cavendish College and the following year was awarded the honorary degree of doctor of science at Cambridge University. In 1974 she started a 15-year collaboration with Professor Mizuno in Tokyo. She maintained that she did some of her best work during her 60s and remained at the Strangeways doing funded research until she was 82.

Throughout her life she was committed to social and racial justice and equality.

Alfred Glücksmann died in 1985. Ilse is survived by her daughter, Miriam.

fields.headline: Hosea Williams
fields.standfirst: Firebrand who became Martin Luther King's 'wild man', using his street knowledge to stoke black protest at southern segregation
fields.trailText: Hosea Williams, one of the most active and controversial members of Martin Luther King's inner circle, has died in Atlanta aged 74. In 1968, he witnessed the assassination of Dr King, who had once described him as "My wild man, my Castro".
fields.body:
Hosea Williams, one of the most active and controversial members of Martin Luther King's inner circle, has died in Atlanta aged 74. In 1968, he witnessed the assassination of Dr King, who had once described him as "My wild man, my Castro". King relied heavily on Williams' fiery rhetoric to stir up black opposition to southern segregation. Once Williams had created a furore, King could arrive much more effectively with his message of peace and reconciliation.

Williams, by his own description, had emerged from an horrendously deprived childhood in pre-war Georgia as "a thug and a gangster". Making full use of the street knowledge this had given him, he was sent to any areas targeted for voter registration or lunch-counter protests. There he would galvanise the black population into such vehement demonstrations that hundreds eventually wound up in the local jails. At the height of the protests, which attracted national and international publicity, King replaced Williams with one of his more emollient lieutenants - often Andrew Young, later President Carter's ambassador to the UN. Young's task was to present the acceptable face of black protest and negotiate a mutually agreeable settlement.

This strategy involved considerable personal risk for Williams, and in 1965 he was lucky to escape with his life when he headed the infamous Bloody Sunday march from Selma to Montgomery in Alabama. Within minutes the state police warned marchers they had two minutes to disperse. Since the size of the procession made it impossible to turn back, the leaders decided to kneel in prayer. At once they were attacked by police with whips, tear gas, and clubs. Williams was beaten unconscious and sustained a fractured skull.

America's television networks interrupted the evening's programmes and all hell broke loose. Within months Congress had passed a powerful voting rights act.

It was a classic example of the street-level realities behind the high-minded campaigns of the civil rights movement, and Williams bore more scars than most. He claimed to have been arrested more than 130 times during the 30-year course of his activities. In one early episode, in Savannah, Georgia, he was forced to survive on bread and water for 35 days.

But he had been trained from childhood to endure such deprivations. His mother absconded from a school for the blind after she discovered her pregnancy. When she died giving birth to a later child, her offspring were left with her impoverished parents. Williams, aged 13, then became friendly with a white girl and had to escape a white lynch mob. He scraped a living as a cleaner, caretaker, farmworker, and anything else that paid. This eventually led to his work for an illegal gambling syndicate and its attendant debt-collecting operation.

A more secure life beckoned with America's entry into the second world war and Williams lied about his age to join the military. He went with the Third Army to Europe, becoming the only survivor of a 13-man platoon hit by a shell in France. The ambulance taking him to hospital with serious leg injuries was also hit and he was again the only survivor. After 13 months' treatment in Britain he was repatriated, but had to walk with a stick for the rest of his life.

His initial commitment to the civil rights struggle was sparked by an incident during his journey home. At one southern stop he tried to drink from the only water fountain in a segregated bus station. A group of whites beat him so badly that he was assumed to be dead. The undertaker found him alive and, seeing Williams with the Purple Heart medal of a wounded serviceman, took him to a veterans hospital.

Before the war Williams had acquired only a rudimentary education, but the GI Bill of Rights allowed him to resume his high school career at the age of 21. From there he continued to university and a master's degree in chemistry. He then joined the agriculture department as the federal government's first black research chemist in the Deep South. For a time he and his wife, Juanita, led a middle-class life, but Williams was increasingly drawn to the accelerating struggle for black civil rights.

He joined the national association for the advancement of colored people and worked his way through its ranks. However, in spite of his ferocious energy and excellent organising ability, he was asked to leave in 1963 when the association learned his mother was unmarried. Williams then joined King's southern Christian leadership council (SCLC).

Soon he was criss-crossing the southern states, encouraging blacks to rebel against segregation. Then came the trauma of King's murder. Williams decided that a more directly political route would serve his cause better. He was elected to the Georgia state legislature, where he stayed for 11 years, and later ran unsuccessfully for mayor of Atlanta. He made an equally forlorn bid for the US Senate but had better luck on the Atlanta city council and local county commission. At the same time he became executive director of the SCLC. However, his relations with its president, the Rev Joseph Lowery, grew strained and Williams was sacked.

His later life was disrupted by alcoholism and he was jailed for drunken driving. There was more scandal when the "church" he founded in Atlanta was revealed to have no premises and to be running Georgia's most profitable bingo operation.

Juanita died in August. Their son died in 1998. Williams is survived by their daughter Elisabeth.

fields.headline: Rent trouble
fields.trailText: My friend Mavis was 60 a couple of months ago. Bus pass, free prescriptions, free TV licence, cold weather payments. Mavis was thrilled. Briefly. Then she discovered that she was in arrears with her rent.
fields.body:
My friend Mavis was 60 a couple of months ago. Bus pass, free prescriptions, free TV licence, cold weather payments. Mavis was thrilled. Briefly. Then she discovered that she was in arrears with her rent.

How come? She doesn't even pay rent. Housing benefit pay it for her. For some odd reason they thought they had overpaid her in the past, so now they were grabbing it back again.

Mavis stared at her documents but couldn't get to grips with them. So I had a go. Double Dutch. We rang estate management (EM). "It's because she's changed from JSA to IS" What? Jobseeker's allowance to income support. Ask housing benefits (HB), said EM. Housing benefits never answer the phone. "Ring the advice bureau." Advice bureau never answers the phone. Or it has closed down.

Mavis gives up in despair. I plod on. Weeks later I locate a helpful fellow at the town hall who makes an appointment for Mavis at a secret HB office that has no known telephone number.

Off we go for Mavis's appointment. An expressionless woman attends to Mavis and explains: from August to September, HB omitted to pay Mavis's benefits, and from August to September HB also overpaid Mavis. Overpaid and didn't pay, both at once. However did they manage that? Wasn't it mad?

A faint smile from the expressionless woman (EW). "You will have to ask the overpayments unit [OU]."

Perhaps, to clarify things, we could see Mavis's file? It hadn't turned up in time for her appointment. EW gives Mavis a form to fill in to send to HB about her missing payments. "How do I do it?" asks Mavis. "I can't tell you what to write," says EW. Mavis may also ring the OU about the overpayments.

"But they'll be engaged," I say.

fields.bodyText: My friend Mavis was 60 a couple of months ago. Bus pass, free prescriptions, free TV licence, cold weather payments. Mavis was thrilled. Briefly. Then she discovered that she was in arrears with her rent. How come? She doesn't even pay rent. Housing benefit pay it for her. For some odd reason they thought they had overpaid her in the past, so now they were grabbing it back again. Mavis stared at her documents but couldn't get to grips with them. So I had a go. Double Dutch. We rang estate management (EM). "It's because she's changed from JSA to IS" What? Jobseeker's allowance to income support. Ask housing benefits (HB), said EM. Housing benefits never answer the phone. "Ring the advice bureau." Advice bureau never answers the phone. Or it has closed down. Mavis gives up in despair. I plod on. Weeks later I locate a helpful fellow at the town hall who makes an appointment for Mavis at a secret HB office that has no known telephone number. Off we go for Mavis's appointment. An expressionless woman attends to Mavis and explains: from August to September, HB omitted to pay Mavis's benefits, and from August to September HB also overpaid Mavis. Overpaid and didn't pay, both at once. However did they manage that? Wasn't it mad? A faint smile from the expressionless woman (EW). "You will have to ask the overpayments unit [OU]." Perhaps, to clarify things, we could see Mavis's file? It hadn't turned up in time for her appointment. EW gives Mavis a form to fill in to send to HB about her missing payments. "How do I do it?" asks Mavis. "I can't tell you what to write," says EW. Mavis may also ring the OU about the overpayments. "But they'll be engaged," I say. "No they won't," says EW. fields.headline: Raising voices
fields.standfirst: If you haven't heard of them, you will soon.  Melissa Benn salutes the political nous and campaigning flair of the Fawcett Society
fields.trailText: If you haven't heard of them, you will soon. Melissa Benn salutes the political nous and campaigning flair of the Fawcett Society.
fields.body:
Tomorrow, the Political Studies Association 50th anniversary awards will honour the work of a small feminist campaign group that has fought its corner valiantly for more than a century of British public life. The Fawcett Society, known simply as Fawcett in the political trade, may never have gained the widespread brand recognition of groups such as Friends of the Earth or Greenpeace but, as the PSA award recognises, it has "shaped the political agenda" in vital ways over the past 50 years and more.

The Fawcett Society is unique. It is one of the few organisations to play what one observer calls "the mood music on modern feminism". Fawcett, a cross-party organisation, campaigns on all the issues that many believe are sorted, out of date or plain dull - equal pay, public imagery of women, gender imbalance in public life, pensions, part-time work and so on. But it also has a brief to influence the influential.

Since Labour's election in 1997 it has inevitably spent a lot of its time lobbying, praising and chiding this government on its sometimes bewildering array of policies and pronouncements on women. Harriet Harman MP, who has worked closely with Fawcett since her sacking from government a couple of years ago, describes the group as "fantastic". "Fawcett is powerful simply because of its arguments. It cannot bring people out on to the streets or organise revolts in the House of Commons or mount fuel protests. What it has instead is campaigning flair and intellectual rigour."

Fawcett's history is, in many ways, the story of respectable British feminism. Founder Millicent Garrett Fawcett collected signatures for the philosopher John Stuart Mill's 1865 petition to parliament calling for votes for women. She went on to form the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies, the non-militant wing of the suffrage campaign.

Fawcett Director Mary-Ann Stephenson, on whose Barbican office wall hangs a suitably grand portrait of Millicent, describes the suffragists as "so unsung. To actually march in public in the 19th century as a woman was very brave. They were incredibly exposed." After the vote was won, Fawcett concentrated on its more diverse pledge to win "equal citizenship for women".

At the high point of second-wave, long-haired, youthful feminism, Fawcett once again seemed to represent a rather stuffy elite, a predominantly middle-class middle aged lobby. But as Stephenson stoutly argues: "An awful lot of women like that changed the world. A lot of the stuff they were campaigning on was really, really unpopular, difficult and uncomfortable."

MP's and other campaigners pay tribute to Shelagh Diplock, Fawcett's Director from 1992 to 1998. But they also point to the changes made by the dynamic, flame-haired Stephenson who, at 30, is now the oldest member of a staff of six, two of whom are part time. Fawcett's recent campaigns reflect this younger perspective on the familiar issues. "Where are the Women" is a good old-fashioned angry campaign directed at the lack of women in business, politics and the media (yes, even now) encouraging the public to tackle employers directly.

Earlier this year, Fawcett launched its Activists Network, which Stephenson hopes will bring in new members. She says: "Whenever I go and speak, women come up to me and say, 'Why didn't I know about you.' People want to join. They just didn't know about us."

But parliament and government are inevitably the focus of Fawcett work. It has recently reported on the poor numbers of women in local government, arguing that the only way forward is to pay councillors. Of parliament, Harriet Harman says: "Fawcett is shaping the climate in which the House of Commons operates. We don't have anything like the National Organi- sation of Women (the mass feminist lobby group in the US) in this country. Feminism has largely made its home in the Labour party. Fawcett provides an independent check on what that Labour party is doing."

Dr Katherine Rake of the LSE, a member of the Women's Budget Group, an independent group of economists, says: "What gets spent on whom is probably the most important part of government policy to scrutinise. Fawcett is prepared to play the boys' game, meet government where its at, which is the economic agenda, rather than on the typically female issues."

Rake has recently produced with Fawcett a critique of government economic policy that exposes the weaknesses of its working families tax credit scheme for women and future problems we are storing up for women pensioners, particularly lone parents.

With luck, the PSA award will encourage Fawcett to keep pushing the politicians and policy-makers. Future plans, say Stephenson, include some kind of work "on domestic democracy, a look at how time and money are carved up in the home". And in the run-up to the general election, the organisation is launching Listen to my Vote, an appeal to women (and politicians) to understand the power of their vote.

Stephenson says: "Its amazing when you look at the gender gap in the US election. Bush had a huge lead among men and Gore among women. If you're arguing with politicians you can make moral arguments about women and you can talk about effectiveness. But sometimes you just have to talk about votes. Fawcett has been talking about votes for more than 130 years. Why stop now?"

For more information about the Fawcett Society visit www.gn.apc.org/fawcett

fields.headline: Jodie's story
fields.standfirst: Last week the body of a young woman was found in Birmingham. She had been strangled, then burned. The news attracted little attention - after all, she was just another junkie. Here  Peter Wilson  , who made a film about her four years ago, recalls the time he spent with a 'fragile, mesmerising girl'
fields.trailText: Last week the body of a young woman was found in Birmingham. She had been strangled, then burned. The news attracted little attention - after all, she was just another junkie. Here Peter Wilson , who made a film about her four years ago, recalls the time he spent with a 'fragile, mesmerising girl'.
fields.body:
I was at home when I got the call. It had been a long week reporting flood stories in the Midlands, and I just wanted a rest. There had been a murder a few days before: a woman, strangled and the body burned. But truthfully, I hadn't taken much notice. Murders don't make the top of the bulletin anymore; they have to be unusual even to be mentioned. And no one knew who she was.

The message was to get in touch with Jodie Hyde's grandmother, Margaret. She had called the office in tears and wanted to speak to me. I knew what it meant, or thought I did. Jodie Hyde must be dead.

I first met Jodie in the summer of 1996. I sat across from her in the back room of a rambling, three- storey Victorian house in Birmingham. I was a BBC reporter and she was a skinny seventeen year old. She wasn't impressed.

She flicked her hair and fidgeted. Whenever I asked something difficult she would gaze off into the distance, but always her head was held high. She was confident, she was young, nothing could touch her. This girl was nothing short of mesmerising. I was there in the warm, cluttered room at the invitation of her grandmother. She was tearing her hair out, and was desperate to find somebody to help her with Jodie.

My report was to be about addiction to lighter fuel, and this fragile, hauntingly beautiful child was telling me her story. In her sleeve, where most girls hide a tissue, she kept a can of gas. Twentyfour hours a day, the hiss of the spray was ever present. She sucked on the plastic nozzle like a baby's dummy.

"All the shopkeepers know me, they know what I want and they get it out from behind the counter. A pack of 12 cans," she told me. "If I were a smoker that would take me six years to get through but they all know I'm sniffing it and I'll be back for more tomorrow. They're only interested in the money"

When I left the house I knew I would make a full-length programme, not a short news report. Butane gas was killing a child every week in the UK. It was more dangerous than heroin and ecstasy combined. Of children who tried it for the first time, 40% died instantly, usually in alleyways, but few people were taking much notice.

The documentary The Trouble With Jodie won a clutch of television awards. The anti-solvents charity Re-Solv used it as part of its campaign to successfully change the law to make it illegal to sell gas to the under-18s. Birmingham Trading Standards gained a rare victory in the courts in 1997 when it prosecuted the shop owner who sold Jodie and her friends crates of gas at inflated prices. But what did the Hyde family gain?

Even before I started filming, Jodie was causing problems. She had run away from home after another family row. Having only just finished a course of treatment she had gone back on the gas immediately, and her grandmother had heard she was sleeping rough.

Margaret came out with me one night, as we looked for Jodie : "She's sleeping in a churchyard where tramps sleep out. They're actually looking out for her but I'm so worried and anything can happen now she's taking the gas again."

Jodie had long since left the family home, and lived with her grandmother, although she remained in close contact with her mother, Tracey. Tracey couldn't let Jodie stay after she started openly sniffing the gas in front of her three younger brothers and baby sister. Tracey looked like Jodie's older sister, but the lines were beginning to form, etched into her face by Jodie's behaviour.

"She's a lovable young girl, always so generous, but the Jodie on the gas is nasty," she told me. "She can be violent, she threw a brick at me once. She's like a monster. The gas really changes her, it's like the name, she's a Jekyll and Hyde."

I eventually found her a few weeks later begging on the streets of Balsall Heath, a run-down suburb to the east of the city, with a can of butane gas jammed up the sleeve of her blue anorak. She didn't want to talk, but a few days later phoned up and invited me to see her at the flat of a new friend she had made. The woman was a registered heroin user and Jodie was helping to look after her children.

Jodie told me happily that she was off the gas, waving her arms in the air to prove that she had no hidden cans of gas. "It's been 30 hours since I had some gas and I haven't even had a craving for it. Usually I get up and don't even have a wash I go straight out to the local shop and buy loads of tins of gas. I've got a fiver in my pocket but I still don't want the gas."

But why didn't her family do more, some might ask? Why not just go round the streets like I did and find her and bring her home. But Tracey and Margaret and the rest of her big Birmingham family had done that many times. Jodie started taking gas when she was 13, introduced by a local kid. They had fought hard to get her on treatment programmes but nothing had worked.

I remember that Tracey just sighed and smiled at my innocence: "Unless I could tie her up, put bars on the windows and lock her in her bedroom, there's no way I can get her off the gas. I just can't physically do it."

Over the next few months, the filming schedule had it's own momentum and Jodie responded. She returned to Margaret's and she looked like an ordinary teenager again. There was talk of going back to college. She said she wanted to go into schools and warn others of the dangers of solvents. She even moved back in with Tracey. A happy ending?

The programme went out in November 1996 in the Midlands and was repeated nationally on the BBC. Newspapers and magazines carried the story. Jodie seemed to bathe in the warm glow of the attention, but no magic wand can solve the problems of drug abuse. Before long she was back on the gas. Then, later, so-called friends introduced her to heroin.

I kept in touch with the family but gradually stopped visiting. I felt uncomfortable that nothing seemed to have been achieved. Then, last weekend, I picked up the phone and called Margaret back. I steeled myself, expecting the news that Jodie had died of an overdose. But Jodie had not been killed by her own reckless use of drugs; she had been murdered. The unknown woman, whose case had featured on the regional news, was the 21-year- old woman I knew so well: Jodie Hyde.

Once again Jodie's story would take me on roller-coaster ride, but this time there would be no promise of redemption. All the chances to change her life had run out, someone had cut away the Hyde family's future. I sat at the back of the police news conference last week and watched as Tracey and her brother clung to each other under the glare of the flashing cameras.

Later Tracey and her partner spoke to me alone, appealing to the public to come forward and help the detectives investigating Jodie's murder. Tracey recalled the best and worst of the times she'd had with her wayward daughter, and returned to those words of four years ago, but with a bitter vehemence: "I should have gone out and found her on the streets, brought her back home and locked her in her bedroom, to keep her away from those people out there, and from that can of gas."

webTitle: Leader: Let every vote count in Florida

fields.headline: Let every vote count
fields.standfirst:
Florida's judges can end this saga

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Strange though it be to say it nearly two weeks after an election, an endgame for the presidential contest of 2000 is finally taking shape. Today the supreme court of Florida will begin a process which should reveal the way out of this bizarre saga.
fields.body:
Strange though it be to say it nearly two weeks after an election, an endgame for the presidential contest of 2000 is finally taking shape. Today the supreme court of Florida will begin a process which should reveal the way out of this bizarre saga.

The judges could rule that Florida's highest election official, Katherine Harris, can go ahead and certify the state's result without waiting for the three counties now undertaking hand counts to submit their revised figures. If the supreme court does that, it will virtually anoint George W Bush as president. For Ms Harris will be free to lock in Mr Bush's current 900-plus lead over his rival, Al Gore. Mr Bush will, however narrowly, be declared the winner of Florida and so the White House.

At that point, Democrats could cry foul - noting Ms Harris's dual service as Florida's chief returning officer and co-chair of the Bush campaign in the state. But they would have few options. It is often assumed that any case in America can always be referred up to the US supreme court in Washington - but that is not so. Only federal matters can be heard there. So the Gore camp would have to switch to a whole new legal track, starting with a lower federal court. They would be unlikely to get much of a hearing: the federal bench is wary of meddling in state matters and, though it may seem puzzling to outsiders, elections are deemed a responsibility for the 50 states not the federal government. Even Gore's own team admits this business is likely to be settled by Florida's senior bench.

If, in the event of a judicial defeat in Tallahassee, the vice president tried to keep up his legal fight, he would run into strong resistance from his own side. Senior Democrats would begin to call time on the Gore effort, urging him to bow out gracefully. After all, many of them have motives of their own. A Bush presidency would be a joy to run against in 2002's mid-term elections: Democrats in opposition could well regain the control of the House and Senate they lost in 1994. Those with presidential ambitions have an even sharper motive: it would be hard to seek the Democratic nomination in 2004 against a White House incumbent - much easier if the spot is vacant.

So the Florida supreme court's decision this week could end the Gore campaign once and for all. But the judges could also keep it alive, if they order Ms Harris to accept the recounted figures. Even then, there is no guarantee. The latest numbers dribbling out of Palm Beach and Broward counties, supposed goldmines of untapped Gore votes, have revealed only a handful of previously uncounted Democratic ballots. The irony is that the recounts may leave the final result pretty much as it was.

Still, the hope has to be that the Florida supremes rule that the manual recounts should indeed count - perhaps by ordering a similar by-hand effort across the entire state. This should be the hope not only of Gore advocates but of those who believe in the democratic process itself. Over the weekend, Republican spinners sought to discredit the recounts, offering unsubstantiated charges of mischief (including a claim that Democrats are concealing the evidence of their ballot-tampering by eating the now notorious "chads"). This is scorched-earth politics, advancing a partisan cause by burning up public trust in the electoral process. The Republicans should cool it, and let the judges decide. We hope the bench lets all the votes count and then - and only then - allows a winner to emerge and this surreal story to draw to a close.

If the supreme court does that, it will virtually anoint George W Bush as president. For Ms Harris will be free to lock in Mr Bush's current 900-plus lead over his rival, Al Gore. Mr Bush will, however narrowly, be declared the winner of Florida and so the White House. At that point, Democrats could cry foul - noting Ms Harris's dual service as Florida's chief returning officer and co-chair of the Bush campaign in the state. But they would have few options. It is often assumed that any case in America can always be referred up to the US supreme court in Washington - but that is not so. Only federal matters can be heard there. So the Gore camp would have to switch to a whole new legal track, starting with a lower federal court. They would be unlikely to get much of a hearing: the federal bench is wary of meddling in state matters and, though it may seem puzzling to outsiders, elections are deemed a responsibility for the 50 states not the federal government. Even Gore's own team admits this business is likely to be settled by Florida's senior bench. If, in the event of a judicial defeat in Tallahassee, the vice president tried to keep up his legal fight, he would run into strong resistance from his own side. Senior Democrats would begin to call time on the Gore effort, urging him to bow out gracefully. After all, many of them have motives of their own. A Bush presidency would be a joy to run against in 2002's mid-term elections: Democrats in opposition could well regain the control of the House and Senate they lost in 1994. Those with presidential ambitions have an even sharper motive: it would be hard to seek the Democratic nomination in 2004 against a White House incumbent - much easier if the spot is vacant. So the Florida supreme court's decision this week could end the Gore campaign once and for all. But the judges could also keep it alive, if they order Ms Harris to accept the recounted figures. Even then, there is no guarantee. The latest numbers dribbling out of Palm Beach and Broward counties, supposed goldmines of untapped Gore votes, have revealed only a handful of previously uncounted Democratic ballots. The irony is that the recounts may leave the final result pretty much as it was. Still, the hope has to be that the Florida supremes rule that the manual recounts should indeed count - perhaps by ordering a similar by-hand effort across the entire state. This should be the hope not only of Gore advocates but of those who believe in the democratic process itself. Over the weekend, Republican spinners sought to discredit the recounts, offering unsubstantiated charges of mischief (including a claim that Democrats are concealing the evidence of their ballot-tampering by eating the now notorious "chads"). This is scorched-earth politics, advancing a partisan cause by burning up public trust in the electoral process. The Republicans should cool it, and let the judges decide. We hope the bench lets all the votes count and then - and only then - allows a winner to emerge and this surreal story to draw to a close.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Queen wrings pheasant's neck
fields.body:
Queen wrings pheasant's neck

The Queen was pictured wringing the neck of a pheasant with her bare hands while watching the Duke of Edinburgh and other guests shooting at Sandringham, Norfolk.

The bird, peppered with shot, was picked up and carried to her by a gundog, reports said. A Buckingham Palace spokesman said: "It was clearly the most effective and humane way of despatching the injured bird."

Police question assassin theory

Detectives say that the man who shot dead a homeopathic healer in front of his brother may have been a robber, not a hired assassin.

Baldev Khrisan Yadev, 55, was shot in the head and in the body, while in a supermarket carpark opposite his offices in Wolverhampton on Friday night.

Co-op soup tins withdrawn

Co-operative societies have withdrawn a batch of 35,000 own brand cans of mushroom and chicken soup, made by HL Foods of Wisbech in Cambridgeshire, after customers complained of an unwelcome smell.

A fault with the tins' seams is thought responsible.

Iris Murdoch fellowship

Iris Murdoch, who died from Alzheimer's disease last year, is to have a research fellowship named after her, the author's husband announced yesterday.

The £150,000 Alzheimer's Society-Iris Murdoch fellowship will be used to research the communication difficulties faced by people with dementia.

Quarter of men work from home

Almost a quarter of employed men now work from home, and half the rest would like to join them, according to the first Work-Life balance survey, part of a government campaign to get employers to offer flexible working.

Some 16% women work from home, and less than a third would like to do so.

Four way split for lottery £5.4m

Four ticket-holders shared Saturday night's £54.m lottery jackpot, with winning numbers 6, 9, 11, 21, 27, and 43; bonus 17. Thunderball numbers were 3, 8, 9, 13, 23, Thunderball was 9. No tickets matched the Lottery Extra numbers.

Caver's body found

The body of Howard Rothwell, 49, of Arkholme, Lancashire, who disappeared while exploring the Three Counties cave system that stretches under Cumbria, Lancashire and North Yorkshire, was found last night.

He and a friend became separated eight days ago and rising water levels - a particular hazard in the system - delayed the search.

Man in court on Enigma charges

Dennis Yates, 57, antiques dealer of Sandiacre, Derbyshire, will appear before Milton Keynes magistrates in Buckinghamshire today charged with blackmail and handling stolen goods in connection with the theft of the second world war Enigma encoding machine.

Police project bad images

Birmingham police are projecting 40ft sq photographs of three "most wanted" men on to its headquarters today as part of a campaign that has used the internet to catch four robbers.

One car per 2.2 people in UK

The UK has one car for every 2.2 people, compared with the EU average of one to 2.1, according to Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders figures released last night.

Floods kill hedgehogs

Flooding has seriously affected hedgehogs, killing and causing pneumonia in unusually large numbers, according to reports from animal welfare centres.

fields.headline: Landmark ruling on judge's conduct
fields.trailText: A landmark ruling by the high court could open the way for more defendants whose convictions are quashed because of unfair treatment by the trial judge to claim compensation from the Home Office.
fields.body:
A landmark ruling by the high court could open the way for more defendants whose convictions are quashed because of unfair treatment by the trial judge to claim compensation from the Home Office.

Lord Justice Rose and Mr Justice Moses have ruled that the behaviour of the judge who presided over the trial of Mohammed Tawfick in July 1996 was "exceptional", qualifying Mr Tawfick for compensation.

In an embarrassing defeat for Jack Straw, the judges quashed his decision not to pay compensation and held that no reasonable home secretary could have come to the conclusion that the way Judge Henry Blacksell conducted the trial was not exceptional. The ruling means that Mr Straw will probably have to pay Mr Tawfick, who spent nearly five months in prison, a five-figure sum.

The home secretary has a discretion to make ex gratia payments to those who have their convictions quashed if the circumstances are exceptional. But until Mr Straw agreed last year to compensate the family of Derek Bentley no award had been made for a judge's prejudicial behaviour.

In the case of Bentley, 19, hanged for the murder of a policeman in 1953, the then lord chief justice, Lord Bingham, said the judge's summing up was "such as to deny Bentley that fair trial which is the birthright of every British citizen".

After sacking his lawyers, Mr Tawfick represented himself at his trial at Middlesex Guildhall crown court in July 1996 for conspiracy to steal and handling stolen goods. During the trial, the judge admonished him: "Do not lie", and said: "Let's not have any more of this trickery."

The appeal court later quashed his conviction. The appeal judges said the trial judge "allowed himself to be drawn into making observations which would in all probability have led the jury to regard the appellant as a liar."

Mr Tawfick, who lives in London but qualified as a lawyer in his home country, Egypt, applied to the Home Office for compensation but was turned down.

Before Mr Straw's May 1999 decision in the Bentley case, he won a judicial review forcing the home secretary to reconsider his case, but Mr Straw rejected his application again.

Mr Justice Moses said in the ruling that Mr Straw had fallen into error by using the Bentley case as the benchmark, and ordered him to pay Mr Tawfick's costs.

webTitle: Threat of extinction stalks farmland bird species

fields.headline: Threat of extinction stalks farmland bird species
fields.standfirst: Conservationists blame herbicides and changes in crop routines
fields.trailText: Farmland birds are under threat of extinction because of intensive farming, conservationists warn today.
fields.body:
Farmland birds are under threat of extinction because of intensive farming, conservationists warn today.

The skylark, grey partridge and corn bunting have fallen in numbers by more than 50% in 25 years and continue to fall at an alarming rate, according to the annual breeding bird survey compiled by the RSPB, the British Trust for Ornithology and the Joint Nature Conservation Committee.

The protectionists blame changes in farming methods over the same period - use of herbicides and shifts in crop growing routines being the most likely causes.

The report says some farmland birds have been put on the conservationist UK Red list, higlighting species that have been reduced in numbers by at least 50% during the last 25 years.

Information collated by volunteer birdwatchers on 217 species found that between 1994 and 1999 the the grey partridge population fell by 43%, the bullfinch by 28% and the corn bunting by 26%; the turtle dove population decreased by 18%, the skylark by 16%, and the linnet by 14%.

Graham Madge, of the RSPB, said: "Most of these birds were widespread 50 to 100 years ago, and we are now seeing the results of changes in the countryside.

"The time of year when crops are sown may seem insignificant, but it means that now many birds cannot find food in the winter."

Research has shown that the introduction of autumn planting of wheat and barley had robbed farmland birds of the stubble fields that helped feed them during the winter.

"We will continue to see further decimation of the bird population unless we address the issue," Mr Madge warned.

The government made a specific pledge in August to take action to stabilise the population of farmland bird, but this was widely described as an enormous task and one of the most ambitious conservation commitments any British government had given.

The dramatic decline of farmland species, as well as a number of woodland species such as the wood warbler and willow tit, are described in the report as "worrying".

Other birds causing concern include the shelduck, the redshank, the kestrel, the lapwing, the oystercatcher, and the great black-backed gull.

The report does cite some exceptions to the gloomy trend, with 35 species increasing in numbers over 1995 to 1999.

Mr Madge said: "Most are small species that have benefited from a run of mild winters. Small birds find it very difficult to keep warm and find food during cold spells. The goldcrest in particular has gone up by 61% since 1994." The wren, the great-spotted woodpecker and the redstart are up 42%.

Species that appear to be stable include the wood pigeon, the collared dove, the song thrush, the swallow, the wheatear, the pied wagtail, the whitethroat, the goldfinch and the greenfinch.

fields.headline: Looking on bright side 'helps babies'
fields.trailText: Women who look on the bright side of life will give birth to healthier babies, sleep well and remain slimmer, new research claimed today.
fields.body:
Women who look on the bright side of life will give birth to healthier babies, sleep well and remain slimmer, new research claimed today.

In two separate studies, both published in the American Psychological Association's (APA) journal of Health Psychology, women aged between 20 and 46 from differing socio-economic backgrounds in America were examined by psychiatrists.

The women were asked to describe their outlook on life and to place themselves on an imaginary social ladder with the 10th and highest rung implying a good job, strong education and secure finances while the first rung suggested insecurity and poverty.

In the first survey, 129 high-risk pregnant women were interviewed and questioned about their attitude towards life.

They were considered high-risk because they had either already had a miscarriage, suffered from diabetes or were having bleeding problems during their current pregnancies.

Mantras such as "I always look on the bright side, I always expect the best" or "I hardly ever expect things to go my way" were put to these women.

Those who responded most positively gave birth to stronger, heavier babies and the process of birth was less arduous.

Psychologist Marci Lobel, who carried out the experiment, said: "More optimistic women had better birth outcomes in part because they exercised more frequently, which improved a baby's greater gestational age at birth.

"These factors may be as important to maternal and foetal health as other factors like medical risk which have traditionally received greater attention."

In the second survey, 160 healthy women aged between 30 and 46 were examined by Nancy Adler, professor of psychiatry at the University of California in San Francisco.

When the women ranked themselves on the socio-economic ladder, those who had a good image of themselves were healthier as a whole. They had no trouble falling asleep at night, kept slimmer and generally felt more fit.

The hormone cortisol which is associated with stress leads to abdominal weight gain and was evident in women who had placed themselves lower down on the scale.

Dr Alder said: "Women who perceived themselves to be lower on the ladder had more stress than their peers."

webTitle: Student knifed to death on lonely common

fields.headline: Student knifed to death on lonely common
fields.trailText: Police began a murder inquiry yesterday when a student was stabbed to death on a lonely, unlit common near the seafront at Southsea in Hampshire.
fields.body:
Police began a murder inquiry yesterday when a student was stabbed to death on a lonely, unlit common near the seafront at Southsea in Hampshire.

John Rees, 23, a final year computer science student at Portsmouth University, was found at a postmortem examination to have died from a single knife thrust in the chest.

Mr Rees, from Shoreham in West Sussex, was crossing Southsea common, three miles wide and a mile long, with four fellow students after a birthday celebration at the seafront Pyramids Centre club. The friends, three men and a woman, left the club at 2am.

Kevin Briscoe, a spokesman for Hampshire police, said: "There then appears to have been an altercation with another group of people which ended with the deceased suffering the stab wound." Mr Rees staggered to a road and collapsed, dying in Queen Alexandra hospital, Portsmouth.

Yesterday police sealed off much of the common in a fingertip search for the knife, and asked residents to check gardens and litter bins for the murder weapon.

fields.headline: 'Two nations' divide yawns for over-50s
fields.standfirst: As well-off embrace a youthful lifestyle, their less affluent counterparts face increased risk of hardship, researchers say
fields.trailText: Britain's over-50s will increasingly be split into two nations, affluent early retirers in search of a better quality of life and low-paid men and women compelled to continue beyond pension age because of financial necessity, researchers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's over-50s will increasingly be split into two nations, affluent early retirers in search of a better quality of life and low-paid men and women compelled to continue beyond pension age because of financial necessity, researchers said yesterday.

Huge increases in the number of middle-aged people living alone after divorce or separation would mean growing demand for rented rooms while more men sliding towards alcoholism and depression would create a new burden for welfare services.

The warning of a dark flipside to the "grey panthers" generation of well-off older consumers, who still see themselves as young, active and sociable, was made in a report for the economic and social research council.

The generation divide over daily lifestyle between those over 50 and young people was disappearing, it suggested. But that also meant the idea of permanence and maturing into older middle-age, indulging the grandchildren, and participating in community networks, was changing too. The report suggested that for some over-50s "more self-focused, hedonistic attitudes will emerge as they imitate the lifestyles of the young". Already surveys suggested that they had similar alcohol consumption, TV, video and reading habits, and DIY and gardening interests, even if they listened to less music or engaged actively in sport.

And the fireside and slippers image was further slipping as men and women went in search of self-fulfilment. More women, who were enjoying independence because of educational and employment opportunities, could choose to live alone.

That meant the divorce rate, which has already tripled in 20 years from 3% to 9% among those in their 50s, could soar as increasing numbers in the age group re-examined their marriages and relationships in the light of their higher expectations.

The majority would, however, suffer increasing financial hardship. More would have to care for their parents, and the problem would be made bigger by the fact that more of the parents would be older men living on their own. Today one in 10 men over 60 live alone, but by 2020 the figure could be one in three.

"This could lead to greater economic hardship for sons and daughters in their 50s as it forms an added burden for those who may still be contributing to the upbringing of their own children from present or past relationships."

In addition, the longer life expectancy of parents meant their children now might have to wait until their 60s for inheritances that would help to pay off mortgages and fund their children's education.

Richard Scase, of Kent University, and Jonathan Scales, of Essex University, authors of Fit and Fifty?, said all this was happening as those in managerial and professional occupations had an entrenched expectation of early retirement.

But for many there would be economic and other burdens. "Evidence suggests that women are more capable than men of managing their emotional and social lives, suggesting that the growth of single person households among those in their 50s is likely to lead to growing social and psychological problems for men."

fields.headline: Drinkers told not to 'get wrecked'
fields.trailText: A trial for Britain's first national advertising campaign warning against drunkenness is launched today, as the alcohol industry seeks to present itself as socially responsible.
fields.body:
A trial for Britain's first national advertising campaign warning against drunkenness is launched today, as the alcohol industry seeks to present itself as socially responsible.

Posters are going up in dozens of pubs, clubs and student bars in Manchester aimed at 18- to 24-year-olds. They include warnings of being "trollied into casualty" and victims' faces being "wrecked", and invite a choice between waking up with a hangover or with a girlfriend.

Government advertising against drink-driving, especially at Christmas and new year, are now common, but the Manchester pilot, based on a slogan "If you do drink, don't do drunk", promises to be the forerunner of an unprecedented blitz on young people's drinking habits.

The four-week trial, backed by local radio advertising, has the support of the local authorities and police. It is being run by the Portman Group, representing beer, spirits and cider manufacturers, to promote sensible drinking and stem alcohol misuse. Young people's reaction will be independently evaluated, but the campaign is expected to go national early next year.

Jean Coussins, director of the group, said: "Many young adults regularly drink to get drunk. They could be storing up long term health problems, but drunkenness also exposes them to immediate personal risks to their dignity, safety and life." The pilot would help tell the industry how to "communicate a message which is not necessarily seen as welcome by its target audience".

Ms Coussins said such a campaign, linked to a "more civilised licensing system" could promote sensible drinking: "Customers who are able to come back another time are a much better bet than people who end up in a hospital, police station or morgue."

A MORI survey indicated that 48% of adults do not see the drinks industry as socially responsible, with 46% viewing it more positively - better than the tobacco industry, for example, which 25% of respondents viewed as responsible, but far worse than food retailers (82%), or the car industry (59%). The survey of more than 1,500 adults found that 59% of the target 18 to 24-year-olds think the drinks industry socially responsible.

But it also suggests that public opinion over government plans to relax closing times is divided - with 39% supporting and 39% against, with rest undecided. More than half questioned thought happy hours led to excessive drinking, and that advertising and sports sponsorship had an influence on consumption - while claiming they had little influence on their own habits.

Posters are going up in dozens of pubs, clubs and student bars in Manchester aimed at 18- to 24-year-olds. They include warnings of being "trollied into casualty" and victims' faces being "wrecked", and invite a choice between waking up with a hangover or with a girlfriend. webTitle: Hostage who vanished into a void

fields.headline: Hostage who vanished into a void
fields.standfirst: Parents of geologist captured by rebels in Angola two years ago say that officials have shown a lack of urgency over his predicament
fields.trailText: Two years ago, Jason Pope, a 24-year-old British geologist, was seized by a group of Unita rebels after an attack on the Yetwene diamond mine in Lunda Norte province, north-east Angola.
fields.body:
Two years ago, Jason Pope, a 24-year-old British geologist, was seized by a group of Unita rebels after an attack on the Yetwene diamond mine in Lunda Norte province, north-east Angola.

Eight people were killed in the attack, including two Britons, David Boutle and Alan Thomas. On November 9, 1998, the day after the attack, Jason was said to be being used as a "pack animal" with three colleagues to carry loot into the bush.

A spokeswoman for his Canadian company, DiamondWorks, said it had been in radio contact with hostages until they were marched beyond the range of their security handsets. "What is puzzling is that they allowed their hostages to communicate with us for so long. This gives us some hope that they will be decently treated," she said.

Nothing has been heard since about Jason. Every potential avenue has been tried to discover what happened to him, where he is being held, whether he is still alive. So says the Foreign Office. Jason's parents, Nev and Alan, disagree.

Their correspondence with the FO has become increasingly ugly, reflecting an anger born out of frustration. It also illustrates how two parties approach such a personal case from an entirely different perspective, one deeply and emotionally involved, the other keeping an institutional distance, to achieve the same end.

In January 1999, Jason's mother wrote to the FO's consular department suggesting a meeting with other families in a similar situation to theirs. "After careful consideration," came the reply two months later, "we would recommend against trying to contact families ... whilst the whereabouts of Jason remains unknown."

Speculation

That, it said, would provoke speculation in the media that Unita was responsible for abducting Jason, running the risk of "seriously jeopardising his safety". The FO said it had already contacted Unita "both directly and indirectly". DiamondWorks had also been in contact with Unita.

It offered to arrange a radio broadcast but made clear it would ensure it was "non-accusatory" and would make no mention of Unita. The FO added that Britain's ambassador to Luanda, the capital, had raised the case with the Angolan government - which is fighting a civil war with Unita - including President Dos Santos. It had approached neighbouring African governments, as well as Portugal, the former colonial power, and the Red Cross. In June, Tony Lloyd, the then minister for Africa, told Patrick Nicholls, the Popes' constituency MP - they live in Teignmouth, Devon - that the FO was doing all it could to establish Jason's whereabouts. "No one will tell us whether he is dead or alive," said Mr Lloyd.

The following month Nev Pope wrote to Cherie Blair. She replied that as a mother she could understand the frustrations and emotions Nev must be feeling.

The FO was continuing to work on the assumption that Jason was still alive, she added, "but this latest report [information from a Unita source who denied the rebels were holding anyone from the Yetwene mine incident] after eight months with no word of Jason is worrying". Mrs Blair went on: "The return to war in Angola is heartbreaking, given the country's enormous potential, with over 1.5m people displaced in the current conflict".

Two months later, in October last year, Tony Blair replied to letters from Nev. "I feel it only honest to tell you," he said, "that the chances of Jason being alive look increasingly remote". It is clear from the correspondence that their personal anguish about the fate of their son led Jason's parents deep into the politics of Angola, to the extent that they came up with ideas for peace negotiations.

It is also clear that Tim Spicer, director of Sandline, the private military company at the centre of the arms-to-Sierra Leone affair, has been working behind the scenes at Diamond Works' request - something which the Foreign Office has acknowledged. As the months went by, it also became clear that Nev believed the FO was holding things back.

Though she has met Baroness Scotland, the FO minister for consular affairs, her requests to see Peter Hain, the minister responsible for Africa, have been blocked. She has been told FO files relating to Jason are classified and their disclosure would "cause harm to [Britain's] defence, security and international relations". She feels the FO has not taken her into its full confidence.

"Jason is still alive and we have to find the right buttons to press to unlock the stalemate we are seemingly encountering," she told an FO official last month. "There was never a sense of urgency about the situation," she said yesterday, "no belief that Jason is still alive."

The FO, in what sounds like a combination of frustration and exasperation, says Jason has been the subject of 230 telegrams. It had contacted Unita, the UN, the Russian and Libyan governments, the Angolan Red Cross, non-government organisations, church groups, the Vatican. Mr Hain had raised Jason's case on a visit to Angola in July.

What clouds this case is the uncertainty which continues to surround Jason's fate. It is something, at least, that the families of those known to have been killed in the same diamond-rich province of Lunda Norte, including another British miner, Patrick Bergin, killed in January 1999, do not have to bear.

fields.headline: Murder suspect taunts police
fields.trailText: The man suspected of murdering British backpacker Brenda Searle has reportedly told Mexican prosecutors that he committed the crime, but dared them to prove it.
fields.body:
The man suspected of murdering British backpacker Brenda Searle has reportedly told Mexican prosecutors that he committed the crime, but dared them to prove it.

Jorge Gamboa, known as "the Cuban", was arrested after Ms Searle disappeared on her way to meet her boyfriend while she was on a backpacking holiday in Mexico in September.

Gamboa was held on charges relating to assaults and rape on other women and later identified by staff at a jewellery store as the man who tried to use Ms Searle's credit card.

Attorney general Carlos Pereira from the Caribbean coast state of Quintana Roo said that Gamboa told prosecutors that he killed Ms Searle, 27, from Buckinghamshire.

He implied that the body had been hidden or destroyed and taunted: "Yes, I killed her, but prove it. If you can show me so much as a shoe, I'll sign the confession."

But under Mexican law the confession may not be accepted as evidence because it was not made in writing or before a judge.

Ms Searle, a British citizen born in Holland, has been missing since September 4 when she failed to meet her boyfriend, tourist guide Andre van de Vooren, at Chichen Itza, the site of a Mayan temple, in the state of Yucatan. She had flown to Cancun then travelled by bus and ferry to Isla Mujares, an island popular with backpackers, and stayed in a budget hotel.

From there she sent an email to her family, saying that she was leaving the next day and had booked a hotel room near the Chichen Itza site.

The following day her credit and bank cards, which she kept hidden in a money belt, were used. On September 8, £800 was charged to her credit card.

After Ms Searle failed to arrive at the Chichen Itza site, Mr van de Vooren spent a fortnight searching for her. Two of her closest friends, Charlotte Holgate and Lisa Eastwood, who had been fellow students at Imperial College, London, also flew out to help and the family hired three Mexican private investigators.

The company where Ms Searle worked, ab.fab Interactive Media Group, in Amsterdam, created a web page for information.

Three Mexican police departments are liaising with Dutch police and Britain's Foreign Office to investigate the disappearance.

Ms Searle grew up in Princes Risborough. Her father, Geoffrey, is English and her mother, Marjo, Dutch. The family moved to the Netherlands when she was 11 but she returned to study in Britain in the early 1990s.

webTitle: Pensioners' nuclear tour prompts security alert

fields.headline: Pensioners' nuclear tour prompts security alert
fields.trailText: They were looking for the village of Arrochar in Strathclyde. What they found was the hub of Britain's nuclear arsenal.
fields.body:
They were looking for the village of Arrochar in Strathclyde. What they found was the hub of Britain's nuclear arsenal.

Four pensioners from Ireland triggered a security alert after they took a wrong turn and drove, unchallenged, into the Faslane submarine base on the Clyde, the home of the Trident nuclear deterrent.

The intruders, two men and two women, believed to be in their seventies, were stopped by security guards after they asked for directions to their intended destination.

The tourists had driven for almost a mile inside the perimeter fence on November 7. It is thought they were waved through the main gate, and a security guard has been suspended pending an investigation into the incident.

A spokesman for Faslane said the incident was being treated seriously. He would not reveal how long the group spent inside the base.

He added: "For some reason, on arriving at the gate these people were permitted to enter despite not having the numerous passes needed before anyone is allowed on. An inquiry is ongoing and a member of staff has been suspended until it is completed."

The heavily fortified base has been the scene of countless protests by anti-nuclear activists, some of whom have chained themselves to the gates or tried to break inside.

fields.headline: When prison won't work
fields.trailText: Your compelling expose of life inside Feltham prison for older teenagers (G2, November 17) should focus attention on this neglected group. The number of 18, 19 and 20 year olds sentenced to prison has increased by 40% since 1994, and the conditions in which they are held have deteriorated commensurately.
fields.body:
Your compelling expose of life inside Feltham prison for older teenagers (G2, November 17) should focus attention on this neglected group. The number of 18, 19 and 20 year olds sentenced to prison has increased by 40% since 1994, and the conditions in which they are held have deteriorated commensurately. Because of the concentration on the needs of the very young teenagers, older boys and girls have suffered. The prison service plans to remedy this by moving them straight into adult jails. We would prefer to see the successes of the new youth justice service replicated for older teenagers, and community-based sanctions developed.

Feltham prison is not alone. Other prisons holding young people are failing. They fail to care for the young inmates, they fail to protect them from bullying, and they fail to prevent future crimes.
Frances Crook
Director, Howard League for Penal Reform

 The issue about Blantyre House (Prisons chief under fire from MPs, November 17) goes beyond the deplorable raid last May. The history of British prisons is littered with antagonism towards regimes that are liberal and empowering. Prison officers who try to operate with dignity and humanity will also often be criticised for being "soft". Will the prison service therefore mount similar "raids" on those who make the lives of committed staff a misery with their hostility towards them?
Prof Joe Sim
Liverpool John Moores University
