E Relton (Letters, November 18) fearlessly outed 43% of letters-page contributors as "smart arses". As every smart arse knows, it takes one to know one.
Danny Proudfoot
Northwich,Cheshire
danny@proudfootd.freeserve.co.uk

 E Relton writes: "On November 11, of the 23 letters published, no less than 10 (43%) could justifiably be called smart-arse letters." It is, of course, "no fewer than".

webTitle: Letters: Climate conference will generate a lot of hot air

fields.headline: Climate conference will generate a lot of hot air
fields.trailText: Just for once, George Monbiot is right - but I am afraid this is for the wrong reasons (The great climate sell-off, November 16).
fields.body:
Just for once, George Monbiot is right - but I am afraid this is for the wrong reasons (The great climate sell-off, November 16).

The real tragedy of the farce currently being enacted in the Hague is that, by concentrating on one greenhouse gas linked by a tenuous theory to a possible small global warming, we are neglecting all the other actions we might take to ameliorate its possibly harmful impacts. In short, the Hague agenda is largely false.

Part of the blame for this must lie with a largely silent, but surprisingly large, group of "greenhouse sceptic" climatologists like myself. We have allowed the debate to be hijacked by computer modellers unwilling to recognise that natural processes they cannot model might be important in driving climate change and by simple wishful thinking by the green lobby.
Professor David J Unwin
Birkbeck College school of geography

 The creation of property rights in climate emissions is an explosive political issue that must not go unchallenged.

As George Monbiot points out, carbon emissions already have a market value, and countries that polluted most in 1990 will get most carbon credits. The world's poorest countries get no credit for their low impact on the environment. Estimated market values for carbon emissions show that the G7 richest countries are running up carbon debts of $13 trillion a year to the world's poorest countries.

If climate emissions are property rights, then the only fair approach is to share them on an equal per capita basis, as advocated by the Global Commons Institute. Emissions trading could help tackle global warming, but only if emissions are allocated on an equitable basis, carbon sinks are ruled out and the system is rigorously policed.

Otherwise climate damage will escalate. This is a man-made catastrophe which we can stop.
Titus Alexander
London

 Contrary to your suggestion (Blyth spirit can lead to cleaner Britain, November 17), using liquid petroleum gas does not reduce dependence on fossil fuels. LPG is simply the gases from crude petroleum cooled and compressed to form a liquid.

In some ways it is worse than normal petrol as energy is used to liquify it and it is possibly less efficient in an engine.
Hans Sanders
Kendal, Cumbria

 You suggest we should recycle more of our waste paper and packaging. But what about those who produce the unsolicited material in the first place?

Every day more catalogues and leaflets come through our letterboxes and with every newspaper and magazine. Perhaps pressure should be put on the real culprits - the manufacturers and advertisers - and less on the ordinary consumer.
Mavis Hooper
Midsomer Norton, Somerset

Otherwise climate damage will escalate. This is a man-made catastrophe which we can stop. LPG is simply the gases from crude petroleum cooled and compressed to form a liquid. In some ways it is worse than normal petrol as energy is used to liquify it and it is possibly less efficient in an engine. Hans Sanders Kendal, Cumbria  You suggest we should recycle more of our waste paper and packaging. But what about those who produce the unsolicited material in the first place? Every day more catalogues and leaflets come through our letterboxes and with every newspaper and magazine. Perhaps pressure should be put on the real culprits - the manufacturers and advertisers - and less on the ordinary consumer. Mavis Hooper Midsomer Norton, Somerset

fields.headline: Tough talk on poverty
fields.trailText: I agree with Polly Toynbee that an alliance for children is needed to keep child poverty at the top of the political agenda (Ladders to the good life, November 17). But for her to describe the new alliance as "sounding distinctly spineless" is premature and unkind - for the simple reason that it has not yet been launched.
fields.body:
I agree with Polly Toynbee that an alliance for children is needed to keep child poverty at the top of the political agenda (Ladders to the good life, November 17). But for her to describe the new alliance as "sounding distinctly spineless" is premature and unkind - for the simple reason that it has not yet been launched.

Toynbee writes that the alliance should be "tough, political, savvy and negative". And indeed, it will face an early test of its "savvy": how to explain why a movement for the end of child poverty is being launched after a government has so recently committed itself to ending child poverty.

The government's pledge to end child poverty in 20 years is unambiguous. There is a danger of any new movement failing into a trap: if it fails to generate the same headlines as pensioners and fuel protestors, will the government use this as an excuse to quietly drop its commitment to ending child poverty? Or does that sound too negative?

Children's organisations face a difficult challenge: how to become a sharper critic of government while responding positively to the government's wish to cement relationships between the voluntary, private and statutory sectors.

Toynbee claims that the chancellor has created the children's alliance. This came as a bit of a surprise. The Child Poverty Action Group has a proud history of working with coalitions. However, despite the need for a new campaign, it values its independence. We will have to think long and hard before joining any movement for which ministers seem keen to take the credit.
Martin Barnes
Director, Child Poverty Action Group

 Polly Toynbee helpfully reminds us of a central thesis for this government, that child poverty is fundamental in reproducing social failure. Yet over at the Department for Education and Employment, David Blunkett and his fellow ministers spend a lot of time and energy denying any link between child poverty and educational attainment.

It's high time the government decided as a whole what it really thinks about education and poverty, and stopped delegating this question to the opportunistic pretences of Blunkett and Tony Blair.
Nigel Blake
Byfleet, Surrey

 On Friday the BBC's Children in Need celebrated its 21st anniversary. Yet nowhere in the self-congratulatory hype was it mentioned that there are now three times more children living in poverty than in 1979.
Alan Mathison
Harrow

fields.headline: Away with wasted votes
fields.trailText: Oona King rightly pleads for electoral reform in Britain (Losers win, November 18). One way of doing this might be to enhance, not reduce as she proposes, the status of marginal constituencies.
fields.body:
Oona King rightly pleads for electoral reform in Britain (Losers win, November 18). One way of doing this might be to enhance, not reduce as she proposes, the status of marginal constituencies.

"Safe seats" are a disgrace to our electoral system, for anybody can win these for his or her party. Contrast this to winning a "marginal", which requires hard work and sustained efforts. Why not make the electoral system fairer by paying all MPs according to a sliding scale, with Britain's safest seat being on the lowest and the most marginal being on the highest point on the scale.
Randhir Singh Bains
Gants Hill, Essex
rs_bains@hotmail.com

 Oona King writes that "while the members' tea room at Westminster is full of chortling [at the Gore/Bush debacle], it is not awash with the revolutionary zeal required to 'bring democracy home'." Is our own democracy going to prove to be another of those exportable British games, like soccer, which achieve their heights in far-away lands while self-interested members of parliament here continue to espouse the first-past-the-post system within a nostalgic world of war-lord statuary, sword-lengths and Norman French?
Lesley Abdel
Lamberhurst, Kent

 Oona King is correct to highlight the inadequacies in the electoral system used to elect the House of Commons. The equally unrepresentative and needlessly complex alternative vote plus, however, is not the answer. What is required is some form of proportional representation. King fails to even acknowledge the existence of such systems, making her the very opposite of the "stickler to detail" that she invites us to call her. AV-plus is at best an irrelevance and at worst a hindrance to a substantially better electoral system. The threat to introduce it should be dropped as quickly as possible.
Charles Gilman
Egham,Surrey
charles@gilman-ebr.freeserve.co.uk

 Oona King is right about the inherent unfairness of our electoral system but dead wrong about a way forward. The effect of the "top-up" system she advocates is to allow the party machines to impose on the electorate MPs who have been elected by no one while still offering electors an unnecessarily limited and controlled choice of individuals at the ballot box.

A much superior electoral system, single transferable vote with quota, is available. Under this system the worth of every individual vote is maximised. Electors can make choices between different candidates put up by the same party. They can also choose to support candidates across party lines. It is widely thought that Lord Jenkins rejected the STV solution because he believed it would be unacceptable to the current prime minister. If that is true it was uncharacteristic pusillanimity. This issue is too important for a poor compromise to be acceptable.
Roger Butler
London
reb@popmail.dircon.co.uk

 Oona King simply does not understand that first-past-the-post is democratic. The Labour and Tory parties prop up each other's governments via a tacit understanding. It says: "We both agree that, whatever we say in public, votes in the ballot box are in themselves meaningless. The only thing that counts is seats in the House of Commons and whoever gets a majority of those can do what they like." Anybody who votes Labour or Tory effectively accepts that agreement. And since Labour and Tory between them get well over half the votes cast, the majority accepts the system and so it is democratic.
Frank Desmond
London

fields.headline: Don't blame the fixers of Florida
fields.trailText: Wherever men and women foregather to criticise and castigate the lawyers of America, there am I frequently to be found, throwing in my bon mots and aperçus with the best of them.
fields.body:
Wherever men and women foregather to criticise and castigate the lawyers of America, there am I frequently to be found, throwing in my bon mots and aperçus with the best of them.

I've been known to laugh heartily at the absurdities of the US's litigation culture, profess indignation at lawyers' greed and decry angrily the legal profession's influence over every aspect of American life. But I think that the current wave of anti-lawyerism engendered by the presidential voting crisis is unwarranted, misplaced and based on misunderstanding.

Part of it is tied up with the xenophobic sniggering shown by the British media at America's current problems. Ho, ho, ho, look at the US, claiming to teach the world democracy and it can't even elect its own president. But how is what's been happening there a negation of democracy? On the contrary, it seems that all the processes have been dedicated to making sure that the democratic machinery will continue to work.

All laws that deal with elections, from presidential to local dog catcher, ultimately draw their power from the constitution. What the Americans have been trying to do, faced with an unprecedented event, is to apply fundamental constitutional principles to the new circumstances. That is a wholly admirable, responsible approach.

And who other than the lawyers and judges can unravel the tangle? The Florida situation is not the their fault. Blame, if you will, uncertainty in the laws themselves (politicians passed them), the unbridled political motivation of the Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris's decisions, the creaking electoral college system and the astonishing closeness of the vote. The four have combined to produce uncertainty, none of it of the lawyers' making.

Far from attempting to hijack the democratic process, they have come on the scene to try to restore its sanity. Politicians have created the mess; lawyers are extricating them from it. That's to be praised, not sneered at.

T he revelation last week that a high court judge on circuit, staying one night in judges' lodgings, costs more than Elton John spends in a year (I have paraphrased a little) reminds me of several stories. A judge's wife once told me of her experience visiting her husband at the sumptuous lodgings provided for him. She, an earlier riser than her spouse, wandered downstairs and asked the servant for a cup of tea. I'm afraid that won't be possible, she was told firmly. She was later informed of the rule that no one was allowed to be served before his lordship chose to descend for his breakfast. That rule, I believe, has now gone.

Another judge, wanting to give his wife a lift to the station on the way to the courthouse, was sternly told that this was not done. What would people seeing the judge in his official robes and Rolls think of him if they saw a woman sitting next to him, cadging a lift? So the wife found herself crouching in the back of the car and scrabbling out to catch her train. But at least the judge's dignity and reputation were not besmirched.

Among the sillier rules - still in force - is that judges on circuit have to stay in the lodgings even if they're close to home. London judges missing their wives have been known, like naughty schoolboys, to sneak out of the St Alban's lodgings late at night, making sure to sneak back early in the morning. All in the cause of the dignity of judicial office. And at the taxpayer's expense.

I rarely dream, so I will share this one. There are three of us chatting in a small living room: Liz Hurley, the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, and me. Hurley turns to Lord Woolf and says: "No one takes me seriously. I'm tired of being treated as a second-rate actress. I want people to think of me as a serious judge." That's it.

webTitle: Advertising Association rallies troops to block kids advert ban

fields.headline: Trade body rallies troops to block kids' advert ban
fields.standfirst: Nov 17: 'Ads more influential on kids than parents'
fields.trailText:
8am: The Advertising Association is holding a major international conference this week in a bid to block a ban on children's advertising, writes Jade Garrett.
Nov 17: 'Ads more influential on kids than parents'
fields.body:
The Advertising Association is this week holding a major international conference in a bid to block a ban on advertising to children.

With Christmas just five weeks away and the government voicing concern over ads promoting expensive toys, leading European psychologists and researchers will report from a range of studies on the subject.

Rupert Howell, president of the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising (IPA), said: "What we have to do is separate the fact from the hysteria.

"Why single out advertising? It's a waste of time. The best way to deal with the issue is to have a strong self-regulatory system, not drive it underground."

Delegates at the 'With the Eyes of a Child' conference will include Dr Erling Bjurstrom, associate professor of the National Institute for Working Life in Sweden.

Dr Bjurstrom's work played a key role in persuading the Swedish government to ban all TV advertising to children under 12.

He will be joined by Dr Brian Young of the University of Exeter, a leading authority on children and advertising, and Ingrid Kjordstad of the National Institute for Consumer Research in Norway, an expert on children and internet advertising.

The issue of advertising for children is increasingly making headlines.

Last week, the Chartered Institute of Marketing released research that suggested advertising may have more power over children than their own parents.

The IPA may have its work cut out to prevent a ban in the light of findings that showed 36% of adult consumers in the UK believe that advertising is the biggest influence on children's lives.

The debate was also fuelled by chancellor Gordon Brown's comments yesterday about the damaging effects of TV adverts on poor families who can't afford expensive brand name toys.

Negative PR surrounding children's drink brands like Sunny Delight also do little to help the IPA's cause.

While Sunny Delight has been marketed as a healthy alternative to fizzy drinks, it has a high sugar content and contains only 5% juice.

webTitle: Charlotte Denny: The US consumer is pumping the world dry

fields.headline: How the US consumer is pumping the world dry
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Petrol
Special report: Global warming
fields.trailText: For latter day new agers, the believers in the digital economy, oil is such an old fashioned commodity that it barely rates a mention. In their visions of the future, the economy will run on ideas and computer codes, and somehow escape one of the iron laws of economics: scarcity.
fields.body:
For latter day new agers, the believers in the digital economy, oil is such an old fashioned commodity that it barely rates a mention. In their visions of the future, the economy will run on ideas and computer codes, and somehow escape one of the iron laws of economics: scarcity.

But if the laws of supply and demand have apparently been suspended in the digital world, they are back with a vengeance in the world of energy, as Opec has demonstrated this year. The production cuts that the oil producers' cartel implemented last year have trebled the price of crude, and some economists believe the soaring price of energy will inevitably send the industrialised world into recession.

"The modern world turns on energy; and the biggest provider of that is petroleum," says Professor Andrew Oswald, from the University of Warwick. "I am sceptical when people tell me that Bill Gates and computers have taken over so we don't need to worry about oil stocks any more."

Rather than being the bad guys, though, it is possible that Opec has done the west a good turn this year by putting up the costs of its favourite fuel, even if the price is a painful slump.

We simply cannot afford to consume as much of the stuff as we have been doing. Burning oil is choking the world with carbon dioxide, an important cause of global warning. Second, even without the hand of Opec interfering, oil prices could be about to rise steeply because of dwindling supplies.

The nightmare scenario is outlined by David Fleming in a recent article - After Oil Prospect, November 2000. "The steep decline in the discovery of oil since 1965 means that production, too, must decline, and the turning point is expected in 2005," he writes.

Such gloomy prognoses have been dismissed in the past by analysts, who argue that there are further reserves out there waiting to be discovered.

But Mr Fleming says that many of these new fields are of lower quality than great oil fields which have fuelled world industry since the war and will be more expensive and slower to extract. The turning point will come when demand outstrips supply, sending prices through the roof.

Higher prices will prompt new exploration and make some marginal fields viable. This will only delay the inevitable, according to Mr Fleming. "Within the period 2001-3, the tension between demand and the reduced growth in supply can only be expected to raise the price of oil supplies even further," he says.

Even the relatively conservative International Energy Agency agrees that world oil supply will peak, although it predicts a deadline of 2012.

But its analysis is based on assuming demand grows in line with past trends. An even scarier possibility is raised by Prof Oswald. At present the US, with its 250m consumers, sucks up the largest proportion of world oil - 19m of the 74m barrels the world uses daily. Two-thirds is used for transportation. "Forget software taking over from steel mills," says Mr Oswald. "It is the rise and rise of the motor car and the lorry which is the issue."

At the moment, the average American consumes 25 times the amount of oil used by the average Chinese citizen. China consumes just 4m barrels of oil a day for transport, despite having five times as many people as the US. But what happens when the growing Chinese middle classes trade in their bicycles for cars?

China is about to open its markets and join the World Trade Organisation, a process which involve painful disruptions for many of its citizens, but growing wealth for many others - and the arrival of foreign car firms will provide the opportunity to spend their money.

The country is industrialising rapidly, and while there are only 15m cars in the country now - one for every 125 people - the numbers are rising rapidly.

Prof Oswald says that once China gets the motor car all bets are off. "It's not clear how world oil demand and supply will cope in our children's lives," he says. It is a problem, too, for the politicians gathering at The Hague this week to thrash out an agreement on cuts to carbon dioxide emissions to tackle global warming.

Developing countries such as China were excluded from the agreement outlined three years ago in Kyoto, when industrialised countries agreed to cut emissions back to an average of 5% below 1990 levels over the next decade.

The US is calling on developing nations to shoulder some of the burden of cutting emissions - provoking outrage from their politicians, who point out that it was the west that put most of the carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

The US position is particularly galling because it has not even managed to sell the relatively modest cuts outlined at Kyoto to an American electorate hooked on oil. The US economy has been firing on all cylinders during the past few years, increasing its demand for energy, and it would now have to cut back its emissions by 20% - a target US industry says is impossibly painful.

One stumbling block which should not be allowed to derail an agreement this week is the question of so-called emissions trading - allowing countries to pay other nations to make carbon dioxide cuts on their behalf.

As a price of signing up to the Kyoto protocol, the US wants to be allowed to achieve its emissions cuts through trading or through other flexible measures such as the clean development mechanism, where developed countries pay to clean up carbon dioxide emissions in the developing world, in exchange for a credit towards their own quotas.

The EU is demanding that emissions trading and other such mechanisms account for no more than half a country's cuts. It is irrelevant for global warming where carbon dioxide is produced - and it makes sense to make the cuts where it is cheapest. If US industry can pay a fac tory in another country to clean up its emissions more cheaply, that will soften the economic impact of the cuts.

If the US signs up to a deal this week then American consumers will just have to change their ways, even if industry is able to make deals offshore. The biggest single contributor to global warming is the private car. US negotiators at the Hague recognise these realities, although few are optimistic about a deal being ratified by Congress any time soon. But if the threat of global warming will not persuade Americans to abandon their love affair with the car, perhaps the prospect of a world running out of oil will.

The US has already used more than two-thirds of its own oil reserves and is now dependent on foreign suppliers for half its daily needs. The remaining reserves are concentrated in countries which regard the US with some suspicion, if not downright hostility. The prospect of being over a barrel to the Middle East might be the shock that America and the world needs to put the necessary investment into cleaner technology.

China consumes just 4m barrels of oil a day for transport, despite having five times as many people as the US. But what happens when the growing Chinese middle classes trade in their bicycles for cars? China is about to open its markets and join the World Trade Organisation, a process which involve painful disruptions for many of its citizens, but growing wealth for many others - and the arrival of foreign car firms will provide the opportunity to spend their money. The country is industrialising rapidly, and while there are only 15m cars in the country now - one for every 125 people - the numbers are rising rapidly. Prof Oswald says that once China gets the motor car all bets are off. "It's not clear how world oil demand and supply will cope in our children's lives," he says. It is a problem, too, for the politicians gathering at The Hague this week to thrash out an agreement on cuts to carbon dioxide emissions to tackle global warming. Developing countries such as China were excluded from the agreement outlined three years ago in Kyoto, when industrialised countries agreed to cut emissions back to an average of 5% below 1990 levels over the next decade. The US is calling on developing nations to shoulder some of the burden of cutting emissions - provoking outrage from their politicians, who point out that it was the west that put most of the carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. The US position is particularly galling because it has not even managed to sell the relatively modest cuts outlined at Kyoto to an American electorate hooked on oil. The US economy has been firing on all cylinders during the past few years, increasing its demand for energy, and it would now have to cut back its emissions by 20% - a target US industry says is impossibly painful. One stumbling block which should not be allowed to derail an agreement this week is the question of so-called emissions trading - allowing countries to pay other nations to make carbon dioxide cuts on their behalf. As a price of signing up to the Kyoto protocol, the US wants to be allowed to achieve its emissions cuts through trading or through other flexible measures such as the clean development mechanism, where developed countries pay to clean up carbon dioxide emissions in the developing world, in exchange for a credit towards their own quotas. The EU is demanding that emissions trading and other such mechanisms account for no more than half a country's cuts. It is irrelevant for global warming where carbon dioxide is produced - and it makes sense to make the cuts where it is cheapest. If US industry can pay a fac tory in another country to clean up its emissions more cheaply, that will soften the economic impact of the cuts. If the US signs up to a deal this week then American consumers will just have to change their ways, even if industry is able to make deals offshore. The biggest single contributor to global warming is the private car. US negotiators at the Hague recognise these realities, although few are optimistic about a deal being ratified by Congress any time soon. But if the threat of global warming will not persuade Americans to abandon their love affair with the car, perhaps the prospect of a world running out of oil will. The US has already used more than two-thirds of its own oil reserves and is now dependent on foreign suppliers for half its daily needs. The remaining reserves are concentrated in countries which regard the US with some suspicion, if not downright hostility. The prospect of being over a barrel to the Middle East might be the shock that America and the world needs to put the necessary investment into cleaner technology. charlotte.denny@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: This week: Jesus Christ down at your local, advice from the likes of Jerry Garcia and Ken Kesey, and urban crime-fighting vigilante - Dog-in-A-Box-With-2-Wheels
fields.trailText: This week: Jesus Christ down at your local, advice from the likes of Jerry Garcia and Ken Kesey, and urban crime-fighting vigilante - Dog-in-A-Box-With-2-Wheels
fields.body:
The Sequel
(In-Movies.co.uk)
So this guy walks into a pub. . . and says that he's Jesus Christ. Mark Williams's sweet-and-sour comedy wonders what would happen if Jesus Christ really did pop into your local on Christmas Day. Would it be all aboard for the Second Coming? Or would you want maybe to test him out a bit? Find out how he makes out with his jaundiced flock in this deft and irreverent short.

The Journey
(AtomFilms.com)
A charming if ramshackle documentary account of one man's road trip across the US looking for enlightenment. Slacker Eric Saperstein's dream was to build a bridge between American youth looking to learn, and elders willing to enlighten them. So he chased down, doorstepped and downright pestered famous people as diverse as Jerry Garcia, Henry Winkler, Jimmy Carter, and Ken Kesey, until they came across with some on-camera advice. A feel-good oddity, which scores low on production values but high on barefaced cheek.

Dog in a Box
(Honkworm.com)
Trusty police dog Simon learns the hard way that cigarettes and oxygen tanks don't mix when he loses his back legs in a freak traffic-ticketing accident. Discarded by the police department he gave five years of his life to - "75 if we're talking dog years" - he is reborn as urban crime-fighting vigilante Dog-in-A-Box-With-2-Wheels. Is he tough? As the Dragnet-style narration says, "Don't piss in my chow and tell me it's raining." A slyly retro cartoon, which aims for mainstream chuckles rather than laddish yucks.

webTitle: Comment: Yvonne Roberts on the work-life balance

fields.headline: Noses to the grindstone
fields.standfirst:
According to a new survey, men want to work from home. Women are not so keen - for good reason
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Once upon a time, corporate man cared who had the biggest desk, whether he was allocated a parking space and how often the boss asked him for a drink after (lengthy) office hours. Now, no more. What the majority of male employees apparently hanker after is a small corner of home in which they can do their business alone.
fields.body:
Once upon a time, corporate man cared who had the biggest desk, whether he was allocated a parking space and how often the boss asked him for a drink after (lengthy) office hours. Now, no more. What the majority of male employees apparently hanker after is a small corner of home in which they can do their business alone.

According to the first of a series of studies commissioned by the Department for Education and Employment, Work-Life Balance 2000, published today, a quarter of men already work from home and a further 38% would like to do so. Among women, 16% work from home and a further 33% wish to follow in their footsteps. The survey, which questioned 7,500 employees and 2,500 employers, indicates that only 5% of workers prefer being home-based because of childcare. Most people want to become "more effective" employees.

The survey - part of the government's attempt to encourage us all to "get a life" and therefore also save the billions of pounds now being forked out on ill health and absenteeism - reaffirms that the British, unlike many other Europeans, can't get enough of work. One-fifth of employees put in more than 60 hours a week (23% of them fathers); one-eighth work both Saturday and Sunday; and almost 40% of employees who work extra hours do so without pay.

Part of the reason for this devotion to duty is that Britain is dominated by small and medium-sized businesses, more than half of which employ fewer than 50 workers. If you work alongside the boss, it becomes all that much harder to watch the clock. Another part of the reason is self-preservation and job insecurity. There's not much point in "getting a life" if you then have no money with which to enjoy it.

The "work-life" debate is also not - as the government perhaps inadvertently implies - gender-blind. As Peter Moss of London University points out, it raises yet again "the wicked issues" - the way in which, in the workplace, time, the valuation of care and the importance of production and reproduction have a profoundly different impact on men and women.

It is telling that far fewer women than men in today's DfEE survey wish to work from home. Why? First, because as relative newcomers to the workplace, their confidence is arguably less. A survey published in the summer by Management Today magazine indicated that 79% of working mothers believe that "presenteeism" dominates the culture of work. Families can ruin your career.

In the same survey, 40% of women said there were times when work was a welcome refuge from home - compared with only 33% of men. Why? Because, of course, home means something very different to females than it does to their male partners. Paid work in the home for men may mean precisely that; for women it means dealing with children and domesticity as they have always done but even more so - because they no longer have the office break.

One of the ironies of the work-life balance debate, of course, is that the solution most strongly pushed - flexibility - can, when too narrowly defined, add to the burden of women rather than diminish it. What it should mean, for instance, is term-time and part-time work without forfeiting a career or training opportunities. What it becomes too often, in practice, is working long hours, for less money (if part-time), staggered over unsocial times such as nights and weekends - and an end to job satisfaction. The DfEE's survey tells us that one in five employees works for companies open 24 hours a day .

In Europe, academics such as Eviatur Zerubavel acknowledge that the time squeeze and the creation of a new work-life balance affect women most acutely and that all parts of society have to contribute to the solutions - employers included. For instance, in Holland some companies offer time banks. Employees accrue time, instead of cash bonuses, which they can use when they please (in Britain only 24% of companies offer modest sabbaticals). Since men now also regularly take time off, women are no longer penalised in their careers when, for instance, they go on maternity leave.

According to today's survey, while almost half of employees are likely to be offered stress counselling to cope with the long hours' culture, only 9% are offered assistance with basic childcare needs. The government is loath to press employers to do more - whether on childcare or in creating a different culture. Yet, according to Professor Shirley Dex of Cambridge University, an end to the long-hours culture would cause almost no financial or organisational costs but produce a number of benefits, including retention of staff.

Employers, of course, know the arguments well. Yet until the government gets tougher and male employees more demanding, work-life balance will continue to be viewed as mainly a female employees' "problem" - one for the girls to sort out as best they can.

fields.headline: ENO's cutesy Italian overkill
fields.standfirst:
ENO Triple Bill
London Coliseum
**
fields.trailText:
ENO Triple Bill
London Coliseum
**
fields.body:
English National Opera's Italian Season dispatches the 20th century in a single evening. The entire tradition since Puccini is defined by a trio of one-act works, two of them never meant to be staged at all. One of the results is that Berio, arguably the most important Italian opera composer since Puccini, is represented not by one of his six full-scale theatre works (five of which have yet to be seen fully staged in this country), but by a twee and wholly unnecessary dramatic packaging of his Folksongs, one of the most widely performed of all his concert works.

The musical perfection of Berio's settings, with their endlessly inventive instrumental accompaniments to a joyously polyglot collection of texts and melodies, is swamped here by Neil Armfield's insufferably cutesy production; the singer Susan Parry appears onstage with a trio of children in tow, to whom she addresses the songs - and the raw directness of Berio's settings, which were written for his first wife Cathy Berberian, is totally lost in the process. The whole thing is too genteel, too comfortable. Sadly it sets the tone for the whole programme.

Furthermore, the choice of Nina Rota's film music for Fellini's La Strada to form the centrepiece of the programme is plain mystifying. Armfield turns this episodic and trivial score into wordless children's street theatre, which is part Lord of the Flies, part Billy Elliott. Though ENO doubtless gains lots of Brownie points by being able to involve its outreach organisation, The Baylis Programme, in the show, the result is never remotely interesting or even diverting, just the waste of a precious slot in this otherwise so enterprising and intelligent series.

At least Dallapiccola's The Prisoner, a bleak one-acter conceived during the second world war and finished soon after, deserves to be in the season on merit, and musically at least ENO gives it the kind of committed and expert performance its compassion and carefully focused outrage deserves. Both Susan Bullock, as the Mother of the incarcerated man, and Peter Coleman-Wright, as the Prisoner himself, give compelling, commanding performances, while Richard Hickox makes sure the playing is always taut and full of tightly controlled anguish.

It is a work, too, that visually fits exactly into Stefanos Lazaridis's Italian Season environment, but Armfield allows the sentimentality that runs through the whole evening to invade the end of The Prisoner, too. A uniformed troupe of children - Hitler Youth? Woodcraft Folk? - march onto the stage carrying bonsai trees, and, at the final curtain, after the Prisoner has been led away to his death, a boy is seen falteringly climbing a ladder. The ending of this opera is so uncompromising that any kind of extra dramatic imagery is unnecessary. Certainly, mawkish imagery of this kind is entirely out of place. Had the first half of the evening not been so consis tently soft-centred, though, it might not have seemed quite as important.

 In repertory until December 13. Box office: 020-7632 8300.

webTitle: How big banks pocket millions from the online rip-off

fields.headline: How big banks pocket millions from the online rip-off
fields.standfirst: Customers lured from high street branches to internet accounts pay the price through low interest rates
fields.trailText: Customers lured from high street branches to internet accounts pay the price through low interest rates.
fields.body:
The big banks are ripping off their customers by more than £80m a year by luring them away from branches and on to the internet.

According to new research, the major banks are saving millions by paying tiny rates of interest to their internet customers even though they cost them a fraction of those using branches.

On average the "big four" - HSBC, Lloyds TSB, NatWest and Barclays - are paying 0.1% rates on current account balances while specialist online banks are offering up to 40 times higher rates of interest.

The big four have an 80% share of the current account market and, according to new research, are cashing in on customer inertia. While statistics show current account customers are more likely to divorce than move to a new bank, they do appear to be increasingly prepared to move to their existing bank's internet site.

However, the Halifax believes this inertia is costing the 2.5m online current account customers of the big four interest payments of £85m a year. And, as the number of internet customers grows, the banks will benefit even more.

The situation has already attracted government attention and in the coming days the Department of Trade and Industry is expected to publish the findings of a survey as to why bank customers are so reluctant to take their business elsewhere.

The banks have been instructed to make it easier for customers to move their accounts by sharing direct debit details, and banks which have traditionally been bigger players in the mortgage market, such as Halifax, Abbey National and Alliance & Leicester, are aiming to benefit by offering more attractive products than the big four.

As yet, despite the pledge to make it easier for customers to move accounts, there is little evidence that customers are moving their current accounts from the big four.

Last week, though, the Nationwide building society, usually more associated with mortgages and savings, claimed to be taking a 5% share of all new current accounts, many of which were for its internet banking.

This appears to be an isolated case. Most of the movement in savings is away from the established accounts of the big four and towards their internet offshoots. Privately, bankers admit this is to their advantage as these accounts are cheaper for them to run. This is backed by consultants Booz, Allen & Hamilton. They calculate that online transactions cost less than 1% of those in branches. Barclays have closed more than 160 of its branches this year alone.

Big push

Barclays is one of the banks which is making a big push for internet customers. It now claims to be the country's biggest internet bank with more than 1.5m customers and is advertising its online business in a campaign fronted by Scottish comedian Robbie Coltrane, who boasts customers can now be their own bank managers by using the net.

Yet, according to the Halifax, customers miss out as a result. David Walkden, general manager of Halifax Online, said: "Millions of people are becoming their own bank managers on the phone and on the net but are not getting anything extra for doing so.".

Halifax, which has only 2m current accounts in comparison with Barclays' 8m, intends to pay 4% interest on current accounts from next year so long as £1,000 is paid in each month. It plans to pay it to online, phone and branch customers and has pledged to set a "crack switching team" on changing customers' direct debits.

It is too soon to know whether Halifax's attempt to win customers by paying interest rates will bear fruit as it it will not start paying the rate until next year. However, if customers can be enticed to open new current accounts, Halifax calculates that the 2.5m online customers of the big four could receive a combined interest payment of £85m a year by taking up its 4% offer.

The "big four" argued yesterday that they do not offer their online customers better rates because they are still able to use branches and the telephone.

A spokesman for NatWest, which is now owned by Royal Bank of Scotland, said: "Our philosophy is to have one current account and for customers to choose how to access us".

New brand

This was view echoed by the other high street banks. Lloyds TSB said: "Remember, no one is being forced to use the internet".

Lloyds TSB said, however, that it would be offering more attractive rates through its new internet bank, to be known as evolve.com, after it is launched later this year.

This route, of setting up a separate brand for the internet, has also been chosen by other banks. For instance, the 0.5m online customers of Abbey National are paid very little interest while the 45,000 customers of its new Cahoot internet bank can expect payments of up to 7.1%.

Yet, even Halifax is setting up a telephone and online operation under a new brand which will offer better rates to customers. The Intelligent Finance unit, advertised to the tunes of Fatboy Slim and currently dogged by technical difficulties, will pay 5% on current accounts, even more than a Halifax-branded account.

webTitle: Without the right outfit, no job

fields.headline: Suits you at interview
fields.standfirst:
No job, no money for clothes. Without the right outfit, no job. As the founder of a US scheme to help women make a fresh start arrives in the UK, Ian Boughton looks at copycat ventures

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: No job, no money for clothes. Without the right outfit, no job. As the founder of a US scheme to help women make a fresh start arrives in the UK, Ian Boughton looks at copycat ventures.
fields.body:
Poppy Max spent his first night in America sleeping under Brooklyn Bridge. And the next night, and then the next two weeks as well, until he finally got started in the rag trade, peddling clothes out of a hand-cart.

Today, when his great-granddaughter Nancy Lublin zips up her suitcase for the flight to London, she follows Poppy Max's own path. He never forgot the other guys under the bridge - when he'd got on his feet, there would always be clothes for the others who still had nothing.

So, when Poppy Max died in 1996 and left Lublin $5,000 (£3,500), she decided to found a non-profit, self-help organisation for women wanting to make a new start. How can you pull yourself up by your bootstraps if you don't have boots, she argued - if a woman doesn't have a job, she can't afford clothes; but without the right clothes, she won't get the job.

Four years later, Dress for Success has suited 40,000 women for their new starts across 60 American cities, Canada, and New Zealand. Her most recent project in London has already clothed 300 clients for interviews.

And as she arrives in the UK today to discuss how British office workers can contribute through her workplace "suit drives", Lublin is politely curious about recent publicity for the new Ready2Work initiative. Reed in Partnership has started a similar scheme to that practised by Dress for Success, but grabbed the headlines by inviting celebrities to donate unwanted clothes for use by job-hunting women.

Liz Hurley, Cherie Blair, Geri Halliwell, Ali MacGraw and Glenys Kinnock were among the first donors, and the reaction was diverse. On the one hand, there was approval for the celebs, whose generosity was followed in sprightly fashion by chain stores making donations in bulk. In contrast, there was a certain cattiness over whether a Liz Hurley outfit would give the right or wrong impression at an interview - and questions about what the jobhunter would wear on Day 2 if she got the job. There was even some quite uncharitable discussion of the celebrities' own taste in what they wore and gave.

"Yeah, an English ex-boyfriend just phoned to tell me that he read about this in the papers there," says Lublin. "I guess somebody copying our idea is a high form of flattery. On the other hand, I'd be pretty disgusted if the original idea just turned into big headlines about fancy suits from flashy women.

"This isn't about 'ladies who lunch' sprinkling love and charity on the poor. The Dress for Success thing is about working women helping other working women - how a woman with a job and kids will take time to pull three suits from her closet just so that three other women can feel confident and make a great first impression at a job interview.

"I have never solicited celebrity suits," she adds. "We get them, but they go right on the rack next to the others, because our focus isn't on who the suits came from - it is on who they are going to."

While the American operation is strictly non-profit, Reed in Partner ship sprang from the holding company's employment division, set up in 1998 to bid for the government's welfare-to-work schemes that were put out to the private sector. It now runs four New Deal schemes and four Employment Zones, in London, Liverpool and Darlington.

Before the celebrity donations idea was born, Reed originally put its own money into buying clothes to help jobseekers. Now there is a target of 200 star-given outfits, with bulk donations from House of Fraser, Whistles and Etam, plus support and storage provided by Susannah Constantine and Trinny Woodall at their Ready2Shop business. It's estimated that 200 job-seeking women will be helped this year alone.

By contrast, the American operation remains relatively homespun in approach. "When I first got the idea, I reached out to three nuns in Spanish Harlem to help me start it - which was a little weird for a Jewish kid - but I knew that these women had great experience in the community," Lublin explains. "They would refer clients to us, and we still operate this way: only there are now 143 member agencies here in New York sending clients.

"We don't ever scrutinize the clients - instead, we carefully select member agencies who send them to us. Our sister programmes who dress the clients are run by passionate and smart people who have dedicated long hours to work for women in their community. Some have even quit jobs to do it."

Dress for Success equips its clients with one suit of clothes for the interview, perhaps with a smart handbag, or an overcoat in winter, and then gives successful job-winners a second outfit to see them through their first week in work. But what is the ideal interview suit?

Ready2Work has stoically put up with taunts about its clients turning up for interviews in stars' party frocks. In fact, those running the scheme explained quite clearly to the celebrities that jobseekers were going for a range of jobs, and would require practical suits or smart separates. The celebs who donated were asked to include a personal message of support for the career hopefuls - and a note of thanks from the jobseeker can be passed back to the celebrity.

Lublin sympathises with the cheap laughs that the star strategy drew, but has no such problems with unsuitable clothes. "To me, an interview suit is just like soccer kit - you can't compete unless you are dressed the appropriate way. We're trying to give women suits so appropriate that their clothing doesn't matter. That means when you are dressed appropriately, then the interviewer will pay attention to your skills and your character, not to what you're wearing. I think the perfect interview outfit is something that the interviewer themselves would wear."

Instead of approaching the stars, Lublin and her British team are about to target working women here, particularly those in large companies, with the introduction of two of her favourite American promotions: "Clear your Closet Week" and "suit drives".

"Oh, we love suit drives," she says. "We encourage offices to set up collection sites for women to bring in clean, contemporary, almost-new suits. It's a great way for busy working women to contribute to the community. Goldman Sachs hosted one in London a couple of weeks ago."

That, says Lublin, was an object lesson in corporate goodwill. Goldman Sachs took over the entire organisation of the project, and cleverly ran it across three days - because people always forget to bring things in "on the day". The result was 200 suits offered by working women to their direct out-of-work contemporaries.

It was also, says Lublin, a demonstration of the co-operative principle. "These suits aren't handouts - each suit is one woman's token of faith in another woman's ability to succeed."

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 12. Voicemail
fields.body:
12. Voicemail

Remember the days before voicemail? When real people answered the phone and companies didn't sound like shopping malls, with soothing music and automated voices? And when "Press one for . . ." wasn't part of our cultural tapestry?

OK, take those rose-tinted specs off right now. Think back. How often were you unable to get through to a company? When you eventually got through to a department, did anyone pick up the phone? And what about those messages left with unwilling colleagues, which you knew would never be delivered? Whatever your take on voicemail, it's here for a while, and you can at least help your contacts by being a good messager.

* Think. Do you need to leave a message at all? If it's complex, would it be better to try later, or maybe send an email or fax instead?

*If you do use the voicemail, give some thought to your message before you start. Avoid burbling, repeating yourself, and then being cut off because you rambled on for too long. It doesn't sound very professional.

*Always give your name ("Hi, it's me again" isn't helpful unless it's a friend) and leave the date and time of your call. Also, suggest the best time for them to ring back. Don't get caught in the voicemail ping-pong game.

* Explain what you want, briefly. Yours may be one of 25 voicemail messages, and only the clearly understood ones will elicit a response. If the call is your first contact with the person, simply saying, "Hi, it's Samantha Green on 020 7777 7777, please call me back" virtually guarantees that the listener will hit "delete".

*Leave your phone number at the end of the message. It saves the listener rewinding to pick it up. Say the number slowly, too. If you write it as you say it, you'll get the speed right.

*Change your own voicemail message whenever relevant. Saying you'll be out until the 17th to someone calling on the 24th gives a bad impression. Make the message welcoming and give callers the hope that you really might get back to them as soon as you're back at your desk.

*Check your voicemail regularly. Urgent calls need a quick response, otherwise the caller may begin faxing, emailing, ringing your colleagues, and leaving messages on your mobile.

*Finally, look on the bright side. At least your voicemail legitimately allows you an hour's peace now and again.

 Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

fields.headline: No G-strings for Tom The Voice
fields.standfirst:
Tom Jones
Clyde Auditorium, Glasgow
***
fields.trailText:
Tom Jones
Clyde Auditorium, Glasgow
***
fields.body:
The knickers began flying through the air even before Tom The Voice appeared on stage. Mainly white and oddly sensible they were - hardly a G-string in their midst. Ladies at the back passed them forward, row by row, cheering as they reached the front. A chap collected them, taking them backstage with a resigned air. There must be a knicker mountain somewhere in the land after a sell-out Tom Jones tour.

Sometimes, of course, Tom handed them back like a prize, having mopped his sweaty, perma-tanned brow or medallioned hairy chest with them first. This only came later, well into the second half of a show that, for all the flying pants, began in perfunctory, slightly muted fashion, but built up into a big flirty party night.

What Tom likes doing best these days, apart from gyrating and rubbing his crotch, are thumpingly funky versions of tracks such as She's Got It, If I Only Knew, You Can Leave Your Hat On and Kiss - even though the real crowd-pleasers are his crooning glories: Green Green Grass of Home, Delilah, and It's Not Unusual. Even the golden oldies are now imbued with lashings of sauce. During What's New Pussycat?, Tom licked his lips, crushed panties in his big, big hands and sniffed his fingers.

As a sex symbol, Tom cuts a surreal figure. In sombre, well-cut suits, he dances like an older relative at a wedding except that when he lifts a leg and waggles his behind, the gesture is greeted with deafening whoops. But the weirdest thing is that his face has been so thoroughly lifted that not a line, not a wrinkle graces it. This means he doesn't look his 60 years; in fact, he doesn't look any age. There is no expressive quality to his face other than from his eyes - and he flirted with the audience by opening them wide, bulging them out from the uncreased landscape they sit in. It didn't exactly have me reaching for my smalls.

Musically, there are several challenges for Tom, all of which he meets with relish. He blends old and new, his own songs and covers (including an unlikely contender, Macy Gray's Sex-O-Matic Venus Freak), with plenty of offerings from Reload, his album of duets. Sex Bomb, sounding even more like Sex Bum live, has him in a 360-degree spin of gyration, jumping on the spot, clenched fists in the air.

He does what he can to cover up for the absence of his famous singing partners, relying on The Voice alone to get him through INXS's Never Tear Us Apart and Elvis Presley's You're Right, I'm Left, She's Gone. One of his very slinky backing singers helps out on Burning Down the House and You Need Love Like I Do. But you can't help missing the guest vocalists, so the brief appearance of Kelly Jones of the Stereophonics, for Mamma Told Me Not To Come, was especially welcome. He didn't look comfortable, though - he sneaked a peek out, saw a tide of undies, and sang looking at Tom or with his back to the crowd.

Tom is so used to the response, he takes it all in his stride, grinning. He was not at ease with himself, though. His shirt collar was bothering him in the second half - he kept tugging at it mid-song - and he so hates the fact that he sweats that he had a special gesture for dealing with it. Wiping waves of it off (when there were no knickers available) with a flick of his hand, he sends the sweat away with a curt movement, trying to make it sexy - and failing.

He does the super-sexy routine compulsively through the evening, even wiggling a long, suggestive bit of his belt for his Full Monty song. The audience - as if out on a big, wild hen night - lap this all up, egging him on. One woman stands at the front, alone in her good behaviour. She has a Welsh dolly in her hand; she makes it dance for Tom during the encores. In a sea of saucy laciness by this point, he doesn't even notice.

 Touring nationally.

fields.headline: Corporate R&B in tin-foil hotpants
fields.standfirst:
Destiny's Child
London Arena
***
fields.trailText:
Destiny's Child
London Arena
***
fields.body:
There's something Orwellian about Destiny's Child, the Houston R&B act who have outsold every other female group this year through a combination of razor-sharp tunes and shiny showmanship. Of the four girls pictured on the sleeve of their 1999 album, The Writing's on the Wall, only two - Beyonce Knowles and Kelly Rowland - have made it as far as London Arena. La Tavia Roberson and Le Toya Luckett have "parted ways", along with recent recruit Farrah Franklin, leaving just Knowles, Rowland and a (presumably nervous) new girl, Michelle Williams.

But the Destiny show steams along regardless. Theirs is the sort of corporate R&B where no single personality predominates. As long as the hits sound just like the records, the crowd wouldn't have cared if it had been three complete strangers on stage. Which in effect it was, for despite effusive introductions ("And now I want you to meet a true angel - give it up for Miss Beyonce!"), by the end of their short set, you were none the wiser about what makes Destiny's Child tick. Do these pristine sirens have any unholy passions? Biscuit crumbs in bed, perhaps?

What did emerge from this slick, pacey show was that blonde-ringleted Knowles carries the most musical weight. She's Tina Turner to the other two's Ikettes, leading the staccato chorus to Bills, Bills, Bills and sinuously bending notes on Say My Name (whose poignant query "You ain't calling me baby, why the sudden change?" aches like prime Joni Mitchell).

She effortlessly prevailed on the obligatory acoustic gospel number, her finale drowning out the others. Did someone say solo career? Rowland, who had broken two toes and was forced to sing perched on a stool, must have been fuming.

In the meantime, though, Knowles is still one of three and they play by the R&B rules. The show was textbook stuff, from the beefcakey boy dancers to the four costume changes, which included tinfoil hotpants and diaphanous harem-girl skirts. There was an image to suit every male fantasy, although the band themselves are strangely sexless, as if the effort of singing about cheating boyfriends leaves them too depleted to actually have any of their own.

They did the ancient time-filler: "Which side of the audience can make the most noise?" They reminded us that the new single Independent Women - from the Charlie's Angels soundtrack - is in the shops. And, of course, they enthused: "You guys in (long pause) London are one of the best audiences we've ever had."

You knew very well that they had wooed Manchester with the same line the night before and would do it in Birmingham the next night. But for some reason - probably sheer musical quality - you liked them anyway.

fields.headline: Can you keep a secret?
fields.standfirst: Almost certainly not, says Judi James. And neither can your colleagues
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Almost certainly not, says Judi James. And neither can your colleagues.
fields.body:
Isn't it just lovely to discover you're not the only one with a hideous personality flaw? Just when we were in danger of turning into a nation of politically-correct, moralising, brown-nosing teachers' pets, up comes a new survey to prove we are all every bit as devious, two-faced, unprincipled and downright underhand at work as I'd expected.

Blabbing is the name of the game. Remember those tasty personal secrets you've been confiding to trusted work colleagues on a reasonably regular basis, safe in the knowledge that all the lurid details of your health and sex life will go no further than the one or two pair of ears you whispered into?

Well forget it. According to new statistics from Office Angels you would have done better in terms of security if you'd plastered your intimate details on the world-wide web. For not only do 77% of office workers find it impossible to keep a secret, evidently, but they'll have told at least two other people within the same working day.

Big communal sigh of relief, then. It's not just me who can't keep her mouth buttoned. It's not that we mean to be disloyal, is it? It's just that personal secrets and work gossip are only worth listening to if you can then spread them around.

And you needn't get all whey-faced with moral indignation if you're the one being betrayed. You would never have told in the first place if the secret was that sacred. The minute you uttered the words: "Don't tell anyone else, but..." you must have known that half the room were already alerting the neon light man at Piccadilly Circus to be on the ready for breaking news.

If you really want to confide in private then see a priest or a psychiatrist Or phone a friend outside your workplace who will only broadcast it about her own office, rather than yours. Because gossip is what makes the world of work go around. It is the only form of business communication that actually works, and works wonderfully well, to boot. I do try to be discreet, honestly. We all do, don't we? But then we meet up with this huge predicament. One of our colleagues is taking us to one side and implying there is some great secret in his/her life that we would give a right arm and two kidneys to hear. All we have to do to be privy to this astounding, mind-boggling, life-changing piece of gossip is to swear it will go no further. The choice is obvious - either be honest and say that their secret has as much chance of being safe with you as a muddy football in the hands of an England goalie, or lie. They have already played the secret up to a point where the drool of anticipation is running down your chest. So what would you do?

I tell all for two reasons: either the so-called secret is so dull that I forget I had sworn on my first-born's life not to blab (Always a good wheeze, as I have no kids), or it is of such national interest that keeping it to myself would be borderline illegal.

According to the survey, other reasons for leaking all include:

 Craving the attention associated with revealing information

 Using the knowledge as a means to demonstrate power

 Breaking the confidence with the aim of helping the situation Or:
 Revealing it by accident

Of course the disgusting downside of all this harmful fun comes when the excrement hits the fan and the blabbermouth is unmasked. Whistle-blowing is - it seems - also rife. The Office Angels statistic has it that as many as 67% of the original blabees discover their secret has been passed around for all to enjoy. Simple and innocently trusting folk though they must - by definition - be, it can only be a matter of a few nano-seconds for them to guess who spilled the beans.

And last of all: never gossip yourself. If you feel a need for total tale security, make sure you are never the one either indulging in or listening to all the updated gossip. Remember the golden rule of all office gossip: What goes around comes around.

fields.headline: From zoo to Yahoo
fields.standfirst:
Karen Harding has dealt with defecating bats, the US army and the Emperor of Japan. Now she has to deal with a young dot.com crowd, she tells Dolly Dhingra.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Karen Harding has dealt with defecating bats, the US army and the Emperor of Japan. Now she has to deal with a young dot.com crowd.
fields.body:
Karen Harding has been the PA to Martina King, managing director of Yahoo! UK and Ireland, for just over a year. Based in South Kensington, Yahoo's staff is very young. Harding, at 41, is the eldest and says she doesn't have a problem with it - which doesn't stop the frequent references to it. "They are so young, it's untrue, it's like they are babies. I'm the oldest - so many of them are in their early 20s. I bring something to Yahoo that the rest don't have," she says. "I've been around for a long time - a lot of things PAs do, I do very easily. There's no substitute for experience and that's a pain for most people, but it's true."

Yahoo itself is a very young company; in just four years it has become a household name. The brainchild of two American students, David Filo and Jerry Yang, it began from their college campus and garden shed as a directory for sumo wrestlers. Yahoo has since grown internationally to become one of the most popular search engines on the world wide web.

Harding says she is definitely not a technophile, but enjoys and appreciates the uses of computers. "I'm not a boffin - I wouldn't know what to do with a computer program if it bit me in the arse." Her duties include the regular secretarial tasks, but one of her major concerns is to ensure that her boss never gets snowed under. "I look after her schedule and make sure she gets where she needs to be. I don't always get a chance to sit with her everyday. I keep an eye on her schedule and make sure she has enough DND [do not disturb] sessions so that she can get her head down and do the work that she needs to. Sometimes she's out so much that I don't get to sit with her for three or four days.

"Martina is quite a media celebrity. We get thousands of emails asking to interview her. She's always on the radio: a lot of people want to get her opinion on things," she says. But keeping up with a dynamic boss rarely fazes Harding. Over the years she has had a colourful employment history. She landed her first job in Frankfurt, Germany, working as a PA in the American army when she ran out of money while travelling after graduating from St Martin's School of Art.

What happened to the art? "Reality slapped me very hard at a very early age, and I quickly learnt that reality meant I had to earn a living," she says. "I know I'm supposed to say how great it is being a secretary, but it wasn't the plan. I learnt to type so that I would have something to fall back on."

But there have been good times: she seems to have enjoyed her time as PA at the Zoological Society of London, where she organised events, conferences and exhibitions. Much of her time was spent dealing with VIPs, including the likes of Lady Thatcher and Ken Livingstone. Her greatest achievement was arranging the visit of His Imperial Majesty the Emperor of Japan. You can almost hear the drum roll.

"It was just such a huge operation. The Japanese don't think of him as a god anymore but his status is still huge. For security purposes you won't get one or two people checking things out, you'll get four or five - and then you'll get another 10 after them, just to make sure. It was my biggest challenge because the Japanese culture is such a precise culture and we had to get all the formalities right."

Moving from London Zoo, where other experiences ranged from having a boa constrictor wrapped around her neck to a room full of bats defecating on her head, into an office took some adjusting to. "Yahoo is the fastest paced office I've ever worked in. I sit next to the sales section and it's very noisy, people are on the phone all day every day. But we have got quieter sections: the producers who design the pages usually work with headphones on so that they can concentrate. Then we've got the engineers who are really focused - they're about the most techie people you can get, and down there you can hear a pin drop," she says.

Being the eldest in the team, staff consider her a comforting figure. "A lot of them call me matron! I'm like a nanny, I'm very tactile. I like giving people hugs and kisses, and people can talk to me and have a chat. And I always make sure that everyone gets a birthday cake and a card."

fields.headline: The inside track: Share options
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: After the great excitement this spring, shareholder enthusiasm for dot.coms has waned a little. But many people are still eager to work for them. Secretarial consultancies report that many of the more staid institutions are having difficulty recruiting because of competition from hi-tech companies.
fields.body:
After the great excitement this spring, shareholder enthusiasm for dot.coms has waned a little. But many people are still eager to work for them. Secretarial consultancies report that many of the more staid institutions are having difficulty recruiting because of competition from hi-tech companies.

In the past, being a big name was an incentive for recruiting support staff. Everyone likes to be part of a success story. Now, the dot.com revolution has made secretaries more adventurous in who they work for.

Share options have become synonymous with the dot.com industry, although in practice they are not confined to it. A couple of years ago, rumours buzzed around of the massive profits Jupiter Asset Management employees made when they became eligible to cash in their options. There was talk of secretaries becoming millionaires (Jupiter refused to comment).

The way the system works is that employees take options to buy shares in the company in exchange for working below the market rate. The best known example is Microsoft. Anyone who took a tranche of options 10 years ago in exchange for a bit of overtime is probably now a millionaire.

In his pre-budget statement 10 days ago, Gordon Brown relaxed the rules over share options to encourage the practice to become more widespread. In the spring, the chan cellor had granted smaller companies the right to issue share options free of national insurance and capital gains tax when they are cashed in. But the scheme was limited to 15 employees allowed up to £100,000 in options each. The hi-tech industry complained that 15 was too few, so the chancellor has promised to rethink, with the likely result that the total will stay the same (ie, 15 x £100,000 = £1.5m) but the tax-free incentives can be shared among any number of employees.

But, as in all share dealing, there is an element of risk. Even shares that you've been handed for next to nothing can collapse in price, leaving you with nothing but a load of novelty wallpaper for all your hard work.

fields.headline: WPM
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: * WPM, snowed under by invites to festive parties as she is, is grateful for any advice she can find on how to behave herself at them. So some "top tips" from communications consultancy The Aziz Corporation on making it through the office party season proved timely. Unfortunately, the handy hints - sensible though they undoubtedly are - don't correspond to WPM's memories (hazy, admittedly) of the ghosts of Christmas parties past.
fields.body:
* WPM, snowed under by invites to festive parties as she is, is grateful for any advice she can find on how to behave herself at them. So some "top tips" from communications consultancy The Aziz Corporation on making it through the office party season proved timely. Unfortunately, the handy hints - sensible though they undoubtedly are - don't correspond to WPM's memories (hazy, admittedly) of the ghosts of Christmas parties past.

The first piece of advice, for example, suggests that it's best to keep one arm free to shake hands, which leaves WPM wondering exactly how she is expected to juggle her glass of Chardonnay and a plateful of mini goat's cheese en crote in the other without running the risk of spilling one or both over the recipient of said handshake.

And another thing: an amusing anecdote can be just the thing to break the ice with strangers, it says. WPM is not entirely sure, however, that her "a funny thing happened on the way to the party" tales wouldn't descend into wails of commuting misery.

Your companion's body language is, as the Aziz Corporation wisely points out, an excellent indicator of how scintillating your conversation is proving. If he or she starts looking over your shoulder to scout the room for more interesting - or coherent - colleagues, you know you're in trouble. No word, though, on whether staring intently at your cleavage (well, it is Christmas) is good or bad.

One piece of advice that WPM will certainly be taking to heart, or maybe inking onto her free arm, is the "40-second soundbite" on who she is and what the hell she's doing at this party. Handy for blather-free introductions, sure, but handier still for those late-in-the-evening moments when all memories of your own name have deserted you. Oh, hang on - top tip number 10: don't drink too much. Ah.

*Glad to hear that Marks & Spencer's chairman and directors have decided to take to the shop floors during the run-up to Christmas. Pitching in with the packing, stacking and wrapping is fairly standard for the big cheeses at many retailers, including Tesco, but this is the first time that M&S bosses will have joined workers at the tills. "The staff in the stores will tell us what they want us to do," explained marketing director Alan McWalter. Now, now staff - be kind. WPM does wonder, though, whether the bosses will return with such goodwill in the New Year to welcome back all those Christmas shoppers armed with receipts and unwanted presents . . .

*Way back in August, Office Hours lamented the depressing state of Britain's workplaces. A potplant here and there is all very well, we moaned, but what about some real change. The Canon Campaign for Better Offices was thinking along the same lines and last week unveiled the winner of its competition to revamp a tired workspace. The Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy in Edinburgh will receive a facelift over the coming weeks and WPM can only assume - without wishing to sound too disparaging about the exising decor - that it thoroughly deserved it. And not a Laurence Llewellyn-Bowen in sight.

*An apology. Last week, this column encouraged readers to contact the House of Commons employment select committee with their views on age discrimination in the workplace. Unfortunately, WPM then made it as difficult as possible for you to do so, by printing the wrong email address to contact. Sorry about that. For those of you who are still keen - and you've got until January to concoct your submission - the correct address is mulleyj@parliament.uk. Honestly. You can check out what the investigation aims to cover by looking at www.parliament.uk/ commons/selcom/edepnt45.htm

*And while you're at it, you could take a quick peek at www.workplaceviolence.co.uk, a new site from conflict management specialists Maybo, the CBI and other interested bodies. It aims to provide a platform for employers and their staff to share advice and experiences, and in turn the site offers research and ideas on how to deal with this increasingly prevalent problem (local government workers and front-line reception staff are often targets). The site's in its early stages, so be patient and expect more information to appear over the next few weeks or so.
