fields.headline: Overly personal assistance
fields.standfirst:
Wanted: good all-rounder, willing to babysit, shop for groceries and lie about the boss's whereabouts. Admin skills an advantage. Kate Hilpern on the role of the PA.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Wanted: good all-rounder, willing to babysit, shop for groceries and lie about the boss's whereabouts. Admin skills an advantage.
fields.body:
Does your role as personal assistant stretch further than you bargained for? Join the club. One in five PAs are asked to cover up for the boss's long, boozy lunches. One in 10 is expected to lie to the manager's partner about his or her whereabouts. And one in 20 babysits the boss's kids.

The research, carried out for career website Fish4Jobs.co.uk, also found that a significant number of secretaries are expected to do grocery shopping for their bosses, while others buy and wrap gifts for the boss's partner - and sometimes their lover as well.

"Clearly the role of the modern secretary is moving beyond the professional support role into the private lives of their bosses," says Rayne Roberts, publisher of Fish4Jobs.

But Alison Eldridge, researcher into gender roles at work, claims there's nothing new about the put-upon PA. "We're witnessing a return to aspects of the PA's role in the dark ages - or at least the 1950s - when she was an 'extra wife' to the boss," she says. "My own research shows this, for it found that male secretaries are far less likely, if ever, to be asked to run humiliating errands, while their female counterparts are asked on a regular basis."

Virginia Richie, 29, a PA in a West End legal firm, is one such woman. "Among the things I've had to go out and buy for my boss are fresh breath spray, corn-plasters, and ointment for his haemorrhoids. And among the things I've been asked to do for him is look after his five-year-old daughter and her schoolfriend for an afternoon. My boss's wife had dropped them off, and my boss said he had to go to a meeting."

The chief reason that many PAs feel they're a wife, mother, nursemaid, diplomat and personal shopper all in one is, according to Eldridge, ironic. "Since the level of responsibility has increased for PAs, so has the level at which managers depend on them."

Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, believes technology and flexible working practices are also accountable. "PAs increasingly own mobile phones and laptops and are available far more than they used to be. As a result, managers can, and do, contact their support staff at home, in the theatre or restaurant, in bed, or even abroad on holiday. This blurs the distinction between professional and private in both the PA's and the boss's job."

Even temps now tend to have mobile phones on which their bosses can reach them, says Gill Stewart, director of recruitment consultancy Tate Appointments.

But you're still most likely to be asked to do things outside your remit if you have a male boss, confirms Sarah El Doori of recruitment agency Office Angels. "I can remember one incident of a PA being sent out by her male boss to buy toupee tapes - sticky pads that hold a hairpiece in place," she laughs. Age is also relevant, she says. "It's my experience that the older the boss and the older the PA, the more likely it is that your role will extend into the personal."

Jo Ashby, a 47-year-old secretary for a health insurance company in Berkshire, agrees. "My boss, who's 59, thinks nothing of telling me to lie to his wife when he's out to lunch with his mistress. I know both women and he's quite happy with that."

So what's the point at which to say "enough"? "When it starts to get you down or you begin to put yourself at risk - whichever comes first," says June Smith, an occupational health worker.

Ruth Marks, a 28-year-old PA in a doctors' surgery in Northamptonshire, is among the many respondents to Fish4Jobs' research who admits to resenting the embarrassment her boss's requirements can cause. "Once, his wife called to speak to him. He told me to say he was out, and she simply replied, 'That's funny. I'm outside in the car and can see him'. She forgave him, but has never been pleasant to me again."

fields.bodyText: Does your role as personal assistant stretch further than you bargained for? Join the club. One in five PAs are asked to cover up for the boss's long, boozy lunches. One in 10 is expected to lie to the manager's partner about his or her whereabouts. And one in 20 babysits the boss's kids. The research, carried out for career website Fish4Jobs.co.uk, also found that a significant number of secretaries are expected to do grocery shopping for their bosses, while others buy and wrap gifts for the boss's partner - and sometimes their lover as well. "Clearly the role of the modern secretary is moving beyond the professional support role into the private lives of their bosses," says Rayne Roberts, publisher of Fish4Jobs. But Alison Eldridge, researcher into gender roles at work, claims there's nothing new about the put-upon PA. "We're witnessing a return to aspects of the PA's role in the dark ages - or at least the 1950s - when she was an 'extra wife' to the boss," she says. "My own research shows this, for it found that male secretaries are far less likely, if ever, to be asked to run humiliating errands, while their female counterparts are asked on a regular basis." Virginia Richie, 29, a PA in a West End legal firm, is one such woman. "Among the things I've had to go out and buy for my boss are fresh breath spray, corn-plasters, and ointment for his haemorrhoids. And among the things I've been asked to do for him is look after his five-year-old daughter and her schoolfriend for an afternoon. My boss's wife had dropped them off, and my boss said he had to go to a meeting." The chief reason that many PAs feel they're a wife, mother, nursemaid, diplomat and personal shopper all in one is, according to Eldridge, ironic. "Since the level of responsibility has increased for PAs, so has the level at which managers depend on them." Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology, believes technology and flexible working practices are also accountable. "PAs increasingly own mobile phones and laptops and are available far more than they used to be. As a result, managers can, and do, contact their support staff at home, in the theatre or restaurant, in bed, or even abroad on holiday. This blurs the distinction between professional and private in both the PA's and the boss's job." Even temps now tend to have mobile phones on which their bosses can reach them, says Gill Stewart, director of recruitment consultancy Tate Appointments. But you're still most likely to be asked to do things outside your remit if you have a male boss, confirms Sarah El Doori of recruitment agency Office Angels. "I can remember one incident of a PA being sent out by her male boss to buy toupee tapes - sticky pads that hold a hairpiece in place," she laughs. Age is also relevant, she says. "It's my experience that the older the boss and the older the PA, the more likely it is that your role will extend into the personal." Jo Ashby, a 47-year-old secretary for a health insurance company in Berkshire, agrees. "My boss, who's 59, thinks nothing of telling me to lie to his wife when he's out to lunch with his mistress. I know both women and he's quite happy with that." So what's the point at which to say "enough"? "When it starts to get you down or you begin to put yourself at risk - whichever comes first," says June Smith, an occupational health worker. Ruth Marks, a 28-year-old PA in a doctors' surgery in Northamptonshire, is among the many respondents to Fish4Jobs' research who admits to resenting the embarrassment her boss's requirements can cause. "Once, his wife called to speak to him. He told me to say he was out, and she simply replied, 'That's funny. I'm outside in the car and can see him'. She forgave him, but has never been pleasant to me again." Nevertheless, some PAs are only too happy to have a role that stretches the definition of office life. Working for celebrity chef Antony Worrall Thompson, for instance, necessitates testing out his recipes. As Jo Hyne, his PA, said recently, "I have no problem at all with getting my apron on."  Some names have been changed.

fields.headline: Akram Khan Company
fields.standfirst:
Akram Khan Company
Riley Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
Akram Khan Company
Riley Theatre, Leeds
****
fields.body:
Akram Khan's arms slam down like pistons and flutter as fast as hummingbird wings in this fascinating programme of works which combine his expertise in classical Kathak dance with scalpel-sharp contemporary moves. Strong, sinuous, yet fluid and hugely expressive, Khan's arms speak volumes in his opening solo, Fix, which builds from sculptured, controlled poses to whirling dervish spins, right arm bending over his head as if winding himself up like a spinning top.

Khan won the Jerwood Foundation Award for choreography last year and it's easy to see why. A master of rhythm, he creates dance for his chosen scores with surgical precision - and his new cross-cultural creation, Contemporary Kathak, is remarkable. Standing sideways, clad in white, he rocks with an almost imperceptible step. Suddenly his right arm punches out and, from then on, it's a flurry of action: torpedo falls and rolls, arms stretching, curving, fingers opening and closing like exquisite lotus flowers.

Fix draws its energy from the Sufi mystics and is danced to a pulsing score layered with monastic plainsong and Islamic devotional chants by comedian-turned-composer Nitin Sawhney from TV's Goodness Gracious Me. It's a gem of controlled power and wit as Khan comes to rest, pulling his knee up on an invisible string, fingers splayed.

He is joined by the excellent Moya Michael and Gwyn Emberton for his trio, Rush. Dressed in black, the three stand with their backs to us as the music begins like swishing water sprinklers then splits the ears. Inspired by the freefall of paragliders - wild speed versus serene stillness - this is a brilliantly crafted piece.

As in Kathak, the power is focused above the waist, from the chest, arms and hands - and here the dancers perform the gestures and motifs either in sequence or together, calling out rhythm changes in the traditional way. The three are hugely gifted individually and make for an impressive whole.

Action eddies from strobe-fast to dead slow and, lit in gold, Moya Michael spins her arms like propellers, while the men glide on outstretched wings. The music prompts the action with gongs and bells and Khan creates a kinetic composite of its rhythms, meticulously crafted and performed.

A short film of his solo, Loose in Flight, full of soaring leaps and spins, completed the programme. The company tours India next month and, with Khan's unique blend of ancient and cyber-modern moves, it looks like the only way is up.

fields.headline: Loves Work
fields.standfirst:
Loves Work
Gate Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText:
Loves Work
Gate Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
The Gate's season devoted to the vagaries of passion has already yielded a precocious masterpiece in Joanna Laurens's The Three Birds: a spellbinding study of sexual obsession. This final piece, devised and directed by the departing Mick Gordon, has less white-hot intensity: it's an amiable, discursive, sometimes touching collection of private love stories but one that, like most authorless pieces, lacks a distinctive viewpoint.

Fittingly for a "work in progress", the Gate has been stripped to the back wall so that you can even see the buses passing by in the street. Four actors - Kay Curram, Gabrielle Lloyd, Elliot Levey and Michael Hadley - come before us on a bare platform to share their own and others' experiences. They talk, simply and movingly, about childbirth and parenthood and then move into the re-enactment of oral testimony: we get love fulfilled, denied, celebrated and cruelly terminated by death, and we also get love reduced to a behaviourist formula in a hilarious reading from Men Are From Mars in which 101 ways to impress a woman ominously includes "offer to sharpen knives in the kitchen".

What is surprising, in this day and age, is the emphasis on procreation and permanence: the show dwells by and large on enduring heterosexual love with only fleeting reference to same-sex relationships. But one of the problems with this kind of selection is that "love" is too all-encompassing a term ever to be fully explored: we are reminded the Greeks had no less than three separate words for it and I felt that many forms of love - of deities, ideas, institutions - were here unacknowledged.

I also longed to know the source of the material: in a literary anthology we would be told, whereas in a spoken one we remain in the dark.

If the show, presented in association with the National Theatre Studio, is to go further, I feel it needs both to widen its range and come clean about the provenance of its material. As it is, we are left beguiled and charmed by an engaging quartet of performers: by Hadley and Lloyd, in particular, as happy northern marrieds looking back on early guilt-ridden adultery; by Curram's impersonation of a young male traveller fumblingly seduced by a Dutch postman; and by Levey's recreation of a house-guest nervously reading Lolita to a frisky nine-year-old.

The show is good on the joys, sorrows and embarrassments of love: if you want to learn about its destructive zeal, however, you have to go back to the great dramatists.

 Until December 2. Box office: 020-7229 0706.
